HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: IN KYOTO;
An Ancient City Hopes to Reassure Tourists That It Is Safe to Visit

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Jan. 23

 BODY:
As if she did not face enough challenges becoming a geisha, what with endless training in the arts of teasing her hair and clients, Keiko Takada now must deal with an unexpected crisis that is affecting her job security.
The earthquake that devastated the city of Kobe, 40 miles to the southwest, did not at first do much damage in the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto. But since then the economic aftershocks have been rattling Kyoto without interruption, cutting sharply into tourism and myriad related businesses. 
 "We're very concerned," said Miss Takada, 17, a maiko, or apprentice geisha. "The earthquake was on the 17th, and that night all of our banquets were canceled. We had many customers in Kobe, so we're very alarmed about our business. I hear there are lots of cancellations, and I wonder what will happen."
Miss Takada paused and delicately adjusted her red and purple silk kimono, and a hint of anxiety showed through the layers of white makeup on her face.
"Even before this there was a recession," she explained earnestly, with the same charm and polish she uses at dinners to entertain business customers. "And now the earthquake has made the situation much worse."
Kyoto was the capital of Japan for more than 1,000 years, until 1868, and it is perhaps the foremost Japanese city for temples, tradition and tourists. But these days, all it has are temples and tradition.
Many of the tourists, on whom 30 percent of the economy depends, have been frightened away by the earthquake. Hotel lobbies are vacant, temple gardens are nearly empty, and entertainers like Miss Takeda are left to sit at home.
With train service disrupted, it is more difficult for people from western Japan to reach Kyoto. And in any case, Kyoto and Kobe are linked in the popular mind as neighbors -- some guidebooks cover both cities -- so that prospective visitors are turned off by the prospect of visiting an earthquake zone.
Nearly 40 million tourists normally visit Kyoto each year -- including 500,000 foreigners, of whom 90,000 are Americans -- but the number is now well below normal.
The city tourist office estimates that tourism has been cut in half, but that may be optimistic. The night sightseeing bus tour, which sold about 100 tickets an evening this time a year ago, is now selling just 20 an evening.
The earthquake has particularly affected the geisha and the tea houses where they work, entertaining businessmen with their charm and music and -- sometimes when the mood and money are right -- their bodies.
Geisha are not regarded as prostitutes, any more than surgeons are to be equated with seamstresses, for a geisha's training has much less to do with sex than with hairdos and music and courteous speech. Instead of fishnet stockings and high heels, they wear layers of kimonos secured with a most daunting obi, or belt.
Kyoto is a center for geisha, with 210 of them and another 71 maiko, but their prices are as impressive as their appearance. A few businessmen can easily spend more than $1,000 on a dinner with a geisha, sating their culinary appetites alone, and now they seem inclined to cut back on such expenses.
"Customers are businessmen, many of them small entrepreneurs from Osaka, Kobe and other areas hit by the earthquake," said Toshio Ozeki, a man who is an official of one of the geisha associations in Kyoto. "Now they would rather use their money to rebuild, instead of on entertainment.
"Even those customers not affected by the earthquake feel they should refrain from going to entertainment areas when there is so much suffering going on," Mr. Ozeki added, a bit regretfully.
Tetsuo Ito, an official in the Kyoto Tourism Association, said that the impact of the earthquake would probably last at least a year. He said the city wanted to get the message out that it was safe, but without any flamboyance that would be in poor taste considering the misery nearby in Kobe.
"Because of the suffering in Kobe, it would be inappropriate to have lots of flashy advertising, but we need to make some efforts to let people know that Kyoto is O.K.," Mr. Ito said.
Indeed, the frustration for people like Mr. Ito is that the only abnormal thing about Kyoto these days is the absence of tourists. While the earthquake jolted Kyoto badly, it caused no deaths in the city, only a few injuries and little damage.
The city's temples and cultural treasures survived almost unscathed. None of the buildings fell over, although a few cracks were reported in walls, and the worst harm was to wooden statues that toppled at Koryuji, a second-rank temple on the outskirts of town.
A 13th-century statue of a servant lost its left arm in the accident, and a 9th-century statue of the god of mercy lost its right arm. Experts are going to reattach the missing limbs, and the damage is expected not to be noticeable.
Dozens of other artifacts at the temple -- including a famous statue damaged in 1960 when a college student was overcome with its beauty and embraced it, snapping off a finger in his passion -- remained upright and were unhurt in the earthquake.
Many Japanese have grown critical of Buddhist temples, saying the monks have grown rapacious with exorbitant demands for money for funerals and other ceremonies. But while the monks acknowledge the criticisms, they attribute the earthquake to chance alone.
"This can't be a punishment," said Yorito Matsuda, the curator of the Koryuji. "We've prayed very faithfully every day and looked after everything carefully."
At the Nishi Honganji, an important temple in the center of the city, about 20 stone lanterns fell over. Homei Komagai, a Buddhist priest at the temple, said that the lanterns were about 300 years old but that they did not seem to have special historic or cultural importance.
A greater concern at the temple was that many of its donors lived in Kobe.
"We're concerned about their safety," Mr. Komagai said, "and also about their ability to continue to contribute."

HEADLINE: President Will Seek a Higher Minimum Wage, Senior Aides Say

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton will buck certain Congressional opposition to seek an increase in the minimum wage as a sign of his resolve to buttress the earning power of working Americans and stress the value of work, senior White House officials said today.
In the face of widespread demands for new requirements that would force welfare recipients to find jobs or lose benefits, administration aides described the President's proposal as one step toward providing new incentives for work. 
 But the proposal would be largely symbolic since some leaders of the new Republican Congress are opposed to the very concept of a minimum wage, much less an increase in the Federal standard, which has been $4.25 an hour for the last four years. The White House is leaning toward an increase to $5 an hour, phased in over several years.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said today that the President's economic advisers had given him their recommendations on the subject over the weekend, and that Mr. Clinton had a "very firm idea" of how to proceed and would announce his decision "at the appropriate time." Mr. McCurry and other officials declined to say whether the President would broach the subject in his State of the Union address Tuesday night.
Mr. Clinton himself, asked whether he would announce an increase in the speech, said only, "Tune in tomorrow." But in discussing the possibility earlier this month, the President noted the long-term erosion in the value of the minimum wage and said, "The number one mission of the country in this recovery is to raise incomes."
For weeks, Presidential advisers and Democrats in Congress have debated how to handle a proposal that appeals to traditional Democratic constituencies like organized labor, but that some economists look askance at and that has little chance of passing. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has proposed an increase to $5.75 an hour over three years, and some unions complain the White House proposal is too timid.
But the White House has been wary lest the proposal peg the President as a captive of old-fashioned liberal thinking, emphasize his weakness vis-a-vis Congress and overshadow the broader blueprint of tax breaks, educational incentives and hopes for the second half of his term that he hopes to sketch in his speech.
Advocates within the Administration like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich have argued that an increase of 50 cents an hour would essentially compensate for inflation since the last increase, from $3.80 in 1991. Coupled with an additional 25-cent increase in coming years, they say, the move would boost incomes of the lowest-salaried workers without big new Government spending and with little overall reduction in employment, positioning Mr. Clinton as champion of the little guy.
It would also redeem a promise of Mr. Clinton's campaign -- one that was deferred in the fall of 1993 to avoid alienating business leaders, whose support the Administration wanted for its health care and trade proposals, and who remain generally opposed to an increase.
The House Majority Leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, today repeated his resolute opposition to any increase in the minimum wage.
"It's a heartfelt issue with me," Mr. Armey told reporters, as he left the White House after a signing ceremony for a new law to require Congress to abide by the same workplace and employment standards it imposes on the private sector, a bill Mr. Clinton described as a first step in making government "more open, more fair, and less elitist."
Mr. Armey added: "I've seen the pain of people who desperately need work having lost their job because of increases in minimum wages. This is not an issue that anybody takes lightly. It's a question of real difference of opinion. I can again just reiterate my point: I will resist an increase in the minimum wage with every fiber of my being."
Much recent economic research has called into question the longstanding view that increasing the minimum wage is undermined by resulting job losses. Economists have found that when the wage is increased, overall growth in income for workers who keep their jobs exceeds the income lost by those who lose theirs, and that a higher minimum wage makes work more attractive than welfare.
Studies also have found that, contrary to conventional wisdom, about two-thirds of the 2.5 million hourly workers who are paid the minimum wage are adults, who often provide much of their family income, not teenagers, who need less help.
Of course, raising the minimum wage also has the effect of shifting the cost of such workers a bit to business and away from the Government. Mr. Clinton's advisers contend that curtailing welfare benefits for those who do not seek work should be coupled with new incentives and higher wages for those who do.
But some conservative Democrats argue that the minimum wage may need to be reduced in some cases to spur job opportunities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton yesterday signed into law a measure that holds Congress to the same Federal laws governing the workplace as the rest of the country. With Mr. Clinton at the White House for a signing ceremony for the Congressional Accountability Act were Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky and former Representative Dick Swett of New Hampshire, both Democrats; Representatives Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Dick Armey of Texas, Republicans, and Representative Vic Fazio, a Democrat from California. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "UPDATE: A Closer Look at a Mixed Record"
 President Clinton rode to the White House on a campaign of ambitious promises. After two years, some have been redeemed, others abandoned. Still more are imperiled by Congress's new Republican majority.
 
The Economy
 Roaring along, with five million jobs created and the budget deficit slashed in half. But Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and his risingj interest rates could slow growth going into the 1996 Presidential election.
 
Taxes
 The wealthiest got a heavier burden, and the poorest got new breaks. But there was a Republican victory before Mr. Clintondecided to honor his campaign pledge of a tax cut for the middle class.
 
Government
 Getting smaller, with 98,000 Federal jobs cut since Mr. Clinton took office and the size of the workforce approaching that of the Kennedy era. But will Vice President Al Gore's knifework be enough to stave off the Republican ax?
 
Trade
 The free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada was passed, the international trade pact was renewed and Mr. Clinton won comitments to vast free trade zones by early in the next century. But the crumbling peso is a reminder that partnerships carry peril.
 
Foreign Affairs
 Haiti is free, North Korea says it will give up its nuclear weapons and the war has quieted in Bosnia. Yet White House wobbliness raises a question: should the credit go to Mr. Clinton or to former President Jimmy Carter?
 
Health Care
 A year in Congress's spotlight leaves the pet project withered with no laws passed and little hope. Even the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton concede that their dream of universal coverge proved a political nightmare.
 
Welfare
 Left on a back burner, the promise to get tough with welfare recipients never came to a boil, allowing Republicans to seize the initiative as they take control of Congress.
 
Social Policy
 Millions of Americans got new guaranteed leave for childbirth and sick care. But instead of ending the ban on gays serving in the military, Mr. Clinton offered this: "Don't ask; don't tell."
 
Crime
 Some 100,000 new police officers are on their way to the streets, and the tough controls on handguns and assault weapons that Mr. Clinton backed are in place. But a renewed fight is brewing as Republicans threaten to strip the crime law of measures they label big-spending and anti-hunter.
 
Politics
 It is still business as usual as Congress delays putting restrictions on fundraising and lobbying, leaving Mr. Clinton to keep on raising millions under loose ruls. But the White House is gearing up to make its proposed tighter rules a test of Republicans' willingness tow ash their hands of old ways.

HEADLINE: Unlikely Pair Confront A City's Budget Woes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
As political partners eager to untangle the financial mess of the nation's capital, they could not be an odder couple.
With liberal spending and hiring practices during his previous terms as Mayor of Washington, Marion S. Barry Jr. had a hand in creating the city's $500 million deficit. Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, a Republican from Northern Virginia and head of the subcommittee that oversees city affairs, is part of the new Congressional majority eager to slash social spending and skeptical of Mr. Barry's leadership. 
 But through the first weeks of the new Congress and the new Barry administration, no partisan fights have emerged. Nor have lines been drawn in the sand. Mr. Barry has assured Congress that he will cut a $3.3 billion budget to return the District to financial solvency, and Mr. Davis has promised to give him time, at least a few months, before Congress would step in to avert the embarrassment of a bankruptcy.
"I think you have to give them the leeway to succeed or to screw up," Mr. Davis said in an interview last week. "They have to be able to make their own decisions."
But what those decisions are remains undefined, adding a dash of tension between the Democratic Mayor and his Republican overseers. Mr. Barry has said only that on March 1 he would announce detailed plans for his budget. They are expected to include layoffs, furloughs and other cost-cutting measures that will mean fewer police, a reduction in hospital services, library closings and less frequent garbage collection -- but most important to city leaders -- a diminished role for Congress in running the city.
Congress, which gives the District about $650 million a year, has demanded at least $140 million in cuts. The City Council has asked for twice that. And Mr. Barry has said his staff has identified at least $431 million in cuts.
How did the capital fall into such disarray? During the 1980's, Mr. Barry nourished his base of support by expanding government employment rolls by thousands and awarding many city contracts on a no-bid basis. By the time his third term ended after his arrest for cocaine possession, the city was careering toward financial disaster. And while his successor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, loudly criticized him for allowing the city to crumble, she failed to cut spending fast enough or deep enough to avert the growing deficit.
By 1991, Mrs. Kelly's first year in office, Washington had become a model of inefficiency, with the highest per-capita expenditures, $9,516, among major American cities, far ahead of second-place New York, at $5,568. The District also had the highest per-capita spending for welfare, $1,156 (with New York second, at $891), according to the United States Department of Commerce.
More recently, the city secured a loan of $250 million from lending institutions to meet its current payroll, Mr. Barry agreed to turn over some control of the city's housing authority to a court, and he said the police force could be reduced by 15 percent, about 600 officers.
To solve this mess, Mr. Davis and Mr. Barry have begun a respectful waltz of accommodation, with Mr. Davis suggesting obvious cuts for the District -- like the District of Columbia Law School and a prison run by the city in Lorton, Va. -- but leaving the details to Mr. Barry.
"I think we're on target," Mr. Barry said.
The city can hardly afford not to be. Already, the new Congress has shown its regard for the District's efforts at greater stature. Just two years after its lone delegate in the House, Eleanor Holmes Norton, gained voting rights for the first time, the new House took them away, prompting renewed cries among residents of "taxation without representation."
The new Congress has also dashed thoughts of statehood, once a major goal of city leaders.
But, Mr. Davis said, the Mayor deserves time to show he is serious about spending cuts in the face of overwhelming skepticism among his colleagues. "I don't think you'll find 1 in 10 who thinks he is going to do it," Mr. Davis said.
Yet, dangling a carrot before the Mayor, Mr. Davis said he would consider commonwealth status for the District, a designation that would eliminate Federal income tax, as a way to attract new residents and businesses. In 1993, local residents paid $1.6 billion in Federal taxes, more than all but Connecticut and New Jersey among the states on a per-capita basis. Yet the city's population has been declining for years, down to 585,000 in 1992.
"It's an idea I really thought was stupid and the District would have thought was stupid two years ago," Mr. Davis said of commonwealth status. "But now I think it's something you ought to look at in your tool bag."
Both Mr. Barry and Mrs. Norton said their staffs were studying the economic implications of commonwealth status, perhaps as an interim step toward statehood, as Mr. Barry said. But cutting fast enough to satisfy Congress may be a more formidable task, given the dire circumstances at hand.
It seems to matter less to Congress where the cuts are made than that they are made quickly.
"You have to get the financial straight early on," said Mr. Davis, a former chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Fairfax County, which faced a $200 million deficit in 1992 before he eliminated it within 18 months.
If Mr. Barry's deliberate response has caused some concern along lawmakers, so have several recent incidents that appeared to call his leadership and judgment into question.
After a high school student was shot to death at school this month by another student, Mr. Barry acknowledged having no ideas how to stop such incidents from occurring again. Nor has he provided details about how the private sector will create 10,000 new jobs, as he promised in his campaign.
He has also drawn criticism for not fully explaining the financing of a new security fence at his home.
But he has navigated successes, as well, including a deal with Abe Pollin, owner of professional basketball and hockey teams, to build a downtown sports arena at little public expense. And those are encouraging signs to Mr. Davis.
"I think the members are now saying: 'You know, we've been embarrassed. We've been defending this city, and look at the situation,' " Mr. Davis said. "So I think at this point, members in both parties and all races are going to have to say: 'Look, we have a problem. Let's not dwell on how it came about, who's to blame. Let's see if we can solve it.' Because, for heaven's sake, the last thing that I believe that Republicans and Congress want to do is take over the city."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "They have to be able to make their own decisions," Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d said of city officials in Washington. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Illinois Town a 'Testing Field' in Labor Relations

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ill.

 BODY:
The ovens of industry are burning with gusto in this old prairie city's east end, where factories abut dormant black cornfields and the asphalt skirts of auto body shops and bowling alleys. Day and night, the A. E. Staley corn milling plant belches plumes of smoke that dust the downtown with a scent as sweet and thick as a bakery's.
A few blocks up 22d Street from Staley, the two-story brick plant of the world's No. 1 tire and rubber company, the Bridgestone Corporation of Tokyo, is operating, too, and so, a few blocks farther up 22d, is the still bigger plant of the world's No. 1 producer of earth-moving equipment, Caterpillar Inc. of Peoria. 
 These are three of Decatur's largest employers. All are embroiled in their longest labor disputes ever, and all are running, although most of their 4,000 unionized workers are on the street. All of which has made this city of 85,000 a national metaphor for the turmoil within an American labor movement to which just 1-in-8 private industry workers belong, less than half the level 20 years ago.
Labor and management are dug in deep in Decatur. Management, blaming competitive pressures, has been mowing down labor costs -- holding down wages, cutting benefits and staff, keeping machinery running 24 hours a day. Labor has given up hope of reversing losses. But more emphatically here than anyplace else, it is trying to halt its slide toward irrelevance.
Decatur "is a kind of testing field," said Robert W. Cassidy, 60, a member of the United Automobile Workers who has been driving forklifts in the Caterpillar plant for 38 years.
The disputes here, involving about 10,000 additional workers at Caterpillar and Bridgestone plants elsewhere in Illinois and in five other states, has also set the stage for a nationwide test for organized labor.
Beginning this month with the railroads, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says, 707 contracts covering the 3.4 million employees of public and private institutions with 1,000 or more workers are up for renegotiation this year, the highest number of workers in the 11 years in which the bureau has kept track.
The Secretary of Labor, Robert B. Reich, says that these negotiations could spur an incipient trend of labor-management collaboration, with both sides seeing something to gain from an employer's success.
In strikebound Decatur, at least, there's no whiff of such amity. "These work stoppages represent three examples of employer aggressiveness in bargaining that we didn't see 15 years ago," said Peter Feuille, director of the Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations at the University of Illinois.
Staley, citing sabotage and vandalism after imposing 12-hour shifts, locked out its workers in June 1993 and brought in temporary replacements. Caterpillar's workers struck last June, blaming management for anti-union harassment; they, too, have been temporarily replaced.
Bridgestone's employees struck in July rather than accept a contract with shift changes, benefit cuts and lower wages than Goodyear workers have won. Although the Government this month goaded Bridgestone and Caterpillar to talk with their unions, Bridgestone says that settlement or not, 650 of its 1,200 strikers here have been permanently replaced.
The Decatur plants, Mr. Feuille said, "are willing to tolerate a great deal of labor-management strife in exchange for a more advantageous contract, so you end up with three very long-running disputes that don't seem to have any end in sight."
The companies' regular workers here are nearly all men 45 to 60 years old who earned $30,000 to more than $60,000 a year. Some are collecting only $60 a week in union strike benefits; most seem to be getting by with part-time jobs, charitable contributions and donations from local unions elsewhere.
But they say that they will pay the price of staying out to defend their wages, job security and eight-hour days with weekends free.
"Push comes to shove and I'm not going any further," said Tom Jordan, 45, a Caterpillar machinist for 21 years and member of the United Automobile Workers union. "If it costs me my job, it costs me my job."
Fred Quick, 57, an inspector who has worked for Caterpillar for 26 years, said, "It's about respect, and a little dignity along with that."
The issue for unions in Decatur and across the nation is not what more they can win for workers, but what previous gains they keep.
Industry, by contrast, is in the strongest position in years to argue for a strike-free less-regulated economy. Like most American industry until the 1980's, Staley, Bridgestone and Caterpillar could grant regular wage increases to workers and pack those increases onto the prices they charge customers.
But with the erosion of trade barriers, the companies say they must work in a global economy and vie with competitors, foreign and domestic, whose costs are lower. They want fewer workers and they want to use them more efficiently -- on days, nights and weekends -- so that they never need to stop production.
So in October 1992, after its last labor contract expired, Staley instituted a wrenching change. Owned since 1988 by Tate & Lyle, the British food processing company, Staley said it would invest in labor-saving machinery, cut the workforce of 750 to 250 or fewer over several years, and institute 12-hour rotating shifts in which for one month, an employee works three days in a row, 6 A.M. to 6 P.M., then takes three days off. The next month, the employee shifts to nights, working three nights on, three off. His total hours each month are about the same as they were in an eight-hour five-day week.
But "you forget about weekends," said Richard Brummett, 49, a Staley worker for 24 years. Companies like Staley, Mr. Brummett said, are simply trying to put unions out of business.
"Absolutely not true," said J. Patrick Mohan, executive vice president of Staley. The workers, he said, are simply "resistant to change."
"Our intention is to try to make the plant competitive with other corn wet-milling plants," Mr. Mohan said. Bridgestone and Caterpillar say they face similar competitive pressures. Caterpillar lost more than $600 million in 1991 and 1992, although it has recovered and had profits last year of $955 million. Trevor C. Hoskins, a spokesman for Bridgestone's American operations, said those businesses lost $1 billion from 1990 to 1992 and are barely profitable now. "We said to the union that we had to return to a competitive position," he said.
That meant workers must help pay for their health insurance, agree to shift schedules permitting plants to run all week and accept a two-tier wage system in which new workers would be paid 30 percent less than veteran workers performing the same jobs.
To block such demands, unions once had a deadly weapon, the strike, which forced concessions from both sides.
Since the late 1970's, however, more job seekers have been willing to cross picket lines. And since the 1980's, more companies have been willing to deploy a mightier weapon than the strike: the permanent replacement worker.
As a result, unions today try to avoid strikes. The number of strikes against employers of 1,000 or more workers has plunged from hundreds a year from the 1940's through the 1970's to fewer than 50 a year in the 1990's, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says. "Strikes don't work," said David Watts, president of Staley's paperworkers' union, Local 7837.
The specter of permanent replacement figures in all three disputes in Decatur. Since companies can permanently replace workers only when disputes involve economic issues like wages and benefits, Staley and Caterpillar workers have emphasized noneconomic issues, like union rights and working conditions.
By contrast, the rubber workers' strike against Bridgestone involves wages and benefits. On Jan. 4, management attempted to scare the union back to the bargaining table by declaring that about half of the company's 4,000 union members had been permanently replaced.
Management could be bluffing. In letters that day offering the temporary workers permanent status, the company said that "under certain circumstances, other factors could result in the return of striking employees to their former jobs." Still, the action has terrified strikers.
Mr. Reich attributes the Decatur companies' tough position to managers who undervalue workers.
All the while, he said, there is another trend afoot. Companies like Levi Strauss in San Francisco and Nynex in New York are underscoring employee loyalty, helping them develop skills and paying them well.
"It's almost as if there are two management philosophies," Mr. Reich said. "One seeks to cut payrolls and reduce labor costs and tries to bust unions or control union power. The other seeks to empower workers and give them a greater voice." Which is winning? "It's too early to tell," he said.
Not in Decatur, where the notions of teamwork lost out some time ago. Caterpillar tried it in the late 1980's, but new management saw the company moving into the red and eventually abandoned the experiment.
In 1988, when Bridgestone bought the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the Japanese managers called everyone, workers and managers, "associates."
"They stressed that we were one and were all working for the same goal," said Randy Gordon, the vice president of Bridgestone's United Rubber Workers Local 713 here.
But Firestone, headed toward bankruptcy at the time, proved a colossal money loser, so labor became a cost to cut.
"Sometime around 1990, 1991," said Mary Brummett, a volunteer office manager for the paperworkers' union her husband, Richard belongs to, "it seems like everybody, all the companies, decided they didn't have to be nice anymore."

HEADLINE: Japan Market Still Nervous Over Quake

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Tokyo stock market tried to recover today from a severe selloff brought on by last week's earthquake, as investors continued to fear that the disaster in Kobe would damage Japan's economy and businesses.
On Monday, Japanese stocks suffered their worst one-day loss in nearly three and a half years. The decline in Tokyo pulled down other stock markets throughout Asia, especially in Hong Kong, as concern mounted that Japanese investors would pull their money out of these other markets to help pay for rebuilding at home. 
 "It looks to me like what you would call a stampede," Jeff Bahrenburg, the equities strategist for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo, said after the Nikkei index of 225 stocks plummeted 5.6 percent on Monday.
The Nikkei fell 1,054.73 points, to 17,785.49, its lowest level in a little over a year. In percentage terms, it was the Nikkei's largest decline in a single day since Aug. 19, 1991, and the 12th-largest fall since 1949.
Today, however, the Nikkei rebounded from early selling and closed up 275.24 points, or 1.55 percent, to 18,060.73 at midday. Still, many traders remained quite skittish about the market's prospects.
In the first two days after last Tuesday's earthquake, stocks barely fell as investors were unsure of the extent of the damage. But as the magnitude of the catastrophe became clearer, the stock decline accelerated, with foreign investors among the most active sellers, analysts said.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index, which accounts for 70 percent of the market's capitalization, dropped 310.17 points, or 4.26 percent, to close Monday at 6,967.93, its lowest level since July 1993. It was virtually unchanged at midday today.
Stocks also fell sharply in Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, Taiwan and Australia on Monday, although most began to stabilize today.
The earthquake is not the only factor depressing stocks in Hong Kong and other Asian markets. Another is the expectation that the Federal Reserve Board in the United States will soon raise interest rates. In addition, Asian markets have been weakened by reports that China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is near death, leading to concerns about instability in China. All this while the Mexican peso crisis has undermined investor confidence in industrializing nations worldwide.
Economists are divided on how the earthquake will affect Japan's economy, which has just started to recover from three years of recession. Most economists say that in the short run the quake, which killed more than 5,000 people, will hurt the economy. Factories have been damaged and cannot produce, and shipping and transportation have been severely disrupted.
But in the long run, the money spent to rebuild Kobe and surrounding cities should stimulate economic growth, as the construction industry booms and people buy homes and goods to replace what they have lost.
"We are bringing years of future consumption right into 1995," said Tod Wood, an economist at Baring Securities in Tokyo.
The disagreements tend to be over the relative duration and size of the negative and positive effects. Those like Mr. Wood who see the positive effects outweighing the negative ones think that stock prices will rise before too long.
But others say that the market might continue to sink and that Monday's huge drop was justified.
"There's been a very large destruction of property and, more important, confidence," said John V. Baldwin, director of research and strategy at Jardine Fleming Securities here.
There are several other ways, besides lost production, that the earthquake could hurt the economy and the stock market.
The costs of rebuilding, which some estimates now put at $100 billion, will add to the national budget deficit. Increased borrowing by the Government is expected to lead to a rise in interest rates, which would dampen business investment.
Japan's banks are expected to suffer because some of their less financially strong borrowers will be pushed out of business by the earthquake and will not repay their loans.
Besides bank stocks, shares of securities companies, electronics companies and electric utilities lost value on Monday, as they did last week. Construction company stocks generally gained last week on the anticipation of increased business, and they showed signs of recovery today from Monday's selloff.
Even before the earthquake, the Tokyo market had been falling from the Nikkei index's recent peak near 21,500, which was reached in June. That is partly because the economic recovery is turning out to be somewhat weaker than the market might have anticipated, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Plan to Aid Business on Tax Fades

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The only item in the Congressional Republicans' Contract With Americathat was meant strictly to be a boon to business appears to stand no chance of becoming law.
The measure, which was supposed to give businesses more generous tax deductions when they bought expensive machinery and equipment, does not even have the support of the industries it wants to help. Top Republican lawmakers have also expressed qualms that it could end up sharply increasing future budget deficits. 
 The prospects are better for a part of the Republican contract of particular interest to individual investors -- more favorable tax treatment of capital gains. But that proposal also faces formidable obstacles: a Democratic filibuster in the Senate and a possible veto by President Clinton.
The Clinton Administration maintains that these two Republican tax measures would lead people to invest their money with more of an eye toward reducing their tax liability than on making a profit, a once-common practice that was largely eliminated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
"These proposals, if enacted, would result in significant tax shelter transactions and encourage investment in uneconomic activities," Leslie B. Samuels, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy, told the House Ways and Means Committee two weeks ago.
The reason, according to Administration officials, is that Wall Street would take advantage of the new tax breaks to create paper losses for executives and professionals with big salaries on exotic shelters similar to the oil and gas ventures, leasing deals and race horse partnerships of the past.
At a new series of hearings before that committee beginning on Tuesday, some economists and tax lawyers will side with the Administration on this point.
But supporters of the bigger tax break for capital gains, which are the profits made from investments, say they will testify that the most abusive tax shelters would still be outlawed.
While capital gains will be subject to a lively debate, the proposal to allow businesses to use a new and more favorable way of writing off investments in machinery and equipment appears to have little enthusiastic support.
"We've got questions about its effectiveness and certainly are taking a careful look at it," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, whose members would be some of the main beneficiaries of more generous depreciation rules.
A prominent business lobbyist, who spoke only on condition he not be identified, said, "As best I can ascertain, this is an orphan with no discernible set of parents in the business community."
The reluctance of businesses to embrace the proposal is based on the political calculation that Congress cannot be trusted to leave the tax laws alone.
Depreciation deductions are meant to allow businesses to write off the cost of investments over the lifetime of the purchase. Different schedules are used for different kinds of investments. Furnaces in apartment buildings, for instance, are expected to last 27.5 years. Computers and automobiles, though, can be written off over five years. While there are variations that sometime allow bigger tax breaks in earlier years, in general that means a $100,000 investment in new computers, say, would translate into a corporate tax deduction of $20,000 a year for five years.
The measure in the G.O.P. contract would make the depreciation deductions on machinery and equipment slightly less generous the first few years and then make the tax break much larger in later years. In almost all cases, the eventual total deductions would be significantly larger than under current accounting rules and much greater than the original price of the equipment.
But business executives worry that they would forgo some deductions in the early years only to have Congress change the law so they never get the promised write-offs.
"There is some element of trepidation about buying a plan that you think may be changed in the long term," Mr. Jasinowski said.
The depreciation measure, called a neutral cost recovery system, sticks out of the Contract With America like a tall tree in the desert. It is the only item in the contract -- the political manifesto that was the platform for the Republican Congressional campaigns last year -- that does not have broad popular appeal.
The cost recovery proposal was introduced in the House last year by Representative Nick Smith, a Republican from Michigan. It never came to a vote. But Mr. Smith had nearly 100 co-sponsors, including Newt Gingrich, who is now Speaker of the House, and Dick Armey, the new majority leader.
Mr. Smith said in an interview today that no particular company or interest had lobbied him on the matter. He said he had offered the measure because he thought it would stimulate economic growth, generate jobs and put American manufacturers on an equal footing with those in other industrial countries where tax breaks are more generous.
One of its attractions, he said, is that it would actually increase tax revenue by $18 billion in the first five years, which is the period in which Federal budgets are usually calculated.
A staff assistant said that the measure was included in part because of budgetary considerations and in part because the authors wanted to satisfy an important Republican constituency, big business.
In retrospect, both seem to have been miscalculations.
While the measure would help lower the deficit slightly in the first five years, it would lose $139 billion in tax revenue in the next five years, according to Treasury calculations. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said the total cost of the measure over 10 years was unacceptable to him.
And Representative Smith conceded, "The response from business has been somewhat guarded."
Mr. Samuels, the Treasury official, testified that the new depreciation rules and the proposed break on capital gains threatened a repeat of the early to mid-1980's, when so many office buildings were built in part because the laws were so generous to real estate tax shelters.
Other tax experts agree that when the taxes on one form of investment are lower than on others, financial instruments are created that are based not on profits but on allowing investors to take advantage of the tax break.
But those analysts say that Mr. Saumels probably exaggerated the effect of the Republican proposals. New tax shelters would be inhibited, they say, by a provision of the 1986 law that the Republicans do not intend to repeal. That provision forbids the extensive use of tax losses on investments to offset tax liability from salaries.
"I don't see a big business on the tax shelter side of this," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: Stock Jitters Over Mexican Aid Package

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market dropped sharply yesterday morning, but rallied just as sharply in the afternoon as Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, sought to reassure nervous financial markets that the Clinton Administration's $40 billion rescue of Mexico "is going to happen."
The leading stock indexes yesterday closed mixed after being sharply negative most of the day. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.02 points, to 3,867.41, the third consecutive decline for the blue-chip index. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.04 points, to 465.82, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.54 points, to 759.51. 
 The markets have been volatile for several days now as investors watched the partisan wrangling on Capitol Hill over approval of the Mexican aid package. Other factors adding to the volatility include the earthquake damage in Kobe that has begun to undermine the Japanese stock market, and a market consensus that the Federal Reserve is all but certain to raise interest rates at its two-day meeting that begins next Tuesday.
Stock, bond and currency traders are therefore scrambling to figure out what to do with dollar-denominated assets, as worldwide demand for credit appears to be rising, in part because of the need to rebuild both earthquake-battered Kobe and Mexico's shattered economy.
The markets followed no clear pattern yesterday. Bond prices fell a little, but the dollar rallied on international currency markets and the price of gold, a fever chart for concern about inflation, fell. Markets calmed following Mr. Gingrich's remarks around 2 P.M. that he would cooperate with the President to pass aid to Mexico.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 325.8 million shares changing hands, slightly above this year's daily average of 323 million shares.
The American depository receipts of Wellcome, a British pharmaceutical company, soared 4 3/8, to 15 1/8, after Glaxo, the world's second- largest drug company, offered to pay $16.20 a share for Wellcome. The combination would create the world's largest drug company. Wellcome was the most active stock, with 9.1 million shares traded.
Cyrix shares closed up 3 3/4 at 26. The company had said on Friday that problems with its high-performance computer chips had been solved and that it planned to sell more of them.
Stratus Computer fell 10 7/8, to 28 3/8, after the maker of extra-rugged "fault tolerant" computer systems reported earnings that disappointed securities analysts, some of whom lowered their stock assessments.
The Kobe earthquake continued to hurt Japanese stocks traded in the United States. The A.D.R.'s of Mat-- sushita Electric Industrial fell 9 1/8, to 142, as one of its major plants was damaged in the earthquake. The A.D.R.'s of Kyocera, a leading ceramic maker for electronic parts, fell 7 1/2, to 128, in part because of worries about the economic effects of the earthquake.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.09 point, to 253.47, with declining stocks outnumbering advancing stocks by 1,399 to 826. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.73 point, to 436.91.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 14 fell, led by Eastman Kodak, which dropped 1 1/2, to 48 1/4. Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 221 advanced, led by Philip Morris, which climbed 1 5/8, to 58 5/8.

TURMOIL IN MEXICO
 MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Mexican financial markets spent another day in turmoil today as investors worried about delays in a United States plan to provide economic assistance.
President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon of Mexico added to investor concerns by reshuffling his Cabinet for the second time after only two months in power.
The Mexican stock exchange and the peso both fell sharply in morning trading and were little moved by a speech to Mexican legislators by Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, in which he promised austerity and Government spending cuts.
Later in the day, however, the markets managed to recover.
After falling almost 3 percent by midday, the Mexican stock market's main indicator, the IPC 37-stock index, ended at 2,068.49, up 2.64 points. Meanwhile, the peso ended lower as the dollar gained value. Today, a dollar bought 5.705 pesos, compared with 5.585 pesos on Friday.
The new peso stood at 3.46 to the dollar just over a month ago before the Zedillo Government devalued the currency and then let it float on world markets.
The stock market rebounded this afternoon after Mr. Gingrich's comments about the United States loan guarantee program.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
I.B.M. Posts First Annual Profit Since 1990

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation reported its first profitable year since 1990 yesterday, with fourth-quarter earnings more than tripling to a level well above Wall Street analysts' estimates.
But revenues from personal computers declined in the quarter, and that helped drive I.B.M.'s stock price down in heavy trading yesterday. 
 Shares of I.B.M. closed at $74.25, off $1.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, after posting losses of as much as $3 earlier in the session.
Analysts said general bearishness in the stock market contributed to the selloff in I.B.M., noting that in many respects the company had a strong quarter. Mainframes and minicomputers sold in greater quantities than expected, and the service operations outperformed estimates in both revenues and profit margins.
In personal computers, however, I.B.M. trailed the rest of the industry's growth, analysts said.
"The only negative in the quarter was that sales growth, at 3 percent, was less than expected," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. "Obviously, they underperformed in PC's, and that's not going to change soon."
"I think it was a solid quarter," he said. "I.B.M. has really executed on the cost side, but sales remain a challenge."
After being roughly tied with Apple Computer Inc. in 1993 for the title of No. 1 seller of personal computers in the United States, I.B.M. slipped in 1994, falling behind the Compaq Computer Corporation, Apple and Packard Bell Inc. to fourth place.
I.B.M.'s personal computer business has stumbled in recent years because of a confusingly large number of product lines and poor inventory management, resulting in shortages of popular models and an oversupply of less successful machines.
For the fourth quarter, I.B.M. had earnings of $1.23 billion, or $2.06 a share, more than three times the $341 million, or 55 cents a share, it reported a year earlier. Analysts had estimated earnings of about $1.75 a share.
Revenue was $19.9 billion, up 6.6 percent from $18.66 billion in the 1993 quarter. The figures exclude the results of a subsidiary that developed computers and software for the Federal Government; the subsidiary was sold last January.
"Despite the progress, we are not satisfied with our revenue growth," Louis V. Gerstner Jr., I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said. "Demand generally was strong across our product line, and demand for mainframes and storage products far outstripped supply. We were disappointed, however, by weakness in our personal computer business."
In a conference with securities analysts, Jerome York, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, said Richard Thoman, head of the IBM PC Company, expected the unit's restructuring to be completed by the second quarter of this year, allowing it to focus on regaining market share. Analysts said that at current revenue levels, the PC business was operating at a loss.
In October, in an effort to reduce confusion and rationalize its product line, I.B.M. cut its personal computer lines from nine to four, and introduced some new models. It also resurrected the I.B.M. PC brand name.
While mainframe computers benefited from the economic recovery, which prompted customers to make long-deferred purchases of these large machines, other I.B.M. product lines grew on their own merits, analysts said. Both the AS/400 line of minicomputers and the RS/6000 line of work stations and servers grew at double-digit rates, Mr. York said.
"The AS/400 is doing so well because they have refreshed the product line and are out there with a brand new marketing strategy," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a consulting firm based in Phoenix. "In the case of mainframes, the customer couldn't wait any longer; they have businesses that need additional capacity."
Mr. York said I.B.M. had cut expenses by $3.5 billion in 1994, and had met 80 percent of its long-range goal of cutting expenses by $8 billion. It will meet that goal by mid-1996 at the latest, he said.
I.B.M. said it ended 1994 with about 220,000 employees, down 14 percent from a year earlier.
For 1994, I.B.M. reported earnings of $2.89 billion, or $4.92 a share, in contrast to a loss of $96 million in 1993. The 1993 loss totaled $8.1 billion when that year's restructuring charge of nearly $8 billion was included. Revenue last year grew 6 percent, to $64.1 billion, with the Government systems unit excluded.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
American Express Net Climbs 16%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations rose 16 percent as consumer spending increased and profits from the company's insurance and mutual fund subsidiary advanced.
The travel and finance company said income from continuing operations increased to $335 million, or 65 cents a share, from $291 million, or 57 cents, a year earlier. 
 "They benefited from the higher spending," said Thomas Facciola, a Salomon Brothers Inc. analyst. American Express is "holding its own" in competition with credit cards such as Visa and MasterCard, he said.
Still, the American Express earnings failed to meet analysts' forecasts of 67 cents a share, according to a survey of 12 analysts by Zacks Investment Research. The results were released after the stock market closed.
The company's operating results exclude profits from the Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage firm in the 1993 quarter. American Express spun off the firm in May. Including those results, net income was down 16 percent from the 1993 quarter, when the company earned $399 million, or 78 cents.
Revenue rose to $3.8 billion, from $3.48 billion a year earlier.
The American Express results are closely tied to the health of the economy, which grew at a 4 percent annual pace in the third quarter. The company said fourth-quarter earnings in its travel services division, which includes the American Express charge and credit card operations, rose 14 percent, to $237 million from $208 million.
Earnings from American Express Financial Advisors, formerly named IDS Financial Services, increased 16 percent, to $114 million from $98 million.
Profits at American Express Bank, the company's overseas banking division, fell 40 percent, to $16 million, from $25 million in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Off in Price For 3d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday for the third consecutive trading session and longer maturities once again took the brunt of investor uncertainty over the Mexican aid package, a weak dollar and coming sales of new Treasury securities.
Shorter maturities received some support from market investors who are moving to "safer" investments in reaction to downturns in overseas stock markets. 
 Traders said volume was light, with shorter maturities already reflecting the expectation of an increase in interest rates of half a percentage point when the Federal Reserve meets next week.
The 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to a price of 9513/32 to yield 7.9 percent, up from 7.88 percent on Friday and the highest yield since Jan. 3, when it was 7.92 percent. Bill rates were steady to slightly lower.
Alan Kral, a portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., a New York investment firm, said the reasons for yesterday's market malaise included worries over the Mexican situation, the Orange County, Calif., bankruptcy and the outlook that the Fed would raise rates again. "The question is, will the next rate increase exacerbate or unveil another Mexico," he said.
At the Treasury's weekly auction, bill rates rose to a two-week high, as the three-month average bill rate came in at 5.8 percent and the six-month rate at 6.24 percent.
Some securities dealers were even selling two-year and five-year notes ahead of this week's new supply. The sale by the dealers and portfolio managers may have added more downward pressure on prices as the supply increased.
Traders and investors are already looking beyond this week's auction of two-and five-year notes to next month's quarterly refunding when the Government will sell 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. The yield on the current coupon two-year note was unchanged at 7.48 percent yesterday, as was the when-issued yield of 7.55 percent on the new issue being sold today.
Municipal bonds fell for the third day. Traders said the market was looking at the sale this week by New York City of $645 million in bonds as a barometer. The sale will be handled by Prudential Securities. The new issue will help the city refinance existing bonds and provide $200 million for capital projects. But the bonds are also expected to save the city money on interest and principal payments on all its debt as it struggles to close a $650 million budget gap.
Because of the city's fiscal problems, it remains to be seen if there will be enough investors to buy these bonds.
Last week, Standard & Poor's said it was considering downgrading the A- rating on the city's $23 million of general obligation bonds outstanding because of the plan to use money from the new bond issue to help close the city's budget gap.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: On Both Sides of the Border, Peso Ills Were Long Ignored

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER with ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration and the Mexican Government were saying until late last year that Mexico was a booming example of an emerging market that would bring wealth to workers in both countries, warnings were running rampant in both capitals that severe economic trouble lay ahead.
According to officials in Washington, the Treasury Department told several Mexican officials beginning last summer that the country's short-term borrowings had reached a dangerously high level and that the peso was being kept artificially high. But on several occasions, officials said, the Mexicans responded that they were aware of the problem, but that nothing could be done during and just after the election that brought Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon to power. 
 In Mexico City, officials now acknowledge that they knew the economy was in serious trouble months before Mr. Zedillo's election on Aug. 21. But they say that for political reasons, partly related to the elections and partly to the ambitions of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to head the new World Trade Organization after leaving office, they chose to continue borrowing and spending at a tremendous pace, sustaining the illusion of a thriving economy.
Today, Guillermo Ortiz, the Mexican Finance Minister, said at a hostile meeting of the legislature in Mexico City that there was "a yellow light" in Mexico's balance sheets that anyone should have seen. He said that while the Government was to blame, so was Wall Street, which "endorsed the economic policies and in particular the exchange rate policy of the Mexican Government."
The series of warnings issued from Washington, however, raises a number of questions about what the Administration was saying in public about the health of the Mexican economy, signals that were picked up by both American companies and investors. In November, as disaster loomed, President Clinton used the Summit of the Americas in Miami, the first meeting of Latin American leaders in nearly three decades, to celebrate Mexico's economic management as a model for the region's growth. He and his deputies issued no warnings that Mexico was consuming too much too fast, or letting its debt grow too rapidly.
Asked today why Mr. Clinton offered no public words of caution, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said, "The President's public comments have always stressed the fundamental strength of the Mexican economy and the commitment of the Mexican leadership to economic and political reform."
But a senior White House official added: "There was a great deal of sensitivity, as the Zedillo administration came to office, about not undercutting the very delicate situation they faced as they tried to form a government, so there was a very conscious effort not to be too heavy-handed. All these sovereignty issues are very sensitive."
Mr. Zedillo, an economist, contributed to the atmosphere of unbridled optimism. Visiting Washington on Nov. 23, just before his inauguration, he talked of economic growth this year "at 4 percent or better, and soon 5 percent, which we need to generate a million new jobs a year."
Now he will be lucky if his economy posts any growth this year and if the number of jobs do not shrink. At the same time, the Clinton Administration is now warning that unless the crisis is resolved, nearly half a million Mexicans seeking higher wages will illegally enter Texas and California during the next year.
In the aftermath of the Mexican debacle, officials in both Washington and Mexico are spinning tales of who knew what and when. The Central Intelligence Agency, for example, circulated a brief warning in July that Mexico's foreign currency reserves were being depleted in an effort to keep up the value of the peso. Now it is recirculating the same report, citing it as evidence that top Government officials had been warned.
But several leading economic officials say that the original warning was buried in a mountain of economic intelligence issued by the C.I.A. "There was no headline, and they know how to get your attention when they want to," one official said.
The agency, officials say, provided no warning in December that Mr. Zedillo was considering a major devaluation of the peso, which precipitated the crisis. Washington was given a half-hour notice of the action.
Other Clinton Administration officials said they warned Mexican leaders last year that the peso was overvalued, especially considering the tremendous pace at which Mexico was printing money.
One senior American official said that while it would be "inappropriate" to discuss private consultations between the Mexican and American Governments, "it would also be a big mistake to suppose that we were unaware of the building problem." Mexican officials, he said, acknowledged the problem but did little.
Today, both Administration officials and the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, expressed optimism that Congress would approve $40 billion in loan guarantees -- essentially cosigning a loan -- in hopes of increasing the confidence of investors in buying Mexican securities again. "It's going to happen," Mr. Gingrich told reporters. Those comments helped reverse slides on both the Mexican stock exchange and on Wall Street.
Mexican officials now acknowledge that they issued far too many short-term bonds -- called tesobonos -- and they say Mr. Salinas's administration passed up several opportunities to devalue the peso slowly, a step that could have averted the huge sell-off in Mexican bonds and other securities.
Mr. Ortiz, the Finance Minister, said that in September he argued that the peso should be devalued in an orderly way when a pact with labor and business was renewed. He not only lost that argument but also was originally passed over when Mr. Zedillo picked Jaime Serra Puche as his first Finance Minister.
Mr. Serra Puche was forced to resign a week after the peso was devalued, and Mr. Ortiz took his place.
Other officials who were carried over from the previous administration say that when Mr. Zedillo took office on Dec. 1 he knew how seriously overextended the Mexican economy was and that a crash could follow. But he also knew that the economy was addicted to the flood of international capital to keep paying its bills. So they said there was not much he could do except act as if nothing was wrong and encourage investors to keep pouring money into Mexico.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Canada's Pale Version of Peso Crisis

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada has raised short-term interest rates for 11 of the last 12 weeks in an effort to stop the precipitous slide of the Canadian dollar, but has failed so far to reverse its downward spiral to a near record low.
The central bank acted because a declining Canadian dollar reduces the value of the nation's wealth and compounds the Government's fiscal problems by increasing the cost of servicing Canada's huge national debt. 
 For Canadians themselves, the devaluation is cutting both ways, making winter trips to Florida more expensive but also making Canadian goods more attractive abroad.
The result has been a paler Canadian version of the financial jitters that sent Mexico into economic crisis when it abruptly devalued its peso last month. Both countries depend heavily on foreign capital.
At just over 70 American cents, the Canadian dollar has shrunk by 5 percent in three months and 20 percent since hitting a high of 89.29 on Nov. 1, 1991. The all-time low was 69.13 cents on Feb. 4, 1986.
Contributing to the depreciation are Canada's budget deficits and uncertainty about a referendum expected later this year on Quebec's independence.
A jump of 2.5 percentage points in short-term rates set by the Bank of Canada over the last two months helped brake the Canadian dollar's slide, but has also added $3 billion to the annual cost of servicing the debt. Interest on Canada's debt already gobbles up 35 percent of Government revenues. The higher interest rates could in time also dampen economic growth.
"There's clearly the risk of a vicious circle," said John McCallum, chief economist at the Royal Bank of Canada. But he added that the Canadian dollar crisis "strengthens the bargaining hand" of advocates of major spending cuts in the Government budget to be presented next month.
The currency imbroglio comes when Canada's economy has sharply improved under Prime Minister Jean Chretien. Economic output in the third quarter of 1994 grew 4.8 percent over the comparable period a year earlier, which is higher than any other member of the Group of Seven industrial nations. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicts that Canada will lead the group in growth both this year and next.
With trade barriers lowered by the North American Free Trade Agreement, Canadian exports to the United States have boomed, soaring 65 percent since 1991. Canada has almost zero inflation. And last year, it created 431,000 full-time jobs in the private sector, dropping Canadian unemployment to 9.6 percent.
But in a world of almost instantaneous money flows, currency markets are prone to what C. E. Ritchie, chairman of the Bank of Nova Scotia, calls the "electronic jury" of traders around the world.
The staggering rise of Canadian debt, more than a third of which is held internationally, has left the Canadian dollar vulnerable.
Over the last five years, Canadian national and provincial governments have run combined deficits of more than $50 billion (Canadian), or $35 billion (United States), annually. Their accumulated debt now exceeds $700 billion (Canadian), an amount roughly equal to the value of all goods and services produced in Canada last year.
As a percentage of the gross domestic product, only Italy's debt is higher among the leading industrial nations. On a per-capita basis, Canada is at the top of the list.
The markets have focused on the Government's credibility in reducing the budget deficit. The Government has promised to cut the deficit from the current 5 percent to 3 percent of Canada's gross domestic product, or to $25 billion (Canadian) by the 1996-97 fiscal year.
If the new Government budget fails to cut spending enough to meet that goal, the Canadian dollar could get even weaker.
Many market traders say the Government should be taking stronger action. "Markets want a clear sense that the Government is prepared to make deep cuts in spending," said Robert Palombi, senior fixed-income analyst for MMS International, a financial markets advisory service in Toronto. "They're demanding a less generous welfare state."
Some complained that the Bank of Canada's governor, Gordon Thiessen, waited too long to raise rates after the Federal Reserve Board in the United States tightened money in December. Last Tuesday, the Bank of Canada raised its benchmark bank rank nearly another full point, to 8.21 percent.
"The market lost confidence in the bank's ability or willingness to support the currency, and this created a feeding frenzy," said Jeff Rubin, chief economist at the Toronto investment house of Wood Gundy Inc.
Dr. Sherry Cooper, chief economist at another Toronto investment firm, Nesbitt Burns Ltd., said the central bank had sought to insulate the Canadian economy from higher rates, but found that it could not do so and still maintain Canada's appeal to international investors.
Mr. Thiessen talked up the Canadian dollar to the Montreal Board of Trade on Thursday, noting that Canada's economic fundamentals, including minimal inflation and high productivity, were strong. "So the underlying situation for the currency," he said, "is one that would cause you to look at the possibility of an increase" in the Canadian dollar's value.
The Canadian dollar has also been weakened by worries about what will happen to Canada's debt if Quebec votes to leave the rest of the country. A separatist Parti Quebecois government in Quebec is committed to holding a provincial referendum on independence this year. The latest polls indicate that a majority of Quebecers want to stay in Canada, but with separatists holding provincial power, they might be able to swing more opinion their way.
So far, ordinary Canadians have not shown much concern over their dollar's fall. "I don't get the sense that anyone's particularly worried," said James Nason, professor of economics at the University of British Columbia. "To the credit of the Prime Minister, the political atmosphere is calm and the drop in the dollar has not hurt exports or jobs."
Canadians point out that a large number of American companies are also benefiting from the lower Canadian dollar. Digital Equipment of Canada Ltd., for example, has the mandate from its American parent, the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., to build personal computers for North and South America. Shipments from the Canadian plant in Kanata, Ontario, jumped 70 percent in the second half of 1994.
The weak Canadian dollar has also helped Canadian store owners along the border. A few years ago, Canadians were spending billions of dollars in American shopping centers, protesting with their feet against the high prices and sales taxes at home. Now the plunging Canadian dollar, helped by lower inflation than in the United States, is luring American shoppers to Canada.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Advances by the Dollar
(By The Associated Press)
The dollar ended slightly higher against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday.
In Asian and early European dealings, the dollar strengthened after investors dumped Japanese stocks, pushing the Nikkei index of 225 issues down 5.6 percent.
But the dollar retreated in New York as many traders became concerned over reports suggesting Congress could reject or cut the Clinton Administration's proposed $40 billion loan-guarantee package for Mexico. Currency dealers expect the dollar to come under pressure if the peso continues to weaken because Mexico is the third-largest trading partner of the United States.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 99.80 yen from 99.40 yen on Friday. It advanced to 1.5145 marks from 1.5115 marks on Friday. The British pound rose to $1.5940 from $1.5890.
"The market has concluded that a failure to pass the Mexican loan package would be a negative for the dollar," said Michael Faust, currency strategist at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money-management firm in San Mateo, Calif.
"It's not only what it might mean for trade with Mexico, but the impact on international capital flows in general," he said. "Money might tend to stay at home."

HEADLINE: Car Makers' Debt Upgraded

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised its credit ratings today on the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, saying they were effectively preparing themselves for tougher competition and costly regulations.
The credit rating agency said it expected Japanese auto makers to become more competitive and believed that the automotive industry's business would decline up to 30 percent with the next recession. In addition, S.& P. said new regulations, particularly the more stringent emissions standards that might be put in place by several states, would be costly for the industry. 
 "Still, the Big Three are taking advantage of this period of prosperity to enhance their financial flexibility to meet these challenges," Standard & Poor's concluded.
Ford's main debt rating was raised to A+ from A and Chrysler's from BBB+ to A-. The company affirmed its BBB+ rating of the General Motors Corporation.
S.& P. cited Ford's return to profitability in Europe, the ability to capitalize on a strong automotive market in North America and the prospects of the company's financial services businesses, which are a "substantial and growing source of earnings."
S.& P. said Chrysler, which last week announced record profits for 1994, had had the most impressive financial performance among the Big Three. It praised Chrysler's successful new products and leanness, accumulation of a $7.5 billion cash reserve and the elimination of the company's unfunded pension liability.
The rating agency praised G.M.'s return to profitability in North American operations but said it was still concerned about the company's long-term potential.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Off Sharply; Oil Prices Turn Downward

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices tumbled yesterday on selling set off in part by sharp declines in overseas stock prices. The downturn halted a four-day rally in gold prices. 
 Crude oil futures also weakened after climbing last week to their highest level since early November. Analysts attributed the setback to increased supplies of reformulated gasoline and a lack of severely cold weather.
Commodities were generally lower, with the Commodity Research Bureau's index falling 1.66 points, to 235.51.
Gold for February delivery fell $4 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $381.40 an ounce. March silver tumbled 9.7 cents, to $4.82 an ounce. And April platinum dropped $5.70, to $417.60, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gold had risen strongly in recent weeks, hitting a high for the new year Friday amid the inflationary implications of rising commodity prices. The CRB index rose 3.99 points last week.
But steep losses yesterday on the Japanese, British, French and German stock markets prompted many international investors to sell precious metals for cash to cover margin calls and other obligations, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
"Often, the initial response to a sharp selloff in stock markets is a flight to cash, because you need liquidity," she said. "Ultimately, you may get a flight to safety, and to gold in particular, if the decline in stock markets continues."
Precious metals were also hurt by technical factors, including silver's drop through $4.90 and $4.85.
Crude oil futures relinquished more than a quarter of last week's strong gains after weekend shipments of reformulated gasoline into New York Harbor relieved a tightness in supplies of the cleaner-burning fuel.
Light crude for March delivery fell 32 cents, to $18.10 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. February heating oil fell 0.32 cent, to 47.82 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline sagged 1.02 cents, to 56.38 cents a gallon, and February natural gas fell 3.6 cents, to $1.389 for 1,000 cubic feet.
"Weather continues to be a negative as well," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures. Temperatures have cooled down to normal in the Midwest and Northeast, but there is no severe cold in sight.
