HEADLINE: Excerpts From Whitman's Address on the Budget

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's budget address to the Legislature today.
Last year, I promised taxpayers that this budget would be different. 
 And it is.
More than ever before, it's your budget.
We held town meetings around the state. Every cabinet member conducted public hearings. We promised to reach out through radio and television to hear your concerns.
We said we'd listen, and we did. . . .
I'm proud of this budget. It keeps promises. It uses common sense to invest our dollars and cents wisely. And it accomplishes a lot.
It absorbs the enormous cost of taking over the county courts. It complies with the Supreme Court's ruling on school funding. It helps municipalities, supports education and provides for New Jerseyans in need.
It reduces the state's reliance on one-shot revenues from $1.6 billion two years ago to $348 million this year -- a 78 percent reduction.
And it includes a $500 million surplus essential to preserving New Jersey's bond rating.
Last year's budget set us on the right course. Our tax cuts established credibility with the people. More important, they helped create jobs for the people.
The numbers speak louder than words.
This past year, the private sector created 60,000 new jobs. That's over 60,000 more New Jerseyans who are supporting their families and contributing to their communities.
We must continue to cut taxes. We are still competing for jobs and businesses with other states across the nation.
Last year, I promised to cut state income taxes by 30 percent over three years for most New Jerseyans. I said lower taxes would be good for the economy and good for our citizens. Today, we're halfway there.
We already have cut income taxes 15 percent for most New Jerseyans. We have removed 380,000 lower-income citizens from the tax rolls entirely. And the tax cuts are working -- even better than I thought.
Our job growth has put tax revenues in the state coffers faster than we expected.
So why wait to reinvest in New Jersey's future? Why wait to return as much money as we can to taxpayers? Why wait until next year to keep a promise we can keep right now?
Today, I am asking the Legislature to complete the 30 percent tax cut in this budget -- one full year ahead of schedule.
Effective Jan. 1, 1996, I want families earning up to $80,000 and individuals who earn up to $40,000 to pay 30 percent less than they did just two years before.
Families making up to $150,000 would pay at least 23 percent less in taxes. And families earning more would save at least 10 percent.
I want all families to have more each year to spend, save or invest as they see fit. And I want the same for business.
In this budget, I am proposing three business tax cuts designed to create new jobs.
Jobs in our inner cities.
Jobs in growing industries.
Jobs throughout New Jersey.
Our first proposed business tax cut is a change in corporate tax policy to encourage multistate companies to invest and employ people in our state. The other two cuts will benefit small businesses, which create up to 95 percent of our new jobs.
I am calling for the repeal of the telecommunications sales tax on Yellow Pages advertising.
I am also calling for a reduction in the corporate income tax rate from 9 percent to 7.5 percent for small corporations earning less than $100,000. That would make New Jersey's small business tax the lowest in the region. . . .
Together, our income and business tax cuts are working to put more New Jerseyans back to work.
Some argue that these tax cuts will force local property taxes to rise.
That simply isn't so.
The state does not collect a penny of property tax. The state does not spend a penny of property tax.
Those functions are the exclusive domain of the counties, the municipalities and the school districts. Property taxes reflect local spending decisions.
High property taxes are the price homeowners pay as school boards and local and county governments struggle to control costs.
It is the policy of this administration to help them win that struggle. . . .

HEADLINE: Cuomo Puts Ideas on Paper And Shops for a Book Deal

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR 

 BODY:
Conservative books are hot, publishers say. Liberal ones are not. But never mind that. Former New York Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whose liberal politics were soundly voted down in November, has decided to weigh in anyway. His proposed book theme: "progressive pragmatism."
In a two-and-a-half-page letter now being shopped around New York's publishing houses by his agent, the former Governor promises a fresh rebuttal to what he calls "Gingrichism" and the "Newt world order." Publishing executives say that Mr. Cuomo is asking for a seven-figure advance. 
 The book, he writes, "will say to America -- we can do better than the plastic populism that convinced voters in 1994 their anger had produced an intelligent plan for the nation's future."
"And then," he goes on, "it will describe something better."
He says his book will include "an economic plan that goes beyond painless tax cuts and makes the investments and insists on the trade relations necessary to succeed in a new global economy."
And he promises to outline "a common-sense approach that recognizes that tragedies like drug addiction, violence, children having children, dysfunctional families, are not visited upon us like earthquakes and floods, but are all avoidable disasters."
"It will be strong and it will be positive," he writes. And, he vows, "I will not simply recast speeches I made in the past."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Cuomo said he had discussed the book idea with at least two publishers. The letter, to Jim Griffin, his agent at William Morris, was his first effort at putting the idea on paper, he added.
But the book, to be finished this fall, would not be his first. The former Governor's words are already immortalized in two published diaries and in a collection of speeches, "More Than Words: The Speeches of Mario Cuomo" (St. Martin's Press).
Owen Laster, an executive vice president at William Morris, declined to comment on how large an advance was being sought.
Carol Schneider, an associate publisher at Random House, which published Mr. Cuomo's two diaries, said that Jason Epstein, who edited Mr. Cuomo's two diaries, was pursuing the new book. "Yes, we're interested," she said. But she declined to discuss the money issue.
Mr. Cuomo laughed when asked how big an advance he was looking for.
"I don't want to get into numbers," he said, "but I don't think that's accurate," referring to a suggestion he was seeking up to $2 million. Then, unable to resist kicking a little dust on Mr. Gingrich, who is still reeling from the furor that arose over his book contract, Mr. Cuomo added, "I don't have any $4.5 million dollar offers."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Economic Report Proposes Novel Step

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As a Senate subcommittee draws closer to holding hearings on baseball's exemption from antitrust laws, members of Congress have received a nonpartisan economic report that questions whether the exemption "serves a useful public purpose."
The 22-page report, compiled by the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress, also shows how the salary cap the clubs have implemented would benefit the owners in an overwhelming economic way and suggests the novel step of placing new franchises in existing large-revenue markets like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles as a way of leveling revenues between high-revenue and low-revenue clubs. 
 The owners were critical last August of a report compiled by Roger Noll, a Stanford economist, for the Players Association, but this one, while not dissecting the numbers the way Noll did, reaches many of the same basic conclusions as he did.
The owners, for example, have linked their revenue-sharing plan to the system that places a cap on club payrolls. But Dennis Zimmerman and William Cox, the economists who wrote the "CRS Report for Congress," conclude that "revenues to be shared with financially weak franchises might be raised from the income of financially strong franchises rather than from the salaries of the players."
Congress is not concerned about revenue sharing and salary caps specifically, but a growing number of members has questioned the link between the strike and the antitrust exemption.
Multiple bills calling for complete or partial repeal of the exemption have been introduced in the Senate and the House of Representatives, and the antitrust subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, whose chairman is Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, is expected to announce soon that it will hold hearings by the middle of next month.
Zimmerman and Cox write that the exemption might have encouraged the owners "not to seek a settlement that players would accept and to prefer an impasse," adding that the exemption reduces the owners' potential losses from declaration of an impasse in negotiations and unilateral implementation of a salary cap.
Without the exemption, they write, the union could challenge the salary cap on antitrust grounds. "A positive outcome of such a challenge," they write, "could result in the imposition of treble damages."
Raising doubts about the value of the exemption for anyone other than the owners, the report says that if options other than "anticompetitive labor practices" are available to correct the problems the owners say exist, "then the social benefits of MLB's antitrust exemption may be questioned."
Looking at the salary cap itself, the economists determined that if the plan had been in effect last year and the season had been played uninterrupted, the owners would have reduced player salaries and benefits by $198 million. The revenue-sharing plan, they add, would have transferred $38 million from high-revenue clubs to low-revenue clubs.
"Much of the remaining $160 million," they write, "presumably would accrue to the large-revenue teams (but could not be spent on player salaries)."
Zimmerman and Cox, however, say there are ways the economic onus would not have to fall so harshly on the players. For example, they write, the owners' concerns about the effect on competitive balance of the disparity between payrolls of high-revenue and low-revenue clubs could be met by diluting the revenues of the wealthier teams.
"In industries operating under competitive conditions," they write, "the existence of businesses with exceptional profits like the New York Yankees would attract new firms into the location, which would capture some of those profits."
Major league baseball, they say, could accomplish a similar result by adding franchises to markets like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, thus reducing revenue of established clubs from such sources as attendance and broadcasting rights.
The established clubs would not like the idea of being used "to finance a solution to the problem," the economists note. "But," they write, "one might ask why this loss would be more unfair than asking players to forgo part of the value of their own talent and skill (their human capital) to solve the problem."
On the other hand, they add, the established clubs could avoid suffering reduced revenues; they could be compensated by fees from the sale of the new franchises.

HEADLINE: Officials Offer New Plan To Retain the Yankees

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Yankee officials have rejected New York City's initial plans for upgrading Yankee Stadium and the surrounding neighborhood, and city officials presented team representatives with yet another proposal yesterday designed to keep the team from leaving the Bronx.
In the latest plan, the city proposes to upgrade the stadium with a new outer wall that copies the stadium's original facade, to add about 100 luxury boxes. It also proposes to increase the number of parking spaces and to make it easier to travel to the stadium by car. 
 John Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, said that when the city presented its plan for the renovations in December, team officials liked the proposal for the stadium itself but were concerned about both parking and access roads to the ball park -- two major fan complaints about the stadium.
The proposal presented yesterday tried to respond to those concerns, Mr. Dyson said, but he refused to provide details on the changes.
George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner, said the team was studying the proposal. "We had a good meeting with the Mayor," he said. "He presented a plan to us. We said we'd study it and get back to you."
Mr. Steinbrenner denied a published report that he had already notified city officials of a decision to move the team out of the Bronx, possibly to the Meadowlands in New Jersey.
"They presented this latest plan to us, which was a revision of one we had seen earlier, but we never even discussed the Yankees' leaving the Bronx," he said.
Referring to New Jersey officials, he said, "We've talked once in a while with them because I have some very good friends over there. That's no secret."
He also said, "To say that I said we would be leaving the Bronx is a total fabrication."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani also denied the report, in this week's issue of The New York Observer, which said that Mr. Steinbrenner had sent a letter to City Hall on Jan. 12 informing officials of his decision.
"It's a false story," the Mayor said. "It's flat-out untrue."
Mr. Dyson said the main objective of city and state officials was to keep the Yankees at their current location in the Bronx. He said there have been no talks with team officials about alternate sites within New York City.
In August, the city and state hired the design firm Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum to draw plans to modernize the stadium and to resolve the traffic, parking and safety concerns that Yankee officials claimed were keeping some fans from attending games.
Earlier proposals from state officials envisioned constructing a bridge from the Harlem River Drive to the Bronx, where fans could park in garages connected to the stadium by a secure walkway -- allowing them to attend games without walking the streets of the Bronx. It was not clear if those proposals were included in the plans presented to the Yankees.
Despite periodic reports -- all denied -- that the Yankees are about to flee the city, Mr. Dyson said the team appeared to be taking the negotiations over the stadium seriously.
"They come back with detailed suggestions or proposals or complaints from their architects and traffic engineers," Mr. Dyson said.
Yesterday morning, when Mr. Giuliani presented the latest proposal, Mr. Dyson said Mr. Steinbrenner reacted favorably. But he added that it remained an open question whether the team, in the end, would stay in New York.
In New Jersey, Carl Golden, a spokesman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, said Mr. Steinbrenner had been talking for years to officials at the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the Meadowlands sports complex. Mr. Golden reiterated the Governor's position that no taxpayer money would be spent to build a ball park, but that the state would help with the construction of access roads to a stadium.
"George Steinbrenner has talked to the sports authority for some time, just expressing interest and staying in touch," Mr. Golden said. "But there hasn't been, to my knowledge, any firm offer, plan, proposal for the authority to consider."

HEADLINE: Fighting Inflation Without Designated Paupers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Those Vital Paupers," Russell Baker's perceptive Jan. 17 column, displays the transparent vacuousness of the concept of the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment, expressed by economists in the acronym Nairu. 
 The cognoscenti who run our Federal Reserve and advise our policy makers believe it is bad for our society if self-interested business people want to hire most of the unemployed. By reducing the ranks of the unemployed (Mr. Baker's "vital paupers") in response to profit opportunities, business people will cause the economy to "overheat."
Consequently, the Nairu seers argue that the Federal Reserve must destroy potential profit opportunities by raising interest rates whenever profitable markets induce entrepreneurs to hire enough workers to reduce the unemployment rate below that embedded in their concept. It is apparently better to keep about 5.8 percent of American workers, who are willing to work, unemployed than to hire them, making them productive, income-earning, taxpaying members of society.
If we require some perpetual proportion of Americans to be unemployed, they must either starve to death or live as "parasites" off government entitlements or private charity. If we end welfare, and private charities do not replace these entitlement payments, three dreadful scenarios are possible.
(1) Unable to obtain any form of income maintenance, the unemployed will slowly starve to death. As they die, the rate of unemployment among the surviving members of society will fall below the critical Nairu value. To prevent inflationary overheating, the Federal Reserve will be forced to destroy additional profit opportunities so that business people, facing slack markets, will fire enough previously employed workers to refill the unemployment ranks to the necessary level.
Under this scenario of starving the unemployed, additional employed survivors must continually be sacrificed. Then, as Keynes noted in a slightly different context, "in the long run we'll all be dead."
(2) The unemployed can attempt to compete with the employed by lowering their wage requirements or improving their skills. If, however, the system always requires a significant portion of the population to be unemployed to prevent overheating, the newly employed will gain their jobs at the expense of the previously employed.
Job search will merely be a game of musical chairs where the Federal Reserve undertakes, as its responsibility, to assure that there are always fewer chairs than players.
(3) Those who are cast on the trash heap of the unemployed without entitlements may decide it is in their self-interest to create an illegal entitlements system -- that is, to steal from the employed, rather than to starve quietly. If as the crime rate increases, society's response is to incarcerate these criminals, the result will be more spending on entitlements for food, clothing and shelter through prisons and orphanages.
If instead, society decides to expand the death penalty rather than locking up such criminals, and if we are successful in catching them, the result will be to reduce the ranks of these unemployed more rapidly than under the starving the unemployed scenario. This will force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates all the more rapidly to replenish the unemployment rate.
Surely a civilized society can figure a way out of this nonaccelerating-inflation-rate-of-unemployment nonsense. Some economists, including John Maynard Keynes, who never were ensnared in the gossamer of the Nairu garment, have advocated policies that do not require a permanent army of unemployed paupers to achieve a prosperous, inflation-free economy.
 
PAUL DAVIDSON
Editor, Journal
of Post Keynesian Economics
Knoxville, Tenn., Jan. 17, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW: HAVE YOU SPOKEN TO ANY JEWS LATELY?;
Is It a New Holocaust? Is It Paranoia? Is It Funny?

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
About halfway through the first act of Bruce Jay Friedman's newest fever dream of a comedy, "Have You Spoken to Any Jews Lately?" a man in the audience explodes more or less metaphorically, speaking words supplied by the playwright. "This is a cheap commercialization of this century's most barbarous act," the man shouts to the actors. "Have you no shame?"
Not really. 
 Shame isn't much in evidence on the stage of the American Jewish Theater, where "Have You Spoken to Any Jews Lately?" opened last night. Yet there's a lot of anger, fear and compassion, sometimes expressed in terms that are as horrific as they are funny. Mr. Friedman is a novelist with sterling credits ("Stern," "A Mother's Kisses") and playwright ("Scuba Duba" and "Steambath"), who has recently been working in movies. Maybe that's why he likes to push his luck when he finds himself in the comparative freedom of the Off Off Broadway theater.
You can still do things here that remain unacceptable in Hollywood. That would include writing a play some people might take to be a comedy about the Holocaust, rather than recognizing it as one man's nightmare prompted, in part, by his own sense of guilt and rootlessness. In New York you are also allowed to write a play, like this one, which is scarcely more than an extended series of blackout sketches, but which has an emotional impact that goes beyond its very free, sometimes sloppy form.
"Have You Talked to Any Jews Lately?" is about Jack Horowitz (Larry Pine), born and bred in the Bronx of devout Jewish parents. He's married to a beautiful, blond Roman Catholic, Flannery O'Halloran (Christina Haag), and the father of an off-stage daughter, Chrissy, who has begun to bug him with questions about who she is. What, exactly, are her roots? Her ethnic obligations?
These are the questions Jack asks himself, though in most other ways he's self-assured and honorable. He has given up a successful career as a hack screenwriter to bring his family back to the sanity of the East Coast. When the play opens, it's off-season in the resort community (which could be one of the Hamptons) where they are year-round residents. Jack stays busy writing a column for the town weekly and helping out at the deli.
Mr. Friedman describes the time as "a few years from now, whenever now is." Israel, we learn, has left the Middle East and is now in Miami Beach. Because the large Cuban presence in Miami goes unmentioned, this gag, like some others, seems underdeveloped and slightly disconnected. References to Quentin Tarantino and Ollie North compete for attention with mentions of Walter Winchell and Irwin Shaw.
The play's principal setting is the common room of the resort town's community center. The weather outside is B-movie stormy as the uneasy Jack awaits an old Hollywood screenwriting pal. Uneasy? He is verging on paranoia. When he turns on the radio, right-wing Christian evangelists dominate the airwaves. He's unable to reach his lawyer, Sid, on the telephone. Willy Gold, his plumber, has disappeared.
By the time of the appearance of the loud, bumptious Danny (Richard M. Davidson), Jack is in a state of high anxiety. Danny's news isn't good. The municpal authorities of the town where he has a summer place have rezoned his property. Even as they speak, says Danny, a road is being built through his living room, "right past the sectional couch." Is "it" happening again, and this time here? Well, Danny also hasn't spoken to any Jews lately, except his wife, Shirley.
In the course of the two acts, played as very dark, but often wildly funny vaudeville entertainment, Jack and Danny become convinced that a new Holocaust is at hand. They are assaulted by the past and present, by memories and fantasies, which are acted out, and by their own bizarre panic. Has the world changed, or are they only acknowledging realities for the first time? Two men and a woman, a cabaret team, dance through the common room. They stop just long enough for the woman to admire the size of Jack's nose. The tradespeople who wander in call Jack "Mr. O'Halloran." The insults take on menace.
Jack shows Danny a T-shirt Chrissy was wearing one day when she came home from school. It bears a large "J," which the principal says was to punish her for jaywalking. The town's barber charms the name-dropping Danny with the list of his summer customers, including Wayne Gretzky. He lures Danny offstage just long enough the shave him bald. The absurd becomes plausible, and the plausible unspeakable. The play's penultimate sequence, set in a boxcar, is a shocker, and something of a coup de theatre.
The director, Michael Rudman, has had remarkable success in staging all this fluidly and with conviction. That's not an easy job on the American Jewish Theater's tiny stage, hemmed in by a ceiling so low you can almost touch it when sitting down. The pacing is lively. The mood is almost festive. The members of the very good cast, headed by Mr. Pine and Mr. Davidson, have all found the gravely lunatic manner the material demands.
Three standouts: Penny Balfour, as the kind of Weimar Republic chanteuse identified with the music of Kurt Weill; Gene Canfield, as the sadistic barber, and Judith Granite as the motherly type Jack and Danny meet en route to a place called Grunwald.
Though "Have You Spoken to Any Jews Lately?" is loaded with Jewish manners, lore, figures of speech and history, it would be a mistake to consider the play as narrowly ethnic as it sounds. Beneath its engagingly disreputable particulars, the play is another consideration of the same kind of moral aimlessness Sam Shepard examined in "Simpatico."
When American social and economic life was dominated by people sharing the same northern European heritage, one could speak of this country as a great melting pot. Today it's apparent that we don't all melt down at the same speed and to the same consistency. Somehow we have to learn to accommodate that fact, Mr. Friedman seems to say. Otherwise, chaos.
 
HAVE YOU SPOKEN TO ANY JEWS LATELY?
By Bruce Jay Friedman; directed by Michael Rudman; sets by James Wolk; costumes by Jennifer Di Figlia; lighting by Deborah Constantine; sound by Bruce Ellman; pianist, Mat Eisenstein; production stage manager, Alexander D. Carney; managing director, Ruth Ann Nightengale. Presented by the American Jewish Theater, Stanley Brechner, artistic director. At 307 West 26th Street, Chelsea.
 
WITH: Larry Pine (Jack Horotitz), Richard M. Davidson (Sid, Shopper, Bar Patron and Hasid), Stephen Singer (Danny), Penny Balfour (Margaret, Tennis Player and Cabaret Performance Artist), Brennan Brown (Local, Vendor and Tom), Christina Haag (Flannery O'Halloran), Gene Canfield (Lee) and Judith Granite (Mrs. Goldman).

HEADLINE: WHITMAN PLEDGES EARLY COMPLETION OF 30% TAX CUT

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Saying that she had kept her promise, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would complete her 30 percent reduction in state income tax rates by next January, a year ahead of schedule. The reduction would be paid for by a catalogue of cuts in state government that would reduce the state work force by 3,350 employees, or nearly 5 percent.
The announcement was a surprise, since most legislators listening to the Governor's annual budget message had forecast a new tax cut of only 5 percent on top of the 15 percent in reductions already enacted, and since Mrs. Whitman herself had indicated in October that she might not be able to keep to her three-year timetable. 
 "We have kept our promises," she said, and when she declared that she could deliver the full 30 percent reduction in two years, it brought legislative Republicans cheering to their feet. [Excerpts, page B5.]
The Democratic minority, caught off guard, sputtered that for all the national attention the Governor has attracted with her tax cutting, she has not managed to arrest a steady rise in total state spending. Mrs. Whitman's critics also pointed out that New Jersey's indebtedness is on the rise and claimed that she was simply shifting the burden from the state income tax to local property taxes, from today's residents to future taxpayers.
Mrs. Whitman's speech set the scene for her appearance in a national broadcast on Tuesday night, when she will offer the Republican reply to President Clinton's State of the Union address, which is to be televised at 9 P.M. Tuesday. [Article, page A14.] Her speech will be built around the theme, developed in Washington and by the Governor, that Republicans keep their promises. It was a motif Mrs. Whitman embellished time and again today.
"Tax cuts are working, even better than I thought," the Governor said in her address. "Our job growth has put tax revenues in the state coffers faster than we expected. So why wait to reinvest in New Jersey's future? Why wait to return as much money as we can to taxpayers? Why wait until next year to keep a promise we can keep right now?"
The selection of Mrs. Whitman to be the first governor ever to reply to a State of the Union address has resonated through the State House for days. Today, a packed Assembly chamber flared into a tumult of bipartisan cheering when Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate president, referring to Mrs. Whitman's speech on Tuesday, introduced the Governor with the words, "Your selection is proof that the best of New Jersey is the best of the nation."
Mrs. Whitman's staff pointedly disavowed speculation that the Governor had increased her tax cut from the expected 5 percent to the full remaining 15 percent to strengthen her reply to President Clinton on Tuesday.
"If you're asking, did we put a one before the five after she was selected to make the Republican response, that is not true and frankly it is insulting," said Peter Verniero, the Governor's chief counsel. He said the decision had been made weeks ago.
The final proposed 15 percent decrease in income tax rates would affect single taxpayers earning less than $ 40,000 a year and couples filing jointly earning less than $ 80,000 a year; those levels were the original target of the Governor's tax cut pledge, and cover about four-fifths of all taxpayers. As of next January, a couple earning $ 80,000 will have seen their top tax rate decline from 5 percent in 1993, the year before Mrs. Whitman took office, to 3.5 percent, worth about $ 600 in savings.
Taxpayers earning more than $ 80,000 will see lesser reductions, but Mr. Verniero said the Governor would seek additional cuts for top earners in future years. Mrs. Whitman eliminated any income tax obligation for those earning less than $ 7,500 last year, about 380,000 people.
The reductions will cost the state nearly $ 500 million a year in revenues, but only about half of that, $ 247 million, will have to be made up in the Governor's $ 16 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, since that budget extends only to the middle of next year. The budget for the current fiscal year is $ 15.4 million.
Mrs. Whitman made it plain today that she was in no mood for her critics' complaints that the failure of state aid to schools and municipalities to at least keep pace with inflation is responsible for an inching up of state property taxes. In her truncated, barely inflected speaking style, Mrs. Whitman sent local governments the clearest signal yet that they are on their own.
"Some argue that these tax cuts will force up local property taxes," the Governor declared in her speech. "That simply isn't so. The state does not collect a penny of property tax. The state does not spend a penny of property tax. Those functions are the exclusive domain of the counties, the municipalities and the school districts. Property taxes reflect local spending decisions."
Although nearly half of the state's 611 school districts will see outright cuts in their levels of state aid, and its 567 municipalities will get no increase at all from the budget, leaders of local government received the speech with resignation and in some cases a sense of relief that the budget news was not worse.
"It's better than we expected, or feared," said William Dressell, director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities. "State aid to municipalities makes up a large portion of the budgets of many local governments, so naturally we were concerned with all the talk of cutting back. So just staying even is a plus, you could say."
While Mrs. Whitman had wavered on the timing of her three-year, 30 percent pledge in October, she said today that better-than-anticipated tax revenue figures that came in Jan. 4 -- spurred by a strong state economy -- made today's bold proposal possible.
In many ways, Mrs. Whitman's challenge was less daunting than the task facing her fellow Republicans in New York and Connecticut. To pay for today's income tax cuts, she had to trim only $ 247 million out of a $ 16 billion budget, while Gov. George E. Pataki in New York has said he will have to cut $ 5 billion out of a $ 34 billion budget to deliver his first round of income tax cuts.
New Jersey is a wealthier state than New York, and its economy has led the region as the pharmaceutical and electronics industries have prospered while Wall Street has yet to recover from the recession. Also, New Jersey's social agenda has always been far less ambitious than New York's.
Governor Whitman is expected to get the budget reductions she asks for. Republicans control both houses of the Legislature and, as State Senator John A. Lynch, leader of the Senate Democrats said after the speech, "Who's going to vote against a tax cut?"
Ever mindful of New Jersey's business climate, Governor Whitman also she she would seek to repeal a tax on Yellow Pages advertising, worth $ 20 million a year; change a corporate income tax to save businesses $ 33 million, and cut the rate of tax on businesses earning less than $ 100,000 a year to 7.5 percent from 9 percent, worth $ 14 million.
That lower rate will give New Jersey the lowest small-business tax rate in the region, the Governor said.
The Democrats were generally subdued in their response, acknowledging that Mrs. Whitman has torpedoed the old language of budget making, based on needs, and substituted her own logic, founded on tax reductions. An example of one Democratic legislative response, from Assemblyman Joseph J. Rogers: "The Governor's 15 percent tax cut announcement advances her carefully tailored public image so she can compete with the O.J. Simpson trial in her ongoing campaign for the national spotlight and higher office."
Henry A. Coleman, a professor of government at Rutgers and a former ranking member of the Republican administration of Thomas H. Kean, said in an interview that the relationship between state spending and local taxes is more complex than Mrs. Whitman's approach would suggest, since many local functions, including the biggest one, education, are required and regulated by state law. He said it was unfair to say that the state has nothing to do with local spending levels, since it mandates many services.
"You can't expect the state to come in and ratify every increase in spending a local government wants with more aid -- that's the argument she's making, and it's a reasonable concern on her part," Dr. Coleman said. "But you really have to balance what is local discretion and what services the state requires localities to buy."
Indeed, Mrs. Whitman proposed two measures today to help move school districts toward greater frugality. One would help school districts merge into more efficient regional districts, and the other would reduce state aid levels to schools that spend too much on bureaucracy.

HEADLINE: State of the Union? One Day, Paralyzed

BYLINE: By Paul Starr; Paul Starr, professor of sociology at Princeton, is co-editor of The American Prospect.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
When the Framers replaced the Articles of Confederation with the Constitution, they gave the Government unqualified and unimpeded fiscal powers. Today, a new Republican majority in Congress proposes to overturn that decision. Speaker Newt Gingrich says he intends to reverse the growth of the Federal Government's role in society since 1932. The legacy he challenges, however, is not only that of Franklin D. Roosevelt but more fundamentally that of Alexander Hamilton.
As President Clinton delivers his State of the Union Message tonight, many Americans will wonder about the fate of particular programs and policies in the new Congress. But the larger question raised by the Republicans is the Government's capacity to act, for they propose not just to shrink programs but to impose a permanent constitutional straightjacket that is likely to paralyze the Government in future crises. 
 The Constitution is a parsimonious document, unencumbered with detailed policy prescriptions. This restraint expresseed confidence in representative government; it left the people's future representatives free to confront problems the Founders knew they could not anticipate. As Hamilton explains in "The Federalist" (No. 30), it was imprudent to set any limit to the new government's taxing power because there was no clear limit to the demands that might be placed upon it. The Constitutional Convention deliberately rejected requirements for supermajorities: impediments to revenue-raising had helped make the Articles of Confederation unworkable.
Today's Republican majority apparently believes it is more capable of making fiscal policy for future generations than were the Founding Fathers. It seeks to prescribe a balanced-budget amendment, to require a three-fifths supermajority for tax increases and to prohibit the Government from imposing requirements on the states except when it assumes 100 percent of the costs.
These measures are frankly intended to disable a Government that many Americans say they no longer trust. Yet those measures severely weaken the Government's capacity to achieve any purpose. They hand weapons to minorities to obstruct majorities: a minority in either house would be able to impede preparations for national defense as well as spending on the poor.
If in the pursuit of a balanced budget in the year 2002, we cut Medicare and social programs and provoked an inevitable angry reaction, it would be all the harder to find money for purposes that conservatives prefer, whether "Star Wars" defense systems, more prisons or intensified border patrols.
The Government capacity's to act is a resource as much for conservative as for liberal purposes. So those who are planting a time bomb under the welfare state may see it explode in their own faces.
The comeuppance could be much more serious for the nation than for any party. The dangers would likely be greatest in a recession. If revenue fell along with economic activity and if three-fifths of Congress could not agree to run a deficit, the Government would be forced to aggravate the downturn by cutting public expenditures as well -- a recipe for turning recessions into depressions.
The Pentagon is committed to maintaining forces prepared to fight two wars simultaneously, but a nation with weakened fiscal powers is much less capable of sustaining such commitments. Our enemies would understand this and act accordingly.
Some critics may dismiss these as empty worries. After all, the amendment, if passed in time, would not require a balanced budget until 2002. But seven years come soon enough. Concerns about the amendment are empty only if the amendment itself is empty of force.
The requirements for supermajorities are the most dangerous element in the Republicans' plan. But even if they reduced voting requirements to an absolute majority of members of Congress -- as many Democrats prefer -- it would give undue constitutional force to the norm of budget balancing.
Denying the Government the routine power to borrow is a surrender to the medieval view of debt that continues to shape popular attitudes. The introduction of credit cards almost three decades ago prompted overwhelming disapproval in public opinion surveys; meanwhile, Americans got the cards in droves.
There has never been a time -- not even during the New Deal -- when public opinion surveys failed to register overwhelming disapproval of government deficits. Yet Americans' disapproval of deficits ought to be taken as a mandate for constitutional prohibition about as seriously as their disapproval of credit cards was taken as grounds for outlawing charge accounts. Credit cards have not doomed the economy, nor will Federal deficits.
The problem of the deficit is its long-term rate of growth, which is due almost entirely to projected health care costs. There are no more grounds for making a zero deficit a constitutionally required objective than for denying corporations or families the ability to borrow. Federal deficits of 1 or 2 percent of the gross domestic product are entirely manageable. If the outstanding debt is inflation-adjusted annually, deficits of that scale typically do not amount to a real increase in the debt anyway.
Judge Robert Bork opposes the amendment as unworkable. So do other jurists, who think that if Congress used accounting gimmicks to portray an unbalanced budget as balanced, the courts would have no competence to enforce the amendment. And some state officials worry that the burdens of Federal cutbacks would be passed on to them. If the Senate does not derail the amendment, such objections may well do so.
The original rationale for constitutional parsimony still stands. We will never know enough about the future to predict the tests that democratic government will face. More than 200 years of American history should assure us that the Republic not only can survive without constitutionally imposed fiscal restrictions, it has been better off without them.
If the Constitution had required a balanced budget, many members of Congress would not sit there today: for one thing, Thomas Jefferson could never have completed the Louisiana Purchase.
Hamilton's legacy of unimpeded fiscal power has been crucial to a system of government that has brought us through wars, depressions and natural calamities to an unchallenged position as the strongest nation on earth.
During the Depression, World War II and the cold war, there was a ready-made answer to questions about why we needed a strong Federal Government. The crisis of Government capacity has erupted today in part because there is no longer any shared sense of the Government's overriding mission. But depressions and wars have not been banished forever; rules we adopt now must be good when the world turns bad. Constitutionalizing fiscal policy is bad for the Constitution and bad for fiscal policy. It would make a mockery of one or a failure of the other, or both.

HEADLINE: Some Mexican Bonds Go Unsold

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
With American loan guarantees for Mexico unresolved, the peso weakened again today and the Mexican stock market drifted.
Interest rates on the latest sale of key Government bonds soared above 26 percent. 
 Even at those high rates, the Government could only find buyers for two-thirds of the $400 million worth of short-term bonds, called tesobonos, that it offered today. By contrast, investors snapped up all the bonds available at the last scheduled sale a week ago, increasing confidence then that the Mexican economy could recover from the bruising devaluation of the peso in December.
The peso fell to 5.745 to the dollar today, down from 5.705 on Monday. It has lost nearly 40 percent of its value against the dollar since Dec. 20, when it traded at 3.46 pesos to the dollar.
Today's disappointing auction of bonds, and the high interest rates the Government had to agree to pay, illustrated how much Mexico's recovery depends on American Congressional approval of the $40 billion loan-guarantee package, now the subject of vigorous argument in Washington and elsewhere in the United States. Mexico's credibility in the financial markets has fallen so low that to some investors, the creditworthiness of the country appears doubtful no matter how much interest it offers to pay.
"The U.S. investing public is waiting to see what is the status of the bailout package," said Scott E. Kalb, managing director of emerging markets research at Smith Barney & Company in New York. "That's the final piece in the puzzle."
Passage of the loan guarantees has been hindered by members of Congress who are trying to add economic and political conditions. The House Banking Committee is scheduled to open its hearings on the package in Washington on Wednesday, with the new Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, testifying. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is to begin its hearings Thursday. A vote on the package would take place after the hearings are concluded.
But the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today, "My assessment is that they are not getting close" to rounding up enough votes to approve the loan guarantees.
Although the Mexican Government is under increasing criticism at home for having run to the United States for help, it acknowledges that recovery would be almost impossible without the American guarantees. On Monday, Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz told angry Mexican legislators that he had been negotiating with private commercial banks and the governments of other nations, in case the American package fell through or the United States Congress imposed conditions that Mexico considered unacceptable.
But even Mr. Ortiz conceded that the alternatives would only delay Mexico's problems, not solve them. He said it might be possible to get commercial banks to place a modest amount of short-term bonds, "but we would not be able to do so in sufficient amounts to really solve for once and for all this problem."
The $40 billion in loan guarantees from the United States would buy time for Mexico, providing assurance for foreign and domestic investors that Mexico would meet its obligations in 1995, and giving Mexico time to sell airports, railroads and other state-run enterprises to private buyers. Proceeds from the sales would be used to permanently retire much of that short-term debt.
The Mexican stock market began the day with substantial gains, but then lost some of its momentum after the results of the bond auction were announced. By the end of trading, the market index closed at 2,095.61, up a modest 27.12 points, or 1.31 percent.
Telefonos de Mexico, the largest company on the exchange, estimated that it would show a pretax loss of 4.4 billion pesos in 1994 as a result of the peso's devaluation. The American depository receipts of Telmex closed in New York today at $35 a share, down 75 cents.
Investors interpreted the outcome of the bond auction today as a sign of Mexico's continuing lack of credibility. The bonds are pegged to dollars and are thus considered the most secure type of Mexican debt. The interest rate for the benchmark 91-day bond rose to 24.98 percent, the sixth straight week that the rate has gone up. Rates for six-month bonds rose to 26.99 percent, and one-year bonds were sold at 21.4 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Crops Holding Promise Beyond Food

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Most of the crops America's farmers raise each year are eaten. But the country's agribusiness is hoping that the small portion that is not consumed can be turned into a new wave of profitable nonfood agricultural products.
Many of the recent innovations, like corn-based golf tees and biodegradable pens, are relatively inconsequential novelties. But others, like new lubricants, fuel additives, and inks, make up the advanced guard of products that could eventually earn billions of dollars annually for farmers and agribusinesses while benefiting the environment. 
 "The 1990's may be witnessing an historic turnaround in the fortunes of plant matter," said David Morris, an economic development specialist at the Institute for Local Self-Reliance in Minneapolis who has studied the potential for using materials derived from plants instead of fossil fuels like oil and coal.
No one expects a return to the early days of this century, when scientists like Thomas Edison and George Washington Carver were famous for their research into new industrial uses for crops and industrialists like Henry Ford not only wanted to run cars on soybean oil but also to build steering wheels and other parts from soybean-based plastics.
World War II and the cheap oil era that followed dramatically highlighted the attractions of fossil fuels, which have a higher energy content by weight and volume, and are easily processed into a variety of wondrously durable plastics and fibers.
Nor is the rebound going to put any oil companies out of business. Farmers would satisfy only a small fraction of the demand for gasoline, fuel oil, plastics and other petroleum-based products even if every bushel of every crop planted last year went to such uses.
Even enthusiasts like Mr. Morris concede that the rebound is starting from a very low base: Fewer than 10 million tons annually of plant matter other than wood go into industrial and construction products in the United States, compared with roughly 175 million tons of petroleum and coal and 300 million tons of inorganic minerals like sand, salt and iron ore. About 6 million tons of corn go into fuel and about 450 million tons of plants end up as food or animal feed.
Still, growing industrial use of crops could slow the nation's increasing dependence on oil and other raw materials imported from politically unstable areas like the Persian Gulf. A Department of Energy study last year concluded that 19 of the 50 most widely used chemicals in the United States could wholly or partly be replaced by biomass feedstocks, as materials from plants and animals are known. Petrochemical companies say that outside of a few niches, raw materials from plants are no match for oil-based products on a cost or performance basis. A crucial part of the equation, they say, is how much industry has invested in existing processes and factories.
The environmental pitfalls of some petrochemical materials are providing a market opening for some agricultural products that cannot compete simply on a per-pound cost basis with petrochemicals. Construction companies, for example, have begun to use Bio-Form, which is made from the oil in rape (a relative of mustard), to coat the wood beams that keep concrete in place while it hardens. The coating allows the workers to remove the wood after the concrete has set. By using Bio-Form, which is made by the Leahy-Wolf Company of Franklin Park, Ill., instead of cheap but noxious substances like waste motor oil, construction companies do not need to give workers gloves or respirators. Because Bio-Form breaks down into harmless components, the companies also avoid the kind of lawsuits many have run into charging them with contaminating their work site.
Other developing market niches have bigger potential, not all of which would come at the expense of oil companies. Phenix Biocomposites Inc., a privately held company in Mankato, Minn., is aiming Environ, a blend of soybean flour, shredded newspapers, and mixers, at the building materials market. "Looks like granite, works like wood," is the company's slogan. An independent study commissioned by the United Soybean Board, a Government-appointed trade organization that oversees spending of research and promotion funds raised from farmers, said that the annual market for such hardwood replacements could be $1.8 billion by the turn of the century.
Phenix's giant neighbor, Cargill Inc. in Minneapolis, is currently leading a new assault on one of the biggest petroleum-based markets of all: plastics. Cargill has been making up to 1,200 pounds an hour of Eco-Pla, a polymer derived from the lactic acid produced by fermenting corn, at a plant it built for $10 million in Savage, Minn. Polylactic acid, as the polymer is known, was discovered in 1833 and has been used in surgical products like sutures and screws because it breaks down harmlessly in the body. But it has cost hundreds of dollars a pound to produce.
Cargill has figured out how to make polylactic acid for as little as $3 a pound in Savage. It has designed a production line for its plant in Blair, Neb., that should be efficient enough for Cargill to make up to 300 million pounds annually for sale at about $1 a pound.
"It looks and functions just like a plastic but has the added advantage of degrading completely when disposed of," said Patrick Gruber, a general manager at Cargill. "This could be the first renewable polymer product to break into a classic petrochemical product stream."
Cargill said various Eco-Pla formulations could be used as paper coatings, fast-food containers and cutlery, disposable diapers and trash bags. Among those on the record as interested is the Packaging Corporation of America, a large manufacturer of packaging material for fast-food companies.
"We see a lot of interest from our customers in biodegradability," said Gordon Putz, vice president of marketing for the Packaging Corporation. He said the company aimed to have Eco-Pla products by 1997.
Because plant chemistry was so neglected as oil and other hydrocarbons came to dominate the economy, researchers say the area is now ripe for innovations like Eco-Pla. And that is without even factoring in the new tools of biotechnology, which make it easier for researchers to manipulate plants to produce bigger quantities of valuable substances or variations on naturally occurring compounds.
But even if the new products eventually begin selling in sizable enough quantities to have a significant impact on the overall demand for major crops, it is by no means clear that farmers will capture many of the benefits. Demand will have to rise faster than their ever-increasing productivity to raise prices. That explains why many farmers are more interested in specialized strains of their crops, like Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc.'s new varieties of soybeans that are low in saturated fat, than new end uses. These hybrids could be sold at premium prices to food processors trying to create healthier products.
But others see new uses as a means for getting better returns. Robert Schemel, who grows corn, soybeans and sugar beets on 3,000 acres in southern Minnesota, is chairman of a new farmers' cooperative that is raising money to build a processing plant to make Environ for Phenix Biocomposites. Once the plant is running, Mr. Schemel said, the farmers who own it will get up to $9 a bushel more for soybeans than the market price, which is currently $5.50 a bushel.
"We want to get as close to the consumer as possible," said Mr. Schemel, who sees Environ as a way to branch into higher-margin products. "If a farmer does not do more to his crop than just grow it, his long-term viability is limited."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 4.71 Points As Stocks Finish Mixed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday, the third session where the leading indexes have been virtually stagnant. The lackluster day was perhaps a harbinger of the next five sessions leading to a Federal Reserve policy meeting that begins on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.71 points, to 3,862.70, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.04 point, to 465.86. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 3.69 points, to 763.20. 
 Traders are watching the continuing financial troubles in Mexico for a clue to worldwide market conditions. The Mexican central bank yesterday could not sell all its dollar-denominated short-term bonds, called tesobonos, and the yield on the 91-day bonds rose to 24.98 percent, from 19.75 percent last week. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
In addition, Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said yesterday that Republican leaders and the White House had so far failed to reach agreement on conditions for President Clinton's $40 billion loan-guarantee package for Mexico. A Congressional vote, which had been expected by Friday, may now take longer.
Probably the only market-sensitive economic report immediately facing traders is the Commerce Department's report on Friday of its initial estimate of economic growth in the fourth quarter.
The economy grew at a 4 percent annual pace in the third quarter, revised upward from 3.9 percent, and some economists, including some Fed governors, have speculated that fourth-quarter growth was even stronger.
The outlooks for inflation, interest rates and the level of corporate earnings are three major factors that move markets. All three factors are unsettled in traders' minds.
Even the strong corporate earnings that have been reported recently have failed to lift prices. Two cases in point: American Home Products, whose fourth-quarter net earnings of $1.30 a share exceeded expectations by 3 cents a share, and Martin Marietta, whose fourth-quarter profit of $1.30 a share exceeded expectations by 5 cents. Martin Marietta closed unchanged yesterday at 44 7/8, while American Home Products rose 1/4, to 66 1/4.
The stock market often takes its cue from the bond market, and bond prices have fallen for four consecutive days. When prices of bonds fall, their interest rates, or yields, rise to attract more buyers, thus weakening prices for stocks.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond is fast approaching 8 percent, a level it has not reached since Dec. 1. The long bond closed yesterday at a yield of 7.92 percent, up from 7.90 percent. The American depository receipts of Kirin Brewery rose 7 1/2, to 107, following reports that its Amagasaki factory had sustained no major damage from the earthquake in Kobe, though the plant has been shut down temporarily.
The A.D.R.'s of Kyocera, a Japanese ceramics makers, rose 5 1/2, to 133 1/2, probably a result of bargain hunting after steady declines in the five previous sessions. Cordis, a maker of catheters, rose 2 5/8, to 60 3/8, after reporting a 42 percent rise in fourth-quarter net, to 78 cents a share.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, reported its first fourth-quarter profit in five years, but its stock price still fell 4 1/8, to 95 1/2.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was slightly above average with 325.2 million shares changing hands.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.23 point, to 253.70, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,265 to 936.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Rise On New York City's Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
New York City's continuing fiscal problems forced the city to pay higher interest rates yesterday on its sale of $658 million in debt.
The offering, which included 30-year bonds, was intended to help the city avoid further cuts in its $31.8 billion budget. It will cost New York millions of dollars in extra interest payments compared with other similarly rated municipal bonds as Wall Street continues to worry that the city's problems will make it more difficult to finance its needs. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani decided to sell the refunding bonds last week to help close a budget deficit after acceding to requests from Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines not to cut another $120 million from the city's school budget during the rest of the school year.
The Mayor has managed to achieve more than $2 billion in budget savings, in part by moving to eliminate 15,000 jobs from the city's payroll. But revenue has dropped, partly because of a decline in Wall Street's fortunes and the impact that has on the city's economy.
The city's problems also affect the creditworthiness and market value of $23 billion in existing New York City securities.
Last week, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it was considering downgrading its A- rating on the city's securities if New York did not continue to cut spending.
Compared with other municipalities, New York was forced to sell its bonds yesterday at higher interest rates to attract buyers.
During discussions among dealers on Friday, the 30-year bond the city sold yesterday was expected to sell at a yield of 7.25 percent. In fact, the yield was 7.37 percent, 47 basis points more than the index of other 30-year municipal bonds compiled by the Delphis Hanover Corporation, a bond research company in Southbury, Conn. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The higher yield indicated that there was even greater reluctance to buy the city's bonds than underwriters had anticipated. By comparison, when the city last sold bonds in November, its 30-year bonds offered a yield that was 10 basis points below the comparable index.
Yesterday's rates drew enough demand that the city sold $13 million more in bonds than the $645 million it had first intended.
Serial bonds were priced to yield from 5.50 percent in 1997 to 6.55 percent in 6.80 percent in 2005, 7.10 percent in 2010 and 7.30 percent in 2013 through 2015.
Some analysts were relieved that the damage to New York City was not worse. Arthur D. Spector, managing director in charge of the public finance department of Prudential Securities, which was lead underwriter on the issue, said orders for the new bonds were about $1.3 billion. "That's not bad in the face of rising Treasury yields and concern about Mexico and Japan," he said.
Rating agencies have said they are unhappy with the city's plan to close its $650 million budget gap for the year ending June 30 by refunding maturing bonds with new bonds. That method just shifts the debt to future years, making it harder to restore fiscal stability later.
That transaction, though it cannot be repeated indefinitely, buys the Mayor time to bring the city's spending in line with revenue. It also gives the New York regional economy a chance to improve while avoiding larger cuts to city programs.
Compared with the city's current borrowing costs, which reflect debt incurred when interest rates were higher than they are today, the new bonds will help reduce costs slightly. David Neustadt, a spokesman for the Comptroller's office, said the city's policy toward refundings was that they must not only generate savings in the first five years, but also over the life of the new bonds.
Meanwhile, in the Treasury market yesterday, prices were lower for the fourth consecutive day on thin trading volume. Amid worries about everything from an interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve to a weak dollar, the Treasury sold $17.25 billion of new two-year notes.
The 30-year bond fell 7/32 , to a price of 95 6/32 to yield 7.92 percent, up from 7.90 percent on Monday.
But some analysts saw signs of light at the end of the tunnel.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist for CS First Boston, said: "There are definitely expectations by the market that the Fed is near to accomplishing its objective" of slowing economic growth enough to reduce fears of inflation.
The following are the results of yesterday's two-year note auction:

HEADLINE: Chrysler In Warning On Rates

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Growth in new-car sales could slow this year and show little gain in 1996 if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates another half a percentage point, the Chrysler Corporation's chief economist said today.
"The Fed has already engineered a soft landing," said the economist, W. Van Bussmann. "Now, a little bit can throw you." 
 Auto makers have been voicing worries about rising rates for months, in an effort to discourage the Fed from further action. But, as sales have improved there has been little evidence that they were not just crying wolf.
In his comments today, however, Mr. Bussmann made the most direct plea yet of any auto maker that the Fed go no further. The Fed is expected to raise short-term interest rates next week, its seventh increase in a year.
Mr. Bussmann's comments, in a meeting with reporters at Chrysler's headquarters here, came less than a week after the Ford Motor Company cited higher rates as the reason for temporarily shutting three assembly plants.
Mr. Bussmann repeatedly said the Fed could squeeze too hard as it tried to restrain the economy. "The Fed is right on the cusp of not flattening the curve, but causing an actual downturn," he said.
The stock prices of auto makers have been slipping on investors' fears that car sales are slowing as interest rates rise. Today, in a slightly down market, the shares of the Big Three were actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange, and all of them lost ground. Chrysler fell 62.5 cents, to $46.75; Ford fell 12.5 cents, to $25.75, and shares in the General Motors Corporation slid 75 cents, to $38.75.
But just about everyone involved is guessing and no one really knows if the auto market is weakening. Many Wall Street analysts continue to say that demand for vehicles remains robust and that the stocks are good values.
Although no one would speak for attribution, several analysts played down Mr. Bussmann's comments today as posturing to deter the Fed. Further, Chrysler's sales projections have been far more optimistic than any in Detroit, and the company may simply be laying the groundwork to use the widely anticipated interest rate increase as a cover for lowering its estimates.
Last week, Ford said dealers had begun reducing their orders for new vehicles, not because customers were staying home but because higher interest rates were raising inventory costs. Ford has not released figures but a spokesman called the drop significant.
Mr. Bussmann said the market remained strong, adding that levels of disposable income, household debt and consumer confidence all augured well. But he said another increase of half a point in short-term rates would cause Chrysler to cut its 1995 industry sales estimate by as much as 100,000 units and its 1996 estimate by up to 500,000 cars and trucks.
Chrysler now projects that sales this year of all vehicles, including heavy-duty trucks, will rise 5.2 percent, to 16.2 million, from 15.4 million last year, and will jump another 3.6 percent, to 16.8 million next year.
By contrast, Ford projects industry sales of 15.8 million to 15.9 million this year, and does not offer a 1996 number. G.M., which was the closest to the mark last year, forecasts sales of 15.6 million this year, and further growth next year.
The industry record, set in 1986, is 16.3 million sales of cars and light and heavy trucks.
While some auto analysts have accused Chrysler of playing Pollyanna with its estimates, Mr. Bussman said, "I think they're out of step." One reason he cited today for his conditional optimism on potential sales was an internal Chrysler study that concluded, contrary to many analysts' fears, that vehicles are as affordable now as they have been in recent years. Mr. Bussmann said that last year 46 percent of American households could afford new cars, compared with 54 percent in 1988 and 47 percent in 1993.
Mr. Bussmann based those figures on a Chrysler-sponsored survey that put the average cost of a new car in the first quarter of 1994 at $16,700. The survey was conducted by Consumer Attitude Research, a Birmingham, Mich., consultant.
The new-car prices found in the survey were substantially lower than those in a Commerce Department study that has been widely used inside and outside the industry. The Commerce Department put the average cost of a new car in the first quarter of 1994 at $19,112.
Mr. Bussmann said the Commerce Department figures overstated prices, because they did not factor in rebates and other discounts. Clint McCully, chief of the consumption branch of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which produced the study, acknowledged those deficiencies and said that his office, prompted by Mr. Bussmann, had begun a review of its survey.
But he added that while the survey overstated some costs, it understated others, and that it was too early to predict what revision might be necessary.

HEADLINE: Top Fidelity Executive Quits Fixed-Income Unit

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Thomas J. Steffanci, who joined Fidelity Investments four years ago to head its fixed-income division, has resigned, Fidelity said yesterday.
Mr. Steffanci, who is 50, is leaving Fidelity, the giant mutual fund company based in Boston, to become a principal at Alpha Select Investments Inc., a small broker-dealer in Portsmouth, N.H., that specializes in developing analytical tools for portfolio management. His resignation is effective Feb. 28. 
 "He was not pushed out," a spokeswoman for Fidelity, Marilyn Morrison, said. "He was not fired."
But some former Fidelity employees, traders at other firms and mutual fund company analysts said yesterday that Mr. Steffanci was a victim of the debacle that swept through the bond markets around the world last year. Mr. Steffanci may have not been asked to leave, those people said, but displeasure among Fidelity's top management about the performance of his division left him little choice.
"He felt that his authority as head of the group was being undermined by senior management," said one former Fidelity employee, who asked not to be identified.
Eric Kobren, editor of Fidelity Insight, a newsletter in Wellesley, Mass., that follows the company, said: "The pressure to produce is extraordinary. It's not something they tell you to do. It's in the walls and in the air."
The Wall Street Journal first reported yesterday that Mr. Steffanci was leaving Fidelity. The company later confirmed the report.
Mr. Steffanci, in a statement issued by Fidelity, said, "ASI presented an exciting opportunity to become a principal at a new firm, and at the same time has allowed me to return to my family and to Southern California."
Mr. Steffanci, who came to Fidelity from CMB Investment Counselors in Los Angeles, will work from California for Alpha Select.
A telephone call to Mr. Steffanci's office yesterday seeking further comment was not returned.
In the same statement, Fidelity said the fixed-income group, at least for now, would report directly to J. Gary Burkhead, president and chief executive of the Fidelity Management and Research Company, investment adviser to the Fidelity mutual funds.
Mr. Steffanci was hired to increase the size and improve the performance of Fidelity's bond portfolios through a more aggressive management style. For three years, it worked well.
When he arrived in 1990 Fidelity had about $12 billion in its fixed- income funds. As interest rates fell steadily through the 1990's, Mr. Steffanci and other bond fund managers diversified into riskier, higher-yielding debt instruments, from derivatives to emerging market bonds.
From 1991 to 1993 the performance of Fidelity's fixed-income funds generally was in the top third of those covered by Lipper Analytical Securities. The assets under management had climbed to a peak of $31.1 billion in early 1994.
Then the roof fell in. Like many other fixed-income managers, Mr. Steffanci was caught by surprise when the Federal Reserve began pushing up short-term interest rates last February.
"They were convinced the Fed's first rate increase would not be followed by others," the former Fidelity employee said. "They had tremendous bets that bond yields would not keep going up, and they kept making them."
Compounding the problem, the fallout of higher United States interest rates affected Mexico, hurting many emerging market bond funds. Fidelity was hit harder than most.
Last year, Fidelity's general United States Government bond funds were ranked at the bottom of the 145 such funds covered by Lipper; its global bond funds were ranked 96th of 106. By the end of December the assets in the 47 funds in the fixed- income group had shrunk to $24 billion.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ousted German Executive Sues Nation's Biggest Bank

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Thirteen months after Metallgesellschaft A.G., the giant German metals, futures and oil trader, was bailed out to the tune of more than $2 billion, fresh recriminations are flying in a bitter court battle that pits the company's former chief executive against its current management and Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest financial institution.
In a case that could shed new light on the events that caused Metallgesellschaft's liquidity crisis in December 1993, its former chief executive, Heinz Schimmelbusch, filed a $10 million suit in New York Supreme Court last Friday, contending that Deutsche Bank used the company's troubles to profit financially and needlessly brought it to the point of bankruptcy. 
 Mr. Schimmelbusch, who was dismissed in late 1993 along with most of the senior management, accused his successor at Metallgesellschaft, Rolando Schmitz, and Deutsche Bank of conducting a "systematic campaign of defamation" that left him unable to get a job.
Metallgesellschaft dismissed Mr. Schimmelbusch's assertions as "grotesque," and Deutsche Bank called them part of a "continuing campaign of disinformation." It threatened to countersue Mr. Schimmelbusch after it publishes the results of a study on the company's crisis. The study, prepared in part by Coopers & Lybrand, is expected to be released in a few days.
Metallgesellschaft teetered on the brink of collapse toward the end of 1993, when the spot price of oil fell below the price of the positions in oil futures taken by its New York energy-trading subsidiary, the MG Corporation, causing huge losses.
Deutsche Bank, which owns 11 percent of Metallgesellschaft, stepped in and dismissed Mr. Schimmelbusch and other top managers, putting in Mr. Schmitz as new chief executive. The new management then added to the losses by closing out the subsidiary's oil-futures positions.
Deutsche Bank persuaded a group of creditor banks to come up with $2.2 billion to bail out the company. The bank is now negotiating with the creditor banks for a further injection of cash into Metallgesellschaft.
Deutsche Bank has been criticized for not paying sufficient attention to its investments. Public pressure has also mounted in Germany to review the practice of letting big German banks hold stakes in German industrial concerns.
Last summer, Prof. Merton Miller, an economist at the University of Chicago, said in a report that Deutsche Bank had mishandled the situation, panicked and needlessly liquidated the futures positions, effectively causing the losses.
Mr. Schimmelbusch is the second former executive to file a suit against Metallgesellschaft. Arthur Benson, its former head oil trader, is seeking damages of $1 billion, contending that the new management sabotaged his efforts to stop the losses.
In his suit, Mr. Schimmelbusch contended that his successor, Mr. Schmitz, and Deutsche Bank officials schemed to take advantage of the industrial concern's troubles and make profits for the bank. He accused Mr. Schmitz, who was a member of the Deutsche Bank board, of precipitating the crisis so that he would be given control of Metallgesellschaft.
Deutsche Bank, in a statement, said that once its case comes to trial, "a full airing of the facts in court will finally resolve any questions about culpability and responsibility."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen as Japan Increases Its Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the yen and other leading currencies after a Japanese Government report showed the country's trade surplus with the United States swelled last year.
Japan's merchandise trade surplus with the United States rose 2.8 percent in December from a year earlier, pushing the surplus for all of 1994 to a record $54.96 billion. The trade gap means Japanese exporters have a large amount of dollars to sell for yen when they send revenue from American sales home. 
 The dollar pared its losses against the yen later in the day. Market participants said they remained concerned about Japan's ability to rebuild after last week's deadly earthquake.
"There were conflicting factors that affected the market," said Tom Hoge, corporate currency trader at the Bank of New York. The trade numbers put pressure on the market until "the market focus went back to the earthquake," he said.
After hitting a low of 99.21 yen, the dollar later settled in New York trading at 99.76 yen, down from 99.80 yen on Monday. The dollar slipped to 1.5125 German marks from 1.5145 marks, and to 1.2710 Swiss francs from 1.2705 Swiss francs.
The dollar will be unable to rise much against the yen, analysts said, as long as the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan remains large. Signs of trade tension between the United States and Japan have hurt the dollar since early 1993, when President Clinton and his aides said a strong yen would help balance trade with Japan by making Japanese goods more expensive.
Market participants' worries about whether Congress will approve the Clinton Administration's aid package for Mexico also weighed on the dollar, dealers said.
In other currency trading, the British pound rose to a two-month high against the dollar amid expectations that strong economic growth would prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates next month.
The pound rose to $1.6014 yesterday, its highest level since Nov. 11, before retreating in New York to $1.5975, up from $1.5940 on Monday.
