HEADLINE: Combatting Pataki, Democrats Offer Own Tax Cuts in a Bid for Middle-Class Support

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Seeking to recapture suburban and upstate voters for the Democratic Party, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has proposed reducing state income, sales and property taxes by $2.3 billion a year by 1997.
The proposal today represents the Democratic alternative to Gov. George E. Pataki's four-year plan to reduce state income taxes by $5.6 billion a year. Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has said his plan would offer the greatest benefits to middle- and working-class people. 
 Under Mr. Silver's plan, a family of four earning $40,000 a year would pay $402 less in income tax than during last year. Under Mr. Pataki's plan, the same family would pay $847 less. Mr. Silver said his plan would also reduce sales and property taxes for that same family, but the amount would depend on the local tax rate and how much clothing the family bought each year.
Under both plans, the greatest tax benefits, in terms of percentage reduction in taxes paid, would go to families earning less than $60,000 a year. But Mr. Pataki's plan would provide a much deeper tax cut for wealthier taxpayers, those earning over $100,000, than Mr. Silver's plan.
Mr. Silver said his plan, while containing a smaller income tax cut than Mr. Pataki's, would provide deeper tax relief for the middle class through a combination of tax reductions. He would not only reduce income tax rates for most taxpayers, but also eliminate the state sales tax on clothing and place a cap on local property tax increases that would be tied to the annual inflation rate.
Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said his plan would be more appealing to the middle class because such taxpayers are more concerned about their local property taxes than about state income taxes. He called the sales tax on clothing "a regressive tax that affects the working people of the state most."
Mr. Silver said he thought that the state could not afford Mr. Pataki's plan, which some Democrats have said could cost as much as $6.5 billion a year when phased in. But he did not indicate how he would pay for his proposal, saying the Assembly Democrats would propose their own version of the state budget only after Mr. Pataki releases his budget plan on Feb. 1.
The state is facing a $300 million deficit in the current fiscal year that ends on March 31 and a projected shortfall of $4 billion in the next fiscal year. Next year's budget shortfall would grow by $1 billion if either Mr. Pataki or Mr. Silver's tax cut plans were approved. The current state budget is $34 billion.
The Democrats currently hold a 94-to-56 advantage in the Assembly, but the Republicans, who already control the State Senate, have made clear that their central political goal is to retake the Assembly in 1996. And Mr. Silver's proposal seems particularly aimed at shoring up Democratic lawmakers in suburban and upstate communities where voters overwhelmingly supported Mr. Pataki last year.
For instance, his proposal for a cap on property taxes would probably have the greatest impact in New York City's suburbs, where property taxes have recently risen in some communities by as much as 20 percent in a year. Also, the state's 4 percent sales tax on clothing has been blamed by merchants on Staten Island and in other communities along the New Jersey, Vermont and Pennsylvania borders for declining sales. All three of those states exempt most clothing from their sales taxes.
Mr. Silver said that eliminating the state portion of sales taxes on clothing would generate enough economic activity and new jobs to pay for itself, $600 million a year by 1997. "Right now, people are buying from catalogues or going across the border to New Jersey to buy the same item of clothing they could get in New York," he said.
Even before Mr. Silver's plan, New Yorkers were virtually assured of getting some tax relief, because the final phase of an income tax cut initially passed in 1987 is scheduled to take effect this year. That tax cut has been delayed since 1990 because of the state's fiscal problems, but Mr. Pataki has vowed to veto any efforts to defer it again.
Both Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki have said they want to modify the 1987 tax cut because it would actually raise taxes for about a third of all taxpayers, most of them people earning under $40,000 a year.
Under Mr. Pataki's plan, income tax rates would be reduced across the board, the number of tax brackets would decline from five to two and the number of people paying the top rate would decline. That top rate would fall from 7.78 percent to 5.9 percent and would apply to families earning more than $50,000 a year. The bottom rate would remain at last year's level of 4 percent and would apply to all families earning less than $50,000.
Mr. Silver's plan would alter the brackets so that fewer people paid the top rate, but his top rate would be higher than Mr. Pataki's. He would keep five brackets: a 4 percent rate for families earning under $30,000 a year; 5 percent for up to $37,500 a year; 6 percent for up to $45,000 a year; 7 percent for up to $65,000; and a top rate of 7.75 percent for families earning over $65,000 a year.
Both Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki would have the standard deduction rise from $9,500 to $13,000 for families. Mr. Silver would continue the so-called household credit for families earning under $32,000 a year; Mr. Pataki would replace that credit with a $200-per-dependent credit that could be claimed by any taxpayer.
Robert J. Bellafiore, a spokesman for the Governor, said that because the top tax rate is scheduled to drop to 7.5 percent under the 1987 plan, Mr. Silver's proposal would actually raise taxes slightly for wealthier taxpayers. "Democrats never learn," he said. "The people of New York State voted for small government, real cuts in spending and real cuts in taxes."
The state portion of the sales tax is 4 percent; municipalities and counties are allowed to increase the tax locally. In most places, the total sales tax is now 8 percent; in Nassau and Suffolk counties, it is 8.5 percent, the highest in the state.
Mr. Silver's plan would therefore reduce sales taxes on clothing everywhere in the state to 4.5 percent or lower, bringing levels much closer to -- though still not quite as low as -- taxes in most surrounding states.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE REACTION;
Republican Leaders Express Wariness of President's Conservative Embrace

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Republicans presented President Clinton tonight as a reluctant convert to the cause of a smaller, cheaper government more attuned to the needs of the middle class. Casting themselves as the authentic agents of change, the Republicans also suggested that Mr. Clinton's actions would not match his conservative words.
"While at times tonight some of the President's ideas sounded pretty Republican, the fact remains that he has been opposed to the balanced budget amendment, he proposed even more Government spending and he imposed the biggest tax increase in American history," said Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, on behalf of her party. She referred to the 1993 budget package that raised income tax rates for the upper middle class and the rich, eliminated various deductions and increased the amount of Social Security benefits subject to tax. 
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, countered that the President's speech was "right on the mark" and a clear indication of his commitment to the middle class. "He made it clear that Democrats are going to fight for America's hard-working, middle-class families, and that while we cut the size of our government, we're not going to make our children, our veterans, or our elderly pay the price."
Mr. Gephardt also hailed Mr. Clinton's pledge of support for an increase in the minimum wage, a key issue with core Democratic constituencies. "No member of Congress has a right to stand in the way of this simple matter of economic fairness," Mr. Gephardt said.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, leader of the Democrats in the Senate, also praised the speech and said Mr. Clinton was "connecting with many of the themes that Democrats and Republicans indicated are priorities."
But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said in a cool response that while the State of the Union Message was "always important," the "more important and most powerful message remains the one that the American people delivered in November." He added, "We welcome any support the President offers as Republicans carry out our mandate to rein in government with less spending, less taxes and more freedom."
In fact, Republicans argued that Mr. Clinton was trying to wrap himself in Republican garb. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested that Mr. Clinton "sounds like he's ready to sign the House Republicans' 'Contract with America,' " the campaign manifesto dealing with issues from tax cuts to welfare restructuring.
Still, even before Mr. Clinton's speech was over, the clear Republican message was that talk was cheap. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas and a Presidential hopeful, said the President "always gives a good speech" but added, "It's the President's deeds we're concerned with."
And Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, asserted, "All too often, President Clinton has signaled right then turned left, which only results in disaster."
For much of the day, Congressional Republicans were muted, presenting themselves as respectful of the Presidency, but consumed with their own agenda and convinced that they -- not the Adminstration -- were driving policy in Washington these days. Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, struck a conciliatory note at a news conference before the speech. "I am not going to go tonight and sit there and say, now, which pieces can I punch?" he said.
Other Republican leaders suggested that they believed they could afford to be magnanimous. "He's on a high wire; we're on a pair of skates," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Republican Conference. "We don't have to worry about all these political decisions the White House has to make to keep him on the high wire."
Mr. Boehner added that he believed the dominant political event of the week would be not the State of the Union Message but the consideration and passage of a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, which will reach the floor of the House on Wednesday.
Mr. Boehner also said that on Monday there was a discussion at a Republican leadership meeting about the need to exercise some restraint today.
"We shouldn't make it any more difficult for them than it already is," Mr. Boehner said of the President and the Democrats. This strategy had its uses for the Republicans. Among other things, it gave them a break in the intense partisan struggle over Mr. Gingrich and his book deal that has dominated much of the news in recent days.
With Mrs. Whitman delivering the formal Republican response, Mr. Gingrich was said to be happy to play a nonspeaking role tonight, part of the stately tableau of the State of the Union, sitting behind the President.
There were some sharper Republican responses today. Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, declared, "The American people will not be fooled by a man who changes his opinions and agenda as frequently as the tides."
But Mrs. Whitman's address was largely an exercise in Republican image making, presenting the party as tested and proven on the state level and ready to take its tax-cutting, government-trimming program to Washington.

HEADLINE: Palestinian 'Martyrs': Defiant and So Willing

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GAZA, Jan. 24

 BODY:
If Abdel Rahim Sukar felt any grief today, he wasn't showing it.
His older brother, Anwar Sukar, was a suicide bomber from the Islamic Holy War group who blew himself up on Sunday in a crowd of Israeli soldiers, killing 19 Israelis and wounding more than 60. 
 "I cried a little at first, but later I stopped," Mr. Sukar said, as men and schoolchildren streamed to his family's house to pay their respects. "When I saw the flesh and blood of the Jews, I was happy.
"It was the best martyrdom possible," he said of his brother's death. "I'm proud of him, and I wish I could have been in his place. This made us walk tall."
Under a makeshift awning, somber but dry-eyed men sat in rows as loudspeakers broadcast eulogies in prose and verse. The suicide bomber was praised as a "heroic martyr of Islam" who had gone to paradise while "inflicting misery on the sons of Zion." Pictures of him and of other dead militants covered the walls, and an Islamic Holy War poster boasted, "We will shake Israel to its foundations."
The gathering illustrated how, while the Palestinians are supposed to be ending decades of conflict with Israel, many are not only still gripped by the struggle but enthralled by a cult of death.
The phenomenon seems to be striking deeper roots as Palestinian suicide bombers carry out a rising number of attacks, killing 57 Israelis in the last year. Just as the bombings have shaken Israel, they have also sent currents of admiration through young men here who declare that they, too, are eager to go to paradise killing Jews.
A generation that in other circumstances might have seen athletes or actors as role models seems to idolize the gunmen and suicide bombers of Islamic Holy War and its militant twin, Hamas. Their pictures hang in homes and are carried in wallets and on key chains. Walls are covered with graffiti saluting them and with bold drawings of their attacks. At some demonstrations, young men wear shroud-like sheets, showing their readiness to die.
The cult was on full display recently at a rally in the town of Khan Yunis honoring another local hero, Ayman Radi, who blew himself up last month in Jerusalem, injuring 13 people.
The crowd was entertained by a group of singers in black leather jackets and ties. Known as "The Martyrs," they looked something like teenage idols from the 1950's, but their songs were about a different kind of love.
"Ayman, pure lover of Jerusalem," the lead singer crooned. "You are safe in paradise next to God. The tears of your mother are roses and jasmine. We are Palestinian Muslims fighting the Jewish army."
Like an American boy with a pack of baseball cards, a youngster walked through the crowd showing off an envelope full of pictures of dead members of the Qassam Brigades, the armed wing of Hamas. Giant posters of Mr. Radi and fallen gunmen, one of them showing a uniformed fighter stepping on a pile of skulls, covered the stage.
Such worship of heroic death first spread here in the late 1980's, when the Palestinian uprising began and many young men witnessed daily bloodshed during street clashes with Israeli soldiers. In recent months, support for anti-Israeli attacks was fueled by growing frustration at the lack of change in living conditions under Palestinian self-rule, and by anger at Israel's continued presence in the Gaza Strip and its control of the area's borders.
To many Palestinians, the suicide killers are models of defiance, rebelling against a life of degradation. Their actions serve as an antidote to the constant nursing of grievances that is a habit here after decades of occupation.
"I'm not living like a human being," said a high-school student at the Khan Yunis rally who gave his name as Mohammed. "This is not a dignified life. Either an honorable life or martyrdom."
A man called Abu Rateb, who is married with children, said: "We're dead now. We live when the pieces of our bodies are collected in Tel Aviv."
Such an end is seen here as a beginning, a passage from a transient and grim existence to the pleasures of eternal life -- a world where, according to Islamic belief, martyrs enjoy 72 virgin brides and are next to God with other righteous men.
Hisham Hamad, a suicide bomber from Islamic Holy War who killed three Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip in November, wrote in his will: "The life of this world is just a game and an accumulation of possessions and children. What God has is better for me than all this. I am sad to leave you, but let me meet God. I love paradise more than this world."
Militant leaders reject assertions that people like Mr. Hamad are desperate and have given up on life, preferring to depict them instead as optimists who chose to sacrifice themselves to bring their people a better future.
"We don't call this suicide, which is forbidden in Islam," said Imad Falouji, publisher of a Hamas newspaper. "These are martyrdom operations. We are commanded to wage holy war for the sake of God. Here the attacker is assured success, he avoids arrest, inflicts heavier casualties on the enemy and gains matryrdom."
But to Dr. Mustafa al-Masri, a psychiatrist at Gaza's only community mental health program, such glorification of death is a sign of depression and despair.
"Our own society is somehow committing suicide," he said. "Look at our streets -- we are neglectful of everything. There is a depression in this country. At social gatherings you hear people talking about basic needs, political and economic problems, but there is no mention whatsoever of the future. In the hopelessness and helplessness of this world, there is the bright promise of the next life."
Dr. Iyad Sarraj, the program director, said that in such a state of impotence, a suicide attack can be a powerful attraction to some people. "It is an act of ultimate control," he said. "You control death, you control life, you control your environment and you decide when to die."
The path to a suicide bombing usually passes through membership in a small, highly disciplined and closed band of militants, where the individual loses himself in the group through total identification with its cause, the doctors said.
The bombers have typically been devout single men from poor backgrounds, in their early 20's, who have experienced a personal loss or traumatic humiliation at the hands of the Israelis, doctors add. Though such experiences are common here, they seem to have pushed some youths to extremes.
"There's a process of brainwashing," Dr. Sarraj said. "You live in a semi-hypnotic state. You become so overwhelmed with one idea that you completely isolate yourself from the rest of the world. You have to conform to the group, and within it you find a new identity."
Signs of this are evident in a notebook left behind by Mr. Radi, a 21-year-old policeman who had prayed regularly, fasted often and immersed himself in the Koran, according to his family.
"Life is beautiful," he wrote a month before he died, "but the more beautiful life is to be a martyr. Paradise is a delicious drink. Our enemies love life, but we adore death, so I am sacrificing my soul and everything I own to God."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gunmen from the military wing of Hamas recently paid tribute to Ayman Radi, a Palestinian suicide bomber, at a rally in Khan Yunis in the Gaza Strip. Mr. Radi blew himself up last month in Jerusalem, wounding 13. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Suburban Cowboys Of the Mild, Mild West

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGHLANDS RANCH, Colo., Jan. 23

 BODY:
Booms in the West invariably seem to spawn mythic symbols.
During the cattle drives of the late 1800's, it was the wild shoot-'em-up cowboy, despite the reality of the typical wrangler, who mostly fought boredom on the lonely trails. During the oil bonanza of the 1970's, it was the flamboyant wheeler-dealer in a 10-gallon hat, probably up from Texas, a caricature that grew all the more vivid after the energy bust.
For the last four years, the symbol of boom times in the Rockies, the fastest-growing region in the country in the 1990's, has been the wealthy Californian. Thousands upon thousands of people called equity exiles are said to have sold their houses in Los Angeles for $300,000 to $400,000 or more, and fled that seemingly cursed urban sprawl for the pristine, wild-grass stretches of the mountains, where they can trot horseback across their new ranch ettes, untethered to congested America, except by fax and modem. 
 Like much of Western lore, however, this image is more grandiose than the truth. Californians have been heading to the Rocky Mountain States in droves. But for every Californian-turned-cowboy who has moved to the thistly range or the mountainside, thousands more have settled near cul-de-sacs in suburbs -- trading a monstrous sprawl for a manageable one.
In Colorado, for example, where the population grew at more than twice the national average last year, 80 percent of the newcomers settled in the suburbs.
The biggest gainer has been Highlands Ranch, a 14-year-old unincorporated development 15 miles south of downtown Denver that promotes good schools, safe streets and strict codes on house and lawn upkeep -- life in the Mild, Mild West. With 30,000 residents, up from about 15,000 in 1990, it is the fastest-growing planned community in the nation. The population is projected to reach 100,000 within 20 years.
While some Californians surely are coming to the Rockies with a bundle in home equity, and can retire early to Telluride, Colo., or Jackson, Wyo., a far greater number -- the workaday technicians and corporate middle managers -- are scrambling to meet mortgages and save for their children's college tuition.
"People look at me and say, 'Oh, you must be rich,' " said Gregg Myers, a 32-year-old shop foreman who bought a $100,000 house here in 1992 after moving from Santa Ana, Calif., with his wife, Diane, 32, now a part-time worker at a recreation center, and their three children, ages 10, 6 and 4.
"But I don't even consider myself to be middle-income, more like lower-middle," said Mr. Myers, a journeyman carpenter with three years of college. "And I just hired two new guys at work from California who are worse off than me."
The newcomers here tend to be technologically sophisticated, an attractive labor force that has motivated companies including Specialty Health Care Services and Chef America, a maker of snack foods, to move to the area from Southern California.
"In the old economy, the talent went where the companies were," said Phillip Burgess, the president of the Center for the New West, a policy and research organization in Denver. "But in the new economy, the companies go where the talent is."
The boom is gobbling up Colorado pasture land for home sites here in Douglas County, the second-fastest growing county in the country after Flagler County in northeast Florida. Residents here voted in November to use tax money to buy and preserve some of what is left of the pastoral charm that attracted so many newcomers in the first place.
"There used to be cows a block from my house," said Micki Clark, the leader of the Open Lands Coalition in Douglas County, "and now I look out the window and see a sea of rooftops."
But many people here look out their windows and see a portrait of the American Dream: rows of handsome two-story houses, meticulously maintained lawns and safe sidewalks filled with children at play.
"Maybe it's a case of growing up watching too much television -- you know, Andy of Mayberry," Mr. Myers said. "But I think people are yearning to belong in a community."
Planned communities, which are developed from a blueprint -- a place for stores here; a place for churches there -- are more common in the West than in the East or Midwest, perhaps because people here tend to be from somewhere else, but still want a hometown ambiance, even if it is a bit contrived.
The commuting time from Highlands Ranch to jobs downtown or at the Denver Tech Center, ranging from 20 minutes to nearly an hour, is often a snap compared with the highway crawl of Southern California. And the neighborhoods here do not have the deserted feel of a bedroom community during the day, because many women stay home with young children.
"Yuppies have a couple kids, and then they want a place that fits their idea of a small town in the Midwest," said Ms. Clark, who is also a mystery writer. "But I grew up in one of those Midwestern small towns, and believe me, it doesn't look like Highlands Ranch. For one thing, in a small town, half the people are poor."
Indeed, as Gregg and Diane Myers recalled, a cousin visiting from Nebraska shrieked in mock horror at the too-perfect picture of the suburban American Dream.
Mr. Myers chuckled as he described the cousin's expression of disbelief at the nearly identical look of the houses, the cars, even the people. "She said, 'This is not real -- I mean, everybody here has exactly 2.5 kids.' "
Rising to the defense of his community, Mr. Myers said that while there was a degree of conformity, there was also more openness to newcomers. When his daughter, Heather, started school as a new second grader in Bear Canyon Elementary School here, she was not excluded by the kind of cliques that often rule the social order in places where the same families have lived for generations.
"We're all newcomers here," he said, "so there's a kind of bond you feel with your neighbors."
The drawback, of course, is that people move out almost as routinely as they move in, because a big share of them are corporate employees who may be transferred every few years. And the experience of seeing friends move away, again and again, can become painful.
Trish Elledge, a 40-year-old civil mediator who has lived in Highlands Ranch since 1992 with her husband, Tom Swinehart, a lawyer, and their two young children, Zachary and Ashley, has formed strong friendships with a handful of women here, only to see them leave, one after another. In the last year, her five closest friends have moved away.
"As a person who has come here to make this a home, I just don't know if I can take this anymore," Ms. Elledge said. "I don't know if I'm going to invest a lot of time and feeling in friendships, because they're just going to go away."

HEADLINE: 'Theme Park' Atmosphere Is Part of Proposal for Yankee Stadium

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
New York City, in its latest proposal to the Yankees, has offered to create what one official called a "theme park" atmosphere at Yankee Stadium with stores and restaurants around the complex and with new roads leading to new parking garages at the ball park, officials familiar with the plan said yesterday.
The proposal was presented on Monday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, who had objected to an earlier plan because he said it failed to address traffic and parking problems that burden the stadium. 
 Although the finer points of the new design have not been drawn, estimates of the project's cost are as high as $600 million, making it the most extensive and expensive strategy for keeping the Yankees in the South Bronx that has yet to be presented. That figure, although far from a definite price, is more than twice the $250 million talked about less than a year ago as the cost of overhauling the stadium and the surrounding neighborhood.
According to officials who attended a meeting on Monday morning at Gracie Mansion, Mr. Steinbrenner indicated that the proposal was more to his liking. "He's taking it seriously and studying the details," Mr. Steinbrenner's spokesman, Howard Rubenstein, said yesterday.
The plan was redrawn to meet the Yankees' desire to have a stadium along the lines of Camden Yards in Baltimore, a distinctive and self-contained entertainment park that is easy for fans to reach and has minimal intrusions from the outside world.
The object, said David Sussman, the Yankees' general counsel, "is to try to get it as close to the state-of-the-art facilities that are being built in other cities."
With Mr. Steinbrenner's veiled and not-so-veiled threats over the years to move his team from its legendary home in the South Bronx to the New Jersey Meadowlands when the team's lease expires in 2002, city and state officials have tried to answer each of his irritations with a new salve. Concerns over safety brought a troop of police officers to patrol around the stadium during games and at Mr. Steinbrenner's request, officials searched for alternative sites for a new stadium. In August, the officials hired the design firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum to draw plans for a renovated Yankee Stadium.
City and state officials say the latest version of the plan envisions constructing new exits and entrances off the northbound lanes of the Major Deegan Expressway leading directly into new parking garages that would be next to the stadium in what is now a park. A bridge from Harlem River Drive would also lead directly to the garages.
In front of the stadium, River Avenue would be widened and spruced up with new lighting and improved facades for existing stores. At the ground level around the stadium, shops and restaurants would be built, allowing the stadium to project an entertainment atmosphere to fans as soon as they were on the grounds. One city official speaking on condition of anonymity compared the desired effect to a "theme park."
Improvements to the stadium itself, already discussed publicly, include about 100 luxury boxes and a new outer wall for the stadium that would copy the original facade of Yankee Stadium. Inside the stadium, concessions and shops would be upgraded in a new concourse area.
The most striking differences between the December plan, which drew objections from Mr. Steinbrenner, and the proposal presented this week are the roads and parking garages that would allow fans to drive from the suburbs directly to the stadium without sitting in traffic on the streets of the South Bronx. Yankee officials have said fans had complained both about the difficulty of driving to the stadium and their fears of crime in the neighborhood.
Also, the new garages, which officials said were tentatively planned for part of Macombs Dam Park, would be next to the stadium, allowing fans to go from their cars directly to the ball park. The new garages would increase stadium parking to 10,000 spaces from about 6,500.
In the new design, said one city official who attended the meeting on Monday, the stadium is "really a self-contained area." But that could raise concerns among some residents and officials of the Bronx who had hoped that a renovated Yankee Stadium would be the centerpiece for neighborhood redevelopment.
Frank Mahoney, an economic aide to Gov. George E. Pataki, acknowledged "a lot of sensitivities" about creating a ball park cut off from the surrounding neighborhood. He said any park areas taken up by new garages would be made up for with new parks in the neighborhood.
A city official, speaking on condition of anonymity, rejected the notion that the plan sought to insulate the stadium from the area and pledged that neighborhood groups would continue to be consulted. Instead, he said, the design is in line with the newest and most successful ball parks around the nation. "They want to be nice to the neighborhood," the official said of the team, "but they also want to give the fans what they want. They want to create an entertainment atmosphere."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON, WITH BOW TO G.O.P., REAFFIRMS HIS THEMES OF '92 AND ASKS NEW COOPERATION

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
President Clinton tonight sought to build a rationale for the second half of his term, at once defending his record and embracing many ideas backed by the new Republican Congressional majority, but amending them to suit the brand of centrist Democrats who elected him.
In a State of the Union Message that was by turns conciliatory and studded with pointed delineations of difference, Mr. Clinton pledged his cooperation in shrinking the Government, cutting taxes, overhauling welfare and cracking down on illegal immigration. But he repeatedly veered away from endorsing specific Republican proposals for dealing with those issues, instead presenting his own ideas as sensible, humane alternatives to more extreme courses of action. 
 Humbled by last fall's sweeping Republican electoral victories, Mr. Clinton offered only a few new programs in a speech that lasted 81 minutes, the longest a President has ever taken to deliver his State of the Union address. Rather, he turned to the themes of his 1992 campaign in resurrecting the notion of a "new covenant" of shared responsibility between government and citizens. [Transcript, page A18.]
Interrupted 96 times by mostly bipartisan applause, Mr. Clinton cast himself as the champion of working Americans by repeating his calls for tax breaks for the middle class and a revision of lobbying and campaign finance laws, priorities that faded in the first half of his term.
"I am frank to say that I have made my mistakes, and I have learned again the importance of humility in all human endeavor," said Mr. Clinton, who began his speech with congratulations to the newly elected majority and to the new Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich of Georgia. "But I am also proud to say tonight that our country is stronger than it was two years ago."
"We cannot ask Americans to be better citizens if we are not better servants," the President added. He argued that government should be smaller in size but not in spirit, called on the nation to participate in political discourse and vowed to oppose any efforts to roll back his victories on gun control.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who delivered the official Republican Party response from Trenton, took pointed note of the changed political landscape, saying with a chuckle that "some of the President's ideas sounded pretty Republican" and proclaiming that her party meant business.
"On Election Day, you gave us your trust," she said in her own talk to the nation. "We accept your mandate. President Clinton, you must accept it as well."
Just a year ago, Mr. Clinton stood at the same rostrum in the House chamber for an exuberant recital of his first-year record and a bold defense of his sweeping health care proposal. In 1993, he unveiled his economic plan with similar fanfare, to rousing cheers in a chamber where the majority Democrats had waited a dozen years to see one of their own in the White House.
Tonight, as the first Democratic President to face a joint session of a Republican Congress since Harry S. Truman almost half a century ago, Mr. Clinton cast his oratorical net wide but set his sights much lower.
He joked that he now knew how the Republicans must have felt on his own victory in 1992, and said with a nod to Walt Whitman that in both elections, "we did not hear America singing; we heard America shouting." Now, he said, "both of us, Republican and Democrats alike, must say, 'We hear you.' "
The President said that for the last two years he had tried to do his part.
"Our businesses are more productive, and here we have worked to bring the deficit down," he said. But he added, "The rising tide is not lifting all boats," and too many people are "working harder and harder for less and less."
He also called on Congress to clean its own house by passing comprehensive restrictions on lobbying, curbs that it stopped short of passing at the close of the last session and that the Republicans have blocked this year.
"There doesn't have to be a law for everything," Mr. Clinton said, asking members simply to stop taking gifts from lobbyists immediately.
"Just stop," he said.
"We don't have to wait for legislation to pass," the President declared, "to send a strong signal to the American people that things are really changing."
On topic after topic tonight, Mr. Clinton sought the political middle ground, extending an olive branch to Republicans but begging to differ as well. He said balancing the Federal budget was a worthy goal but challenged them to show how they could do so without raising taxes or endangering Social Security benefits.
He recalled his own longstanding commitment to overhauling welfare so that it became only a temporary transition to a life of work, but he warned against punishing children who need help most.
"I want to work with you, with all of you, to pass welfare reform," he said. "But our goal must be to liberate people and lift them up from dependence to independence, from welfare to work, from mere childbearing to responsible parenting. Our goal should not be to punish them because they happen to be poor."
In others ways, Mr. Clinton split the differences.
He endorsed raising the minimum wage to bolster the earning power of the poorest workers, but without saying by how much. His advisers said he preferred an increase of at least 75 cents, to $5 an hour; Some Democrats favor increases twice that size, while some Republicans oppose any minimum at all.
The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said the President had opted for a general endorsement of an increase in the minimum wage as a step toward negotiated compromise, rather than a specific suggestion that might be dismissed out of hand. "This is obviously one that he could basically posture on and send something up that goes nowhere," Mr. Panetta said. "But his hope is that the Congress will recognize the need to do something with the minimum wage."
Among the steps the President endorsed on the immigration issue was adoption of a national computer system to keep track of citizens and aliens authorized to work in this country. That would allow employers to check the immigration status of job applicants. Such a system was recommended by a commission headed by former Representative Barbara Jordan, Democrat of Texas.
The proposal has drawn criticism from ethnic and immigrant groups, but the White House hopes it will stand as a contrast to more conservative proposals like California's Proposition 187, which, now stayed by the courts, would deny public services and benefits to undocumented aliens.
Mr. Clinton also called for a new public-private campaign against teen-age pregnancy, in which, Administration officials said, Hillary Rodham Clinton will probably play a role.
In the most starkly partisan moment of the evening, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that several members of the last Congress who voted for the ban on 19 types of assault weapons had lost their seats as a result and that "some of you who are here because they voted for it are under enormous pressure to repeal it."
Without using the word "veto," he said sternly: "A lot of people laid down their seats in Congress so that police officers and kids wouldn't have to lay down their lives under a hail of assault weapon attack, and I will not let that be repealed. I will not let it be repealed."
That was too much for the Republicans who had applauded many of his other proposals; they remained seated and silent while most Democrats rose in applause.
As is his practice, the President had worried over and polished the speech until virtually the last minute, sending fourth and fifth drafts back to his principal domestic and foreign policy speech writers, Donald Baer and Robert O. Boorstin, in late afternoon. He spent most of Sunday and today in his study in the White House, fussing particularly with the opening and closing sections.
Aides said he had prepared for the address by reading old speeches, including the declaration of his candidacy for the White House in October 1991, when he promised to restore the American dream for "the forgotten middle class."
In fact, all the atmospherics of the President's address were intended to stress his support for ordinary working Americans and for partnership between government and citizenry.
Mrs. Clinton, who in past years was flanked in the House gallery by captains of finance, labor and big business whose support the Administration wanted for its economic and health care programs, sat tonight among members of Americorps, her husband's national service program, in which students receive scholarships and stipends in exchange for community work. She also paid homage to a military that has often regarded her husband warily, sharing the row with Cpl. Gregory Depestre, a Brooklyn-born marine who was brought up in Haiti and served as a peacekeeper there last year, and with the family of Jack Lucas, a marine from Mississippi who served on Iwo Jima and was the youngest man in this century to be awarded the Medal of Honor.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: NEWS ANALYSIS;
A Deflated Presidency

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
A year ago, the polls showed President Clinton in good political shape, buoyed by an improving economy. So he waved a pen at Congress and the nation. Give me a health care plan that covers everyone in America, he demanded; if you resort instead to half-measures, I will veto them.
In the end, of course, Congress gave Mr. Clinton no health care legislation at all, and the electorate gave him a swift punch in the nose, in the shape of sweeping Republican triumphs at the state, local and national levels. 
The State of the Union Message that the President delivered tonight was notably short on demands for action and long on appeals for comity, a demonstration of just how much he has been weakened in the last 12 months.
Then, he was on the offensive, promising change as broad as it was bold. He attacked those, like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, now the majority leader, who supported incremental change in health care. Now, he is on the defensive, proposing nothing remotely resembling the revolution that he and Hillary Rodham Clinton once espoused; instead, he called for gradualism a la Dole.
"Last year, we bit off more than we could chew," Mr. Clinton said in a moment of clear-eyed candor. "This year, let's work together, step by step, to get something done."
There were no explicit veto threats, although the President insisted he would not accept any tax cut that threatened to send the deficit soaring.
So much has the political climate changed that Mr. Clinton was obliged to defend the very idea of activist government. With politics and politicians under a cloud, with Washington a symbol of incompetence, with term limits and privatization in vogue, he sought to rekindle the faith in government that burned in the days of Franklin Delano Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy.
Politicians and public servants, he said, are "keepers of a sacred trust," not the self-aggrandizing windbags depicted by cartoonists and hosts of talk radio.
Many of those who sat before him, new to Washington and to public life, won election by attacking the records and even the motives of the Democrats who dominated the House of Representatives for four decades and the Senate for most of that time. To their way of thinking, upholding the public trust involves minimizing government, rather than putting it back onto a pedestal.
For those who hoped that the President would move to the middle in response to the election returns, the speech was a success. But for those who hoped for signs of a new political acuity and a new personal discipline in the White House, it must have constituted a disappointment -- almost an hour and a half long and a reminder of Mr. Clinton's seemingly endless nominating speech at the 1988 Democratic convention.
As Mr. Clinton spoke, his parlous situation was evident to the public. According to a new CBS News poll, 78 percent of the electorate expects Congress to have more influence over governmental affairs than he -- but many of the same respondents are dissatisfied with the way Congress is doing its job.
The months ahead will center on a battle for the symbolic high ground: are the Republicans the agents of change and the Democrats the defenders of the bureaucratic status quo? Or are the Democrats the agents of change and the Republicans the reactionary champions of trickle-down economics? After almost three months in which he played a largely passive role, the President joined that battle tonight, and its outcome will determine his electoral fate.
Mr. Clinton sought to go the Republicans one better, advocating "leaner, not meaner" government, calling for campaign-spending reform, attacking lobbyists and insisting that government should work for average Americans. Not only did he congratulate the Republicans on their victories, he even used some of their party's favorite phrases.
Still, the President spoke up strongly for several Democratic programs that the new Republican majority may try to eliminate, including gun control, the service corps and Medicare. He could hardly have done less without risking the alienation of his political base.
Echoing, with a bow to the politics of the 1990's, the words that Theodore C. Sorensen wrote for President Kennedy's inaugural, Mr. Clinton made this appeal to the nation: "We must not ask government to do what we should do for ourselves. We should rely on government as a partner to help us do more for ourselves and for each other."
With the country already in open rebellion against tax levels that are lower than those of many Western democracies, the President will be hard pressed to find the revenue for even the modest kinds of initiatives that he seemed to be calling for. Some legislation, like the increased minimum wage that Mr. Clinton is seeking, would cost the Federal Government relatively little.
He may overcome the most formidable obstacles that the Republicans had hoped to place in the path of Big Government. Early ratification of a balanced-budget amendment by the requisite three-quarters, or 38, of the states, seems improbable.
In addition, the amendment appears unlikely to contain the Republican-proposed language, part of the "Contract With America," that would have required a three-fifths "super majority" to increase taxes. But it will probably still require more than a simple majority for tax increases. The likely formula is an absolute majority -- that is, a majority of the total membership, rather than those present and voting -- and that in itself is something the old Congress would never even have considered adopting.
Keenly aware of the President's skills as a communicator, to say nothing of the tactical advantages enjoyed by any occupant of the White House, the Republicans made collegial noises all day. Speaker Newt Gingrich said he planned to concentrate on the ideas he and the President had in common, not the points in the speech that he most strongly disagreed with.
But Republican arguments have already been embraced by the voters, and that has shifted the agenda.
Without last November's election returns -- and especially the failure of the Democrats to take a single seat in the House or the Senate away from the Republicans -- it seems improbable that Mr. Clinton would have returned to the idea of a middle-class tax cut, which he promised during the 1992 campaign, then abandoned in his campaign for deficit reduction beginning early in 1993.
Without those returns, would he have increased military spending? Without them, would Democrats like the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, be talking earnestly about a flat tax that differs only in emphasis from the one long espoused by right-wing Republicans?
And without Gov. Pete Wilson's overwhelming re-election in California, fueled in large measure by resentment against illegal aliens, would Mr. Clinton have chosen to place so much emphasis on that issue this evening?

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Help Persuade Financial Company to Stay

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In exchange for a pledge to keep more than 4,000 jobs in New York City for at least 20 years, the CS First Boston Corporation, a major financial company, will receive breaks on city taxes worth more than $50 million, city officials announced yesterday.
With its decision to stay in New York, CS First Boston plans to consolidate operations in a 1930's limestone building on East 24th Street owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. CS First Boston has 3,700 employees in four sites in the city. 
 For a year, executives said, CS First Boston has been considering alternatives to the high costs of doing business in New York City. One plan included moving operations that did not require a presence in Manhattan to New Jersey. In comenting on the decison to stay in New York, David C. Mulford of CS First Boston refused to say that the company would have left if the tax breaks had not come through. But Mr. Mulford added that the outcome of the search "probably would have been different."
The tax incentives will include a $27.3 million exemption on sales taxes for the purchase of equipment, fixtures and furniture and up to $17.7 million in tax credits that will be tied to job growth for 20 years. CS First Boston said it expected to add up to 5,550 jobs in that period.
Clay B. Lifflander, president of the Ecconomic Development Corporation and the Industrial Development Agency, which negotiated the deal, calculated that the city could recover the tax breaks in less than three months based on the estimated annual $115 million in tax revenues the company generates for the city.
Starting next year CS First Boston will move to 16 floors at 11 Madison Avenue, a prominent building that occupies the entire block bounded by Madison Avenue, Park Avenue South and 24th and 25th Streets.
The neighborhood, which real-estate brokers have called Midtown South, has emerged in recent years as a thriving office, retail and restaurant district, as service companies appreciate the architectural richness of older buildings.
The CS First Boston lease with Met Life, which continues to own and operate the building, is for 20 years. The companies would not give details.
In the move CS First Boston will give up 700,000 square feet in locations that include 509 Madison Avenue and 599 Lexington Avenue. With the transaction CS First Boston plans to increase its trading-floor operation threefold.
The North Building of the former Met Life headquarters was designed in 1932 by Harvey Wiley Corbett and D. Everett Waid. It is known for the vaulted entrances at each of its four corners.

HEADLINE: Albertis S. Harrison Jr., 88, Dies; Led Virginia as Segregation Fell

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Albertis S. Harrison Jr., who served as State Attorney General and Governor as Virginia made its last stand against racial integration, died on Monday at his home in Lawrenceville, Va. He was 88.
The cause was a heart attack, the Governor's office in Richmond said. 
 Mr. Harrison's time in office came as the state turned from a rural to an industrialized society, and he contributed significantly to that development with road construction and other economic programs. He also left a legacy of a greatly improved educational system.
Allied with the conservative organization headed by Harry F. Byrd Sr., Mr. Harrison took a more cautious position on desegregation, avoiding its doctrine of "massive resistance."
By virtue of his office, Mr. Harrison was involved in confrontations with the Federal Government as Attorney General from 1958 to 1962 and then as Governor until 1966. These included Virginia's legal battles to continue a poll tax and close public schools in Prince Edward County, which ended up leaving black pupils without a formal education for four years.
The county supervisors ordered the public schools padlocked to avoid integrating them. White pupils then attended a private academy with their tuitions subsidized by the state. Most of the 1,700 black children had no schools to go to while the issue was decided in Federal court.
Prince Edward County was the only school district in the country to resort to such extreme measures. In 1963, schools were ordered to open, and when the Supreme Court agreed in 1964, the supervisors gave in rather than risk prison. By then, the Governor was advising Virginians to heed the law unless they were willing to face prosecution, and civil-rights leaders were generally pleased with the level of compliance in the state.
After he left the Governor's Mansion, Mr. Harrison became a judge of the state's Supreme Court of Appeals, retiring in 1981. In 1968 he headed a commission that streamlined the State Constitution, and one clause the panel purged from the 1923 version was a commandment that "white and colored children shall not be taught in the same school."
Albertis Sydney Harrison Jr. was born into Southern aristocracy in Alberta, Va., in Brunswick County. His home sat on a tract deeded to an ancestor, Henry Harrison, by King George II in 1732. His family tree boasted one Benjamin Harrison, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, along with William Henry Harrison and a second Benjamin Harrison, the 9th and 23d Presidents, respectively.
A graduate of the University of Virginia Law School, Mr. Harrison easily made his way into Virginia's political elite as he served as Brunswick County prosecutor before being elected Attorney General.
As Governor he persuaded the Legislature to increase educational financing for new schools and laboratories, to raise teachers' pay and to provide an enhanced teacher scholarship program, among other things. He pressed for state-supported colleges, technical schools and improved vocational training.
He helped to modernize state banking laws to attract investment and accelerated highway construction.
His survivors include his wife of 54 years, Lacey Barkley Harrison, and a daughter, Antoinette H. Jamison of Richmond.

HEADLINE: Beyond Wool And Down

BYLINE: By NEAL KARLEN 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
THE gaggle of grumpy old ice fishermen, looking mummified in untold layers of drab wool dating from the Eisenhower Administration, began making fun of my blindingly bright, state-of-the-art winter sports clothes as soon as I stepped onto the 14-inch-thick ice covering Lake Minnetonka just outside this city. The sunfish weren't biting that moment in subzero January, so my father's angling buddies took a timeout from their fishing holes to critique my outfit. I was testing the latest synthetic winter wear in the direst of circumstances -- in Minnesota, also known as the nation's icebox.
So there I was, looking like an extra from "Plan 9 From Outer Space," as they began their fashion review by laughing at my lightweight, waterproof three-fingered lobster gloves by Pearl Izumi ($40; all prices given here may vary from store to store). The gloves, designed with a synthetic called Entrant to provide the protection of mittens with the flexibility of gloves, locked my hands in a permanent Mr. Spock greeting. I was a nightmare in neon, not a properly dressed fisherman, my father's friends suggested, and I hid from sight the gloves' stitched-in terry-cloth nose wipe. 
 Nor were they moved when I showed off my "expedition weight" long underwear, made of Capilene by Patagonia (the top costs $60; the bottom, $45) and my Tempest parka by Montbell that weighs only 19 ounces and has water-repellent zippers and a double-front storm flap ($290).
They weren't even impressed by my Gore-Tex waterproof oversocks by Rocky ($40), one of the biggest footwear trends in the winter sports industry. "Ice fishing isn't a sport," scoffed Abie (the Mavin) Schwartz, 82, considered by many to be the dean of Minnesota winter angling. "Ice fishing is a punishment!"
Hearing the guffaws, I consoled myself with the knowledge that at least I was toasty and mobile in my lightweight get-up. At one time, only elite athletes and would-be Edmund Hillarys dressed in the new fabrics. But now these synthetic fibers can be found everywhere, in everything from lounge wear to panty hose. Even the eco-minded can rest easily, as polyester fleece fabrics like Polartec are being made from recycled plastic soft-drink bottles.
But they don't come cheap. Prices of winter skiing outfits can easily top $1,000, though if sales are any indication, buyers haven't seemed to mind. Polyester-based fabrics (which most of these synthetics are) now make up about 95 percent of the winter sportswear market, and sales have grown 20-fold in the last 15 years, according to several Midwestern outfitters. Sales of Polartec have grown 25 percent a year for the last two years, reaching $200 million in 1994, said Jeff Bowman, the merchandising manager at Malden Mills, the maker of Polartec.
Synthetics like Capilene and Polartec have been around for a while, but now there are a half-dozen weights of Capilene and more than 100 types of Polartec.
One almost needs a Ph.D. in chemistry to keep track of the ever-multiplying polyglot of fabrics, coatings and insulations, from polypropylene to Thermolite. They keep one warm when soaked (by either the elements or one's own sweat), by "wicking," or pulling moisture away from the skin while still insulating the body.
While a garment cannot be both 100 percent waterproof and breathable, most synthetics make it possible to enjoy all winter sports in weather ranging from a sleet storm to a blizzard. Manufacturers design clothes to match sports, from stop-and-go activities like rock climbing to continuous exertions like biking.
With so many choices, I decided to test a few of the latest clothes to see whether they were any match for the Minnesota winter.
I began my field test with a control study; I went cross-country skiing at Theodore Wirth Park on a windy 14-degree day wearing a cotton flannel union suit, cotton sweatpants and hooded sweatshirt and a woolen sweater. Within minutes I was sweating like a sumo wrestler; unwicked, within a half-hour I was frozen.
The next day, I ventured out in the synthetics. For a stop-and-go activity I chose ice skating at the Lake of the Isles rink. Though the temperature was a modest 27 degrees, my bare head and neck quickly felt numb. I put on a tasseled wool hat from Dale of Norway ($34) with a new polyester fabric called Gore-Wind Stopper that warmed the ears while avoiding scratchiness. A pullover Patagonia neck gaiter ($15) made of Synchilla, a fabric of recycled plastic, covered the throat.
Though polypropylene is often criticized for retaining body odors and burning up in the dryer, Early Winter's polypropylene midweight Prolite 5000 long underwear (pants $30, top $32) proved to be a good choice on the ice. Sweat wicked off quickly, keeping me dry as I skated hard, yet there was still enough weight to keep me warm while standing around watching the hockey players at the adjacent rink.
It had been snowing on and off all day, so for midlayer warmth I wore a North Face heavy fleece Denali insulating jacket ($160), a garment known to keep its warmth even when wet. My last layer was a Trekker shell by Marmot ($200), a totally windproof and waterproof Gore-Tex item that proved extremely useful when the flakes began to fall and blow again. Outdoor Research's two-fingered Gore-Tex glove ($65) kept the hands warm but not overheated.
Two days later, a midnight bicycle ride around Lake Calhoun at 10 degrees provided a good test for high-aerobic wear. I chose a light, highly breathable Aero/D top by Lowe Alpine ($80), with Microfiber, Lycra and reflective stripes. For bottoms, I wore Lowe's Powerstretch tights ($54), made of Polartec. I added a pair of lightweight Bugaboo pants by Columbia ($73). Two pairs of Ultimax hiking socks from Wigwam, made of wool blended with a variety of synthetics ($8.50 a pair), were enough to keep my feet comfortable.
The ultimate test, however, came the following afternoon, when I had the date with the ice fishermen. After they finished ridiculing my ensemble, they retreated to their fishing holes. They may not have been interested in my Gore-Tex oversocks by Rocky, but I had to know the truth about them.
I'd been assured that this oversock was so remarkably waterproof that I could stand in a bathtub full of water and not get my feet wet. Huddled inside an ice shack, I slipped off a Sorel boot that had been worn for 20 years by my late grandfather. The manufacturer's claim had better be right, I thought, as I stuck my foot into the water churning up through the hole in the ice, or I will never dance again. I listened for my scream, but it never came. The sock worked.
But does it matter? I went back outside with the tough old guys in their woolens. With what my new clothes cost, they estimated they could buy a new fish shack, a portable ice auger and enough minnows to last until the next millennium.
A few hours later, the most painful results were in. Abie Schwartz had caught 13 healthy sunfish, my father 7. Lying on the ice was my sole catch, a puny sunny, lighter even than my lobster gloves.
"Warm enough?" Mr. Schwartz said, laughing.
 
Modern Bear Grease
 Here are some of the most common synthetic fabrics and fibers found in winter sportswear:
 
CAPILENE -- A polyester fiber from the Patagonia company. The inner core repels moisture from the skin by pushing it to the outside of the fabric, a process known as wicking. The outer surface attracts this moisture, spreading it so that it dries quickly. Used in underwear, linings and socks.
 
ENTRANT -- An elastic coating of waterproof polyurethane that breathes through microscopic holes; the more Entrant painted on, the more waterproof and less breathable a garment. Licensed to several manufacturers for winter outerwear like gloves and for rain jackets.
 
FIELDSENSOR -- A synthetic yarn made by Toray, it wicks moisture away from the body. Most often found in first-layer garments and liners.
 
GORE-TEX -- A thin insulation laminated to a variety of outer fabrics, it provides both waterproofing and a way for sweat to escape. Used in outerwear, rainwear and active wear.
 
HOLLOFIL -- Du Pont's Dacron polyester hollow-fiber insulation that is often found in economy-brand apparel and sleeping bags. Hollofil II, its premium brand, reduces fiber-to-fiber friction that usually causes insulation to flatten.
 
MICROFIBER -- A tightly woven, very fine fiber that both breathes and offers protection against wind and cold. Among the brands available are Super Microft and Versatech. Used for ski outerwear, active wear and sleeping bags.
 
MICROLOFT -- This three-year-old Du Pont synthetic fiber, made of filaments thinner than human hair, works as an insulator. Highly water-resistant, Microloft is found most often in sleeping bags, gloves and outerwear.
 
POLARTEC -- The name for several fabrics made of polyester fleece by Malden Mills for many manufacturers. Polartec comes in several weights, including a polyester pile, a double-sided microfiber, a Lycra stretch version and a version made of recycled plastic. Used as an inner-layer fabric.
 
POLYPROPYLENE -- A strong, paraffin-based fiber (derived from petroleum) with wicking capabilities. Used in underlayers.
 
PRIMALOFT -- Interwoven polyester microfibers made by Albany International as a lightweight, heat-retaining alternative to down. Most often found in outerwear and sleeping bags.
 
SYNCHILLA -- Patagonia's brand name for Polartec fleeces.
 
THERMOLITE -- Dacron polyester by Du Pont that provides lightweight insulation for gloves, footwear and outerwear.
 
THINSULATE -- A light polyester blend by 3M of 35 percent polyester and 65 percent olefin that is spun into a thin insulation. Found in hats, gloves, outerwear and ski wear. NEAL KARLEN

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Helping Mexico Help Us

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
There is an old saying among bankers that when someone owes you $1,000 that's his problem, but when someone owes you $1 million that's your problem. That bit of wisdom is good to remember as you listen to the demagogues opining that Mexico's debt crisis is Mexico's problem. Mexico owes us $100 billion. That's our problem.
That is frustrating for a lot of people to acknowledge. And they are right to feel frustrated. The $40 billion rescue package that President Clinton has proposed for Mexico is a crazy cross between highway robbery and self-help -- a joint venture by Pancho Villa and Robin Hood. But on balance we have to go through with this bailout, because in today's intertwined global economy we can't save ourselves without saving Mexico, and we can't bail out the little guy without bailing out the billionaires as well. 
 There was a telling story in The Washington Post last week quoting "Congressional sources" as saying they saw "little political gain in approving . . . a plan to bail out Mexico's economy when members, particularly Republicans, believe they were elected to deal with problems closer to home."
I've got news for those Congressional sources: In today's intertwined global market, Mexico is "home." There is far more American industrial investment and mutual-fund investment in Mexico today than there is in our own state of New Mexico. And the economic collapse of Mexico would damage the U.S., Latin America and Canada far more than the bankruptcy of New Mexico. To some extent, "home" is where the wallet is, and right now, if you check your pension fund or mutual fund, you will find that your wallet is spread from Toronto to Tierra del Fuego.
In the 1982 Mexican debt crisis, Mexico's foreign debt was held by a few big American banks. That crisis was resolved by 12 bankers sitting in a dining room with a few Mexican officials and rescheduling Mexico's loans. Since then, though, global finance has been democratized. In today's intertwined global economy, the big holders of Mexican debt are not 12 banks but millions of individual Americans. If the Mexicans wanted to renegotiate with them, they would have to use Shea Stadium, not the 21 Club.
But where things get even more complicated is that those millions of investors fall into two categories. In one category are speculators who borrowed billions of dollars at low interest rates in the U.S. several years ago and invested them in Mexican bonds paying 11 percent. They made a killing, and now that things have gone sour, they are frantically dialing 911 for Uncle Sam. The problem is that the other investors in Mexico were your pension fund and mutual fund managers, investing your money in search of higher returns. And if Mexico goes Chapter 11, not only will millions of Americans lose directly on their Mexican investments, but indirectly from lost trade, jobs and destabilized financial markets. That is why Patrick Buchanan is a fraud when he postures as protector of the "little guy" and argues against the Mexican bailout. The truly populist thing to do is to protect the people's money, and, like it or not, Robin Hood and Billionaire Bob have a joint peso account.
The Mexico crisis also demonstrates how we have gone from a world dominated by superpowers to a world dominated by supermarkets. It is the Tokyo, New York, London and Frankfurt bond markets that will have as much say as governments in determining Mexico's fate. If Stalin were around to describe this new power structure he would ask: "How many mutual funds does the Pope have?"
In this crisis, the supermarkets told the Mexicans that they would only reinvest their money in Mexican bonds if Mexico restored investor confidence by pledging some Mexican oil revenues as collateral. The Mexicans, and the Clinton team, initially resisted this appeal, telling the markets that oil was Mexico's national patrimony, its crown jewels, and any Mexican government that hocked them could be toppled. They appealed to the markets to think of the big picture. Weren't U.S. Government guarantees enough?
The markets said they were interested in the bottom line, not the big picture, and they preferred jewels. Mexico is now going to have to put some oil on the table. In the first major test case between the superpowers and supermarkets, score this one for the supermarkets.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The State of the President

 BODY:
A State of the Union address is normally about policies and promises. But at the center of President Clinton's speech last night lay a political question: Can this President, after a decent first year and a disastrous second, regain his standing with the American people and his own party? What lent drama to this speech was not what it said about the future of America but what it would show about the future of one man.
Bill Clinton is plainly aware how hard it is going to be to regain his footing. He cannot simply offer himself as a watered-down Newt Gingrich. But as he acknowledged in his first sentences, he cannot ignore the forces, including dissatisfaction with government in general and with his vacillating leadership in particular, that swept the Republicans to power. 
 The speech was extraordinarily long, but the President met the test of showing renewed engagement and the makings of an agenda that could compete with the Republicans'. He offered himself as a centrist alternative between the old-style Democrats and the new-style Republicans who have promised in their "Contract With America" to take a sword to social programs.
To that end, he pledged to reduce tax burdens on the middle class and "end welfare as we know it" -- and to listen to Republicans who seek the same ends. But he stressed he would not accept fiscally irresponsible tax-cut proposals that would "explode" the deficit, put economic recovery at risk or diminish Medicare. On welfare, he said he agreed that the goal must be to move people from "dependence to independence," but that he would not countenance legislation designed to punish people "because they happen to be poor."
He offered only a few new programs -- an unspecified increase in the minimum wage, an increased effort to identify illegal immigrants, a campaign against teen-age pregnancy, an incremental approach to health-care reform.
In a sense, this was a speech haunted by the President's own mistakes and missed opportunities. He challenged the Republicans to follow the spirit of campaign finance and lobbying legislation killed by the Democratic leadership of the last Congress. His "new covenant" language, taken directly from his acceptance speech at the 1992 Democratic Convention, had more to do with the way he successfully campaigned in 1992 than the way he has ineffectively governed in the White House.
Mr. Clinton had some winning ideas, but the test for him is making those words live through his behavior. He can regain his authority and regain a chance with the voters only by putting prolonged attention and specific legislation behind a few key items such as welfare reform, ethics legislation, further and responsible "reinvention of government" and what he called his "step-by-step" health-care reform. Mr. Clinton needs to show that he can winnow a defined menu of priorities from the intellectual buffet of his speeches.
As has so often been the case with this President, it is not his intelligence or grasp of policies that is in doubt, but his follow-through. This speech met the minimum requirement of giving him a toehold from which he can begin a march over the ground he has lost.

HEADLINE: Quake Recovery Doesn't Equal a Boon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Through Kobe's Rubble, an Economic Rainbow" (news article, Jan. 18) cites experts claiming that the earthquake in Japan could give a boost to an economy struggling to recover from a long recession. The economist Henry Hazlitt has passed on, but I imagine that he would have said, There you go again using the "broken window fallacy." 
 The expert is at least right in the first conclusion that there will be more business for the construction industry. But this new employment and industry arises at the opportunity cost of lost business elsewhere, which will not occur because money is redirected toward reconstruction.
As Hazlitt put it in "Economics in One Lesson," the experts "see only what is immediately visible to the eye" while neglecting invisible costs to the rest of the economy. If we accept this fallacy, we should also expect to see bombing campaigns included in the next fiscal stimulus package.
 
THOMAS L. MARTIN
Associate Prof. of Economics
University of Central Florida
Orlando, Fla., Jan. 19, 1995
