HEADLINE: Hedge Funds Still 'Steaming Ahead'

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The wisdom on Wall Street in recent months has been that the private investment partnerships known as hedge funds have lost their luster.
In fact, many shined in 1994. Despite the well-publicized losses of Wall Street's most famous hedge funds last year, many others did well. And many new funds are popping up, attracting both new talent and investors. 
 Names like Michael Steinhardt, Julian Robertson, Leon Cooperman and Mark Strome all suffered heavy losses in 1994 -- after they racked up gains as high as 143 percent in 1993. A few especially hard-hit funds even went out of business last year.
But the success of other, relatively small hedge funds has helped maintain interest in the sector even as some bruised investors have withdrawn their money. Kynikos Associates, a New York-based manager that specializes in profiting on falling stock prices, was up 44.5 percent in 1994. Investors in Bricoleur Partners of San Diego, which invests in the stocks of smaller-capitalized companies, had profits of 34 percent. And Long Term Capital Management, the bond arbitrage hedge fund started by John Meriwether, a former Salomon Brothers vice chairman, was up 20 percent.
And although the tremendous rate of growth fed by the high returns of 1993 has slowed, new funds are still being introduced, stealing some of Wall Street's top talent away from prestigious investment banks like Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers.
There may even be some hedge fund legacies in the making. Wayne Cooperman, the son of Leon Cooperman, has formed a fund with Ricky Sandler, whose father, Harvey, is also a longtime hedge fund manager. David Steinhardt, the son of Michael Steinhardt, is also starting a fund.
"The ship is steaming ahead just as fast, and it is taking on more passengers," said George P. Van, chairman of International Advisory Group Inc., a consultant based in Nashville that tracks more than 600 funds and that estimates that a total of $ 120 billion is currently committed to about 3,000 funds. "Hedge funds are here for the foreseeable future. I don't think there has been any respite whatsoever."
The reason is that hedge funds offer both wealthy investors and managers the three things that they covet most: secrecy, a relatively unregulated environment and the prospect of immense profits.
Because they are private limited partnerships with 99 or fewer investors, the funds largely escape regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and are not required to make their results public. Indeed, the funds are barred from advertising their services.
This exclusivity means that the funds cater only to wealthy clients. For example, the funds tracked by Mr. Van require a minimum investment that ranges from $ 50,000 to $ 25 million.
The large majority of managers, including the biggest names, also have the bulk of their personal wealth tied up in the funds, which can be an extra measure of comfort for many outside investors.
In exchange for the promise of above-average returns, hedge fund managers receive between 1 percent and 2 percent of their funds as a management fee, as well as anywhere from 20 percent to 25 percent of the profits that they generate. Investors may be obligated to commit their money for as short as one month or as long as three years.
Hedge fund redemptions last year were more modest than many thought they would be, averaging around 15 percent for 200 funds tracked by E. Lee Hennessee, who runs a hedge fund advisory group at the Republic New York Securities Corporation.
And most of the withdrawals came from the larger funds. Budge Collins, a San Diego fund manager who divides $ 1 billion for investors among a variety of smaller hedge funds, said that his fund has expanded so far this year.
In addition, when it comes to hedge funds, bigger is not necessarily better. Many managers believe that the amount of money that poured into some of the bigger funds at the beginning of 1994 made them too unwieldy, limiting the kind of investments they could make. Meanwhile, the smaller funds performed better.
"We don't want to get big," said John H. Debs, one of the managers of NV Partners, an $ 80 million fund based in Palo Alto, Calif. "We're the old-fashioned hedge fund, the one those guys used to be before they got famous," he added, referring to Michael Steinhardt and George Soros.
Some managers even decided to shrink themselves by returning money to investors. The Tudor Investment Corporation closed two of its eight funds, reducing its assets under management to $ 1 billion from $ 1.7 billion. Paul Tudor Jones 2d, the company's chairman, said in a statement last fall that it would be easier for him to resume producing double-digit returns with a smaller asset base.
The term hedge fund, which dates back to the early 1960's, originated because the managers, in addition to buying stocks, could sell them short, meaning that they could bet that certain stocks would decline in value.
Proponents of such hedging strategies say that their odds of beating the market are increased because the probability of a hedge fund portfolio's declining in value is much less than that of a portfolio that can profit only if stock prices rise.
In the five-year period that ended on Sept. 30, hedge funds delivered a 12.4 percent average net annual return to their investors, compared with a 9.2 percent average annual return by the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, according to Mr. Van of International Advisory Group. Also, the average risk of loss for the funds was 17.3 percent, compared with 21.5 percent for the S.& P. 500, he calculated.
"If you look at the hedge fund universe, you get better performance at half the risk," said Mr. Collins, the San Diego fund manager.
Most mutual funds do not sell stocks short and do not borrow heavily to make larger bets because of complex tax and regulatory requirements. Therefore, the average investor cannot participate in a hedged-fund style portfolio.
Throughout most of their careers, the successful hedge fund managers like Mr. Steinhardt made their reputations as highly skilled stock pickers. It was only in the early 1990's, as the gap widened between short- and long-term interest rates, that they became known as "macro" managers because they borrowed heavily to make large bets on broad economic trends, like the direction of interest rates.
As their success gained more attention, money poured into dozens of new hedge funds specializing in a wide variety of investment strategies from emerging markets to takeover stocks. But the biggest new funds formed in 1992 and 1993 were Soros and Steinhardt wannabes.
By borrowing at short-term rates and investing in long-term bonds, these hedge funds made millions in 1992 and 1993 simply by holding their portfolios. And when bond prices continued to rise, they made even more money.
"In 1993, you couldn't make a mistake," said one newly minted macro manager who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It was impossible to lose money."
But when the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates last February, the party came to an abrupt halt.
At one point, Michael Steinhardt saw his $ 4.5 billion under management shrink by one-third in a matter of weeks. David J. Askin, who ran a supposedly "market neutral" fund, saw his $ 600 million under management implode when the bottom fell out of the mortgage-backed securities market. He subsequently filed for bankruptcy.
Major losses present a serious challenge to hedge funds because most managers have a so-called high-water mark, or an agreement that they will forgo their cut of the trading profits until their investors' losses are made good. That means that a fund that loses, say, 50 percent of its value must rebound 100 percent before the manager gets his investors back to even and once again can begin taking his 20 or 25 percent cut of the profits.
Mr. Steinhardt, whose partnership never had a provision for a high- water mark, considered closing his fund late last year. In the end, he decided to remain in business, but told his investors that he would not forgo his cut of the profits.
The decision shocked many investors and managers who thought it unfair that Mr. Steinhardt would be able to make 20 percent, or $ 300 million, through recouping the $ 1.5 billion needed to bring his investors back to where they started at the beginning of 1994.
But as it turned out only about 15 percent of the money in Mr. Steinhardt's funds was withdrawn from the fund at the end of last year, according to one of his investors who requested anonymity.

HEADLINE: Bailing Out France's Biggest Bank

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
During the 1980's, the advertising slogan at Credit Lyonnais was "The Power to Say Yes." These days, as the big state-owned bank claws out from under a huge pile of bad loans and ill-fated investments, the French taxpayers who are footing most of the cleanup bill can only wish that it had more frequently said no.
With auditors just now getting a handle on the scale of the problem at the bank, which is the world's largest outside Japan, Credit Lyonnais' chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, is deep in negotiation with the French Government on the terms of yet another bailout package. The Government last year put up $4.4 billion in fresh capital, loan guarantees and other aid to keep Credit Lyonnais afloat, and industry executives said the tally this time would be at least as much again. 
 Because the French Government is clearly unwilling to allow the bank, the nation's largest financial institution, to fail, Credit Lyonnais seems assured of survival. But its once grandiose vision of serving as the financial backbone of France and Western Europe has been largely shattered, replaced by a sober focus on its core businesses: retail and commercial banking in Europe, and commercial banking, capital markets and asset management in Europe, the United States and Asia.
"Part of the difficulty at Credit Lyonnais was that too much importance was given to size," said Olivier Perrain, a spokesman for the bank. "The focus on size is being abandoned. But we are confident we can still be a player on a worldwide level."
Mr. Peyrelevade is selling chunks of the company's far-flung holdings, hoping to raise $3.8 billion, and shutting down other operations and cutting employment by 10 percent to reduce costs.
In the last year he has sold $1.7 billion worth of assets, including a 19 percent stake in Adidas A.G., the athletic shoe company, and a 65 percent stake in the FNAC entertainment retailing chain. On the block now are the bank's 125 movie theaters in Europe and its bank subsidiary in Brazil.
Mr. Peyrelevade, who was brought in to clean up the mess a year and a half ago, hopes that with financial help from the Government, asset sales and cost-cutting, Credit Lyonnais will be able to wipe clean the legacy of its mistakes.
Those mistakes included big bets on real estate projects that later collapsed and direct investments in steelmakers, airlines and other companies that foundered during the recession. Altus Finance, the bank's investment arm, ran up big losses in 1993 and in the first half of last year.
Then there were the bank's loans to a veritable rogue's gallery. Big borrowers included Robert Maxwell, whose fraud-ridden media empire did not long survive him, and Bruce McNall, the former owner of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team, who recently pleaded guilty to defrauding Credit Lyonnais and six other banks of more than $236 million.
The single biggest lending disaster may have been the bank's involvement with Giancarlo Parretti, a little-known Italian investor who persuaded the bank to finance his acquisition of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film studio. Mr. Parretti and his partners, whose backgrounds and financial strength were hazy to say the least, then defaulted, leaving Credit Lyonnais -- and by extension the French Government -- the unlikely owners of a Hollywood icon.
The bank now has $2.5 billion on the line with MGM, including loans and additional funds pumped into the studio in an attempt to whip it into shape. Under American banking law, Credit Lyonnais will have to sell MGM by 1997, and it is still unclear how much of its money the bank will be able to recover through a sale.
Credit Lyonnais backed some winners as well. It was a partner with the New York investor Leon Black's Apollo Partners in acquiring, at firesale prices, the junk bond portfolio of the failed Executive Life Insurance Company of California. The bank's investment paid off handsomely when prices of the high-risk bonds bounced back strongly.
Good news, however, has been rare for Mr. Peyrelevade, an elite Socialist technocrat who previously ran Union des Assurances de Paris, France's largest insurer. Hoping to move quickly to end the bank's woes decisively, Mr. Peyrelevade has antagonized the conservative Government by pressing for more and more financial help at a time when France is trying to pare back the bill for supporting ailing state-owned companies.
If the bank's woes have been traumatic within the institution, they have also helped speed a retreat by France from its "dirigiste" tradition -- state control of key industries, augmented by interlocking shareholdings and financial support among big companies -- which has long been accepted on both the left and the right here. The strategy was urged on Credit Lyonnais by the Socialist Government during the last decade.
As a result, the bank today holds big stakes in money-losing French industrial giants like Aerospatiale, the aerospace company, and Usinor Sacilor, a steel company.
The ultimate goal of the Credit Lyonnais cleanup is to privatize the institution, in which the French Government has a 76 percent voting stake. Public investors hold an additional 22 percent of the equity in the form of nonvoting shares. Other French financial institutions, such as Banque Nationale de Paris, have already been privatized, and are none too pleased at seeing Credit Lyonnais, their biggest rival, being underpinned with taxpayer money.
Moreover, with banking long since having become a global business, neither Credit Lyonnais nor any other French bank can afford to prop up other national industries at the cost of profits and international competitiveness.
"We are still in our hearts reasonably dirigiste," said one senior banker in Paris. "But we are also living in a market economy with international forces, and there are conflicts there. We are now in the process of solving those conflicts and inevitably they are being solved in the direction of more freedom."
A report this month by a group of French political and business leaders concluded that the experience of Credit Lyonnais "will not have been useless if it allows the French banking system to emerge stronger, better established and above all more useful in the long and complex transition from interventionism towards the market."
For now, though, executives and auditors are poring over the books, seeking to determine exactly how much the bank stands to lose from its bad loans and failed investments. Estimates of the total bill range as high as 50 billion French francs, or about $9.4 billion. But having believed last year that they had a handle on the size of the problem, only to find they had badly underestimated the cost, executives said no one could say for sure what the final figure would be.
The goal of the bank and the Government is to have a thorough audit completed and the bailout package completed by late March or early April. They then plan to close the bank's books for 1994 with the financial assistance package in place, allowing the bank to begin its accounting for 1995 with its old problems wiped out. Mr. Peyrelevade said last month that he believed Credit Lyonnais could be profitable this year.
Bank executives said the underlying business was in reasonably good shape. With 2,100 branches in France and 900 in the rest of Europe, Credit Lyonnais is confident of remaining a dominant force in retail banking as the industry consolidates and the European single market puts an increased premium on economies of scale. Analysts said, however, that Mr. Peyrelevade still had a way to go in bringing costs down to the levels of the bank's best competitors.
With the gradual end of the recession around the world, analysts said Credit Lyonnais should also see some growth in its corporate lending and capital markets activities.
"The bank could have fared much worse," said Sasha Serafimovski, who tracks Credit Lyonnais for Merrill Lynch. "Peyrelevade has done a good job to hold it all together."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Securities Given Lift By Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities rose yesterday for the first time in five sessions following a surprisingly successful Treasury auction.
Also helping bond prices were hints in the Senate testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that the Fed might be nearing the end of its yearlong round of interest-rate increases. 
 The Treasury auctioned $11 billion of five-year notes yesterday, which produced a yield of 7.79 percent. Traders said the auction, which drew good retail interest, went smoothly, with the yield slightly lower than the 7.80 percent the market had anticipated. It was also the lowest yield for a five-year auction in three months, since an October yield of 7.55 percent.
Earlier, the bond market picked up strength on what traders termed a short-covering rally as prices began to rise after Mr. Greenspan, in testimony to the Senate Finance Committee, declined to say whether the Fed would raise rates at its policy-making meeting next week.
While Mr. Greenspan gave the strong impression that the Fed had not yet finished raising short-term rates, some bond traders said they interpreted his remarks as hedging against an increase next week.
Short-covering occurs when traders buy back borrowed securities that they had previous sold short in the hopes profiting from lower prices. But if prices begin to rise instead of fall, though, the short sellers need to cover their short positions by buying back the securities to limit their losses.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the market turned stronger in the afternoon on the results of the auction. He said traders spent the morning hoping the five-year notes would cheapen so they could get them at a decent price.
"The problem with the Greenspan testimony was that it was interpreted in a number of ways by any number of people," Mr. Burtnick said. "The biggest interpretation was a softening-the-tightening stance, even that the Fed may not tighten. This brought buyers back to cover shorts."
Still, Mr. Burtnick said, "not everyone is thinking that the Fed is done tightening." He added, "In the meantime we may see an upside to the market but the market is prepared to punish those who get too complacent."
The 30-year bond rose 20/32 , to a price of 9526/32 to yield 7.87 percent, down from 7.92 percent on Tuesday. Shorter maturities also rallied on the chance that there will not be rate increases.
The only new piece of economic data released yesterday -- that existing-home sales for December rose 1.8 percent, to 3.89 million units annually -- was said to have had no impact on the market.
"A lot of things fell into place for the market today," Mr. Burtnick said. He notes that the 30-year bond, which has traded within 2 1/4 points in December and January, will maintain that range over the short-term.
"While the market may be strong today," Mr. Burtnick concluded, "I don't think it is a sign that things have suddenly gotten well. This was just a matter of shorts being squeezed out of the market."
The municipal market, like that for Treasuries, gained on the day. The Bond Buyer's index of 40 issues remained unchanged, with the average yield at 6.81 percent.
Concerning the New York City bonds that were priced on Tuesday, Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said his firm saw big retail demand for the shorter maturities. The insured bonds went well, while investors picked up the long maturities.
But the sale by the city of some middle maturities was soft, causing it to extend the selling period.
Mr. Roden said that the New York City issue was not given enough publicity and that investors were reluctant to buy with the probability of a rate increase by the Fed so strong.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Remark Raises Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks followed other financial markets higher yesterday, after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, made some ambiguous remarks about inflation that seemed to indicate to many traders that any increase in interest rates next week might be the last for a while.
But some analysts said a rally in the bond market, which helped lift stock prices, might have been caused in large part by technical factors. 
 And whatever happened yesterday, the wild card remains the Government's report on fourth-quarter growth in the gross domestic product, set for release tomorrow morning. The market is looking for stronger growth than the third quarter's rate of 4 percent, perhaps as much as 4.5 percent.
"But I don't think a number north of 4.5 is in the market right now," said Todd Clark, managing director of Mabon Securities, meaning prices reflect that level of growth but not higher. "I can see the bond market giving back everything it gained and stocks following behind if we see a big number."
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.75 points, closing at 3,871.45. The broader Standard & Poor's rose 1.58 points, to 467.44.
But the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.22 points, to 760.98, pulled down in part by a rout in shares of the Compaq Computer Corporation and other high-technology companies.
After rising as much as 28 points on the Dow Jones industrial average, stock prices fell in the last half-hour of trading, where computer-guided trades appeared to sharply increase trading volume.
Meanwhile, bond prices rose and the yield on the benchmark Treasury 30-year bond fell for the first time in five sessions, to 7.87 percent from 7.92 percent. And dollar gained against the German mark, rising to 1.5167 marks from 1.5125 marks.
In his testimony before the Senate Finance Committee yesterday, Mr. Greenspan reiterated a familiar position, but various traders interpreted his remarks differently.
Since 1994's inflation rate of 2.7 percent matched that of 1993, Mr. Greenspan said, "it would appear that we have gotten close to achieving effective price stability, though we are not there yet."
Mr. Greenspan added that the prospects of extending the recent trend of what he called low and hopefully declining inflation were "fundamentally good, but there are reasons for some concern, at least with respect to the nearer term."
Many traders interpreted those remarks to mean that the Fed would raise interest rates at the two-day meeting of its policy-making committee, which begins on Tuesday. Higher interest rates make the dollar more valuable and dollar-denominated assets like stocks and bonds more attractive.
But other traders noted that when asked if interest rates would rise soon, Mr. Greenspan replied, "I don't know."
It is possible that when bond prices did not fall with Mr. Greenspan's remarks, what is known as a "short covering rally" hit the bond market and spilled into stocks.
Short-sellers sell borrowed shares or bonds or dollars in the expectation that their price will fall. When prices do not fall as expected, the market is squeezed into a short-covering rally.
Compaq, the nation's largest computer maker, shocked Wall Street by reporting fourth-quarter earnings of 90 cents a share, instead of the expected 94 cents a share. Compaq also said that first-quarter profit would only equal last year's earnings of 80 cents a share.
Compaq, the most active stock of the day at 19.7 million shares, fell 5, to 37 3/8. A variety of computer stocks fell, too. Intel fell 5/8, to 70 7/8; Storage Technology fell 3 5/8, to 22 3/8, and Apple Computer dropped 41/64 , to 4063/64 .
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal with 342.3 million shares changing hands, about 5 percent above this year's daily average of 325 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.71 point, to 254.41, with advancing stocks outnumbering decliners by 1,201 to 956. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.12 points, to 438.52.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Compaq's Net Up but Stock Falls

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Shares in the Compaq Computer Corporation plummeted yesterday in unusually heavy trading after the company released fourth-quarter earnings that fell a few pennies short of Wall Street analysts' expectations. The slide by Compaq, the present leader in the personal computer marketplace, dragged many other technology stocks down as well.
Compaq shares closed yesterday at $37.375, down 12 percent, or $5, on volume of nearly 20 million shares -- far and away the most actively traded issue on the Big Board. Hewlett-Packard was down $2.375, to $103; Dell Computer off $1.875, to $42.75, and I.B.M. down $1.625, to $72.375. 
 Stocks of other computer makers also fell, as did those of chip makers like Intel, Texas Instruments, Advanced Micro Devices and Motorola.
Other earnings reports in recent days, including those of I.B.M. and Apple Computer, have led to declines in share prices even when earnings exceed Wall Street's expectations. That has left analysts to puzzle over what is going on, with some pointing to profit taking by mutual fund managers and other investors and others saying that investors are jittery about the economy.
Some analysts said yesterday that investors had overreacted to Compaq's earnings news and noted that the entire shortfall could be attributed to the devaluation of the Mexican peso. They also said that investors had been primed for several months to expect a slowdown in personal computer sales growth and seized on the Compaq release as evidence that the day of reckoning had come.
"I think there was an overreaction," said Andrew Neff, an analyst with Bear, Stearns. "My perception is that Compaq is in the best position it's been in for years," he added, noting that the company should benefit in 1995 from new desktop machines using Intel's Pentium microprocessor, a refreshed notebook product line, consumer purchases and the recovery of the European economy.
Mike Murphy, publisher of the California Technology Stock Letter, a newsletter in Half Moon Bay, Calif., commented: "Wall Street was clearly looking for a problem. I don't believe there is a slowdown, but now we have to wait until the March numbers to see."
For the fourth quarter, Compaq reported earnings of $243 million, or 90 cents a share, up 61 percent from $151 million, or 58 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Fourth-quarter sales rose 48 percent, to $3.25 billion, from the $2.2 billion reported in the fourth quarter of 1993. Analysts had expected earnings of 94 cents a share, on average.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Darryl White, Compaq's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said, "I know that we delivered excellent financial results, and in many cases exceeded our own financial models." He said current Securities and Exchange Commission regulations constrained the company's ability to manage expectations more closely.
Compaq cautioned analysts to expect relatively flat earnings in the first quarter of 1995 relative to the corresponding period last year, but Mr. White said this was entirely a result of a strategy to lower profit margins in order to gain market share. Compaq has brought gross profit margins down to 23 to 24 percent; a year ago they were 27 percent. "It's a much more competitive range for our market-share strategy," he said.
By one objective measure, the Compaq strategy has succeeded. According to Dataquest, a research company in San Jose, Calif., Compaq vaulted to the top in worldwide sales of personal computers in 1994, overtaking I.B.M. Compaq climbed to 10.3 percent in market share, from 8.1 percent, while I.B.M. dropped to 8.5 percent from 10.8 percent and Apple dropped to 8.5 percent from 9.4 percent.
David Wu, an analyst with S. G. Warburg, said the slippage of Compaq and the other technology stocks had more to do with market psychology than financial performance, but he nonetheless lowered his ratings on technology stocks across the board. "The market psychology has now turned on technology stocks from very positive to negative," he said. "Stocks with positive surprises don't go up; those with negative surprises get clobbered."
One exception to the technology slide yesterday was the Lotus Development Corporation, the software company, whose shares climbed despite a decline in earnings. The company reported that half its revenues now come from communications and work group software, which is less susceptible to competition from the industry giant, the Microsoft Corporation.

HEADLINE: Orange County Tax Advice

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Jan. 25

 BODY:
Orange County, Calif., long a bastion of support for lower taxes and smaller government, was advised by its banking consultants to consider raising taxes to make it through its financial crisis.
The county's newly appointed underwriters, Goldman, Sachs & Company and A. G. Edwards & Sons, said in written presentations to county officials obtained by Reuters that higher taxes should be considered to boost the county's revenues. 
 Many county officials, however, said they still opposed raising taxes.
 "I support absolutely no new taxes to pay for the debacle," said the County Supervisor, Jim Silva. Aides to two other county supervisors said their bosses would also oppose new taxes.
On Dec. 6 Orange County filed for bankruptcy protection, after sustaining a loss now estimated at $1.7 billion in its investment pool.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Broad Rise on Hint Of Increase in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher against other leading currencies yesterday, strengthening after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, gave the impression that interest rates may rise again.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Finance Committee that the robust economy was growing too rapidly, which could ignite inflation.
"There are increasing reports that firms are considering marking up the prices of final goods to offset" rising raw material and production costs, Mr. Greenspan said. "But any such deterioration should be contained if the Federal Reserve remains vigilant." 
 The comments added to the expectations among currency traders that the Fed's Open Market Committee would increase interest rates at its meeting next Tuesday. Higher interest rates increase the dollar's value by making dollar-denominated securities more attractive to international investors.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.5167 German marks, up from 1.5125 late Tuesday. It also rose to 1.2765 Swiss francs from 1.2710 francs. And the British pound fell to $1.5915 from $1.5975.
But the dollar slipped against the Japanese yen, falling in New York to 99.52 yen from 99.76 yen.
Most currency traders have been expecting the Fed to raise rates for a seventh time since February -- probably by half a percentage point -- to cool the economy and keep inflation low.
"There's no reason to think the Fed won't be on target with the rate hike," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank.
A report on home sales yesterday also showed evidence of economic strength. Sales of previously owned homes rose last year to the second-highest level ever, a real estate trade group said.
The dollar also benefited from "safe haven" buying earlier in the day, stemming from erroneous reports of the downing of a missile in Russia. A Russian news agency reported that a missile originating in Northern Europe had been shot down. It turned out that a Norwegian space rocket had been launched without incident.
But because Russia's military is embroiled in a war in Chechnya, the report set traders scrambling to buy dollars as a safe haven currency. Many had been short on dollars, so the spree pushed up the dollar more than a pfennig against the market in interday trading.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BOEING CO. (BA,N)

 BODY:
The Boeing Company reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits fell 48 percent, citing declining deliveries of its jet airliners, rising costs and lower investment income.
The company earned $157 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with earnings of $304 million, or 89 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue dipped 10 percent, to $5.12 billion from $5.66 billion. 
 Boeing delivered 270 commercial jets in 1994, compared with 330 in 1993.
Frank Shrontz, the company's chairman, said the improving performance of the airline industry must be sustained before substantial new orders for aircraft could be expected. But Mr. Shrontz said Boeing was making strategic investments in new products and businesses and manufacturing processes in anticipation of a return to long-term demand for commercial jets.
Boeing's military and space sales rose 8 percent, mostly because of the company's participation in the United States space station program.
For the year, Boeing earned $856 million, or $2.51 a share, compared with $1.24 billion, or $3.66 a share, in 1993. Revenue fell to $21.92 billion from $25.44 billion. (AP)

HEADLINE: Resales Up For Homes; '95 Dip Seen

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Despite rising mortgage rates, sales of previously owned homes rose to the second-highest level ever last year, but a real estate trade group predicted today that housing activity would slow significantly this year.
The existing-home sales rose 1.8 percent in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.89 million from 3.82 million a month earlier, the National Association of Realtors said. 
 For the full year, sales totaled 3.97 million, up 4.3 percent from 1993's 3.80 million and second only to 3.98 million in 1978. All regions posted gains.
"Those are the best numbers we're going to see for a while," predicted John A. Tuccillo, the organization's chief economist.
The number of down payments on existing homes began dropping substantially last October, suggesting slower sales starting this quarter, the real estate group said. Contract closings often trail initial deposits by several months.
"My guess is that we'll see in February and March that something has gone haywire in the real estate industry," the association's president, Edmund G. Woods, said.
Mortgage rates rose last year from less than 7 percent in February to more than 9 percent last month. An increase from 7 percent to 9 percent would add $209 to the monthly payment on a $150,000 mortgage.
The Federal Reserve, which raised short-term interest rates six times last year to keep inflation in check, is to meet next week to consider whether to raise them again. Most analysts expect further rate increases then.
Prices of existing homes remained relatively stable last year. The median price was $107,700 last month, up from $107,400 a year earlier. The median is the midpoint, meaning that half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
Regionally, the West posted the biggest sales gain last year, a 7.1 percent advance, including a 2.4 percent gain in December. The median price in December was $143,600, down from $143,700 a year earlier.
The Northeast had a 4.2 percent gain in 1994, although sales in December were unchanged from November. The median price at the end of the year was $134,700, down from $137,000 in December 1993.
In the South, sales rose 3.7 percent last year, including a 9 percent jump in December. The median price was $92,400, down from $95,700 a year earlier.
Sales were up 3.1 percent in the Midwest, although they fell 6.4 percent in December. The December median price was $88,100, up from $85,700 at the end of 1993.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply As a 14-Month Rally Ebbs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after their failure to reach new highs prompted speculative profit taking.
Analysts said the volatile price action might indicate the market was at or near the end of a 14-month rally. 
 On other commodity markets, precious metals also weakened and lumber futures rose sharply. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities slipped 0.5 point, to 235.11
Copper for January delivery plunged 4.15 cents, to $1.403 a pound. The more active March contract sagged 3.35 cents, to $1.3835 a pound.
March deliveries matched Tuesday's intraday high of $1.427 early in the day, but failed to reach $1.429, the contract high set Jan. 19.
"There was just general disappointment we weren't able to better yesterday's highs, let alone recent contract highs," said a Paine Webber commodities analyst, Bernard Savaiko. "Profit taking set in then, and professional traders really started to lean on the market."
"I think the market's just about had it at these levels," said Peter Cardillo, research director at Westfalia Investments. "It's beginning to show signs of weakness from a technical standpoint and even some fundamentals."
Among the negative fundamentals are slackening demand from China and perceptions that United States consumption will decline this year as higher interest rates slow economic growth.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said yesterday that the economy was growing too rapidly, a possible signal the Fed would soon raise interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan's comments prompted selling of precious metals, which tend to do best during periods of inflation and rapid economic expansion.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, February gold fell 90 cents, to $380.90 a troy ounce; March silver sank 4.7 cents, to 79 cents a troy ounce.
In lumber trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, spruce two-by-fours for March delivery leaped $10, the maximum daily advance permitted by the exchange, to $319.50 for 1,000 board feet.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
In the cloud of a natural disaster, some see a silver lining.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE Kobe earthquake destroyed 10,000 buildings, closed one of Japan's major harbors and broke the back of the transportation system. Look on the bright side, though. The monumental effort of reconstruction will help to power the sluggish Japanese economy from its worst recession in decades.
Sound familiar? You've heard it before -- and often from practitioners of what is called the dismal science. But don't take it too seriously. For, as any introductory textbook in economics will confirm, this quarter-truth drawn from the ideas of John Maynard Keynes begs to be qualified. And who better to do the qualifying than Paul Samuelson, author of the first economics textbook to bring the ideas of Keynes into the mainstream? 
 The core notion here, closely linked to what veterans of Econ 101 will remember as "the paradox of thrift," is simple. If people and factories are underemployed, the repairs after a disaster create income from resources that would otherwise have been idle. "Hurricanes make work for glaziers," Mr. Samuelson allows.
Actually, the consequences may prove even more serendipitous. When a homeowner digs into his savings (or insurance money) to replace the broken windows, the glazier is paid. And when the glazier spends the money on a new car, the incomes of auto workers go up. And so forth. This "multiplier effect" adds a little or a lot to the initial jolt of stimulus, depending on how much leaks out in the form of savings and taxes from each round of spending.
Governments can work the same miracle by putting money in people's pockets. Keynes facetiously suggested burying 100 notes in abandoned mines, thereby invigorating the moribund British mining industry. Hitler offered a different means to the same end: rapid rearmament, which made the Third Reich an island of prosperity in Depression-bound Europe.
What worked for Hitler also worked for F.D.R. "The true cost of the battleship Missouri was negative," Mr. Samuelson concludes, since the military buildup did not divert resources that would have been used to add value elsewhere in the economy.
Look closely, and you will see this Keynesian version of the free lunch popping up in the oddest places. Trade protectionists are gung-ho to create jobs and profits for American companies by making it harder for foreigners to sell their goods here. The idea is so powerful that it dominates the rhetoric of free traders, too. During the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement the White House talked endlessly of the jobs that would be generated by stimulating exports, and nary a word on how cheap imports from Mexico would bless American consumers.
Perhaps the trendiest variation on the theme comes from environmentalists. Don't think of the cost of recycling packaging materials or switching to eco-friendly fuels, Vice President Al Gore suggests; marvel at all those terrific high-paying jobs that will be created along the way.
How, then, can those without degrees from Harvard or Kennesaw State separate the cloud from the silver lining? Disasters can only do more good than harm, Mr. Samuelson argues, if a nation "has been experiencing bad macroeconomic luck or policies."
The Kobe earthquake fits the description since Japan has been wallowing in recession for years. So did Hurricane Andrew, which led Washington and the nation's insurers to pump billions of dollars into Florida when the construction industry was running at half-speed. But the North American trade accord presumably does not. Nor do power-plant scrubbers or space stations or antimissile defenses -- all of which drain resources from other productive activities when the economy is booming.
Put it another way. Suppose the new GATT world trade agreement does create a million jobs, as proponents trumpeted. If the American economy is already running near full employment, the Federal Reserve is pledged to destroy a million jobs by tightening credit. The alternative would be unacceptable inflation.
What makes the disasters-equal-jobs equation yet more problematic is that rebuilding property or manufacturing weapons is never the ideal way to stimulate an economy. For one thing, the specialized demand is bound to create production bottlenecks. Japan, presumably, will soon find itself with too few bulldozers to clear the rubble and too many factories producing cars that can't be driven on Kobe's streets.
More to the point, disaster relief adds to national output only when other policies to promote full employment have failed. In the case of Japan, bureaucrats in the Ministry of Finance have been sucking their thumbs for three years waiting for the recession to go away. "In my book," Mr. Samuelson says, "the Japanese economy is the worst managed in the world."

HEADLINE: Defense for Simpson Attacking Prosecutors' 'Rush to Judgment'

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Lawyers for O. J. Simpson began their attempt today to convince jurors that he is not a murderer but the victim of a sloppy police investigation and a rush to judgment by overzealous prosecutors.
In the first three hours of his opening statement, Mr. Simpson's chief lawyer, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., described his client as a flawed but reformed husband, a conscientious father, a public-spirited citizen. He said the case against Mr. Simpson was precisely what the opposing lawyers said it was not: character assassination and a tabloid prosecution. 
 "This case is about a rush to judgment, an obsession to win at any cost and by any means necessary," he said. The prosecution, he continued, "talks about a trail of blood, where there is no trail."
"There are trails that lead toward innocence," Mr. Cochran said, "and they were not pursued."
Mr. Cochran said he would introduce two witnesses who either saw suspicious people on the street around the time of the killing of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman or heard Mrs. Simpson shouting at an unidentified man after the time prosecutors say the killings occurred and only moments before Mr. Simpson was seen at his own home. He said the police had failed to interview these witnesses.
He also said that blood found under Mrs. Simpson's fingernails and on her thigh matched neither Mr. Simpson's blood nor that of Mr. Goldman and that blood found on her back had never been analyzed. Fingerprints, palm prints and shoe prints found on objects at the scene of the slaying, he said, were not Mr. Simpson's.
And Mr. Cochran hinted darkly at serious police misconduct, specifically that samples of Mr. Simpson's blood disappeared and then were used to fabricate evidence. "It seems to me that the fact that blood mysteriously appears on vital pieces of evidence and it's predicted what the results will be regarding DNA when that evidence is still in the police lab is devastating evidence of something far more sinister."
At the end of the day, prosecutors struck back, complaining bitterly that they had been ambushed by new material today, like the witness who was near Mrs. Simpson's house on the night of the slayings. They said the material should have turned over beforehand, and they demanded that Judge Ito address the issue. The judge scheduled a hearing for Thursday.
One highlight today, the second day of opening arguments, came when Mr. Simpson hobbled over to the jury box, pulled up the left leg of his pants and unveiled his knee. After summoning Mr. Simpson, Mr. Cochran told the jurors in the back row to feel free to stand up and then proceeded to give a guided tour of Mr. Simpson's battered knee, the legacy of a career on the gridiron. "There are scars going up and down and sideways," he said of what the incisions of four operations had left.
Mr. Cochran then discussed the consequences. He said Mr. Simpson was the only person authorized to use a golf cart at Pebble Beach because he could not walk 18 holes. He clearly implied that such a person could not have run in and out of a crime scene like a gazelle.
Moments earlier, Mr. Cochran described the chronic rheumatoid arthritis that afflicts Mr. Simpson's wrists. In stating that Mr. Simpson could not shuffle cards during a game of gin rummy on June 12, he implied just as forcefully that he could not have wielded a knife.
"He was perhaps the greatest running back in the history of the N.F.L., but you pay a price," Mr. Cochran said. "What no defense in the National Football League could do, mother nature and father time have taken their toll."
Mr. Cochran's presentation, largely low-key and conversational, occasionally impassioned, often disjointed, had not ended when court adjourned. He promised to conclude on Thursday with an examination of the Los Angeles Police Department crime lab, which he called "a cesspool of contamination."
Among the other points he made were: Tire tracks found at Mrs. Simpson's home did not come from Mr. Simpson's Ford Bronco. None of the hairs on the glove found there were Mr. Simpson's, while a hair on the ski cap came from someone else, according to the prosecution's own forensic tests. The blood samples cited by the prosecution in its opening statements on Tuesday were collected haphazardly and were "either old or degraded or contaminated by the people who collected them and tested them." The prosecutors, Mr. Cochran said, mentioned only five drops out of "thousands and thousands" that were found at the scene.
Given the amount of blood involved, Mr. Cochran said, what was remarkable about Mr. Simpson's Bronco was that it contained so little blood, not so much. Mr. Simpson has told the police that the blood in the car had come from a cut he suffered earlier that day. Evidence suggested, Mr. Cochran also said, that Mr. Goldman had put up a valiant struggle before he was murdered, yet photographs of Mr. Simpson taken after his arrest showed no bruises anywhere.
At one point Mr. Cochran produced a mystery envelope, thought to contain a knife Mr. Simpson bought several weeks before the killings but which, defense lawyers will argue, he never used. Prosecutors objected and the envelope was never opened, but afterward, another lawyer for Mr. Simpson, Robert L. Shapiro, said the contents of the package would prove that the police department was incompetent because they were overlooked during two police searches.
"In an effort to find any evidence not to exclude but to include Mr. Simpson, they searched everywhere in the area of Los Angeles. They searched Chicago; they searched everywhere they possibly could think," Mr. Cochran said. "They could not find the weapon or any clothes because Mr. Simpson, the evidence will show, did not have one."
What the authorities found, Mr. Cochran charged, they mishandled, using "covered wagon" methodology to handle "21st century cyberspace technology." Only once did he approvingly mention Irwin Golden, the deputy medical examiner: in recounting Dr. Golden's prior testimony that two knives might have been used for the killings. Otherwise, he faulted Dr. Golden for a multitude of sins, failing to analyze the contents of her stomach, appearing late at the crime scene, mixing and thereby contaminating evidence.
Just about the first person Mr. Cochran mentioned by name, after Martin Luther King, Lincoln, and Cicero, was Mark Fuhrman, the police detective who inspected the crime scene and later found a blood-stained glove at Mr. Simpson's estate that matched one found at Mrs. Simpson's condominium in Brentwood, and who, the defense contends, is a racist. The prosecution was hiding Mr. Fuhrman, Mr. Cochran charged, but the defense would smoke him out.
Turning to his suggestion about other suspects, Mr. Cochran said a couple on a blind date passed Mrs. Simpson's apartment at 10:25 P.M. the night of the murders and saw nothing amiss. Another woman, who was turned away when she called the police to report that she had spotted four men walking near Mrs. Simpson's condominium around the time of the killing, wearing ski caps and carrying something in their hands, then speeding away.
Those four men, two Hispanic and two whites, may have followed Ron Goldman there, Mr. Cochran speculated. But, he said, when the woman called the police after the killings to report what she had seen, she was told "we've got that case all wrapped up." She then called the District Attorney, whose operator said she was too busy talking to a psychic to speak with her.
"They didn't want to listen, because they had made their decision in this rush to judgment," he said. He hinted at additional evidence to come, including a bloody knife found by a bystander.
Repeatedly, Mr. Cochran said prosecutors had withheld facts and names from the defense because they did not fit into their theory -- a theory, he scoffed, whose central time line was built around the plaintive howls of a dog to prove the killings took place around 10:15 P.M. "They have to keep everything squashed in there," he voice rising in indignation. "You're going to see there there was no time to commit this crime."
Television coverage of the trial was given a reprieve early in the day, after Judge Ito exacted abject apologies from those responsible for inadvertently showing a glimpse of an alternate juror on Tuesday night. The judge threatened to pull the plug on the cameras but decided in effect to order that the camera be nailed down, that is, be limited to a single wide-angle courtroom shot, until certain modifications were made. Even that did not entirely allay his fears, however; concerned that jurors' reflections could be seen in plexiglass, he ordered it had it covered with hair spray.
Mr. Simpson's lawyers also began the even more formidable task of rehabilitating their client, who Mr. Cochran called "the living embodiment of the American dream."
Throughout the day, two huge photographs sat in front of the jury box: one showed Mr. Simpson, with his characteristic broad smile, hugging his daughter at the dance recital in which she performed the day of the killings; the other was taken the night before at a black-tie, $25,000-a plate Jewish charity function. With Mr. Simpson in the picture was Paula Barbieri, the model Mr. Cochran described as his client's girlfriend.
Those pictures, he said, symbolized several central points for the defense: that Mr. Simpson was a good family man, who insisted on returning from New York for his daughter's recital to atone for missing her first communion; that he was in a good mood that night, and not glaring at Mrs. Simpson menacingly, as prosecutors say; that he was reconciled to the end of marriage and had moved on to someone else, and that he was a public-spirited man, too busy being good to do bad.
Mr. Cochran talked of Mr. Simpson's "circle of benevolence" and what he called his "philanthropic largess." So often was Mr. Simpson out of town for charity affairs or shooting films and playing in Bryant Gumbel's golf tournament, Mr. Cochran said, that he could not have stalked anyone. Those instances where Mr. Simpson showed up where Mrs. Simpson already was, he said, were mere coincidences.
Mr. Cochran took issue with prosecution assertions that Mr. Simpson turned his wife into a Barbie doll, stressing that when he bestowed gifts upon her, like apartments in San Francisco and Laguna Beach, "there were no strings attached." He said Mr. Simpson was a good provider, giving Mrs. Simpson $4,000 a month for food. Far from keeping her unemployed, as prosecutors have said, he encouraged her to pursue a career as a decorator, finding her work and paying her to redecorate their own home.
In other respects, his account of Mrs. Simpson was more equivocal. He described an incident in which Mrs. Simpson slapped a maid and mentioned pointedly how she and her circle of friends went out dancing until 3, 4, 5 in the morning. "Nobody was controlling these women," he said. He also said it was Mrs. Simpson, not his client, who pushed for a marital reconciliation.
For the most part Mr. Cochran, wearing a blue suit and red tie and a two-toned handkerchief to match, spoke quietly to jurors, without flourishes for which he is known. At times he grew more intimate, clasping his hands and leaning over the lectern.
The jurors, wearing tags containing numbers and bar codes, watched intently but without emotion. A few took notes in pads the court had provided; one sipped Evian water.
Several pitches seemed aimed at the overwhelmingly black jury. Mr. Cochran quoted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and noted Mr. Simpson's rise from a poor and "spindly-legged youth" with rickets to a man "able to amass some assets."
Mr. Simpson bought a house for his aged mother, he added, pointing to the dignified elderly woman in a wheelchair sitting in the gallery. He also noted that every year Mr. Simpson anonymously donated $5,000 to a charity for inner city black youth, and that he continued to buy uniforms for children in in Potrero Hills, the poor neighborhood in San Francisco in which he was reared.
"This is the man," he said. "He became rich and famous, but he didn't forget."

HEADLINE: GREENSPAN GIVES STRONG IMPRESSION RATES WILL CLIMB

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Giving the strong impression that the Federal Reserve has not yet finished raising short-term interest rates, Alan Greenspan told Congress today that several harbingers of revived inflation required the Fed to remain "vigilant."
In an appearance before the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, avoided direct comment on the central bank's policy-making meeting next week, where Federal Reserve officials have long been expected to vote to raise interest rates again. At the same time, Mr. Greenspan said nothing to disabuse Wall Street of that notion. In comments that echoed those of other Federal Reserve officials in recent days, he clearly implied that the economy remained too robust to count higher inflation out. 
 Tightness in the labor market and other strains on the economy could "lead to some deterioration in the price picture in the near term," Mr. Greenspan said, "but any such deterioration should be contained if the Federal Reserve remains vigilant."
Still, the financial markets saw glimmers of hope in his testimony that next week's expected increase could be the last for a while. Stock and bond prices rose.
The Federal Reserve has raised rates six times since last February in its effort to prevent what it views as a runaway economic expansion in excess of 4 percent annual growth from causing prices to accelerate. By gradually raising rates, the central bank hopes to squeeze consumer and business borrowing enough to slow the economy to a more sustainable pace of roughly 2.5 percent.
But the danger -- which economists at the Chrysler Corporation and other industrial companies are increasingly worried about -- is that the Federal Reserve may be overreacting and could topple the economy into another recession by tightening its monetary grip too much.
Even though inflation has been running at less than 3 percent for three straight years -- the best record since the early 1960's -- the Federal Reserve is worried that the economy has been too strong recently for its own good.
"I see it as crucial that we extend the recent trend of low and, hopefully, declining inflation in the years ahead," Mr. Greenspan added. While the prospects are "fundamentally good," there are grounds for "some concern." Mr. Greenspan cited, for example, the fact that the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4 percent, in contrast to that of the late 1980's "when wages and prices accelerated appreciably." While consumer prices and the prices of goods going out the factory door have barely budged, he said, the costs of parts and supplies at earlier stages of production were starting to accelerate.
Mr. Greenspan also used the occasion to lecture Congress about the risks of widening the Federal budget gap. With both Republicans and Democrats proposing tax cuts this year, Mr. Greenspan contended in response to questions that the budget deficit was the nation's No. 1 economic problem. He urged lawmakers not to make it worse, insisting that any revenue loss should be minimal and, in any case, should be made up by equal or greater spending cuts.
"We're going to have chronic fiscal problems if we don't cut spending," Mr. Greenspan said, declaring tax cuts to be of low priority and best accomplished by lowering tax rates. By contrast, the current proposals, from both Republicans and from President Clinton, rely primarily on tax credits that would do nothing to lower rates in ways that might provide greater incentives for work and savings.
Mr. Greenspan also said he was "a little chagrined" that the findings of the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform were not taken more seriously. The 32-member commission, headed by Senators Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, found that spending on Social Security and other Federal benefit programs were rising at unsustainable rates. But the commission disbanded at year's end after failing to agree on a remedy it could recommend to the President.
Mr. Greenspan said much of the so-called inflation premium in rates on long-term bonds would simply evaporate if action were taken on this front and would result in lower interest rates.
Returning to a theme he expounded earlier this month, to the delight of Republicans looking to free up money for tax cuts, Mr. Greenspan said that the deficit could be narrowed simply by eliminating the bias in the Consumer Price Index that causes overpayment of entitlement benefits and an excessive inflation adjustment in tax rates.
Mr. Greenspan, who said the Fed believed the index overstated inflation from 0.5 to 1.5 percentage points, recommended today that Congress specify a commitment to maintain the purchasing power of retirees while eliminating the bias that overpays them.
Mr. Greenspan also recommended that the retirement age be moved back to reflect changes in life expectancy.
In commenting on the risks of inflation, Mr. Greenspan pointed out that more companies were buying materials in advance because they thought they might become more expensive or in short supply. Reports of worker shortages have become "more common," he said. These are all signs pointing to the prospect of greater price increases.
On the other hand, Mr. Greenspan said, "trends in money and credit expansion have remained subdued" and have not yet become the financial tinder needed to kindle higher inflation.
Committee members made little effort to dissuade the Fed from pushing rates up again despite pleas from auto makers and some other industries that the cumulative restraint -- much of which has yet to be fully felt -- could prove too much.
An exception was Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat, who said that higher rates would make it even harder for Mexico to resolve its financial crisis. Mr. Greenspan responded by saying that Mexico would benefit from the Fed's proper focus, the long-term growth of the United States economy.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Proposal Beyond Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today began debating a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, one of the most profound measures to come before Congress in years. Set aside the claims and counterclaims about Democrats being profligate and Republicans wanting to destroy Social Security and bankrupt the states. Those are political side issues.
What is really at stake is a fundamental and ostensibly permanent change in the way the American Government works. Powerful arguments can be made for and against such a change. Here is an examination of three of the strongest arguments for such a constitutional amendment and the way opponents are rebutting them. 
 As a matter of principle, the Government should have to live within its means just as states and cities and families do.
Until relatively recently, this was the dominant view of American fiscal policy. Except during wartime, large Federal deficits -- the difference between what the Government spends and what it receives in taxes and other revenues -- were out of the question. Proponents of the amendment often cite this quotation from Harry S. Truman: "There is nothing sacred about the pay-as-you-go idea so far as I am concerned except that it represents the soundest principle of financing that I know."
Most economists agree that the huge deficits the Government began running in the 1980's are dangerous to the future. Charles L. Schultze of the Brookings Institution compares the deficits to termites gnawing at the foundation of a building. Benjamin M. Friedman of Harvard says the country is consuming its seed corn.
James M. Buchanan of George Mason University, winner of the 1987 Nobel Prize in economics, told Congress a few years ago that the country had "lost the moral sense of fiscal responsibility."
But many who feel most strongly about the need to reduce the deficit do not favor requiring that revenues match expenditures every year. "There is nothing magic about a balanced budget," Mr. Friedman said.
Ideally, they say, the budget would be in surplus in good times, and run manageable deficits when the economy was in recession.
In fact, states and cities and families do not always balance their budgets. State and local governments issue bonds to finance projects like turnpikes or sewer systems. Families take out mortgages on their homes and loans to pay college tuition. No one considers that financially irresponsible. And no one, opponents of the amendment say, should consider it wrong for the Federal Government to go into debt periodically to make the country better for the next generation.
But the Federal Government is like a family that borrows heavily to finance vacations each year. The Government's debt has increased at a faster rate than its income year after year after year. If a state or a family did that, it would be in trouble, too.
Without the discipline of a constitutional amendment, politicians will never take the steps necessary to reduce the deficit.
The deficit, forecast to be $176 billion this year, has fallen for the last three years because of the strong economy and because of deficit reduction measures enacted in 1990 and 1993. But primarily because of the rising cost of health programs, it will resume shooting up next year, unless new steps are taken, until it reaches a whopping $322 billion in 2002, according to projections by the Congressional Budget Office.
The problem is that the deficit cannot be reduced substantially simply by eliminating wasteful programs and cracking down on welfare cheats, as some conservatives seem to think, or by raising taxes on the wealthy and slashing spending at the Pentagon, as some liberals apparently believe.
The only way to get the Government's finances under control is to enact measures that would be unappealing politically -- so unpopular, in fact, that they could cost the politicians who support them their jobs.
A constitutional amendment might provide these politicians the political cover they need to cast courageous votes.
The argument on the other side is that the politicians will still face the hard choices about raising taxes and cutting spending, and their votes will be no less unpopular because of a constitutional requirement.
Some opponents of the measure fear that relying on a constitutional amendment instead of political leadership could result in Federal judges making policy that elected officials should be making. That, of course, is what happened when politicians failed to desegregate schools, and judges stepped in and decided which children went to which schools.
The requirement that the budget be in balance would force the Government to set priorities.
For years, politicians have acted like hungry people in a free buffet line. Rather than decide which dishes to take, they simply pile up their plates with everything.
Under the budget laws enacted in 1990 and 1993, priorities must be addressed when new programs are considered. Taxes cannot be cut without offsetting spending cuts or tax increases. Similarly, Government benefits cannot be increased without counterbalancing measures. And discretionary spending, which includes everything from battleships to ballpoint pens, is frozen so that if spending is raised for one item, another must be cut.
But nothing requires the Government to strip programs and examine tax breaks already on the books. A balanced-budget amendment would require the President and Congress to decide between the ham and turkey and roast beef on their plates -- to review every program in the Government and decide which ones to keep and which ones to discard.
There is little incentive for politicians to do this now. They win votes by cutting ribbons and passing out favors. Few constituents vote for politicians who specifically take something away from them.
The other side of this argument is that a constitutional amendment would not relieve the pressure on politicians to respond to their constituents. So instead of doing it by spending money or granting tax deductions, they might adopt less obvious measures. They could impose or withdraw regulations, place new requirements on states or businesses, set up quasi-government authorities to borrow money or find other means to satisfy voters that are less visible, less efficient and less controllable than writing checks.

HEADLINE: Gore Rules Against Merger of A.I.D. and Others Into State Dept.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Administration has rejected proposals by the State Department to consolidate three major independent agencies under the department's authority, senior Administration officials said today.
Vice President Al Gore made the decision not to consolidate the three -- the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency -- after asking the State Department three weeks ago to come up with suggestions for streamlining the foreign-policy apparatus. 
 But the issue remains open because several prominent Republicans in Congress have urged eliminating A.I.D. and the arms control agency.
The White House decided against merging the agencies into the State Department because they are already trying to cut staff and costs and a new consolidation would impede such efforts. "It's important to finish the restructuring task inside each agency," said one senior Administration official.
According to one official, Mr. Gore decided against consolidation because, with so much on the Administration's foreign policy agenda, there was concern that such a move would set off jurisdictional battles between the agencies' personnel and the State Department.
Officials from all three agencies had put up a fight to remain independent, saying consolidation would be time-consuming and would make it harder for the Government to carry out their missions.
For example the arms control agency, which has 250 employees, was set up in 1961 to be a voice that would be free of Pentagon pressure to increase the nuclear stockpile and State Department pressure not to hurt diplomatic relations.
The Agency for International Development, which has 2,950 employees, was set up the same year to concentrate on long-term development strategies while the State Department focused on shorter-term diplomatic concerns.
Mr. Gore is to meet with the heads of the three agencies on Thursday to inform them of his decision not to merge them into the State Department.
Administration officials said Secretary of State Warren Christopher was neutral on the reorganization proposals, which were backed by Thomas E. Donilan, his chief of staff; Lynn E. Davis, undersecretary for international security affairs, and Timothy E. Wirth, the State Department counselor.
By some estimates, the merger would have saved more than $200 million a year. When the Administration announces its "no merger" decision, it will also announce streamlining by the agencies, several officials said.
For example, A.I.D., which has already closed 23 offices overseas and cut its staff by 10 percent, is to announce additional closings, agency officials said.
Joseph D. Duffey, director of the United States Information Agency, said in an interview tonight that merging his 8,300-employee agency into the State Department would have complicated his streamlining efforts. He has eliminated most of the agency's magazines and traveling exhibits, and has merged many of its overseas libraries and commercial reference centers.
"We have already made many shifts and changes, and we feel we're still in the process," Mr. Duffey said.

HEADLINE: Blantyre Journal;
Foes Gather to Jeer Fallen African Founding Father

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BLANTYRE, Malawi, Jan. 19

 BODY:
During three decades of eccentric, regal despotism, Life President Hastings Kamuzu Banda usually had a red carpet unfurled before him when he ventured out into his realm.
So there was a ghoulish curiosity in the crowd that gathered outside the High Court of Malawi the other day, hoping to see the fallen ruler and his confederates endure that humbling ritual of accused celebrities, the perp walk. 
 "Kamuzu, you have killed our sons!" some chanted, and a few yelled for blood. But most stood quietly, eager to see if this man who once held them in thrall would look any different now that he had been cut to mortal size.
Eight months after he conceded defeat in an election that was forced upon him, Dr. Banda has been charged with ordering the murder of four top officials of his own Government. The men were rounded up by the police and clubbed to death with hammers and crowbars.
The 12-year-old crime, its grisly details itemized in 1,000 pages of testimony, has absorbed this little sliver of southeast Africa, a country that prides itself on being a pocket of gentleness in a cruel continent.
Even more than the elections last May, the case has become a rite of passage from the rule of one man's whim to the rule of laws.
"We're not wanting vengeance in this matter," said President Bakili Muluzi, who defeated Dr. Banda. "We're not even wanting to use it as a political issue. But according to the laws of Malawi, you kill, you are tried."
Echoing some of the gawkers outside the courthouse, he added, "We must put the record right and make sure that nobody in my position, today, tomorrow, would ever commit atrocities like that and get away with it."
In his mid-90's and reportedly given to depression and lapses of memory, Dr. Banda lives under luxurious house arrest and faces the possibility of being hanged if he survives the year or more his murder trial is expected to take. His lawyer, Lovemore Munlo, describes Dr. Banda as being "in terrible shape."
So far, Mr. Munlo has gotten his client excused from appearing in court.
Dr. Banda (he earned a medical degree from Meharry Medical College in Tennessee) led the protests that won independence from Britain in 1964. Within two years he had consolidated all power in his own hands.
The Victorian peculiarity of his rule -- he dressed formally in homburg hats and ordered long-haired male tourists shorn at the airport -- made him seem more comical than brutal. Even now many Malawians revere Dr. Banda as the father of their country, and blame any cruelties committed during his rule on his despised right-hand man, John Tembo, who also faces charges in the case.
But the murder accusation, compiled by an independent commission created by Mr. Muluzi, has badly battered Dr. Banda's lingering reputation as a strict but well-intentioned patriarch.
The commission found that in 1983 four men whose loyalty Dr. Banda had questioned -- three Cabinet ministers and a member of Parliament -- were arrested at police roadblocks, blindfolded, taken to a forest outside Blantyre and killed.
"I was the one who had the hammer and I hit him at the back of the head, where I knew, according to my police training, he would die immediately," said one policeman whose testimony filled pages of a local newspaper.
The police packed the bodies into a blue Peugeot and rolled it over a cliff, and later presented the deaths to the country as an accident.
The commission had only circumstantial evidence that Dr. Banda and Mr. Tembo ordered the men killed. The police official to whom Dr. Banda supposedly gave the command later died, although his wife and deputy say he told them about his instructions.
But Robert Mzikamanda, who was secretary of the investigating commission, said there was "debate, but no doubt" about Dr. Banda's role. Within days of receiving the report, the chief prosecutor ordered the former President and three others arrested.
Dr. Banda's lawyer, Mr. Munlo, says the police must have acted on their own. The murder case, he argues, is a vengeful circus intended to distract public attention from the economic misery that has conspicuously worsened since Dr. Banda lost power.
"There is an enthusiasm to punish Dr. Banda," the lawyer said.
It is true that President Muluzi could use a timely reminder of how bad things used to be, since many of his people are already muttering that life was better under Dr. Banda.
Since the elections, the currency has lost more than half its value. The inflation rate is over 40 percent. Foreign aid, which keeps the Government afloat, is threatened by Republican control of the United States Congress and by competition from the more glamorous new democracy in nearby South Africa.
The Government is also under pressure from others who lost husbands and fathers to search the past to its depths.
Vera Chirwa, a human rights lawyer, contends that thousands died mysteriously. She and her husband, Orton Chirwa, spent 11 years in prison, much of the time manacled hand and foot in solitary confinement. Her husband died in custody in 1992.
"It's not enough," she says of the current murder case. "My children would like to know, how did their daddy die?"
But in an interview at the hilltop palace he inherited, Mr. Muluzi said his country cannot afford a witch hunt, even if it wanted one.
Investigating the one case, he said, has already cost his impoverished Government $250,000. In addition, courts have made huge compensation awards to victims of the past Government, which Mr. Muluzi calls forcing the new democracy to "pay for Banda's sins."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Demonstrators held a sign that, translated, means "Tembo is crying now" in Blantyre, Malawi, last week. Ex-President Hastings Banda and John Tembo, his chief aide, face charges in connection with four killings. (Reuters)
