HEADLINE: Trying to Help Aid Plan, U.S. Asks Mexico for Border Crackdown

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In an effort to overcome Congressional opposition to a proposed emergency aid package for Mexico, top Clinton Administration officials said today that they had asked Mexico to help prevent illegal aliens from crossing into the United States and to place strict controls on its economic policy.
The proposed conditions for the bailout package would effectively give the United States enormous influence in how Mexico deployed its police along the countries' border, battled narcotics and managed its economy. 
 But in the more than four hours of Congressional hearings on the package today, not a single member of the House Banking Committee, Democrat or Republican, expressed support for a $40 billion set of loan guarantees -- in which the United States would essentially co-sign a loan to the country -- and several members vowed to defeat it.
By the end of the day, Republican leaders who earlier had predicted quick approval of the package, probably by the end of this week, were saying that it would take far longer to negotiate and that the outcome was in doubt.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, complained that the White House had failed to rally its own party around the deal and said that despite his support for the plan, Republicans would not engineer its passage alone.
"Unless there is some help on the other side of the aisle, forget it," Mr. Dole said. "It is not going to happen."
In the most explicit description yet of the conditions that would surround a loan guarantee, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that Mexican leaders had agreed "in principle" to turn over to the United States all of their country's earnings from foreign oil sales if Mexico defaulted on American-guaranteed loans.
The loans would be intended to restore investors' confidence in Mexico and enable it to borrow money again on world financial markets after last month's devaluation of the peso. The devaluations were caused by Mexico's overborrowing of short-term funds and printing too much money.
Even while the Clinton Administration's promise of tough conditions was appearing to win few converts on Capitol Hill, it remained unclear how Mexico would react to the escalating list of political and economic conditions tied to any loan. Opponents of the Government in Mexico City have already criticized plans to tie repayment of any loans to the state-run oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, and the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon has repeatedly said that it would accept no conditions that compromised Mexican independence.
Asked about objections in Mexico, a senior Clinton Administration official said today, "The fact is, they don't have a lot of bargaining chips."
At today's hearing Mr. Rubin, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, fielded heated questions about the proposed rescue and warned again that the United States had little choice but to come to Mexico's rescue.
If Congress fails to act, Mr. Christopher said, "America's prosperity and security will be put at risk" as the financial crisis spreads around the world.
Later, in an interview, Mr. Rubin predicted that if the package was not approved quickly, there could be "a catalytic impact around the world" as investors pulled billions of dollars out of other emerging markets that have followed Mexico's formula of economic reform.
"This creates the possibility of less capital," Mr. Rubin said, "and social and political troubles that could follow."
But the Administration is facing growing objections, many from members of Congress, who complain that the biggest beneficiaries of the loan guarantee will be some of the richest American and Mexican investors. Those investors bought $28 billion in the Mexican notes, or tesobonos, that the government cannot pay off since the 35 percent devaluation of the Mexican peso.
The Administration's problem is that the United States cannot bail out Mexico's economy -- and thus help preserve 700,000 American jobs that are linked to exports to Mexico -- without also saving a raft of investors both here and abroad. Those investors run the gamut from millionaires to holders of pension and mutual funds that joined the boom in investing in Mexico.
So far, the Administration's message that the stakes go far beyond bond holders has largely fallen on deaf ears on Capitol Hill.
"People don't understand it," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, "and they think it's a bailout of big guys."
Compounding the Administration's troubles is widespread confusion over what Mexico would be required to do in return for the help.
Mr. Christopher has fought to keep political conditions -- especially on illegal aliens and drugs -- out of the authorizing legislation in Congress, for fear that opponents of the North American Free Trade Agreement would load the bill with more and more demands. So the Administration is pressing for a "side letter" from Mexico, in which the Zedillo Government would commit itself to crackdowns on emigration and narcotics without making that a strict condition of the loan.
Even the financial conditions are murky. There are several versions of the bill authorizing the loan guarantee, but the Administration has yet to submit a single bill for formal debate.
Today it was rushing to placate Democrats who insisted on new conditions that would require Mexico to tie wage increases to increases in productivity, a way of assuring that Mexican products -- already, thanks to the devaluation, a third cheaper in dollar terms than they were a month ago -- will not be made even cheaper.
Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the banking committee and supports the bailout, said today that the bill was "the most ad hoc process of development of legislation I have experienced in my public life."
Administration officials said they were walking a tightrope between satisfying Congress and preventing the insertion of conditions so onerous that they would slow Mexico's growth or lead to the spread of anti-government uprisings. Some members of Congress say that the guarantees of repayment are a sham and that the United States, for example, would hardly cut off the money Mexico earns from oil if the Mexican economy worsened.
"What we're going to do if the deal goes south is take the money they will desperately need to keep their people fed?" asked Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts. "Politically, it will never work."
Mr. Kennedy, echoing a theme heard from conservatives and liberals alike today, said: "Let the markets work it out."

HEADLINE: Leader Calls Essex County Debt-Riddled

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The new Essex County Executive warned today that the county was facing a deficit of $161.5 million, or nearly one-third of its operating budget, accusing his predecessors of mismanaging the books so badly that he had been left with a pile of unpaid debts.
The County Executive, James W. Treffinger, a Republican who won office by painting the county government as corrupted by decades of Democratic rule, vowed that he would not raise taxes to make up for the deficit. He said he would try to close it by selling assets, controlling spending and, if necessary, laying off some of the county's 6,000 workers. 
 He also said he would consider transferring some of the county's responsibilities to municipalities, a proposal that was quickly criticized by some local officials.
"This is the worst fiscal crisis ever to befall a county in New Jersey's history," Mr. Treffinger said at a news conference this morning at the Essex County Hall of Records. "If this county fails to take the necessary steps to completely downsize, overhaul, cut and turn around the county's operations, then financial disaster will be the price of such failure."
[Many of New Jersey's local officials reacted with dismay today at their first glimpse at how much state aid they can expect under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's 1996 budget. Article, page B6.]
Mr. Treffinger's report on the deficit capped off a year of disarray in Essex County, New Jersey's largest. Last February, the previous county executive, Thomas J. D'Alessio, a Democrat, was convicted on Federal extortion charges just as he was putting together the 1994 budget.
Donald Biase, the county administrator, served as acting county executive, but for much of the year the government appeared rudderless. The 1994 budget was not adopted until August for a fiscal year that had begun in January.
The budget practices criticized by Mr. Treffinger had already caught the attention of Wall Street. Moody's Investors Service, a leading bond-rating firm, downgraded the county's bonds from A1 to A last month, saying that county officials had not shown proper fiscal discipline and had allowed debt to increase at too great a pace. A lower rating generally means that a bond issuer must pay higher interest.
The report today infuriated some Democrats on the county's governing body, the Board of Freeholders, who charged that Mr. Treffinger had rounded up any possible financial liabilities that the county might have and crammed them all into the 1995 budget in an attempt to smear the Democrats.
The Freeholder president, Joseph DiVincenzo, said he was so disgusted by Mr. Treffinger's move that he had decided to call for the abolition of the county executive form of government, which has existed here since the late 1970's. Mr. DiVincenzo agreed that the fiscal crisis was serious, but he also maintained that every new county executive plays with the statistics in an effort to lay the blame on his predecessors.
"Every time this happens, two years into the new administration, there is a miraculous turnaround and the new administration claims they have created a budget surplus," Mr. DiVincenzo said.
Mr. Treffinger said the 1995 deficit had ballooned to $161.5 million because he had been forced to come up with money for bills that Democratic officials, he contended, had repeatedly put off paying. That spending included millions of dollars in contributions to litigation and worker's compensation funds, he said. The 1995 deficit also includes a $35.5 million shortfall left from 1994.
Mr. Treffinger said state regulators had given him more time to write the 1995 budget. He said he hoped to submit it by March 1.
Responding to the Democratic attacks, Mr. Treffinger denied that he had manipulated the budget figures.
"The numbers speak for themselves," he said. "For the first time we have described the real cost of running this government. For the first time, we don't have a smoke-and-mirrors budget."
Mr. Treffinger met with Moody's officials on Tuesday in New York City to assure them that he was taking strong steps to rein in spending. Paul Devine, a vice president at Moody's, said Mr. Treffinger was correct in laying out all the county's liabilities in the 1995 budget, instead of spreading them out over a series of budgets or hiding them.
"It's important to note that some of these things might be a liability over the next year, but not on a continuing basis," Mr. Devine said. "But we liked the fact that they are willing to put everything on the table and look at all the issues they have to address."
Mr. Devine noted that the county's bond rating was downgraded not only because of its budget difficulties, but also because the county is becoming increasingly urbanized, a change reflected in more poverty and unemployment, along with higher costs for social services.
Essex County has nearly 800,000 residents, and includes low-income urban areas like Newark and East Orange, as well as wealthy suburbs like Montclair and Short Hills.
At his news conference today, Mr. Treffinger likened the county's fiscal crisis to that in Orange County, Calif., a comparison that some fiscal experts said was overstated. But Mr. Treffinger said that if he were to rely only on new property taxes to meet the budget gap, there would have to be a 62 percent tax increase. That, he said, he would not do.
"Raising taxes has not solved the problem," he said. "It has only exacerbated the problems in Essex and enhanced a governmental culture of tax, spend and borrow."
Glenn Grant, the Business Administrator of Newark, the largest municipality in the county, called the county's budget gap "devastating." He said Mayor Sharpe James was open to meeting with county officials to discuss how Newark could help. Yet he cautioned that the city already handled enough of the county's responsibilities.
"Our Mayor has said we want to work with the new County Executive," he said. "But I can't allow Newark taxpayers to bear an unfair burden for the county's failure to run a good operation, to keep their fiscal house in order."

HEADLINE: Prof. Edward Shils, 84, Is Dead; Researcher on Intellectuals' Role

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Prof. Edward Shils, a theoretical sociologist noted for his research on the role of intellectuals in the formation of public policy and the exercise of power, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 84.
The cause was cancer, according to the University of Chicago, where he held the title of distinguished service professor. 
 One of the most sought-after experts in his field, Professor Shils was esteemed for his erudition and the breadth of his interests. His ties with the University of Chicago went back more than five decades, and he had continued to write and travel and meet with students until just weeks ago.
Professor Shils taught sociology, social philosophy, English literature, the history of Chinese science and many other subjects that reflected his grasp of various cultures and fields.
He spent part of the year in England, where he was associated with the University of London, Kings College and Peterhouse at Cambridge University, and the London School of Economics. Over the years he had lectured at various European universities.
He was the editor of Minerva, a quarterly that is circulated internationally as a "review of the social, administrative, political and economic problems of science and scholarship." He founded the journal, published in London, in 1962. It was named for the Roman goddess of wisdom, invention and technical prowess, and its influence belies its modest circulation of about 800.
In 1979, at the invitation of the National Council on the Humanities, Professor Shils became the eighth person to deliver the annual Jefferson Lecture, the highest national distinction for scholarly achievement.
He also received the Balzan Prize, awarded by an Italian foundation for fields without Nobel Prizes. In presenting Professor Shils the 1983 prize, the foundation cited him for combining the empiricism of American sociology with the theoretical thinking of European sociologists, thus contributing "toward a truly universal, general sociology, as opposed to the 'French,' 'German,' and 'American' sociologies."
Born in Springfield, Mass., Professor Shils graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1931 and earned a master's degree at Cambridge in 1961. In 1933 he went to the University of Chicago as a research assistant and became an instructor and, by 1950, a professor.
As a high school student, he discovered the work of the German sociologist Max Weber, whom he continued studying and writing about throughout his career. He translated works by Weber as well as the sociologist Karl Mannheim.
Among his many publications and books was "Tradition" (University of Chicago Press, 1982). Showing the sweep of his knowledge with a wide-ranging analysis, the book's theme was that the modern tendency to exalt in the new just because it is new ran counter to basic anthropological and sociological realities.
He is survived by a son, Adam, of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Outsider Art Comes In

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Calvin and Ruby Black settled in the California desert in the 1950's, they opened a rock and crystal shop. To attract attention to it, they carved child-size dolls from redwood and sugar pine, then costumed them and set them outside, even on the roof. These figures came to be known far and wide as the Possum Trot dolls.
Fewer than 60 dolls were ever made. But four of them now live in Gael and Michael Mendelsohn's house overlooking a golf course in Westchester County. "There's Gina, on the left, and that's Jan," Mrs. Mendelsohn said, "and then there's Muffins. I think the Blacks thought of her as their own child." 
 Mrs. Mendelsohn, who has a master's degree in folk art studies, is not without her own feelings of parental pride.
Outsider Art is on the move. For quite some time, the sculptures, carvings, paintings, dolls and masks by 20th-century artists who never had formal training have been lining the walls of pristine SoHo galleries, intriguing visitors with their colorful "canvases" (cardboard, plywood, concrete), their media (aluminum foil, discarded Masonite, house paint, rusted metal) and their raw energy.
Now, Outsider Art is coming home to roost in master bedrooms, as dining-table centerpieces, and in sedate entrance foyers from Lake Shore Drive in Chicago to Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
Even though the prices of Outsider Art continue to rise at auctions, galleries and art fairs, many of the works are still affordable for first-time collectors. But fans say it's their human, down-to-earth appeal -- the visual equivalent of singing the blues -- that strikes a responsive chord. "After the hype and pretentiousness of the 80's, I feel that Outsiders manifest a return to honesty and integrity," said Marion Harris, a dealer in
Simsbury, Conn. Three years ago, she discovered Jerry W. Coker, a 58-year-old Arkansas artist who makes portraits of people he has known -- he calls them "identity masks" -- from pieces of tin and metal.
More and more people are entering the Outsider arena, following in the tracks of celebrity fans like Tim Robbins, Susan Sarandon, Peter Gabriel, Jonathan Demme, R.E.M. and the Talking Heads.
This weekend, collectors, dealers, curators and scholars are expected to converge at the center of the outsider art tornado: the third annual Outsider Art Fair, which opens tomorrow night and continues through Sunday at the Puck Building in SoHo.
"This is an art show that's become a convention," said Sanford L. Smith, the organizer of the event, which will feature 34 dealers -- three from Europe, the rest from all over the United States.
The term "Outsider Art" may have first been used by Roger Cardinal, a British historian, in his book, "Outsider Art" (Praeger, 1972), about the work of people "innocent of pictorial influences." He was referring to the French artist Jean Dubuffet's vast collecton of art by mental hospital patents, now housed in the Musee de l'Art Brut in Lausanne, Switzerland. But the term "outsider" has been expanded to include all kinds of self-taught, visionary and intuitive artists.
Many of the artists that are now considered top of the line will be represented at the fair, from William L. Hawkins, an Ohio painter who died four years ago, to Minnie Evans, a North Carolinian who died in 1987, and Simon Sparrow, a painter and street evangelist who was born in 1925 in West Africa and now lives in Wisconsin.
Mr. Hawkins usually included his birthdate -- July 27, 1895 -- in his dynamic paintings, some in house-paint enamel on Masonite. Mrs. Evans's work as a gatekeeper in a North Carolina garden inspired her lush floral compositions, done with graphite, ink and crayon. Mr. Sparrow used beads, glitter and costume jewelry in his collage, which often have a religious theme.
"Much of the work breaks preconceptions of what people think self-taught art can look like," said Aarne Anton, the owner of American Primitive Gallery in New York. "The diversity of materials used and the range of personal visions continues to extend the horizons of the field." That may be because the artists, some of them preachers, often bring to their work a strong spiritual component. Many come from the rural South and from Pennsylvania; often they had led ordinary lives only to bloom as artists in old age.
The urban environment is also becoming a fertile source for younger artists. Curtis Cuffie of Manhattan is an artist represented by Art on the Edge, a nonprofit group of artists who are homeless.
"His life and his art are one," said Tina White, the group's director. Mr. Cuffie assembles his totemic sculptures on the sidewalks from discarded fabric, old cans and broken clocks.
Joseph Jacobs, the curator of paintings and sculpture at the Newark Museum, where "A World of Their Own: 20th-Century American Folk Art" opens tomorrow, said: "While the 19th-century folk artists positioned themselves within a tradition, the 19 artists selected here all work in what I call 'esthetic isolation.' And most of these artists don't think of their own work as art."
But the people who collect it certainly do. Some trust their own instincts while others are interested in what are now considered the blue-chip names in the field: "I like the more recognized artists, and when I buy I like to buy stories," said Mrs. Mendelsohn, whose collection now includes pieces by Mr. Hawkins, Mr. Sparrow, Thornton Dial, Bill Traylor, William Edmondson, Martin Ramirez and Henry Darger.
Mrs. Mendelsohn has covered windows and removed mirrors in her house to get more wall space for her collection. "These things are fun and colorful and often make me laugh," she said, adding, "And make Michael cry when he gets the bills."
Frank Maresca and his partner, Roger Ricco, of the Ricco/Maresca Gallery in SoHo, have represented Mr. Hawkins since they first saw his work 12 years ago in Columbus, Ohio.
"He was dipping his one paintbrush into cans of enamel paint and producing some of the most surprising and fresh images that I had ever seen," Mr. Maresca said.
Prices for large Hawkins paintings have gone from $3,000 to $4,000 a decade ago, Mr. Maresca said, to $30,000 to $50,000 today.
Outsider Art often elicits an emotional bond. "I call them my family," said Carmen de Lavallade, the dancer, pointing to the painted concrete busts by Vernon Burwell in the SoHo loft she shares with her husband, Geoffrey Holder, the choreographer.
In fact, letting go is sometimes hard to do. But 47 of the couple's American folk art and Outsider pieces will be sold at auction at Sotheby's on Monday.
"It's time to share them," Mr. Holder said.
Guests at Monty and Anne Hill Blanchard's traditionally decorated Upper East Side apartment often ask -- diplomatically, of course -- whether the paintings leaning against the bookcase or the sculptures standing on the Oriental rugs have been placed there only temporarily.
"Oh, no, this is how we really live," Mrs. Blanchard usually replies.
A professor of economics who is originally from Alabama, Mrs. Blanchard and her husband, an investment banker who comes from North Carolina, have collected more than 400 pieces of Outsider Art in the last decade.
Their apartment is dotted wall to wall with works by artists now considered the masters of the moment.
There's an early glass tower by Howard Finster on a 19th-century Southern sideboard in the foyer, and a red, white and blue Hawkins painting of a building in the living room. "Discrimination and Electricity," a three-dimensional piece by Thornton Dial is in the dining room; so is a bejeweled Simon Sparrow collage of a lion, which hangs above a silver tea service.
"As different as they are, they all capture us with their visual intensity," said Mrs. Blanchard.
The furniture in the living room of the small East Side duplex in which Herbert Waide Hemphill Jr., has lived since the late 1950's was long ago under the avalanche of birdhouses and paintings, weathervanes and painted signs, carved animals, skeletons and masks that fill every inch of the space.
A founder of the Museum of American Folk Art, Mr. Hemphill, 66, began with a duck decoy when he was 7. In his 60 years of collecting he has amassed about 2,000 objects, sculptures and paintings, 450 of which have been acquired by the National Museum of American Art in Washington.
"I bought things that no one else wanted or that dealers had the eye to buy but couldn't resell," he said.
Up until a few years ago, Mr. Hemphill traveled far and wide with a friend who would drive him around, taking a Southern route to the West, returning East through the Dakotas along back roads.
Arriving in a small town, Mr. Hemphill would search out the local artists. "The preacher would know, the newspaper would know, the bar would know," he said. "There were artists everywhere," he said. By all accounts, there still are.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH EDWIDGE DANTICAT;
Haitian Tales, Flatbush Scenes

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
IT was the kind of dark, cold New York winter day that sun-drenched people from the Caribbean dread. But Edwidge Danticat, a 25-year-old Haitian-American novelist who immigrated to Brooklyn a little more than a dozen years ago, would not let it dampen her spirits.
"You want some coffee, tea?" she said in a soft melodic voice, as if the liquids would warm the day. "The tea is cannelle." 
 So Ms. Danticat (her name is pronounced ed-WEEDJ dahn-tee-CAH), the author of "Breath, Eyes, Memory," her first novel, which was published by Soho Press last spring and received respectful reviews, set small flowered, ceramic cups on a coffee table. She settled into a plastic-covered velour chair in the beige-carpeted living room of her parents' attached brick home in East Flatbush and explained that the cannelles, or cinnamon sticks, had been bought just blocks away, from Haitian street vendors.
"It's wonderful," she said, pouring the steamy light brown liquid into the cup. "It's like 'infusion' tea. Haitians think of tea as a cure-all."
While much is written about the troubled, mountainous island nation, Ms. Danticat's debut novel is probably the first to chronicle the Haitian-American experience. In the last decade, the number of Haitian-Americans has grown to more than a million; their communities are centered in New York and Miami.
The book is about four generations of Haitian women who struggle to overcome poverty, powerlessness and abuse. The story is told through the point of view of Sophie Caco, a teen-ager who, after spending years with her aunt in rural Haiti, is reunited with her mother in Brooklyn. Sophie feels compelled to return to Haiti after she learns that her birth resulted from her mother's rape there.
Critics have praised Ms. Danticat's vivid sense of place and her images of fear and pain, which have been compared to Alice Walker's.
The New York Times Book Review said the book "achieves an emotional complexity that lifts it out of the realm of the potboiler and into that of poetry."
Ms. Danticat has dared to probe into some of the most painful and hidden Haitian traditions, including "testing," a mostly rural practice in which a mother inserts her fingers in her daughter's vagina to ascertain that she is still a virgin.
"Haitian men, they insist that their women are virgins and have their 10 fingers," Sophie's aunt says after Sophie is tested, explaining to her the virtues of virginity and the reasons for testing.
Sitting in her living room, Ms. Danticat said that among Haitian-American women, "there is a great deal of rage toward the book." At readings across the country, she said, some of the strongest opposition comes from middle-class Haitian-American women who consider themselves modern and liberated. They are ashamed of things like testing, she said, and some, raised in cities, are shocked to learn that it is exists.
"I think a lot of people see Haiti as the good guys against the bad guys," she said. "It is so much more complex than that."
Ms. Danticat insisted that the story is not about herself, although she too was raised for several years by an aunt in Port-au-Prince after her parents -- her father, Andre, is a cabdriver, and her mother, Rose, is a factory worker -- left for Brooklyn in search of a new and better life. She said the most autobiographical aspect of the book is the heroine's emotional reaction to coming to America. Like Sophie, Ms. Danticat said it left her feeling severed from her roots.
"The first time was when my mother left, when I was 4," Ms. Danticat said. "I remember vividly being yanked from her as she was getting on the plane. The second time was coming here. My uncle had a laryngectomy. At that time I was the only person who could read his lips and understand what he was saying. Without me he would have had no voice."
Ms. Danticat began working on what became her first novel soon after she arrived in Brooklyn, in 1981. Taunted at school for her Creole lilt and her not-so-hip wardrobe and coiffure, she found solace in her writing. Even her dimpled and expansive smile faded as she recalled the painful memories of those early years in New York.
"It was very hard," she said, shifting in her chair as if to dispel an intense feeling that was still with her. " 'Haitian' was like a curse. People were calling you, 'Frenchy, go back to the banana boat,' and a lot of the kids would lie about where they came from. They would say anything but Haitian."
It was a time when the bodies of Haitian boat people routinely washed up on the beaches of South Florida. The early 1980's was also a time when Haitians were officially classified as a high-risk group for AIDS by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.
Her love for Haiti and things Haitian, of which she spoke again and again in the course of a day's visit, was deepened by memories of neighbors in her first building who helped her through the tough years.
On Sundays, they shared pumpkin soups, as people do in Haiti. They looked after each other.
"It was a . . . la cour," she said, referring to a Haitian courtyard, where almost communal living is commonplace among the poor, especially in the countryside. "It was a shelter in a storm."
The ambiance at that building, in Flatbush, was not too different from that in Bel Air, the teeming Port-au-Prince slum where Ms. Danticat spent 12 years before coming to America.
"This friend of mine kept saying that in Haiti his mother had a maid, but here his mother is a maid," she said. "I can be friends with women that, if we lived in Haiti, our paths would never cross. People where I was from were the maids."
Ms. Danticat, however, has become a quintessential Haitian-American, living in both worlds and speaking flawless American English interrupted with an occasional Creole word.
She dresses smartly and conservatively. On this day she was wearing an ankle-length black skirt , a black sweater and moccasins; her hair was in long, narrow braids. She looked every bit the Barnard College and Brown University graduate that she is.
She has blended her two worlds, and when she talks about her beloved East Flatbush, her delight shows through.
She relishes the sounds of calypso, compa and reggae that thunder from the assorted shops along Avenue D in the East 40's, a stone's throw from her parents' home. The conversations on the streets are enlivened by hints of the Caribbean, peppered with a Haitian Creole clip here and a Spanish intonation there.
In fact, after living in Providence, R.I., where she earned a Master of Fine Arts degree at Brown, she craved the familiarity of East Flatbush and rushed back to Brooklyn and her family, which includes three brothers -- Eliab, 24, a teacher in the Bronx, and Kelly, 20, and Carl, 18, both college students.
"To me, Brooklyn is the world," she says, adding that she tells people she is from Brooklyn by way of Haiti. "I can eat Haitian food or any food I want. You just can't get that anywhere."
In the tradition of Haitian families, where art and literature are seen more as pastimes than vocations, her parents still think of her as unemployed.
But she is very much at work.
A tiny room on the second floor, decorated with her Alpha Kappa Alpha relics and African tarot stickers, serves as her bedroom and office.
She writes on a Macintosh that is perched on a desk under a loft bed. It is there she completed a second book, "Krik? Krak!," a collection of short stories to be published by Soho in April. She is doing research on another novel about Haitian sugar-cane cutters in the Dominican Republic.
When she rejoined her family in New York in 1981, Ms. Danticat told her father of her aspiration to become a writer. But he had other ideas. He told her she could write on weekends. A more respectable profession like medicine would be more suitable, he thought.
"My parents think that it's a hobby that ended up well," she said of her writing. "The only time that my work seemed honorable was when they came to the book party. That's when they finally grasped the importance of it."
During her high school years, Ms. Danticat said, she barely spoke above a whisper because she was embarrassed by her accent, which has now faded to almost nothing.
Having published her novel, she has to wear the mantle of being "the voice" of Haitian-Americans. It is a responsibility that she has accepted hesitantly.
"I think I have been assigned that role, but I don't really see myself as the voice for the Haitian-American experience," she said. "There are many. I'm just one."

LENGTH: 358 words

HEADLINE: Public Television and 'Elitism'

 BODY:
When the new Congress swept into Washington, budget axes at the ready, the Public Broadcasting Service became a prime candidate for the chopping block. PBS was an "elitist" enterprise, the ax-men said, a frothy confection of opera and animal programs, aimed at the rich folks up East. But a poll conducted this month by the respected Opinion Research Corporation of Princeton for PBS finds broad, bipartisan support for the very system that many in Congress seem bent on dismantling.
The poll, which sampled 1,005 Americans age 18 and above, reveals an especially deep concern about the declining quality of programming on commercial television; 82 percent believed that commercial television was too violent, especially for young chilren. Nearly 85 percent of the respondents said Congress should either maintain public television's funding at current levels or increase it -- with nearly half of those who responded advocating an increase. Support for public television was broadly bipartisan, reaching 80 percent among Republicans, 86 percent among independents and 90 percent among Democrats. Nine in ten respondents disputed the charge that public television is "elitist," saying that PBS programming offered something for people from just about all backgrounds, regardless of education and income. 
 Government funds support a mere 14 percent of the PBS budget, at a cost of $1.09 per American per year, but they provide a crucial core of support to generate additional contributions. The myth of "elitism" is exposed by the way the money is actually spent. WNET-TV in New York City receives 7.78 percent of its money from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting; the rest comes from private sources. But WJWJ-TV in Beaufort, S.C., gets 55.3 percent of its budget from the corporation.
The richer stations could survive without public money. The poorer, often rural stations could not. The collapse of government funding would lead to a truly elitist system, with the richer regions having access to quality and educational programming and the poorer regions left to the mercy of the marketplace, meaning commercial television.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 468 words

HEADLINE: A Proposal Worth Fighting For

 BODY:
On three separate occasions during his State of the Union address, President Clinton declared that he and the Republicans must work to "build the middle class and shrink the underclass." He said too many Americans had been left behind by the economy's recovery, and he offered several remedies. One was new -- raising the minimum wage. One was old -- cutting taxes on the middle class. The others consisted mainly of limp warnings to Republicans not to pass irresponsible welfare programs or constitutional amendments.
The minimum-wage proposal is worth fighting for. It would fulfill the President's campaign pledge to make work pay -- by which he meant that full-time workers should earn enough to raise their families out of poverty. Mr. Clinton said he would let Congress write a minimum-wage bill and decide how much the rate should be raised, a strategy reaffirmed by his aides today. He needs to be more assertive and shoot for a $5-an-hour minimum. 
 He reaffirmed an earlier pledge to trim taxes on the middle class while warning that he would reject a tax cut that "explodes the deficit." He was less forthright on other issues. He opposed punitive welfare reform, but did not threaten to veto a G.O.P. attempt to strip welfare programs of the guarantee that Congress would provide money to serve every eligible family. Mr. Clinton said he would fight a balanced-budget amendment but, oddly, he did not reject outright an idea he knows is rancid.
Some Administration officials have recommended raising the minimum wage from $4.25 an hour to $5. At that level, a fully employed parent of two children would earn almost $10,500, and could also qualify for a tax credit -- in effect a cash rebate -- of up to $3,500 and food stamps worth about $3,000. After subtracting payroll taxes, the family would keep about $16,000 -- enough to lift it out of poverty.
The G.O.P. objects because higher wages, it says, threaten to strip low-wage workers of their jobs. The evidence is mixed, but most research shows that employment effects are small, perhaps trivial. Research also shows that most minimum-wage workers are adults, not teen-agers. Nor can Washington achieve the same end by boosting the tax credit alone; the complexity of this credit creates a strong disincentive to work at higher wages.
Sadly, the Republicans seem viscerally opposed to Mr. Clinton's proposal -- even though his small hike would leave minimum wages, after accounting for inflation, well below levels that prevailed in the 1970's.
Though Mr. Clinton drew few sharp lines Tuesday night, fudging on the balanced budget amendment and on the G.O.P.'s welfare bills, he scored a rhetorical hit on the minimum wage -- pointing out that his audience earned more in a month than minimum-wage workers earn in a year.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: THE VOTERS;
Some Who Like What They Heard but Are Sure They've Heard It Before

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIVER GROVE, Ill., Jan. 25

 BODY:
Frank Faruggia's family and half a dozen friends, frequent guests in a household that always seems to be bustling with them, sat watching the State of the Union address on a television set in the Faruggias' kitchen on Tuesday night.
As President Clinton spoke of coming "to this hallowed chamber two years ago on a mission," admitted that he had made some mistakes since then but told too of the lower unemployment and inflation the country had experienced under his stewardship, Mr. Faruggia just stroked his beard. 
 As the President declared that he was "proud to say tonight that our country is stronger that it was two years ago," Mr. Faruggia's friend John Valentino, a plant engineer, lighted another Marlboro.
As the President resurrected his "new covenant" and spoke of plans to ease the financial burdens of the middle class, Mr. Faruggia looked over at Mr. Valentino, and the two of them laughed.
"New Deal, New Society, New Contract, New Covenant," Mr. Faruggia said. "Same dragon, different head."
It was as if they had heard all this before, they said. And although they could not find much to disagree with in the President's speech -- who is against welfare reform or less bureaucracy, they asked -- they doubted that Mr. Clinton or even the new Congress would do much of anything.
"It's like a cheap life vest," Mr. Faruggia, a 40-year-old part-time police officer who owns a hot dog stand and repairs cars on the side, said of the speech. "It'll float two or three weeks, and then it'll go down the tubes."
The skepticism runs deep in this working-class Chicago suburb of 10,000 people, where a few elections ago most people would tell you they were Democrats but where last November most people went Republican like the rest of the country. This used to be Dan Rostenkowski territory. But in November the former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee lost by 66 percent to 34 percent here in River Grove to Michael Flanagan, an unemployed lawyer who had never held elective office but who was Republican in a Republican year.
This used to be Clinton country as well. But since the President's election, Loretta Page, Democratic precinct captain, has become Loretta Page, Republican precinct captain.
"I was a Bill Clinton fan," said Mrs. Page, who watched the President's address in her own home, not far from the Faruggias'. "I voted for him because he made you feel good, and it helps he's good-looking. But I think, 'Poor Clinton, he tried to bite the whole apple and swallow it.' He needed to pick something and stay with it."
He vacillated, she said, on welfare, could not get a health care overhaul passed and seems ineffectual to her. So she is a Republican now. "We have changed here in the village," she said.
In Mr. Clinton's address, Mrs. Page heard nothing to pull her back to the Democrats. Not that she disagreed with much of what he had said. She supports the assault-rifle ban enacted last year, his call for changes in the health care and welfare systems, and the minimum-wage increase he spoke of. "You couldn't disagree with it," she said. "It was so generic. You hear it over and over and over. How many times can you hear it and you don't see any result from what you're hearing?"
She began reciting her disappointments. "Remember a year ago he said he would not sign a health care bill except his own?" she said. "He came on strong. What did we get? We got zero."
Yes, she said, she knew that Congress had not come up with a health care bill and had sidetracked the Clinton plan. "But you see, he's the head," Mrs. Page said. "It was up to him to muster support or do whatever he had to do."
But some of those skeptical of Mr. Clinton said they would not write him off just yet. Similarly they said they would not necessarily vote for a Republican Presidential candidate next time, with Republicans already in control of Congress. "Right now we got enough of them in there," Mr. Faruggia said. "Too many is not good."
Nor do they necessarily see the new Speaker of the House as their leader of choice. People in River Grove are still asking themselves, Who is this Newt Gingrich, and how did he become whoever he is so fast?
"You'd think he was just given the throne next to Jesus," said Donald Gedeon, a retired X-ray installer who voted Reagan, Reagan, Bush, Clinton in the last four Presidential elections and now has his doubts about both parties.
"I think everybody's given up on these politicians," Mr. Gedeon said. "No matter who's in, they can't do the job. We got the budget deficit, the trade deficit. We got this crime coming in and drugs coming in by the warehouse-load. We got the education system coming apart at the seams. Everywhere you look, we got a tragedy.
"We need to all go to church and pray this all works out. They say when there's nowhere to go, you'll go to you knees." ISABEL WILKERSON

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Faruggia, his daughter Frankie and his wife, Rosalie, were joined by family and guests when the President spoke. "It's like a cheap life vest," Mr. Faruggia said of the speech afterward. "It'll float two or three weeks, and then it'll go down the tubes." (Paul Merideth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Third-World Quebec

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Jan. 24 Business Day article on Canada's weak dollar: Such problems will continue as long as the Quebec elite persist in their quest for power under the guise of independence. With companies just beginning again to invest in Canada, another referendum this year will renew the age-old doubt that may pull Canada back into recession. 
 While independence will spell economic strife for Canada, it will mean catastrophe for Quebec; the United States will have a third-world country north as well as south of the border.
 
NIGEL WRIGHT
New York, Jan. 24, 1995

HEADLINE: In Congress, A Wave Of Humbleness

BYLINE: By JENNIFER SENIOR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
After months of depicting Washington as a den of spoiled scamps, the 86 newly elected members of the House of Representatives have made an alarming discovery: they have to live here.
Suddenly, looking like a Washington outsider is dreadfully inconvenient. Living near the Capitol is key. Long hours are unavoidable. So the freshmen, faced with the grim realities of legislative life, are nearly collapsing on themselves to show that their spiritual roots are still back in their districts. And they have dingy, gloomy, tiny digs in Washington to prove it. 
 "I think they're putting up lean-tos in front of the Supreme Court," Representative Barney Frank, a longtime Democrat from Massachusetts, said, rolling his eyes. "They've got this downscale competition going on: 'I have a smaller apartment than yours. My furniture is shabbier than yours.' It's vogue to minimize your contact with this place."
Never mind that many of the new members of this class come from some of the nation's toniest neighborhoods. Never mind that some of these freshmen spent hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of their own fortunes to defeat their opponents. Now that they have arrived on Capitol Hill, many of them say they are living lives of collegiate austerity, cramming themselves into tiny studio apartments, sleeping in twin beds, purchasing furniture at Ikea.
"They're afraid of giving the impression that Tom Foley did," said Peter Tierney, the Congressional liaison at Yarmouth Management, a property management company on Capitol Hill. Mr. Foley, the defeated Speaker of the House, owns a legendarily beautiful town house near the Capitol, complete with a lap swimming pool in the backyard.
"They say that they want a place to sleep and that's it," Mr. Tierney added.
The desire to appear unentrenched is particularly urgent among the 73 new Republican Representatives, many of whom campaigned for term limits and decried the complacency of Democratic incumbents. Nearly all of them make a point of saying that they are not bringing their families to Washington. And few are buying places of their own, even though it may be more cost-effective than renting.
"My wife and I had a choice between renting a nice place far from the Capitol or a dump nearby," said Representative Jon Christensen, Republican of Nebraska, who ran campaign advertisements showing pictures of his opponent's half-a-million-dollar home in Chevy Chase, Md. "We chose the dump."
Representative Mark Sanford, Republican of South Carolina whose net worth is roughly $ 1 million, according to his office, is sleeping on a a single futon in his office, he said, because he does not want to attach himself to Washington.
During his campaign, Representative Zach Wamp, Republican of Tennessee, went so far as to propose that the Government build officer-style quarters for members of Congress at two military bases near Washington. When he brought the idea up in Washington, it didn't go over well with his peers.
Representative Wamp is living in a hotel. "I'd rather not own any furniture in Washington," he said. "This forces me to go back to my district."
Austerity, of course, is relative. Representative Wamp, though he may not be investing in furniture, is still spending $ 70 for every night he passes at the Capitol Hill Suites. (He said he hoped to be in Washington no more than 12 nights a month.) And while it may be humble by Capitol Hill standards, Representative Christensen's two-bedroom apartment rents for $ 900 a month -- about the going rate, said Buck Waller, a property manager at Yarmouth Management.
Over the last two decades, members of the House have been living increasingly rootless and humble lives, Congressional scholars said. They pointed out that now many of the members have working wives or husbands who can't simply pick up and leave their jobs. And owning two homes, after all, is extremely expensive, considering that Representatives are paid $ 133,644 -- a pay cut for many of them -- and do not receive a housing allowance. Representatives are also getting younger -- 59 percent of this year's freshmen are 45 or younger -- which often means that they have young children.
"As a mom, I know I can't uproot my children in the middle of a semester," said Sheila Jackson Lee, a newly elected Democrat of Texas. But transience, some freshmen are realizing, also comes at a price.
"Most are frightened about the prospect of leaving their families, yet they've made their commitments," said Mark Foley, a freshman Republican of Florida. "They're honor bound not to settle here, with their discussions of term limit and so on. But I've seen them moping."
Peter Hoagland, the defeated Nebraska Democrat, said he bought his half-million-dollar house in Maryland because he wanted to be with his five children. "That kind of bogus campaign rhetoric, in the end, is going to discourage members of Congress from bringing their families out here, and it will make the House even less family-friendly than it already is," he said last month as he was packing up his office.
Because the Washington housing market currently favors buyers, a few freshmen who can afford a second home are kicking themselves for having eliminated the option of buying one.
"I pledged in my primary campaign not to buy a home," said Representative Jerry Weller, Republican of Illinois. "It has limited my options. It probably would be more economically efficient to purchase a condo somewhere."
According to seasoned realtors in this city, freshmen aren't living all that differently from some of the most seasoned lawmakers on Capitol Hill; they're just a bit louder about living low on the hog.
Newt Gingrich, Speaker of the House, lives in a small, rented apartment on Capitol Hill. Dick Armey, the new House majority leader, slept in the members' gym for a year until then-Speaker Thomas O'Neill Jr. kicked him out. When Representative Sanford unrolls his futon in his office, he joins a fraternity of Congressmen who sleep in their offices, including Representative John Linder, Republican of Georgia.
Several longtime Democratic Representatives have been crowding together for years. Charles E. Schumer of New York, Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut and George Miller of California share a two-bedroom town house on Capitol Hill. Representatives Schumer and Gejdenson sleep in the living room.
"The arrangement includes cookies," said Representative Miller, who owns the apartment and has a wife and five children back in Martinez, Calif. "I do the laundry, and Durbin traps the rats."
The churlishness of last year's electorate has also made the freshmen nervous about settling in. "Once I begin to look at this place as my home, I'm sure the voters of my district will want to return me to Rhode Island for good," said Patrick J. Kennedy, a new Democratic Representative who watched his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, endure a close race before winning last November.
Every class has its exceptions. Sonny Bono, the singer-turned-mayor-turned-Republican Congressman, has purchased a $ 600,000 town house in Hillandale, a gated community in the city's Georgetown section. He will move in with his wife and two young children.
"When I was wrapped up in a celebrity career, I wasn't as solid on the family end," said Mr. Bono, who also has two grown children from previous marriages. "Now, I'm able to rectify that."
Perhaps the most surprising potential-buyer exception is Representative George Nethercutt, Republican of Washington, who handily defeated Speaker Foley after portraying him as the ultimate victim of Washingtonitis. The Representative is hoping to buy a house for his family right outside Washington.
"Do I want to spend $ 2,000 or $ 3,000 in rent, or toward a mortgage?" he said. "It's simply economic for me."
Could purchasing a home send the wrong message to his constituents?
 "There's a certain reality to this life of being a member of Congress," he said. "I think the voters understand that. Besides, I can always sell it."
 The article also misstated the number of children of Representative George Miller, Democrat of California. He has two children, not five.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Home Section last Thursday about the living quarters of some members of Congress referred incorrectly to Representative John Linder, Republican of Georgia. He has a town house in Washington; he does not sleep in his office.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steady, With Report On Economic Growth Due

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies as dealers waited for today's report on the gross domestic product for further clues about the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates.
Many dealers said they already expected the Fed to raise rates by half a percentage point. A robust G.D.P. report could prompt the Fed to raise rates more steeply, they said. Higher rates make dollar-denominated investments and deposits more attractive. 
 "If the Fed doesn't raise rates by half a percent, the dollar will be in big trouble," said Laurence Hayward, a currency dealer at Nationsbank of Texas in Houston. "People expect them to do at least that much."
The dollar is likely to gain if the gross domestic product figures show that the economy grew at an annual rate of 4.6 percent or more during the fourth quarter, Mr. Hayward and other dealers said. It rose at an annual rate of 4 percent in the third quarter.
Yesterday, in late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.5177 German marks from 1.5167 on Wednesday. It slipped to 99.40 Japanese yen from 99.52 yen. The dollar was unchanged against the Swiss franc, at 1.2765 francs. The British pound fell to $1.5905 from $1.5915.
Earlier in the day, the dollar had slumped amid concern that Congress would not approve the Clinton Administration's proposed $40 billion loan-guarantee package for Mexico.
Turmoil in Mexico's financial markets hurts the dollar because of the close economic ties between the two countries. Mexico is the United States' third-largest trading partner. Since the Mexican Government devalued the peso, it has fallen 37.6 percent against the dollar.
"The Mexico package is key, and the dollar will ultimately suffer if it doesn't go through or if it has too many conditions attached to it," said Peter Wilson, a bond analyst at the Nomura Research Institute in London.
Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, told Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, at a Congressional hearing today that the aid effort was "collapsing in dramatic fashion." His comments renewed doubts on the plan's future.
The dollar rebounded later, after the International Monetary Fund said it had reached a tentative agreement to extend $7.8 billion in loans to help the Mexican Government resolve its financial crisis.

HEADLINE: Dow Slips by 1.01 in Restrained Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market ended another erratic session with little change yesterday in restrained trading, as traders awaited the Commerce Department's estimate today of fourth-quarter economic growth.
As such, the market continued on the trend that it has followed now for six straight sessions, in which it ended with little change but showed pronounced volatility during the day. 
 Traders say that pattern is likely to persist until next Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve concludes its two-day policy meeting to decide whether or by how much to raise interest rates.
"We're going to jump around up and down, but at the end of the day we'll be pretty flat," said David H. Butler, director of equity trading at Kemper Financial Securities Inc.
Yesterday was typical. After the Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 18 points by 12:30 P.M., it rose another 17 points before finally closing at 3,870.44, down 1.01 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.88 point, to 468.32, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 3.41 points, to 757.57.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 312 million shares changing hands, about 4 percent below this year's daily average of 324 million shares.
"It was a very confusing day," said Bill Allyn, director of listed trading at Jefferies & Company. He noted that corporate earnings reports were strong so far, which is normally bullish for stocks. "But the market would be up a lot more if there wasn't this uncertainty about interest rates hanging over everything."
Many traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates by at least half a percentage point, so stock and bond prices are likely to show little reaction if the Fed does indeed announce such a rate increase.
But a rate increase of less than half a percentage point might be viewed as a drag on the market because traders would suspect that the Fed was weakening in its fervor to fight inflation, analysts say. Conversely, a larger increase of, say, three-quarters a percentage point might signal to markets that the Fed was finished raising interest rates for the year. Markets would probably rally then, Mr. Butler of Kemper Securities said.
The big newsmaker of the day, and the most active stock at some 14.5 million shares, was Dr. Pepper/7Up, which hit a 52-week high of 32 5/8 before closing at 32 1/2, up 2. Dr. Pepper's board accepted a $2.5 billion buyout offer from Cadbury Schweppes of Britain.
Affymax, a Netherlands-based pharmaceuticals company, also established a 52-week high of 30 before closing at 29 1/2, up 11. Glaxo the British pharmaceuticals giant, offered to pay $485 million, or $30 a share, for Affymax.
In still more merger news, Hillhaven, a hospital-management company, touched a 52-week high of 26 7/8 and closed at 26 1/4, up 3 3/8. Horizon Healthcare, a rival, made a surprise bid for Hillhaven, offering $28 a share. Hillhaven said it would study the proposal.
Bertucci's, a pizzeria chain, hit a 52-week low of 7 before closing at 8 1/2, down 2 1/4. Bertucci's said its fourth-quarter earnings were likely to be unchanged from the year before and that sales were "disappointing."
ALC Communications, a long-distance telecommunications company, dropped 2 1/2, to 28 1/2, after it reported fourth-quarter net of 45 cents a share, 3 cents below Wall Street expectations.
Gentex, an auto parts maker, fell 3 1/8, to 22 3/4, after it reported fourth-quarter net of 26 cents a share, one cent short of analyst projections.
And Singer, the sewing-machine maker, established a 52-week low of 25 3/8 before closing at 25 1/2, down 2 7/8. It reported fourth-quarter net unchanged at 69 cents a share.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.51 point, to 254.92. Advancing stocks almost equaled declining stocks, with 1,115 gainers and 1,019 decliners. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.78 point, to 437.74.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up in Price For 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were up yesterday for the second consecutive day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Budget Committee that the "torrid growth is slowing down."
In a clear sign that investors are confident the Fed will not quickly raise interest rates again if it nudges them up next week, as expected, prices of Government securities rose in all maturities. While Mr. Greenspan, in a second day of Congressional testimony, warned of a possible rise in inflation in the near term, he said it "can be contained by the Fed." 
 The central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy for the months ahead, meets Tuesday and Wednesday.
Yesterday, the 30-year bond rose 12/32 , to a price of 965/32 , to yield 7.83 percent, down from 7.87 percent on Wednesday, its lowest in a week. In the last two days the market has rallied a full point in price, or about $10 for every $1,000 in bonds that investors hold.
Early yesterday, the Commerce Department's latest report on durable goods showed a rise of 1.4 percent in December, after a 3.2 percent gain in November. But durable goods orders outside military orders fell eight-tenths of a percent.
Ronald R. Reuss, chief economist at Piper Capital Management, in Minneapolis, said that the market responded when Mr. Greenspan said that the torrid pace of economic growth was slowing. "If the economy can slow to a 2 to 3 percent growth mode it will take pressure off the Fed from continuing to raise rates," Mr. Reuss said.
"We still expect the Fed to raise rates next week, because there is still insufficient evidence of a slowing," he said. "The first signs were in the retail numbers at year-end, and now we would expect housing to slow along with exports because of the devaluation in Mexico, and because it raises the price of American goods substantially."
Most market participants still expect the Fed to raise interest rates 50 basis points next week in an attempt to insure that the economy slows enough to contain inflation. "But at the same time the Fed must be careful as the economy slows, it does not want to remain too tight, for too long," Mr. Reuss said.
Municipal bond prices were little changed for a second day as investors concentrated on this week's $2.7 billion supply of new debt.
Bonds from New York City's $658 million debt offering started trading in the secondary market, with the 7 1/4 percent bond due 2024 up a half- point to a price of 99 to yield 7.33 percent. When the bond was sold on Tuesday it was yielding 7.37 percent, 15 basis points higher than had been expected. That reflected concern that the city's $650 million budget deficit for the 1995 fiscal year could cause the rating agencies to downgrade the city's debt and make it more expensive to borrow.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
COCA-COLA CO. (KO,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings jumped 22 percent on strong volume increases, particularly in foreign markets.
The world's largest beverage company reported net income of $567 million, or 44 cents a share, up from $466 million, or 36 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier. 
 Per-share earnings matched the mean estimate of 15 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Revenue climbed 19 percent, to $4.02 billion from $3.37 billion.
International volume in cases increased 13 percent in the quarter, exceeding Coke's estimate last month that it would rise 10 percent to 12 percent. The company said its international volume had increased by double-digit percentages for the last six months. Domestic volume rose 8 percent in the quarter.
For the year, Coke's net income increased 17 percent, to $2.55 billion, or $1.98 a share, from $2.18 billion, or $1.67, in 1993. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $16.17 billion.
International soft drink operating income rose 18 percent in 1994 on volume growth, price increases in line with inflation, improved efficiencies and the effects of a weak dollar, Coke said. The company did not disclose its operating income gain for the United States.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A theory says even the Dow doesn't like San Diego's chances.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
POOR San Diego. Even the stock market seems to be forecasting that the Chargers will lose the Super Bowl.
That forecast comes from a theory that says the performance of the stock market in the two months leading to the Super Bowl can indicate which team will win. It makes no sense, of course, but it has worked well during the last two decades. 
 The theory, introduced in this column six years ago, holds that the franchise ranking first in the alphabet -- in this case, San Diego, as it faces the San Francisco 49ers -- will win if the stock market has gone down from the end of November through game day.
Unfortunately for the Chargers, the Dow Jones industrial average ended November at 3,739.23, and since has risen to 3,870.44. Barring a collapse in trading today, the stock market will have voted with the bookies, who have installed the 49ers as 18 1/2-point favorites.
Just why, you might be asking, should the Dow have anything to do with the Super Bowl? It doesn't, but Wall Street has long searched for a connection, or at least a correlation. A theory saying that the Super Bowl forecasts the stock market has been around for years, and has done surprisingly well, though last year's game provided a forecast that would not work out unless the Dow zoomed to at least 3,945.43 today.
With that theory in mind, this column set out six years ago to use the stock market to forecast the football game. We introduced a theory that during the previous 14 years would have correctly forecast 12 of the games, using a simple alphabetical approach. Since then, it has gotten five of six correct, raising its record during two decades to 17 of 20.
That is not bad. During the same period, the favorite team in Las Vegas betting has managed to win only 15 of 19 times. (One game, in 1982, went off with no favorite, and so does not count.)
The theory is that if the Dow rises from the end of November to the Super Bowl, then the franchise from later in the alphabet will win. Most times the market goes up, and most times the team from later in the alphabet wins. It has been the misfortune of the American Football Conference, which has lost 10 consecutive games, to often be represented by teams from early in the alphabet. The theory holds they will win only if the Dow has dropped before the game.
The only times in the last two decades that the theory has failed to work were in 1982, 1986 and 1990.
As it happens, San Francisco was involved in two of those games, winning despite the fact the market had fallen coming into the Super Bowls of 1982, when it beat Cincinnati, and 1990, when Denver was the loser. In the other failure, a rising market did not help New England, when it lost to Chicago in 1986.
As for the better-known Super Bowl indicator, which uses the results of the game to forecast the market, the theory is that if a team from the old National Football League wins the game, the stock market will go up in the following year. If one from the old American Football League wins, the market will go down.
Last year's Super Bowl victory by the Dallas Cowboys (old N.F.L.) over the Buffalo Bills (old A.F.L.) forecast a rising stock market. Unfortunately, that is not what happened. Since the last Super Bowl, the Dow is down. As a result -- and barring a big rise today -- that indicator's record of forecasting the stock market is now 24 of 28, with failures after the 1970, 1987, 1990 and 1994 games.
Anyone who thinks either of those indicators makes any sense, or should be relied upon in buying stocks or betting on football games, probably should not be permitted to manage his or her own money. But such a person might be interested in the following forecast: If San Diego does win the Super Bowl, the economy will tank in 1995.
That is based on the fact that the last three years that saw at least one quarter of decline in gross domestic product were 1982, 1986 and 1990. Those were also the years that the stock market failed to forecast the results of the Super Bowl.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Durable Goods' Best Rise in 16 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Factory orders for durable goods like cars and computers rose 1.4 percent in December, capping the biggest annual increase in 16 years, the Commerce Department said today
But analysts noted the strength at the end of the year came from military and transportation orders. Excluding those components, demand was much weaker than it appeared. 
 Orders for durable goods -- products expected to last three years or longer -- totaled a seasonally adjusted $161.4 billion in December. It was the second straight advance, including a 3.2 percent gain to $159.1 billion in November. Orders dropped eight-tenths of a percent in October.
The December increase helped push orders for 1994 up 13.9 percent, the biggest advance since an 18.3 percent surge in 1978. Orders rose 8.6 percent increase in 1993.
"Over all, the report still shows strength in the manufacturing sector, but there are a few signs of softness emerging," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
These signs, she said, include a possible drop in retail sales during the December shopping season and a recent buildup of inventories at the wholesale level that could mean fewer orders as businesses clear excess stocks from their shelves.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, testifying on Capitol Hill for the second straight day, said there were signs that the buoyant economy was "simmering down."
"The very torrid rate of increase is slowing down," Mr. Greenspan told members of the Senate Budget Committee. "It's no longer flat out. Fairly good moderate growth is occurring."
Nonetheless, most economists expect the Federal Reserve to increase short-term interest rates next week for the seventh time in a year in an attempt to insure that the economy cools off enough to keep inflation from accelerating.
In another report, the Labor Department said first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 13,000 last week to a seasonally adjusted 325,000, lowest since 321,000 during the week ended Dec. 24.
New jobless claims had risen to 354,000 during the week ended Jan. 7, mostly as a result of seasonal factors. In its durable-goods report, the Commerce Department said military orders shot up 65 percent last month, led by large increases for ships and tanks. Excluding the military component, orders dropped eight-tenths of a percent.
Military orders are often volatile, Ms. Reaser noted, adding that "the increase is not going to be an ongoing factor." Military orders fell 6.2 percent in November and 16.3 percent in October.
The orders for ships and tanks also helped drive the transportation sector up 5.4 percent. Without this sector, orders were up just one-tenth of a percent.
Other increases included primary metals, up 5.2 percent, and electronic and other electrical equipment, up 3 percent. But orders for industrial machinery and equipment were down 5 percent, the second dip in a row.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft were down four-tenths of a percent, the second monthly decline. These orders often are a barometer of business investment plans.
But unfilled orders rose seven-tenths of a percent, the fourth consecutive advance, suggesting the need for faster production and more jobs.
Shipments increased seven-tenths of a percent, the seventh gain in a row.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
 While much of the Northeast remains in the doldrums, Massachusetts, the state hit hardest in the recession, is coming back. But this recovery is different. Big manufacturers like General Electric and Digital Equipment are on the sidelines. Massachusetts is counting on small companies to provide jobs. [Page A1.] 
 The Justice Department's antitrust division is investigating efforts by insurers to prevent banks from issuing annuities. [D1.]
 Factory orders for durable goods rose 1.4 percent in December, capping the biggest annual increase in 16 years. [D2.]
 
Companies
 Wellcome rejected an unsolicited $14 billion takeover offer made by Glaxo as inadequate, but put itself up for sale in hopes of attracting a better offer. [D1.] Glaxo agreed to acquire Affymax, a drug discovery company, for about $533 million. [D5.]
 Dr Pepper/Seven-Up agreed to be bought by Cadbury Schweppes for $1.7 billion. The combination of the two soda makers would have a 17 percent share of the American market. [D1.]
 Horizon Healthcare offered $1.5 billion for Hillhaven in a bid to create one of the nation's largest nursing home chains. [D1.]
 Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines posted weak financial results, and Continental Airlines projected a loss. [D2.]
 Teledyne agreed to pay $13 million to settle charges that the company illegally exported tons of weapons-grade material. [D2.]
 Spectrum Information Technologies said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. [D2.]
 Paine Webber said its fourth-quarter earnings fell 71 percent, excluding a charge for its purchase of Kidder, Peabody. [D2.]
 J. P. Morgan confirmed that it planned to lay off some of its staff because of leaner times in securities markets. [D3.]
 Scotts agreed to acquire Stern's Miracle-Gro Products, creating the world's largest maker of lawn and garden products. [D3.]
 Procter & Gamble said it would take a $50 million after-tax charge to cover its losses from the earthquake in Kobe, Japan. [D3.]
 MCI Communications reported that revenue in the last three months of 1994 climbed 9 percent. [D3.]
 The National Transportation Safety Board's chief said Boeing had not told all it knew about incidents involving its 737 jets. [A12.]
 
International
 The International Monetary Fund tentatively agreed to lend Mexico $7.8 billion. [A10.] Mexican officials denied that they would make political concessions to the U.S. in return for $40 billion in loan guarantees. [A10.]
 
Markets
 Mutual fund managers reported a surprisingly good first month of 1995 in cash flow. Bargain hunters are buying Latin American stock funds. Domestic stock and bond funds are also up. [D1.]
 Prices of Treasury securities rose after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, warned of a possible rise in inflation but also said it "can be contained by the Fed." [D5.]
 The stock market ended another erratic session with little change. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.88 point, to 468.32. [D6.]
 Cotton prices jumped to a three-and-a-half-year high amid rising demand at home and abroad. [D15.]
 The dollar was steady against most leading currencies. [D15.]

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A2-A10
 
RUSSIANS ACCUSED OF BRUTALITY
Grozny residents say Russian troops have turned increasingly brutal now that they control much of the Chechen rebels' capital. A1
 
MOSCOW'S MONEY PROBLEMS GROW
Russia has dug itself into a hole with Western Governments and with the I.M.F., which is currently debating a $6 billion loan that Moscow is counting on. A6
