HEADLINE: Small Companies Lead Way As Massachusetts Rebounds

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The empty, unrented buildings along Boylston Street are beginning to fill with freshly painted shops and coffee bars. Not far away, Fidelity Investments' new trading room, larger than a football field, juts into Boston harbor like a brilliantly lighted luxury ship boarding for its maiden voyage. And along Route 128, the suburban highway where the now-shrunken computer giants of the 1980's got their start, new stars with names like Powersoft are emerging.
The signs of economic revival have been unmistakable for months. While the rest of the Northeast remains in the doldrums, Massachusetts, hit harder in the last recession than any other state, is coming back. But this recovery is different. The state's big manufacturers like General Electric and Digital Equipment -- engines of growth in the past -- are on the sidelines. Instead, more than ever, the people of Massachusetts are counting on small, little-known companies to give them work. 
 These particular small companies make the Massachusetts recovery a microcosm of the sort of economic growth that may give the United States an edge in global markets, in the view of many economists and policy makers. The recovery is led mostly by high-tech operations that hire the nimble and the very skilled to turn out pioneering products and develop new services ahead of anyone else.
But there is a catch. These companies, like similar operations elsewhere, offer few jobs to former assembly-line workers. Tens of thousands of these workers lost their jobs here when the boom that former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis touted as the Massachusetts Miracle collapsed more than five years ago.
"I think that a 'recovery with holes in it' is a not-unfair characterization of what is going on in Massachusetts," Gov. William F. Weld said in an interview. Nor does he hold out hope that many production workers who lost their jobs will see their old wages of $13 to $16 an hour. Standard manufacturing, even of computers, is dying in Massachusetts, he said, and "no governor better try to swim against the tide on that one, or you are destined to failure."
Going with the tide, Governor Weld has presided over a recovery that has added back nearly half of the 355,000 jobs lost since late 1988. In retrospect, the economy hit bottom in 1992, a year after Mr. Weld, a Republican, took office. But the job growth was too spotty until recently for anyone to declare with any certainty that the recovery was for real.
"It is a sober and gritty recovery," said Ira Jackson, a senior vice president at the Bank of Boston. "The hubris and arrogance of the region have been deflated, but we are getting some confidence back."
As always in Massachusetts, the recovery is centered in Boston and environs, where the state's employers are concentrated. Last year's job growth reached 4.7 percent, more than double that of any other Northeastern state and well above the rate for the nation as a whole.
But the rebound is uneven. Boston's famous hospitals, for example, are merging and cutting staff even as medical industry employment is rising smartly at outpatient clinics, for home care, and at H.M.O.'s. Similarly, while several banks failed or merged during the recession, shedding thousands of workers in the process, mutual funds based here are stronger than ever, now managing a fifth of the nation's fund assets.
Fidelity alone has added 2,000 employees since 1992, including many of the 160 young men and women who staff the new trading room. It is built over a wharf in the city's modernistic World Trade Center. Here Fidelity handles a portion of its own vast securities and foreign exchange trading, and increasingly acts as a broker for big institutional investors like pension funds.
"We think if we build a good trading machine," said Sherif A. Nada, president of Fidelity Capital Markets, "we can compete with Goldman, Sachs; Salomon Brothers, and Morgan Stanley for these investors."
But for all of Boston's vigor as a financial center, the heart of this recovery -- and its future -- seems to lie with small, high-tech companies developing and selling new software, medical devices, biotech drugs and telecommunications equipment. They cluster along Routes 128 and 495, which arc around Boston and its universities, the training ground for many high-tech entrepreneurs.
A lot of the small companies fail, of course, driven under by competitors who develop a new software twist, a better medical device or a stronger sales force. And that may prove the Achilles' heel of the recovery. "I would be skeptical that a long wave of economic growth for Massachusetts can be built on the basis of small companies trying to eat one another's lunch," said Bennett Harrison, an economist now teaching at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. "Their life expectancy is too short."
Still, in this expansion many more of these small operations are surviving than failing. As a group they have contributed nearly 40,000 jobs to the state's employment growth since early 1992. Now Governor Weld and his advisers are gambling that at least some of the minor leaguers will hit on popular products and become leading employers, mimicking Microsoft's growth in the Seattle area or Intel's in the Silicon Valley of California.
"We are on an upward curve," said Prof. Michael E. Porter of the Harvard Business School, a Weld adviser. "When a company gets to 500 employees or more, as several have, and then grows at 20 percent a year, you have rapid job creation."
With this model in mind, Mr. Weld has pushed into law several tax cuts and other measures intended to reduce the cost of doing business in the state, and thus make smaller companies more willing to expand here. Home building and retailing, along with other support industries, would then flourish to serve the new, educated workers. And Massachusetts would once again enjoy a prosperity that in the past had depended on manufacturing as a base.
Textile mills and shoe factories made the state wealthy early in the century, and a different set of big manufacturers -- military contractors and minicomputer makers -- performed that role in the 1980's, the next period of great prosperity.
Raytheon and General Electric added tens of thousands of workers in the 1980's to make jet engines, missiles and other weapons, only to lay them off as military spending fell. Similarly, Digital Equipment, Prime Computer, Data General and others took on tens of thousands of workers when their minicomputers became hot sellers worldwide, only to shed them as desktop personal computers displaced the cabinet-sized minicomputers. And as they shrank -- Digital's payroll in the state has fallen to 13,500 people from 34,000 in 1989 -- they gave up their quarters along the Route 128 high-tech corridor to newcomers.
The Powersoft Corporation, for example, which has developed a way to write personal computer software more easily, now occupies the landscaped glass and brick building where Digital's directors once met. Most of Powersoft's 500 employees in the state are college graduates, the norm for these small, information-oriented companies.
That is also the case at the EMC Corporation, which eschews manufacturing, like nearly all of the growing companies in Massachusetts these days. EMC, whose main product is software that permits small storage disks to talk to one another and to big computers, sells the software already embedded in a cabinet-mounted disk system. But the disks themselves and the other equipment are purchased ready-made from suppliers, mostly from out of state. The testing, final assembly and the loading of the software take place at an EMC plant on Route 495.
The manufacturing companies that soared in the 1980's have shed more than 100,000 jobs since 1988, most of them held by workers with only high school diplomas -- forcing these employees to scramble for other work or more schooling, or both.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, in a study of 3,000 former military workers, found that most, after periods of unemployment, did indeed find new work. They went into retailing and office work and jobs like truck drivers, cooks, landscapers and mechanics. Some joined the small machine shops that still dot the state. The unemployment rate, partly in response, has fallen to 5.7 percent from 9.6 percent in May 1991. But they took pay cuts of 20 percent on average, raising an economic quandary that is particularly acute in Massachusetts.
The recovery is fostering, in effect, two sets of workers, two levels of pay, two standards of living and two outlooks on life -- what Sara Johnson, a New England specialist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm in nearby Waltham, calls the "Massachusetts Dichotomy."
Rodney Gagnon, a 26-year-old software engineer, is in the upper tier, where switching jobs is routine rather than wrenching. After graduating in 1990 from the University of Massachusetts, he joined Banyan Systems Inc., whose networking software helps personal computers talk to one another. He left in 1993 for an I.B.M. job in Florida. "I wanted to try a large company and try living in another area," Mr. Gagnon said.
The I.B.M. job soured and Mr. Gagnon rejoined the fast-growing Banyan last July at $45,000, a bit more than his I.B.M. salary and $7,000 above his last wage at Banyan. "I am expecting a promotion in July to senior software engineer and I would guess a raise of 8 percent," he said with confidence.
Susan Comeau, 41, also made the transition from job loss to work, but in the lower tier. Officials at General Electric, which has eliminated 7,000 jobs at its jet engine plant in Lynn, hold her up as model of retraining.
Anticipating a layoff, Ms. Comeau enrolled a couple of years ago as a business student at a local college. "My choice was to retrain and not to beat a dead horse into the ground by trying to match my old salary," she said. She found a marketing job last year at Nutramax Products, which sells eye drops, cough drops, baby products and the like.
The pay is $26,000 a year, far below the $40,000 Ms. Comeau earned after 21 years as a G.E. production worker. Anger about this is self-defeating, Ms. Comeau says, and she must concentrate on her new career in case her husband, still a G.E. employee, loses his job, too.
"Now I'm an apprentice again," she said. "But the potential is there to get my old salary back a few years down the road. That's what keeps me going."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clinton Warns Major Leagues To Settle Strike

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Warning that the major league baseball strike was trying Americans' patience and imperiling thousands of jobs, President Clinton today threw increased White House power behind efforts to force a mediated settlement.
Mr. Clinton ordered a Federal mediator to bring baseball's players and owners back to the bargaining table, and he set a Feb. 6 deadline for them to make substantial headway toward ending the strike. Otherwise, he warned, the Government would ask the mediator to propose a solution. 
 With the start of spring training looming and no settlement in sight, the strong words from the President were reinforced on Capitol Hill, where some members of Congress have threatened to strip baseball of its antitrust exemption if the dispute is not settled.
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, who volunteered his office today as a site for renewed negotiations, did not mention that prospect directly. But he said Congress might have to act in some way. "If the players and owners are unable to find common ground and find it soon," Mr. Dole said, "then we will have to find some way to empower those who are the most important element in the baseball equation, the fans themselves."
Together, their warnings made plain that neither the White House nor Congress wants to be seen as standing by passively now that another baseball season may be in peril. Spring-training camps are due to open on Feb. 16, and the regular season is scheduled to begin on April 2.
But the thrust of Mr. Clinton's message appeared to reflect particular concern about the potential peril for Florida, the state that plays spring host to 20 of baseball's 28 major league clubs and one that is crucial to his political prospects.
"America has been living without baseball for too long," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued today. Saying the dispute was "imperiling the livelihood of tens of thousands of workers whose jobs depend on baseball," he declared: "It is time for this strike to end."
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner of baseball, and Donald Fehr, the players' union chief, said today that they welcomed Mr. Clinton's statement and looked forward to renewed talks. But at a meeting in Washington where mayors from around the country told baseball players and owners about their concern over the strike, neither side expressed much optimism that the dispute could be resolved quickly.
The Florida economy is more dependent on spring-training tourism than is Arizona's, the other warm-weather state where the major league clubs have long set up camp and attracted thousands of fans. Florida is also the only one among the country's largest states whose Governor, Lawton Chiles, is a Democrat, meaning that it has become particularly important for Mr. Clinton to maintain his goodwill.
It has been more than a month since talks between the players and owners broke down. With the training camps due to open soon, the owners are now moving ahead with plans to field teams with replacement players -- a prospect that could sap spring training of much of its appeal and one that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole both signaled that they hoped to avert.
The President has no power to force an end to the strike, and he has stopped short of endorsing the threats by members of Congress to repeal baseball's antitrust exemption if the dispute is not settled. But his strong statement was most direct intervention since the strike began last Aug. 12, and his aides said it signaled a decision within the Administration that the mediator, Bill Usery Jr., should now adopt a more assertive role.
Mr. Clinton did not appoint Mr. Usery, a former Labor Secretary, until last Oct. 14, more than two months after the strike began, and he has seemed content to allow the mediator to play a low-key role. But in his statement today, the President asked Mr. Usery "to bring the owners and the players back to the table, and to step up the pace and intensity of his mediation efforts." He said he wanted Mr. Usery to consider putting forward his own recommendations if the players and owners are not at least on track toward a speedy settlement by the Feb. 6 deadline.
While the timing appeared to have been coincidental, Mr. Clinton's appeal was certainly reinforced by Mr. Dole's message, who invited the players and owners to use his offices for "some good old-fashioned, brass-knuckled bargaining."
Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton's statement had been drafted after weeks of deliberations in which Labor Secretary Robert Reich and Bruce Lindsey, a deputy White House counsel who is the President's chief adviser on the issue, had grown increasingly pessimistic about the prospects for a settlement of the strike.
In the statement, the President said he still believed that it would be best if the owners and the players settle their dispute themselves. But he warned that the strike had left baseball with "a tarnished image," and he suggested that a more aggressive Government role was necessary in part because the prolonged dispute was "trying the patience and depressing the spirits of millions of baseball fans -- including me."
Mr. Clinton said he would ask Mr. Usery to offer his own recommendations for a settlement after Feb. 6 "if he believes it appropriate." In an interview tonight, Mr. Reich described such a step as one that would "bring a great deal of public pressure to bear" on the players and owners to settle their dispute.
For his part, Mr. Fehr said: "Major league players welcome today's action by President Clinton to stimulate a resumption of bargaining and intensive mediation. The players have been ready and willing to resume bargaining since the owners broke off talks Dec. 22. Now, more than a month after the owners walked away from the table and implemented their salary cap, it is apparent that spring training is in jeopardy, as well as the 1995 championship season. We hope the owners well agree to return to the bargaining table."

HEADLINE: Defense Dept. Plans to Close Fewer Bases

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Facing resistance from the military services, Defense Secretary William J. Perry today backtracked from a top Pentagon goal and said the round of base closings this year -- which had been expected to be the largest of four -- would be smaller than anticipated.
In a speech to the United States Conference of Mayors, Mr. Perry said fewer bases would be ordered closed than in 1993 because "in previous rounds we closed those relatively easy ones." 
 "Everything from now on will be more difficult," he said.
Mr. Perry later said he had trimmed the Pentagon's original goal in recent weeks after the military services told him it would be too difficult and too costly in the near term.
Fewer closings would send aftershocks through the Pentagon and the country. While they would spare many communities economic turmoil, they would also shrink the long-term savings the Pentagon had been counting on to help pay for troop salaries and new weapons after the turn of the century.
Three independent commissions, which met in 1988, 1991 and 1993, decided to close 70 major installations. It takes five to six years to shut a base, which in the short term is very expensive.
Mr. Perry said today that it would cost $15 billion to close and clean up the 70 bases, but that by the end of the decade the Pentagon would save more than $4 billion a year by doing so.
By the Secretary's own admission, the services are keeping open more bases, depots, shipyards and laboratories than the shrinking post-cold-war military needs, bleeding money from training and operations accounts. He said today that the overall size of the military had dropped by 33 percent in the past eight years, but that the number of installations had shrunk by only 20 percent.
As recently as last fall, lawmakers and senior Pentagon officials anticipated even larger long-term savings from the closings this year, which some officials predicted would be larger than the three previous rounds combined.
But as the services began to consider what they would actually close, they dropped hints to Mr. Perry that their original estimates were overly ambitious. The services are to submit their final recommendations to Mr. Perry in the next few weeks.
The Secretary does not make the final decision on base closings, but he has tremendous influence. By March 1 he will submit a list of recommended closings to an independent commission, which can then add or subtract bases. Under the base-closing legislation, Congress will have to approve or reject the panel's decision as a whole later this summer.
Mr. Perry gave the first signs of pulling back a month ago when he told reporters that he expected the 1995 round of decisions to be "about the size" of the 1993 round, when 35 major bases were ordered closed and 27 others were reduced -- or in some cases expanded.
But in recent weeks, the Secretaries of the three armed services have told Mr. Perry that after the three previous rounds there were no more obvious targets and that their reduced budgets could not pay for the cleanup of a large number of bases.
"We're down to the tough choices, and the question of how much money we have for closing and cleanup," said one senior Defense Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, as did others in the department.
Another official said, "In a time when our budget is under considerable pressure, we are constrained by the up-front costs of closing."
The official said that even with fewer closings than planned this year, the military would still reap billions of dollars in long-term savings from the reduction in bases.
Pentagon officials said today that they might ask Congress to approve legislation authorizing additional base closings in the future, depending on the recommendations the services submit to Mr. Perry.
The Navy accounted for most of the base closings in 1993, but the Army is expected to provide the majority of the closings this year.
Army officials have already expressed concern about closing many bases in the United States before troops from deactivated units in Europe can be reassigned to posts in this country.
"We're taking very seriously the goal of tailoring the cold-war infrastructure to the post-cold-war Army of 495,000 people," a senior Army official said. The Army's strength is now about 530,000.
Army officials insist that the Army has more than fulfilled its share of closings by shutting down scores of installations in Germany and elsewhere in Europe.

HEADLINE: Mexicans Deny They Would Order Border Crackdown in Return for U.S. Loan Guarantees

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Mexican officials strongly denied today that they would agree to block migrants from crossing illegally into the United States or give American officials greater influence over their anti-drug efforts in return for $40 billion in proposed loan guarantees.
United States officials also backed away from suggestions on Wednesday that they would try to use the aid to win such concessions from Mexico. 
 "We have been very, very, very careful in dealing with the Mexicans on this," said an American official familiar with the discussions. "In some cases we may want to push the Mexicans farther than they are. But we are trying to make the case to people that we are already working well together, and that we are getting increased assurances of cooperation."
"We are not," the official went on, "trying to come up with any sort of political conditions on this."
What commitments Mexico might make to win Congressional approval of the loan guarantees in the United States has become a sensitive political issue in both countries.
Without waiting for the Clinton Administration, Congress has variously demanded the opening of Mexico's state-run oil industry to private investors, Mexican efforts to stop illegal migration to the United States, and an end to Mexico's amicable relationship with Cuba.
In response, a growing number of Mexicans have begun to oppose the plan, arguing that the loan guarantees and their conditions could jeopardize the independence of this country without solving its deeper economic problems.
"The series of conditions that the White House and the United States Congress seek in order to aid Mexico financially show the characteristics not of an economic operation but of open and inadmissible blackmail," the left-leaning newspaper La Jornada editorialized on its front page last week.
As in the United States, much of the criticism in Mexico comes from political agendas that go far beyond the $40 billion. And as was the case in earlier negotiations over the foreign debt and North American trade, the outcry may partly serve the Mexican Government's cause by hinting to the American Congress that refusal to help could bring more political instability south of the border.
Many Mexican political analysts believe their countrymen care less about the threats to their sovereignty that the loan guarantees might imply than about the economic disaster that could ensue if they are voted down.
Yet concern about a nationalistic backlash has become increasingly evident in the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon. One after another, senior Mexican officials have been paraded in recent days to promise that the country's dignity will not be risked. In a hastily scheduled speech on Tuesday night, Mr. Zedillo himself mentioned the word sovereignty 19 times.
"The highest aim of my Government is the full exercise of national sovereignty," he said. "We will accept no commitment that violates national sovereignty or threatens the legitimate interests of the Mexicans."
Mexican and United States officials have not differed in their public description of the financial conditions of the proposed guarantees.
Because of the difficulty Mexico faces in persuading investors to renew the $28 billion in short-term debt securities it has outstanding, it plans to use the guarantees to issue new debt bonds that would be repayable over a period of up to 10 years. Mexico would pay a commission and interest. As collateral, the Mexican central bank would also have importers of Mexican oil deposit their payments with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, putting them under American control in the event Mexico had trouble paying them back.
Just as American critics of the guarantees have portrayed them as outright loans, so have Mexican opponents suggested that they would give the United States control over Mexico's oil exports. But the more political conditions that might be attached to the plan have been even more open to interpretation.
According to officials from both countries involved in negotiations on the assurances Mexico might offer to make the loan guarantees more attractive, Mexico has said it will pledge greater cooperation with the United States on such matters as immigration, drug control and environmental protection along the border. But the assurances that Mexico would provide are not expected to be very specific, and they are not expected to require new formal agreements.
On the migration issue, senior Mexican officials said the Zedillo Government's main commitments would be to promote greater economic development in regions that have traditionally exported undocumented migrants to the United States and to expand a special police force created to deal with crime along the border.
Mexico has already announced that it is considering both of those steps, and officials said they might consider allowing migrants caught sneaking across the border to be deported into the Mexican interior.
In testimony Wednesday before the Banking Committee of the House of Representatives, Secretary of State Warren Christopher cited the expansion of the special police force as an example of the "very significant" actions that Mexico would take on law enforcement and narcotics.
Yet the force, known in Spanish as the Grupo Beta, has in fact had the primary mission of protecting undocumented migrants from criminal attacks.
Mexican officials said that what the Zedillo Government was prepared to do about narcotics was to increase the exchange of intelligence between the two countries and step up their cooperation in fighting money laundering by traffickers. The administration has also made those commitments in the past.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Tentatively Approves $7.8 Billion Loan to Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
While skirmishing over a proposed emergency aid package for Mexico continued in the United States Congress, Mexican officials announced here today that the International Monetary Fund had tentatively agreed to lend Mexico $7.8 billion, the largest loan made by the organization in its 50-year history.
The Mexican officials said they believed that the money, because of the international commitment it represents, would boost Mexico's chances of getting the larger package of loan guarantees from the United States. Opponents of the $40 billion American package have complained that the United States would bear too much of the burden for Mexico's rescue. 
 In Washington today, top Administration officials appeared for a second day of questions about the proposed loan guarantees, and garnered little support on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, urged the Senate to vote for the loan guarantees to prevent a financial panic around the world.
Mr. Greenspan said that "if this was strictly about Mexico, I would say there is absolutely no reason" for a Federal bailout, adding, "But it is not just about Mexico."
Several senators said that while helping Mexico was a laudable national goal, they were having a difficult time explaining to constituents why American taxpayer dollars should be put at risk to bail out Mexican leaders -- and American investors who put $16 billion into short-term Mexican bonds -- while Orange County, Calif., is permitted to go into bankruptcy without Federal intervention.
"I know no one in the financial community who is against this," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat. "I know no one in my constituency who is for it. There is no support."
At a news conference at the National Palace in Mexico City today, Guillermo Ortiz, the Finance Minister, and Miguel Mancera Aguayo, Governor of Mexico's Central Bank, said the Monetary Fund's loan would complement but not replace the $40 billion in proposed guarantees by the United States.
Whatever money Mexico draws from the fund must be paid back in three to five years. Mexico could use the money the way it uses its international reserves, to buy pesos to stabilize the currency or pay off maturing bonds.
Loans guaranteed by the United States could last as long as 10 years, allowing Mexico to rearrange and extend its external debt, which is now dangerously concentrated in bonds lasting one year or less. As confidence in Mexico wanes, investors are redeeming those short-term bonds in large numbers, putting increasing strains on the Mexican economy.
Mexico wants to use the United States guarantees to issue long-term bonds to replace up to $28 billion in short-term bonds that are indexed to dollars and will fall due this year.
To make the $7.8 billion loan announced today, the International Monetary Fund had to make a rare exception to its rules. Mexico still owes the fund more than three-quarters of a $4.8 billion loan authorized in 1989. Each of the 179 member nations may borrow against an established quota, but outstanding loans from the fund must be deducted from that amount.
The rule was waived in this case, but Mexican officials had to submit a disciplined economic recovery plan, and agree to the fund's supervision for the duration of the loan.
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, said in a statement today that Mexico's recovery plan was "strong, coherent and credible."
The fund's executive board is expected to vote on the loan commitment on Wednesday, with approval all but certain.

HEADLINE: Fishing Rights Ruling With Bounty of Anger

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SUQUAMISH, Wash., Jan. 25

 BODY:
Chief Seattle, who is buried here within view of the city that was given his name, died more than 120 years ago. But a treaty he signed with a simple "X" in 1855 continues to haunt ancestors of the Americans who claimed this land from the natives.
Citing a clause in that treaty giving 15 tribes in the region fishing rights, a Federal court ruling last month gave Indians the right to take up to half of the shellfish from Puget Sound, one of the nation's top producers of oysters, crabs and clams. 
 With the ruling, the Indians plan to begin harvesting shellfish from private beaches, state parks, even areas where commercial oyster growers have set up elaborate farms. Land owners, outraged over the decision, which they call a grave threat to property rights, say they may press Congress to abrogate parts of the 19th-century treaty.
The ruling by Judge Edward Rafeedie of Federal District Court in Los Angeles has generated new animosity between Indians and non-Indians who have been fighting over fishing rights for most of this century. Two weeks ago, gunshots were fired over the heads of Indians who were digging clams on a beach on the Olympic Peninsula.
No one was hurt, but some property owners say the gunshots could be a harbinger of things to come if the Indians try to take shellfish from private land.
"Things are starting to heat up," said Bill Dewey, manager of an oyster farm and a spokesman for 65 shellfish growers in Puget Sound. The court ruling, he said, "has the potential to devastate this industry, and people are very upset."
The dispute hangs on a few words in a treaty dated Jan. 22, 1855, signed by Chief Seattle and dozens of other leaders of various Puget Sound tribes, with Isaac Stevens, the territorial Governor. Recent court rulings have interpreted a clause in that treaty to mean that the Indians get half of the valuable fish in the Puget Sound area. This clause has proven to be a continual struggle in the multimillion-dollar fishing industry.
In some years, Puget Sound, with more than 2,000 miles of coastline on inlets, fjords and islands, is the leading shellfish producer in the nation. Its oyster and clams, particularly the huge geoducks that can fetch $8 a pound in Asian markets, are sold worldwide. The shellfish growers say they will not be able to operate their businesses if Indians come onto their tidelands.
The Indians, who now take less than 4 percent of Puget Sound's shellfish harvest, mostly from public land, say the property owners are overreacting. They say they can harvest half the tideland marine bounty without disturbing the saltwater farms that have been developed over the last century.
Their treaty, signed by President Franklin Pierce, approved by Congress and upheld by the Supreme Court, is not something that should be subject to political whim, the Indians say.
"Treaty rights are property rights, but you don't hear the property rights freaks in the new Congress or the Washington State Legislature coming to our defense," said Tony Forsman, executive director of the Suquamish Tribe, one of the 15 tribes that have signed treaties allowing them to take fish from Puget Sound. "You hear all this talk about the 'Contract with America,' and the Contract with Washington State. What about the contract with the Indians?"
The Suquamish, whose small reservation is just across Puget Sound from Seattle, have about 800 members. Chief Seattle was a leader of the Suquamish and the Duwamish, another Puget Sound tribe.
The treaty of Point Elliott, which Chief Seattle signed, is similar in wording to other treaties Governor Stevens made in a whirlwind tour around the Pacific Northwest.
In each of these treaties, the Indians ceded most of Washington Territory to the United States, in return for reservations, a cash payment and the right of taking fish at usual and accustomed places "in common with all citizens of the Territory."
Twenty years ago, in a decision that set off a war of words, vandalism and lawsuits, Judge George Boldt of Federal District Court in Seattle ruled that the phrase "in common with" in the treaty meant that the tribes could take up to half of all the salmon in Washington. That ruling was upheld by the Supreme Court.
Last month, Judge Rafeedie extended Judge Boldt's ruling to shellfish. But he went another step as well. The treaty says that tribes cannot take shellfish "from any beds staked or cultivated by citizens." But Judge Rafeedie said the tribes could harvest clams or naturally occurring shellfish that may lie beneath the cultivated beds. This interpretation surprised both sides.
"A lot of oyster farmers cultivate natural production to help their farms," Mr. Dewey said. "What this court ruling means is that the Indians could come in and get 50 percent of our labors, without paying anything for it. That makes it impossible to run a business."
In addition, waterfront property owners are concerned about the ruling, which they fear will let Indians will trespass on their yards and driveways to get to the tidelands.
"It's our view that the Indians gave up the right to any access to this property once they ceded it to the United States," said James M. Johnson, a lawyer for United Property Owners of Washington.
The Indians of Puget Sound have been in court for decades, trying to uphold the fishing provisions of their treaties. In more than 30 cases in the Federal appeals courts, the Indians have lost only once.
Now, with the shellfish ruling, the Indians say they see a chance to build a new tribal economy in a fast-growing industry, worth at least $30 million annually in Puget Sound.
The shellfish growers have proposed that the Indians get their 50 percent on designated public beaches. Before the court ruling, the tribes had proposed numerous settlements, including an offer somewhat similar to the one now promoted by the shellfish industry.
It was rejected, Mr. Forsman of the Suquamish Tribe said, because "these political leaders have not had the guts to stand up and deal with us on a government-to-government basis." Mr. Forsman was one of the main negotiators for the Indians. After the tribes won in court, they said they had no incentive to renegotiate.
Property owners say there is an incentive. If the Indians start harvesting shellfish from private land, as they indicated they will in a plan put forth two weeks ago, they will face harassment and threats to their lives, property owners say.
"If they go ahead and hit the beaches, there's probably going to be more people shooting over their heads and other problems," Mr. Dewey said.
The Indians cannot start harvesting half the shellfish until Judge Rafeedie enters his final order. He has asked that all sides submit a plan to him, by the end of January, outlining how they would manage the shellfish.
The shellfish industry and property owners have appealed his decision. If they get to the Supreme Court, they feel they have a backdoor chance with the new, more conservative court, to overturn the much more significant Boldt decision on salmon.

HEADLINE: Civil Justice System Is Overhaul Target

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Major proposals for remaking the civil justice system, long a priority of the Republican right, are almost certain to reach the floor of Congress within the next few months. But the thrust of proposed changes is still much in doubt.
House Republicans have pledged a quick vote on The Common Sense Legal Reforms Act, a grab bag of measures intended to strengthen defenses against torts, lawsuits seeking damages -- what Corporate America sees as an unprincipled attack on property and enterprise and what many consumer groups see as their leverage against corporate power. 
 But some Senate Republicans hope to redirect Congress's energies toward less ideologically charged questions regarding the cost of civil justice. Their goal is to force plaintiffs and defendants to think long and hard before taking cases to court -- and, in the process, assure swift resolution of disputes and a slashing of the nation's legal bills by tens of billions of dollars.
While there is bitter disagreement over the virtues of the Senate and House proposals, both friends and foes characterize the Senate's approach as revolutionary. "These initiatives are more Draconian than any we have previously seen," said Pamela Gilbert, the legislative counsel for the Malkin & Ross law firm who has served as the senior lobbyist for consumer groups opposed to overhauling product liability laws. "Together, they would virtually eliminate tort actions."
Changes to the rules governing damage suits have been a political issue for at least two decades. Proponents focus on the impulse of courts to pick the deepest pocket and the incentives to fraud. Opponents defend the system as the best way of assuring justice to the average American. But the political debate has largely been driven by financial interest.
On one side are businesses and insurers seeking to limit their liability. On the other are independent plaintiffs' lawyers whose incomes are leveraged on both the volume of claims and the size of settlements and jury awards. Plaintiffs' lawyers have won most of the legislative battles, often with the quiet cooperation of the defense bar, which also has a financial stake in keeping the lawsuits coming.
While civil justice reform does not rank with affirmative action or welfare as a hot button for the Rush Limbaugh crowd, it probably commands greater support from the new Republican Congressional majority than the higher-profile provisions of the "Contract With America" -- in part because it places Republicans squarely on the side of business, large and small, and against the trial lawyer bar. What is more, the change in Congressional leadership will make it difficult for opponents to block floor votes.
The civil justice measures in the "Contract With America" are relatively easy to analyze because most have been pressed by business lobbies for some time.
Most prominent is a "loser pays" rule, under which the loser in a court case would pay both sides' lawyers' fees. Proponents see it as the answer to what they consider a legal form of blackmail, cases in which plaintiffs make unsubstantiable claims because they know it is cheaper for defendants to settle than to go to war. The plaintiffs' bar has generally condemned "loser pays," saying it would discourage many ordinary citizens from filing justified lawsuits. Last week, the American Bar Association's committee on litigation denounced the proposal as "a regressive tax on the right to litigate."
The "honesty in evidence" provision is drawn from the same ideological well. It would bar the admission of expert testimony in Federal court unless the testimony was based on "scientifically valid reasoning" and the expert's compensation was not linked to the outcome of the case.
The target is what Peter W. Huber, an engineer and lawyer, called "junk science" in his book "Galileo's Revenge" (Basic Books, 1993). But Tom McGarity, a law professor at the University of Texas who is identified with plaintiffs' rights, said the Supreme Court had already given judges sufficient discretion to shield juries from disreputable evidence. Professor McGarity worries that the new test would lock in establishmentarian views of science.
"The courts are not qualified to judge scientific merit," Professor McGarity argued in a recent interview.
The House Republicans' proposed changes in product liability laws also fit the business-versus-trial lawyers' mold. Defendants would be liable for punitive damages only where there was "clear and convincing evidence" of malice. "Joint liability" for pain and suffering would be ended, effectively blocking disproportionately large claims against defendants who had played minor roles in causing injury. And product sellers would be liable only for the harm they themselves caused. Kmart could thus not be punished for selling a poorly designed chain saw.
Yet another big-ticket item on the House's civil justice agenda is a change in securities law that would limit "strike" lawsuits, class-actionsuits by owners of securities who claim that management has exaggerated a company's health. Proponents acknowledge that stockholders need some means of redress, but argue that the right has been abused by trial lawyers who have turned the process into high-stakes extortion.
"Management can't afford to bet the company's future on a jury verdict," said Tom Proulx, a co-founder of Intuit, a California software company, who is now leading a coalition opposed to strike suit abuses. "Even meritless cases must be settled."
While House Republicans wish to tilt the torts playing field, two Senate Republicans, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Spencer Abraham of Michigan, want to change the nature of the game. Their goal is not to stop unmerited legal claims, but to drive down the cost of civil justice by deterring litigants from using expensive legal strategies and by giving lawyers incentives to settle.
For starters, the two would abolish the "collateral source" rule that allows a successful plaintiff to collect once from his own insurer and a second time from the defendant.
Trial lawyers have long argued that plaintiffs should not be penalized because they were prudent enough to buy insurance. But Michael Horowitz of the Hudson Institute, a conservative research organization, says that the most significant result is overuse of the health care system. He notes that in Hawaii, where the state provides universal health insurance, tort claimants averaged 53 visits each to chiropractors, costs that would have to be compensated a second time by losing defendants.
Also high on the McConnell-Abraham list is a measure to prevent plaintiffs' lawyers from taking excessive contingency fees when substantial compensation is never in doubt. Where the defense made an early offer of settlement -- say, $100,000 -- and the offer was accepted, the plaintiff's lawyer would be able to collect only reasonable hourly fees. Where the plaintiff rejected the $100,000, his lawyer would be permitted to collect only a fixed percentage of an award in excess of the originally offered sum.
"Attorneys' compensation should be proportional to what they risk," said Jeffrey O'Connell, a law professor at the University of Virginia who, with Mr. Horowitz, has provided much of the intellectual horsepower behind the Senate proposals.
Most striking, the two Republicans would expand on a radical idea offered a decade ago by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is now the House minority leader. Where, early on, a defendant acknowledged liability for economic losses -- the plaintiff's lost income, uncovered medical bills and the like -- he would not be liable for punitive awards or pain and suffering damages unless the plaintiff could demonstrate "willful misconduct beyond a reasonable doubt."
The point, Senator McConnell said, is to keep cases from dragging "when the parties just want to get it over with." Both sides, he said, stand to benefit: Defendants would avoid the risk of giant losses, while injured plaintiffs would not wait years for compensation.
Trial lawyers counter that there is more to law than "getting it over with," asserting that justice requires adequate incentives to go to court.
Just how the politics of civil justice reform will sort out is anyone's guess. While Republican leaders are sympathetic to the idea of delivering bills for early floor votes, the committees with jurisdiction could bog down on other parts of the Republican agenda.
First clues will come from the response to Congressional hearings, which will probably be held next month in both houses. Bill Kristol, a Republican strategist and chairman of the Project for a Republican Future, said much would depend on how the issues were framed.
"Republicans need to make this a pro-citizen initiative, not a pro-business one," Mr. Kristol said.
In the Senate, legislation may be broken into pieces, with product liability, securities law and the McConnell-Abraham proposals considered separately. There may be tactical advantages to one big push, but supporters worry that the least-popular provisions could leave the entire effort vulnerable to filibuster, the way provisions favoring drug companies helped sink product liability legislation last year.
"If 41 people are against you," Senator McConnell recalled, "you're dead."
Perhaps the greatest imponderable is the role of the White House. In the debate on product liability legislation, President Clinton cautiously sided with opponents of change.
But in the aftermath of midterm elections, some members of the White House staff have reportedly been lobbying for a fresh look at civil justice, one that might help the President reclaim the role of New Democrat. From this perspective, the McConnell-Abraham proposals may offer Mr. Clinton an attractive alternative to the House Republicans' approach.
"He could take credit for a bill that helps the people who work hard and play by the rules," Mr. Kristol said.
For the moment, the President has no official position. All that Abner Mikva, the White House counsel, will say is, "The Administration is looking at the options."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, left, and Spencer Abraham of Michigan, both Republicans, want to change the nature of civil litigation. Their goal is to drive down the cost of civil justice by deterring litigants from using expensive legal strategies and by giving lawyers incentives to settle. In the House, Republicans have proposed a more ideologically charged overhaul of the system. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
Bolivar as an Idealist Thwarted by Messy Reality

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Toward the end of Thea Musgrave's intriguing new opera, "Simon Bolivar," which is receiving its world premiere performances at the Virginia Opera here this week, there is a scene in which the many flaws of the work recede to the background, and the vital episodes of this acidic score come together. Bolivar, who is still known in South America as El Libertador for his fight against Spanish colonial rule, is ill and near the close of his career.
After bloody battles, he has led six countries to freedom, but he has also been stymied again and again in his attempts to unify them. There have been conflicts among his generals, quarrels over whether to compromise the revolution's ideals and outrage over his own lust for power. 
The scene depicts him in a fevered delirium in which figures from his past emerge out of choral clamor to condemn his actions; he begins to see his life's work unravel. The music also recapitulates its past: the thudding rhythms of battle, the dissonances of sinuous wind lines, a drone that has been a sign of dread, and fragments of biting lyricism. The opera, in this scene, shows what it might have been with a tighter conception, and what it still is, intermittently: a tragedy, in which honorable political goals become muddied, and idealism is thwarted by messy human realities. Shortly thereafter, the stage Bolivar despairingly sings what the real Bolivar actually wrote: "Those who serve a revolution plough the sea."
In the excellent performance I saw on Thursday night (the last will be on Sunday, before a short run in Richmond), this was the emotional climax of an evening that was alternately powerful and predictable. Ms. Musgrave, who was born in Scotland, is something of a "house" composer here. Her husband, Peter Mark, is the general director and principal conductor of the Virginia Opera and this is the fourth of her operas he has presented (including "Mary, Queen of Scots," which also came to the New York City Opera).
"Bolivar" was originally commissioned by the Los Angeles Music Center Opera and the Scottish Opera, both of which canceled their plans to stage it, apparently because of economic problems. Mr. Mark took it on, led a polished performance, and made certain that it was given a striking production by Lillian Garrett-Groag, with sets by John Conklin. The opera will also be given an entirely different production in March at the Staatstheater Regensburg, in Germany.
Mr. Conklin created a look for this work in his "Ghosts of Versailles" manner: a unit stage that shows a room from a classical museum in which plaster has fallen, pillars are awry and a giant Napoleonic picture inspired by David hangs crookedly at mid-stage. This set is bothersome at first because of its blunt symbolism of revolution and old-world wreckage. But Ms. Musgrave's opera quickly segues from one battle scene or encounter to the next in a restless, abridged version of Bolivar's life, running events on fast-forward, so that Mr. Conklin's unchanging design actually ends up giving some surreal coherence to the historical fantasy.
But one of the work's problems is that Ms. Musgrave is of two minds. She wants to be both a realist and an idealist about Bolivar, a tragedian and a soap-box orator, and the two styles wrestle with each other. There is no need, for example, for the dutiful piling on of battle scenes (finely choreographed by Holly Harbinger, who has billing as "Fight Master") or for the crudely conceived framing of the work. It begins with a revolutionary teacher, Simon Rodriguez, raising young Bolivar's political consciousness, and ends in a modern dictatorship in South America, where Rodriguez's contemporary counterpart does the same for a latter-day Bolivar who gazes up in awe at a gargantuan statue of the revolutionary. This is Ms. Musgrave making points rather than making drama.
In fact, her score is too full of italics. The battle scenes use tapes of real gunfire and by the middle of the work, the rebellious music has become so unrelentingly aggressive that there is nowhere else for it to go. Even the choice of language is partly politically motivated. Ms. Garrett-Groag, who is Argentine, convinced Ms. Musgrave to translate her English libretto into Spanish and provide English supertitles, perhaps in a quest for cultural authenticity; this was to no great advantage, since the singers did little to make a case for the language's sound and style.
But Ms. Musgrave is also too talented a dramatist to let this be simply another operatic life of a political saint. When the music succeeds, it manages to evoke a mixture of aspiration, frustration and anger that Ms. Musgrave sees in Bolivar. Stephen Guggenheim did not quite have the right heroic tenor to pull this off; he tended toward a light, somewhat tight sound, without giving the character's constant duress enough color or modulation. Ms. Musgrave's portrait of Manuela, the woman Bolivar loves, is actually the most compelling; her lyrical singing lines can have a fearsome power; a despairing second-act aria surges with fiery bitterness. Amy Johnson's soprano is not sensuous, but its skillfully used, slightly edgy precision brought the role to life.
The score also glinted with imagination when its obsessive Expressionism was tempered with elements of South American folklore, including a dance that Bolivar himself knew, a Venezuelan melody, and, in a private joke, a pavane that comes from Ms. Musgrave's "Mary."
More of that imagination would have helped the structure of the drama as well. Had this opera tried to tell less of Bolivar's life with fiery musical rhetoric, and focused more closely on the nuanced psychological and political confrontations in the second act, had it avoided preaching and not retreated from its tragic insights, it would have borne a large harvest; as it was, there was much to admire, but much energy was also spent ploughing the sea.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Orioles Are the Pride Of America

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
IT'S nice to hear elected public servants talking about ending the baseball strike. But how can we help them?
I have a suggestion. Go out and buy a Baltimore Orioles baseball cap and wear it, day and night, until further notice. Their black-and-orange insignia has become a symbol of resistance to scab baseball. 
 Forget all the flapdoodle of the Dallas Cowboys being America's Team. That was just a marketing slogan from a haughty regional football team.
It is fitting that the Baltimore Orioles play only a few miles from Fort McHenry, where Francis Scott Key wrote "The Star-Spangled Banner." The Baltimore Orioles are America's Team now.
"I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my baseball," -- Nathan Hale Angelos.
The Baltimore Orioles respect the baseball fans of America. The owner, Peter Angelos, is on record that he would rather play no games at all than send out a team of replacement players.
"Give me baseball or give me death," -- Patrick Henry Angelos.
A lawyer who has worked with unions, a newcomer to baseball, Angelos does not want to insult the history of baseball by digging up stock clerks and putting them in the uniform worn by both Robinsons and all the Ripkens, too. Now America must use the Orioles' ball cap as its banner.
"Shoot, if you must, this old gray head, But spare my Orioles' dignity," -- John Greenleaf Whittier Angelos.
Why wear the cap of one of the new-breed crotch-grabbers of the National Basketball Association? Never mind the faddish San Jose Sharks cap. Forget about the black-and-white Raiders cap that once stood for mindless biker-style resistance. Give up the black-and-white Chicago White Sox cap. Put away your old Jordan Bulls cap. Both those teams are owned by Jerry Reinsdorf, one of the leaders of the salary cap-or-scabs movement.
Even in the dead of winter, wear that Orioles ball cap, particularly if you're inside the Beltway. They're starting to pay attention now. Yesterday, President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, both offered their services to help end this strike.
The politicians are apparently hearing from merchants in Florida and Arizona who fear a huge drop in tickets and hotels and restaurants for the annual pilgrimmage to spring training if the owners send in the clowns.
The President set a deadline of Feb. 6 for the owners and the players to settle their grievances.
If it does not happen before then, the President and the Senator could presumably put bipartisan pressure on Congress to rescind baseball's exemption from antitrust legislation. Even that gesture would be worth something at this point. It's getting ugly out there.
Owners are holding ludicrous tryout camps, bringing in nobodies. The owners are issuing pious statements that they will cut ticket prices for these threatened scab games. Some lumbering oaf is going to wear the uniform of Willie Mays. Some splay-footed reject is going to wear the uniform of Roberto Clemente. Some incompetent is going to wear the uniform of Al Kaline. How dare they?
Only one other team has shown respect for baseball. The Toronto Blue Jays, forbidden by provincial law from using replacement players, might play their so-called official games in Florida, but at least the Blue Jays' management will not force Cito Gaston and his coaches to work with these desperadoes. The club leadership understands it would be wrong to make proud baseball people work in public with unskilled labor. For that, all Canadian baseball fans should wear a Blue Jays cap, as a sign of respect for the game.
There are complex issues to be worked out. The players, of course, are arrogant and overpaid and simplistic, and wouldn't identify with other unions. But it is the owners who are still fixated on a salary cap to solve the troubles they made by spending too much money. The owners have put vendors and ushers out of work in the big cities; now they threaten hotel maids and busboys with unemployment in Florida and Arizona. I'm sure they don't care.
Put on your Blue Jays cap in Canada. Put on your Orioles cap in the States. Let the caps send the owners and the players and the politicians a message: Baseball, yes. Scabs, never.

HEADLINE: Governor Whitman's Trade-Offs

 BODY:
The popularity of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to cut New Jersey's personal income tax by 30 percent in three years cannot be disputed. Her swift delivery on that promise has propelled her onto national television and high up the list of potential Republican nominees for Vice President.
But the publicity must not obscure the facts. Mrs. Whitman tells the nation that she and her party stand for smaller government, but the $15.9 billion budget she presented this week is $1 billion more than the last one by the previous Governor, Jim Florio. What's more, her stunning record of income tax reduction has overshadowed its less welcome accompaniment: increases in other taxes in the name of fees and "closing loopholes," and postponement of state expenses through long-term borrowing and the delay of payments to public pension funds. 
 Some of Mrs. Whitman's proposals seem blind to the people they hit. She wants to tax the full price of discounted items purchased with store coupons, a move that targets the thrifty and the poor. She also pretends her proposal to continue a supposedly temporary surcharge on motor vehicle registrations is not a new tax. Those who expected it to expire on schedule are entitled to disagree.
On a larger point, the Democrats have scored with their charge that she is forcing local property taxes up by curbing state aid to localities and school districts. She asserts, disingenuously, that the state has no say over property taxes. In reality it has considerable sway. What Trenton does affects local budgets in all sorts of ways.
However, the Democrats' assertion of a direct link lacks proof, too. Common sense says they are right; if state aid goes down, local taxes are apt to go up. But there is another option -- less local spending. To that end, Mrs. Whitman's new budget includes two innovative incentives -- penalties for school districts with excessive administrative costs, and rewards for districts that save money through regional cooperation.
As for her spending program, Mrs. Whitman is frank to admit it involves pain. While total aid to schools is up, most of the increase goes properly to "special-needs" urban school systems; roughly half the state's districts will take a cut. Her most striking proposal for savings is a plan to eliminate 3,400 state jobs, primarily through privatization. Perhaps some jobs are not needed. Even so, this is a brutal transference of state salaries into the pockets of taxpayers.
The strength of economic recovery in New Jersey has helped Mrs. Whitman cut taxes even faster than she promised. But the boldness of her move in that direction is diminished by her lack of concern for future taxpayers who will face the bills she postpones.

HEADLINE: Myopia on Mexico

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has failed to rally Congressional support for its plan to stabilize Mexico's peso. That is alarming. The crisis threatens to engulf not only Mexico but other recently reformed Latin American economies as well. U.S. financial interests are also at risk, from Wall Street speculators to the pension and mutual-fund accounts of millions of middle-class Americans. Finally, the crisis is a major test of Washington's ability to act decisively in an international emergency that is as close to home as those emergencies come.
Yet even after hearing Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and the Federal Reserve's Alan Greenspan describe the economic dangers, and Secretary of State Christopher the diplomatic consequences, members of House and Senate committees remained decidedly cool to the package. The plan would provide $40 billion in loan guarantees, at minimum financial risk to the U.S. 
 That is a troubling start to a Congressional session in which bipartisanship will be required on matters of vital national interest. There has been little political courage on this issue from either party, but Democrats are most conspicuously to blame. Most of them opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement, which only passed because most Republicans voted for it. Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, hint they would be willing to mobilize Republican support behind the guarantees, but only if the Democrats share the political risks.
Some Congressmen believe, wrongly, that the guarantees would help Mexico at the expense of the U.S. Populists criticize the rescue package as a bailout of rich speculators, which, in part, it is. Liberal Democrats want to use the loan guarantee legislation as a way to reopen negotiations on Nafta, particularly on issues like wages and working conditions in Mexico. Conservative Republicans want to use it to impose structural changes in the way Mexico runs its economy -- forcing Mexico, for example, to establish an independent currency board and privatize its state oil company.
All these goals have merit. But holding the loan guarantees hostage to them flagrantly offends Mexican sovereignty. President Ernesto Zedillo, who is already under fire for his insistence on freer markets and more democracy, among other things, could never agree to such conditions. Humiliating the Zedillo Government would set back the goals of both American liberals and conservatives.
With a volatile crisis south of the border and back-benchers of both parties paralyzed by shortsightedness, the Clinton Administration and Republican and Democratic leaders of both houses need to work together to make clear the importance of passing the Mexican loan guarantees without further delay.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
$40 Billion Questions

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
It's a normal thing: ask for a loan, or go co-signer, and you have to answer a few questions.
We don't want to seem stingy or mean, but maybe U.S. and Mexican officials involved in the Mexican economic disaster would not mind skipping their press conferences and do a little answering under oath. After all -- $40 billion, you know. 
 1. Exactly when did these officials find out Mexico was in deep trouble because of its borrowing from foreign and Mexican investors?
Two New York Times correspondents (David E. Sanger and Anthony DePalma) report that in the summer of 1994, both governments knew about it. Which officials, please?
2. Seeing trouble coming, what did they publicly tell Mexicans and Americans so they could hold up before buying more pesos or bonds?
Nothing, it appears, even though some investors were getting private word that made them antsy.
3. Why the silence?
The Mexicans did not want to interfere with the grand economic press they were getting, or with the ambitions of two politicians. Ernesto Zedillo wanted to be elected president. The outgoing President, Carlos Salinas, wanted to be chosen head of the World Trade Organization. Any audible gurgles from a Mexican economy drowning in debt would not do either man much good.
4. And the U.S.: Could it be that the Administration had so enthusiastically promoted Mexico that it would have been terribly embarrassing -- an election coming up and all -- to disclose that Mexico "suddenly" could not go on backing up its pesos and bonds unless the U.S. offered heavy loans to bail out investors?
These questions and others raised by the conduct of the two Governments point to deliberate concealment of important reality -- cover-up, you might say.
So: It is not common sense to lend $40 billion more to a country whose leaders so botched things up, to be handled by the same American officials who participated in tamping down the economic truth.
The Administration and some investors tell us not to worry -- the collateral will be Mexico's oil revenues. Also we will watch their economy, like regular hawks.
Great: First we become the day-to-day overseers of the Mexican economy. The Mexican people will just love that. Then, if Mexico defaults, Sheriff Yanqui goes in and grabs the oil revenues that it regards as a national patrimony.
The only way the Mexican Government could prevent a revolution would be to renege on oil payments before the first one was made.
Americans who talk about seizing Mexican oil revenue seem never to understand the deep national emotions of third-world citizens -- particularly when told to shut up because they can't afford pride.
Given those passions, the political explosiveness of the collateral and the cover-up record, the loan carries risk and is not the failproof "loan guarantee" both countries say it is.
Then the question is if the $40 billion is needed to save Mexico and the world economy. Who says so?
Representative Charles Schumer, the New York Democrat, is proposing something less grandiose. He says lend Mexico less than $10 billion, for one year. Then use our clout in the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to get them to take over. That would reduce U.S. risk, but not thrill the other nations. (If the collateral is sound and the cause so important, why do Germany and Japan, eager trading partners of Mexico, so demurely hang back from making the loan?)
Economic aid is often justified -- but not $40 billion to a country whose mess was created by the cowardice of bureaucrats and the mistakes of investors, theirs and ours.
Americans would be foolish -- I am being exquisitely polite today -- if they agreed to any loan before they found out which American and Mexican investors would be the big beneficiaries. Then, we need aloof testimony from expert non-officials and non-politicians on how much damage would really be done if the loan is refused.
Would it touch off world crisis -- or just prevent losses that countries and investors should handle themselves -- if they want to play big shots in a free market?
And those questions at the beginning -- even for a miserable $10 billion, sworn testimony would be nice.

HEADLINE: Margaret Kahn Ryan, 93, Financier's Daughter, Dies

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Margaret Kahn Ryan, an heir to a New York financial fortune who carried on her father's interests in opera and art, died yesterday at her apartment in Manhattan. She was 93.
She died of natural causes, her son, John Barry Ryan 3d, said. 
 Mrs. Ryan, known as Nin, was a daughter of the financier Otto Kahn, a turn-of-the-century multimillionaire who became a benefactor of the Metropolitan Opera even though the Met at first would not assign him a box in its "diamond horseshoe," where rich New Yorkers hobnobbed at intermission.
She joined the Met's board in 1956, and after the company moved to Lincoln Center in the 1960's and announced that it was facing a financial crisis, she worked on an emergency fund drive to raise $3 million. She became an honorary director in 1981.
Mrs. Ryan was also an art collector whose French Impressionist paintings hung on the walls of her triplex apartment on the East Side of Manhattan and, in summers when she went to London, in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Mrs. Ryan was born on July 4, 1901, at Cedar Court, Kahn's mansion in Morristown, N.J. Kahn's biographer John Kobler wrote that he was closer to her than to his other children. Father and daughter, Mr. Kobler wrote in "Otto the Magnificent" (Scribners, 1989) "golfed together, rode together, swam together, chaffed each other, went to the opera together, and when apart, corresponded frequently." Sometimes their correspondence included long poems. He signed his "Fathie."
When she was in her 20's, she met and married John Barry Ryan, who was working as a reporter for The Newark Ledger. It was a union of financial dynasties: Mr. Ryan was a grandson of Thomas Fortune Ryan, a Virginian who migrated to Wall Street in the 1870's and made millions in railways, tobacco and insurance. He was said to have been the largest single owner of diamond fields in the Belgian Congo.
The wedding took place at Kahn's Fifth Avenue mansion on Feb. 9, 1928. Mrs. Ryan called her husband "Johnny" and her father declared, "It is my deliberate conviction that you are the nicest girl in this here republic."
Kahn added, in a letter mailed after she had been married for a year, at a time when she and Ryan were vacationing in Palm Beach, "I should love to be with you in the pink palazzo by the southern sea, but there is really no sense your being in this relentless city, because during the day the evil spell of the office claims me."
Kahn was a power at the Met until a few years before his death in 1934. Mr. Kober wrote that when Kahn first became involved with the company, the Met had an unwritten rule that no Jew could own a box. He was finally permitted to buy one, in the "diamond horseshoe," 17 years after he had joined the board. The Kahns had Margaret baptized at an Episcopal church in Morristown in 1911, along with her older sister, Maud, and her younger brother, Gilbert.
In 1951, two years after Mrs. Ryan's mother, Addie, died, Mrs. Ryan and the other Kahn heirs sold Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Young Student" for $90,000. They gave the money to the Metropolitan Opera. The Met put up a plaque, first at the old house on Broadway and later at Lincoln Center, that said the money had made possible new productions of Verdi's "Don Carlo" and Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte." The "Don Carlo" was Rudolf Bing's first production at the Met.
Among the other productions to which Mrs. Ryan contributed was the 1960 revival of "L'Elisir d'Amore," by Donizetti.
Five years ago, one of her paintings, "The Bench" by Manet, was sold at auction for $16.5 million. Manet's account book showed that the 1881 view of a garden was first sold for 2,000 francs to the Paris dealer Durand-Ruel, who sold it a year later to a Paris stockbroker for 2,500 francs and bought it back 10 years later for 6,000 francs. The painting remained in the dealer's hands until the Ryans bought it in 1945 for an undisclosed sum.
Besides her son, who lives in Manhattan, she is survived by a daughter, Virginia, the Countess of Airlie, who lives in London; eight grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margaret Kahn Ryan. (Bill Cunningham, 1994)

HEADLINE: Mexico Needs Vigorous Growth, Not Austerity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ronald I. McKinnon's "Flood of Dollars, Sunken Pesos" (Op-Ed, Jan. 20) is one of the few accounts of Mexico's financial crisis that focuses on the devastating role of foreign investors. But Mr. McKinnon identifies only half of their fault. 
 He points to the international bankers and mutual fund investors, mostly in the United States, who were "eager to overlend" -- pushing capital into Mexico during 1993 and 1994 -- but are "jittery" investors and "likely to pull their money out in a crisis." Yet he misses the point that the specified crisis was not so much generated inside the Mexican economy as precipitated by the foreign investors themselves, together with rich Mexican nationals, when they lost their nerve last year, in reaction to Mexico's political, not economic, disturbances, and pulled out huge amounts of capital.
Mexico's deficit on current account was not troublesome in itself. And it is incorrect to attribute the deficit to domestic inflation (since inflation actually fell from 145 percent a year in 1989 to 8 percent in 1993 and still less in 1994). Nor was the deficit due to any runaway consumption and importation (the rise of Mexican imports in 1994 was mostly covered by rising exports).
From this we can see the error of the Zedillo "recovery plan," which is to reduce import excess by imposing domestic austerity, in effect causing a recession. What Mexico needs is a return to vigorous growth, with renewed inflow of foreign capital. For this, the proposed international guarantees on Mexico's loans are essential.
 
EDWIN P. REUBENS
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Jan. 23, 1995
The writer is an emeritus professor of economics at City College, CUNY.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Mexico Needs Vigorous Growth, Not Austerity;
Free Trade as Welfare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The collapse of the Mexican peso and the call for a $40 billion bailout are only two of the nasty side effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement that many of us predicted two years ago. This is but the beginning of a process that will continue until Mexico is drained of natural resources and the United States is drained of jobs and money. 
 Recently you spoke editorially of the need to end "corporate welfare." Free trade is the greatest corporate welfare scheme of all. It is nothing more than a taxpayer-supported subsidy of multinational corporations, which have cut themselves free of any allegiance to the countries that spawned them. The result is that financial assets and production facilities are moved across international boundaries with no thought to the terrible social, environmental and economic consequences that follow.
President Clinton and Congress have a difficult choice to make. They can ward off economic collapse and possibly revolution in Mexico by spending $40 billion we don't have -- knowing that this solution is only temporary and the crisis will recur.
Or they can bite the bullet, find other, less costly ways of shoring up Mexico, and let the free-trade frenzy subside to a manageable level, even if some corporations are damaged in the process. For the sake of both the United States and Mexico, they should choose the second alternative.
 
DAVID EHRENFELD
New Brunswick, N.J., Jan. 20, 1995
