HEADLINE: Where the Blue Paper Cups Are;
A Warehouse Store in Queens Serves Ethnic Traditions

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
After they have saved enough money frying breakfasts and washing produce, just before they are ready to fling open the doors of their gleaming new bagel shop or deli or diner, there is still one last ritual to perform, one rite of passage that will usher the foreign-born entrepreneurs into the mainstream of the culinary life in Queens.
They must buy their first case of Greek-style blue paper coffee cups. And most likely, they must purchase it at Zahner's Cash and Carry restaurant supplies in Woodside. 
 Each week, the vast, densely stocked warehouse store at 62-35 30th Avenue sells at least 400 cases of the takeout cups, which are so ubiquitous that they have become a staple of any police show or movie attempting to demonstrate its New York authenticity. At 1,000 cups a case, that's 1.7 million cups of "we are happy to serve you" a month, almost enough for a cup of overheated coffee for every man, woman and child in the borough.
And the cups' Hellenic statuary is no longer reserved for the Greek diners that first made them popular. Now they are demanded in bulk by Colombian coffee shops, Pakistani and Korean delis, and, increasingly, Arab- and Turkish-owned restaurants and stores. Serving coffee and milk in the blue cups has become an essential part of the immigrant restaurant experience.
"Everyone wants that cup, no matter what language they speak," said Elisa Deixler, the store's manager. "It's the only paper coffee cup we sell. Twenty-seven dollars a case, not including lids."
For Ms. Deixler and her staff of 40, selling paper goods, chinaware and bulk foods to the borough's restaurateurs has brought New York City's shifting immigration and economic patterns directly to their cash register. As it has for generations, the restaurant business remains a popular portal into the middle class for many newcomers, and the store's location at the center of northwest Queens puts it at ground zero of the city's most diverse ethnic-restaurant district.
To the north are the taverns and diners of Astoria, to the south the Irish pubs and Korean barbecues of Woodside and Sunnyside, to the east the Indian and South American restaurants of Jackson Heights and Corona. On any given morning, proprietors from all these ethnic group and more gather around the pot of free coffee at Zahner's cashier station, their two-level carts bulging with butter, soup stock, soybean oil, and paper goods.
Nichos Gregoriou, owner of the Pinocchio Greek restaurant in Astoria, was first in line on a recent day, stocking up on cases of tomato paste, Open Pit barbecue sauce and napkins. Behind him was Tony Esposito, owner of Pastafina Restaurant and Pizza on Third Avenue at 28th Street in Manhattan, buying 15 dozen eggs, 20 pounds of angel hair pasta, and cases of feta cheese and thyme. Peter Bodziony, whose mother owns Stylowa, a Polish restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was next, followed by Maissa Ahmed, proprietor of Maissa's Bagel Shop in Astoria.
Sipping a last coffee before they began the day's lunch preparations, the owners grumbled collectively about the state of the food-service economy.
"I come here almost every day from Manhattan because it's cheaper here in Queens, and these days every dollar counts," Mr. Esposito said. "That should tell you something about how business is doing."
"It's O.K. lately, not great but O.K.," said Ms. Ahmed, an agricultural engineer who came to New York four years ago from Egypt. "But there are many days when I want to go back home and be an engineer."
Ms. Ahmed, whose bagel shop supports her husband and four children, said many immigrants with a little money to invest continue to put it in the restaurant business, which allows them to build an independent economic base before moving on to other middle-class pursuits.
"People come here and want to work on their own," she said. "They do not want to work for someone else. You put in a lot of hours, but we all know how to cook and usually like to do it."
Ms. Ahmed confirmed the general impression at Zahner's that many more immigrants from the Middle East have been moving into the restaurant business lately. Scott Wexler, executive director of the New York Tavern and Restaurant Association, said he shared the sense that the Greek domination of the restaurant industry in Queens -- where coffee shops and diners have long predominated -- has given way to a far broader spectrum of owners.
"We're seeing a lot more different ethnicities," he said. "Frankly, I think it takes someone not experienced in the difficulties of working in the industry to want to get into it."
When Hy Cohen bought the bar-supply business from the Zahner family in the mid-1950's, it was a tiny operation in Jackson Heights without a single wok or phyllo pastry. Now, said Ms. Deixler, Hy Cohen's granddaughter, at least 90 percent of her customers have a first language other than English, and she has hired employees to match.
"We've got guys who speak Greek, Hindi and Spanish," she said. "Now what we need is somebody who speaks Korean. That would help a lot."
The store, one of the largest of its kind in the city, is unusual in two respects that have made it particularly popular with small ethnic restaurants. For one, it stocks everything from whisks and uniforms to bulk feta cheese and ketchup packets. For another, it is self-serve, allowing patrons with limited English to select or simply point to the items they want, rather than filling out an order form.
Its popularity has allowed the store to develop an early-warning system on demographic food trends. Over the last two years, employees realized that Greek immigrants were starting to prefer the more lucrative construction trades.
"All of a sudden, we started getting more requests for Arab pocket pita and less for gyros pita," said Marios Christodoulides, the store's Cypriot-born floor manager. "We knew something was going on."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senators Fire Away at Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Republicans were isolationist on peacekeeping but expansionist on NATO, cooperative on counterterrorism but stingy on the peso.
Granted, a single hearing of the House Committee on International Relations is not a Republican Rorschach test. But in their two-and-a-half-hour encounter today with Secretary of State Warren Christopher on the state of the world, the Republicans left no doubt that their approach to foreign policy would be more scattershot than strategic. 
 Despite the Republicans' determination to strengthen the United States economy, for example, more than one member attacked the Administration for its pro-business decision last year to ignore China's poor human rights record and to extend its trade privileges. By contrast, not one Republican brought up Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Russia's military assault on Chechnya was mentioned only in passing.
And while Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, argued that the United States should open its doors to the Cuban refugees in camps in Guantanamo, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Republican of Florida, urged an airtight naval blockade should Fidel Castro again allow his people to flee.
The issue highest on the Republicans' agenda is to limit the American role in United Nations peacekeeping and in its financing.
In his testimony today, Mr. Christopher attacked the Republican plan, warning that it could leave the United States with an unacceptable choice for every emergency: "acting alone or doing nothing."
The House bill being discussed, which is similar to legislation introduced in the Senate, would both challenge the authority of the President as Commander in Chief and drastically change how the United States calculates its contributions to United Nations peacekeeping.
Under both plans, the President would have to seek Congressional approval to supply troops to a United Nations operation under a foreign commander, and the Pentagon would have to charge the United Nations for much of the equipment and services it now provides free.
Such an approach could cost the United Nations $ 1 billion a year, and much more if other countries that donate troops, equipment and services follow suit. If enacted, Mr. Christopher warned, the proposal "would threaten to end U.N. peacekeeping overnight," and would almost certainly lead others to withdraw their voluntary contributions.
Mr. Christopher said the proposal to force the President to seek Congressional approval before putting American troops under United Nations command "is unconstitutional, and it is certainly, in my judgment, very bad policy."
Mr. Christopher found an ally in Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, who asked whether the United States could have aided South Korea in the 1950's or fought to push Iraq out of Kuwait in 1991 if the bill had been law then.
"They could not have," Mr. Christopher replied.
The committee is to complete a draft of the peacekeeping portion of the bill on Friday, before the measure goes to the floor, even though Representative Lee Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and former chairman of the committee, contended that the Democrats had not seen the latest version and that he wanted to delay consideration until next week.
Even Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Christopher's Republican predecessor, told the committee two weeks ago that "micromanagement" of foreign policy was a "bad idea," and he admonishing members not to waste time challenging Presidential prerogatives.
For the most part, the Democrats today rallied around the Administration's foreign policy performance.
Proving that one's place in the pecking order of Washington can rise or fall abruptly, they chose heaped praise on Mr. Christopher, the man probably most excoriated for the foreign policy performance of the last two years.
"I find it interesting that thus far, you have not received a single commendation for the many achievements of your service as Secretary of State," Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, told Mr. Christopher. "So let me publicly state that on behalf of the vast majority of the American people, I want to thank you for your indefatigable efforts in so many parts of the world, for doing so much to bring about peace and prosperity on this globe."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A headline and a subheading yesterday about a hearing on foreign policy misidentified the location. It was in the House of Representatives, not the Senate.

HEADLINE: Haunted by Conspiracy

BYLINE: By Michael Eric Dyson; Michael Eric Dyson is author of "Making Malcolm: The Myth and Meaning of Malcolm X."

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
The allegation that Malcolm X's daughter Qubilah Shabazz conspired to murder Louis Farrakhan focuses attention on two crucial issues: the persistent role of conspiracy theories in contemporary black culture and the contradictory legacy of Malcolm X, assassinated in a Harlem ballroom 30 years ago next month.
The Shabazz case brings to the surface a submerged but powerful current of lingering suspicions toward the Government. It is well known that for decades the Federal Bureau of Investigation carried out an aggressive campaign of monitoring and subverting black leaders and organizations. From the Southern Christian Leadership Conference to the Black Panthers, from Paul Robeson to Jesse Jackson, black activists were subjected to a range of perverse tactics designed to distort their public image and undercut their influence. 
 Such abuses dramatically increased the level of distrust, bordering on paranoia, of many blacks -- not only toward the Government but toward each other, as fellow activists sometimes turned out to be informers. Since then conspiracy theories have continued to proliferate, a ragtag combination of fact, fantasy and fear.
Unfortunately, the proponents of such theories sometimes ignore real culprits lying closer to home. In the 1960's political groups like the Black Panthers and Nation of Islam had authoritarian, almost repressive tendencies; anyone who raised objections to the group's strategy or criticized its leaders was dealt with harshly. Conspiracy theorists were quick to blame outside manipulation for the resulting turmoil, when the source of the trouble was clearly within.
Many blacks were caught in a dilemma. If they acknowledged the vicious acts of intimidation by the Government, they were admitting that conspiracy theorists had a point. But if they played down Government interference, because they suspected black groups of exploiting conspiracy thinking, then they risked understating the extent of outside manipulation.
The Shabazz accusation dredges up many of these anxieties. Unquestionably, the timing of the Government's announcement provoked enormous skepticism. If it knew about the alleged murder plot for seven months, why wait until now to bring charges, just weeks before the 30th anniversary of the assassination?
It is probably fruitless to hope for an answer to this question. But more important, we should not allow this sad and bizarre turn of events to distract us from the more difficult business of reassessing Malcolm X's life and work. And such a reassessment is overdue, for it could point the way toward a moral and social climate in which it no longer makes sense to kill a human being because the vision he or she promotes is strange or threatening.
Perhaps the most harmful legacy of 1960's militant nationalism is the idea that principles can be defended with violence. Though not always manifest in physical violence, intolerance is still expressed rhetorically in the black community. Malcolm X himself was known to call Martin Luther King Jr. "Uncle Tom" and "Reverend Dr. Chickenwing." But he was able to change his mind -- primarily because he was also able to criticize himself, a quality that sometimes seems to be extinct among American leaders.
In one facet of his thought, however, Malcolm's views never wavered. His harsh indictment of the depredations encouraged in the ghetto -- drugs, prostitution, hustling -- reflected a fundamental puritanism. Despite his withering public assaults on white morality, Malcolm, like many blacks, breathed in the ethical atmosphere of mainstream America.
His conservative morality in a sense prevented him from truly respecting or understanding aspects of black culture. He saw mostly pathology in the conk, the Lindy Hop and the zoot suit, largely because he associated them with his past, the days when he was Malcolm Little, an unrepentant hustler. Yet like contemporary hip-hop culture -- which Malcolm would most likely have condemned for its explicit sexuality and glamorization of drinking and drugs -- black ghetto culture of the 1940's and 50's must also be seen as a bulwark against the racism of the larger society that embodied the spirit of ordinary people.
Black youth today, for its part, has rightly fixed on Malcolm's rage at racism and economic misery. Angry words from his speeches have appeared in rap songs, on posters and on T-shirts. One can only hope that his humanitarian legacy will eventually prove as powerful a resource. Surely this is the most lasting feature of Malcolm X's thought -- the vision of social and personal transformation he expressed in his last year, when he renounced narrow nationalism and embraced people of all colors as brothers and sisters.
As we approach the 30th anniversary of his death, one of the greatest gifts black people can give one another is the ability to disagree -- and to turn our disagreements not into reprisals but into opportunities for communication and understanding.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 Signs of slowdown were evident in a report showing that economic growth had accelerated to 4.5 percent. Despite the strong growth, the data also showed inventories of unsold goods climbed more rapidly than expected, suggesting that factory orders could taper off early this year. [Page 1.] 
 A top computer security expert is intent on catching hackers who used a new break-in technique to steal files from his own well-guarded computer. The stealth and sophistication of the attack indicated that many of the millions of computers connected to the global Internet network could be at risk. The expert, Tsutomu Shimomura, considers solving the crime a matter of honor. [33.]
 Orange County suspended all 17 employees of the treasurer's office after finding questionable accounting practices. [43.]
 
Companies
 Time Warner will pay $2.3 billion for the cable television business of Houston Industries. The acquisition would give Time Warner 690,000 subscribers in five states, strengthening its position as the nation's second-largest cable system operator. [33.]
 The effects of two jet crashes continue to weigh on USAir. The carrier estimated that it lost $110 million in revenues in the fourth quarter because passengers continued to avoid it after crashes in July and September. The estimate is in addition to the $40 million in revenue the airline said it lost in the third quarter. [33.]
 A hearing into the Sept. 8 crash of USAir Flight 427 was suspended to give Federal investigators more time. [6.]
 Complaints against Kidder Peabody and three former executives have been recommended by the S.E.C.'s New York office. The civil administrative charges being considered entail securities fraud in the case of Joseph Jett, who has been accused of manufacturing $350 million in phony bond trading profits. [33.]
 The Sumitomo Bank expects a loss of about $2.8 billion this fiscal year as it writes off mountains of bad loans. The disclosure was a stunning one in Japanese banking, which is typically conservative and taciturn. Few banks are expected to follow the lead of Sumitomo, the third-largest bank in the world. [33.]
 The Wellcome Trust still intends to sell its 39.5 percent stake in Wellcome to Glaxo despite management's rejection of the bid. The decision diminishes Wellcome's chances of evading a $14 billion hostile takeover offer by the rival British drug maker. [35.]
 Lockheed agreed to pay a $24.8 million penalty as it pleaded guilty to Federal charges of bribing an Egyptian legislator in the $79 million sale of three C-130 Hercules transport planes. [35.]
 
Markets
 Treasury bonds surged. Investors were heartened by data showing a high level of inventories, signaling a slowdown. [33.]
 Stocks ended little changed, with earnings news driving many stocks. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.07 points. [34.]
 The dollar was weighed down by concerns about the prospects for the United States loan package to Mexico. [44.]
 Gold prices fell sharply after the Government reported strong growth but with low inflation. Energy prices also dropped. [44.]
 
International
 A plan to rescue Mexico is headed for defeat in the United States Congress, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, warned. [3.]
 
Your Money
 The retirement plan of Orange County employees may be at risk. The California county's bankruptcy serves as a warning for the millions of other people who work for states, local governments and nonprofit groups that offer similar retirement plans. [31.]
 Investors will have more chances to buy stocks directly from companies under new securities rules. [31.]
 Even the not-so-rich can now be venture capitalists. [32.]

HEADLINE: 17 Orange County Workers Are Suspended With Pay

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Jan. 27

 BODY:
All 17 employees of the Orange County treasurer's office were suspended with pay today after the discovery of still more questionable accounting practices within the agency.
"These irregularities are, in my opinion, serious," said Tom Daxon, the interim treasurer brought in from Oklahoma as part of the crisis team dealing with the bankruptcy of the nation's fifth-largest county. 
 The decision to place the entire staff on leave "came after discovering additional indications of accounting irregularities within the agency," the county said in a statement.
Mr. Daxon and other officials told a news conference there was no indication any of the employees placed on leave had broken any laws.
"We want to make certain that people who do business with Orange County understand that the business that goes on in the treasurer's office is beyond reproach," Mr. Daxon said. The vacated treasurer's office positions will be filled by county employees from other departments and selected county employees with finance and accounting skills.
Last Saturday, county officials said $85 million had been diverted into two special accounts at the treasurer's office. The latest estimate of this and other diversions is now between $130 million and $140 million, according to Mark Rohman, an expert with the Arthur Andersen accounting firm, which is reviewing the accounts.
The effect of the diversions was to transfer some losses from Orange County itself to about 135 California agencies participating in an investment pool, officials said.
Bruce Bennett, the lawyer heading the financial reorganization for the county, said it did not change the overall loss estimate of $1.7 billion.
The treasury office shake-up came a day after a top executive of KPMG Peat Markwick said the accounting firm's name had been incorrectly used to imply endorsement of a $600 million Orange County bond offering underwritten by Merrill Lynch & Company, the county's lead broker.
Merrill Lynch maintained that its dealings with the county had been proper. But Peat Marwick's assertion sheds new doubt on whether bond buyers were misled about the county's risky bets on interest rates.
Bond buyers have sued Merrill Lynch and have previously indicated they intend to add Peat Marwick and other professional advisers to the county as defendants.
The official statement for the bonds says twice that Peat Marwick approved inclusion of its auditing report and the 1992-93 Orange County financial data it had certified.

HEADLINE: Bonds Gain On Signs of A Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds rallied yesterday, driving rates down to their lowest level in more than three months, on signs that the economy might be cooling off and that inflation remained in check.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond jumped 14/32 , to 9710/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.73 percent, from 7.83 percent on Thursday. The market had its biggest one-day gain yesterday since Dec. 2, and the 30-year bond's yield was the lowest since Oct. 19, when it was 7.67 percent. 
 For investors, the last three days of trading have added about $21.25 for each $1,000 of bonds.
While the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the economy grew at a strong 4.5 percent pace in the last quarter of 1994, the data also showed that inventories of unsold goods climbed more rapidly than expected. The high level of inventories signals that production and growth could slow if consumers cut back spending.
The other positive in the report on gross domestic product was the inflation data. The implicit deflator number, which measures pricing within the overall economy, was up 1.6 percent, from 1.9 percent in the previous quarter, and up 2.1 percent for 1994 -- the lowest rise in 30 years.
The data "suggest that we have yet to see evidence of a pickup in inflation," said Michael Englund, chief economist at MMS International in San Francisco. "In general, it also helps to lock in the expected 50- basis-point Fed increase next week," he said. The Federal Reserve, which last raised short-term interest rates on Nov. 15 by 75 basis points, is widely expected to increase rates after its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday and Wednesday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
While many traders and analysts say they expect the next increase by the Fed to be its last for some time, Mr. Englund said he saw at least one more increase coming at the Fed's March 31 policy meeting. The Fed has raised short-term interest rates six times since last February in an effort to slow the economy and prevent inflation from accelerating.
Bond prices have climbed since Wednesday, when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Budget Committee that the "torrid growth is slowing down." Mr. Greenspan's testimony instilled confidence among investors that the Fed's strategy was working.
Prices of municipal bonds and mortgage securities also surged yesterday.
Although there were signs that growth may slow in the months ahead, the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter still showed that the economy was strong, a fact that makes it even more likely that the Fed will raise rates next week. Mr. Englund of MMS International said, "It was obvious from the G.D.P. estimate that there was sufficient widespread momentum in the fourth quarter, despite efforts by the Fed to slow basic growth." He said strength in consumption had run above the trend for the last three years.
Among the signs of strength in the fourth quarter were equipment spending, which grew at a 20 percent clip. "The interest-rate-sensitive equipment sector is further evidence that the Fed's efforts to slow the economy have thus far been inadequate," Mr. Englund said.
The bond market will next turn its attention to next week's announcement by the Treasury about the size of its quarterly refunding and the Government's report on January employment, which will be released on Friday.

HEADLINE: Stocks Finish Mixed On Economic Report

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday, despite a rally for bonds that saw their biggest gains in more than two months. Stock and bond traders reacted differently to news that the economy grew as strongly as expected in the fourth quarter but that growth may be slowing.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.45 points, to 3,857.99, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.07 points, to 470.39. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index gained 1.34 points, to 758.91. 
 For the week, the Dow lost more than 11 points.
The Commerce Department reported that the nation's gross domestic product grew at a robust 4.5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, but that a large part of the growth -- more than one-sixth -- appeared to come from a buildup of inventories.
Such a buildup, analysts say, may indicate that the economy is slowing, as companies are unable to sell goods that are piling up in warehouses. A slowing economy would mean the Federal Reserve was more likely to curb its pattern of raising interest rates.
"If I were on the Fed and looking at these numbers, I would do nothing for now," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, head of a global economic consulting firm that bears her name.
"But considering what the market expects," she said, "I'm sure the Fed will go for a 50-basis-point increase" at its at its meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday, or later in February. Fifty basis points equals half a percentage point.
Following the release of the G.D.P. report, bond prices rose sharply; the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell for the third consecutive day, to 7.73 percent from 7.83 percent.
Traders said several technical factors might have accounted for the stock market's turning in a mixed performance. For example, several stocks with rising prices did not trade at the beginning of the session and thus did not counteract the morning's drop.
"It was a funny market from the standpoint of a lot of delayed openings missing the day's highs, which basically occurred in the first 15 minutes of trading," said Donald Kimsey, a senior technical analyst at Smith Barney.
Walt Disney, LSI Logic and others had delayed openings, often because of order imbalances following the reporting of earnings. Disney, after hitting a 52-week high of 50 1/2, closed at 50 1/4, up 3, after reporting a surge in earnings on Thursday. LSI Logic, a semiconductor company, rose gained 3 1/4, to 43 1/2, on strong fourth-quarter profits reported on Thursday.
Lakeland First Financial Group, a savings and loan in New Jersey, hit a 52-week high of 29 1/2, before closing at 28 3/4, up 7 1/4. Valley National Bancorp, also of New Jersey, agreed on Thursday to buy Lakeland for $128 million.
Other companies' stocks fell on their earnings outlook. Microtouch Systems, a maker of screen-based systems for computers, fell 4 3/4, to 30 3/8, after analysts who follow the company said first-quarter revenue was likely to decline from that of the fourth quarter.
Similarly, Legent, a computer software company, fell 4, to 30 1/4, after it reported first-quarter revenue growth that was less than analysts expected. Trinova hit a 52-week low of 24 1/4, before closing at 25, down 3. Trinova, which makes rubber products and air-conditioning systems, warned analysts of a likely slowdown in business.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 339.5 million shares changing hands, about 14 percent above the daily average of 298 million shares for the last six months.
In Tokyo, Japanese stocks closed slightly higher yesterday after a week of big losses. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 33.51 points, to 18,104.35. For the week, however, the Nikkei was down 735.87 points, or 3.9 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concerns About Mexico Aid Erode Dollar's Early Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against leading currencies yesterday as concern about the prospects for United States aid to Mexico offset a mounting conviction that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next week.
The dollar surged in early New York trading after a report showed that the United States economy grew at an annual rate of 4.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. 
 The report on gross domestic product confirmed expecations that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday and Wednesday. Higher rates make dollar-denominated investments and deposits more attractive to foreign investors.
But the dollar's gains evaporated after Republican leaders expressed doubts that there would be enough Congressional support to gain approval of the Clinton Administration's $40 billion loan-guarantee package for Mexico.
"Mexico still weighs on the dollar," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York.
Mexico's financial crisis has been a drag on the dollar because of concern that it could harm growth in the United States. Mexico is the United States' third-biggest trading partner. There are also concerns that the Federal Reserve might be compelled to sell dollars for pesos to support the sinking peso, which has fallen almost 40 percent since it was devalued on Dec. 20.
The dollar rose as high as 1.5194 German marks before settling at 1.5150 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.5177 marks on Thursday. The dollar was unchanged at 99.40 Japanese yen. It slipped to 1.2746 Swiss francs from 1.2765 francs. The British pound fell to $1.5890 from $1.5905.
The dollar fell after House Speaker Newt Gingrich said it would be "hard work" for Congress to approve the aid package.
While the dollar has been supported by expectations of another Fed increase in interest rates, it may take an increase of 75 basis points to bolster the dollar because a smaller rise has been anticipated for so long, said Andrew Larkin, currency salesman at Postipankki Ltd., a Finnish bank in New York. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sumitomo Bank Expecting Huge Loss From Bad Loans

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In what analysts say was a signal of the first annual loss for a major Japanese bank since the end of World War II, the Sumitomo Bank said today that it expected to report a loss of about $2.8 billion this fiscal year as it writes off mountains of bad loans.
The announcement, which stunned bankers here, reflects the magnitude of the bad-debt problem afflicting Japanese banks. But the move by Sumitomo, the third-largest bank in the world, was also praised by analysts as a bold attempt -- at least for the normally conservative Japanese banks -- to bite the bullet and resolve problems quickly. 
 "It's a gutsy move," said Alicia Ogawa, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in Tokyo. "It's completely unprecedented. It will make other banks answer the question of why they are not doing that."
Many major banks in the United States have had losses from writing off bad debts. Investors often regard these moves as positive for the long run because they speed the cleanup of the balance sheet.
But in Japan, analysts said, the all-powerful Ministry of Finance has restrained banks from reporting losses for fear of undermining public confidence in the banking system.
As a result, banks have been disposing of their bad loans bit by bit, and selling stock in companies they own to compensate for the write-offs. "If every bank did not take equity gains, every bank would have a net loss," said Elizabeth Daniels, banking analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo.
The slow disposal of bad debts, however, has been delaying Japan's recovery from a three-year-long recession, because banks weighed down with bad loans have been reluctant to lend new money.
Analysts said Sumitomo's action might be emulated by some other banks, but not by many. Most banks do not have the financial strength that Sumitomo has to withstand a big loss. And the Finance Ministry, which approved Sumitomo's move, might be reluctant to see the practice spread too widely.
"To suddenly start having a half-dozen or a dozen banks taking a loss, that might cause some worries," said J. Brian Waterhouse, an analyst with James Capel in Tokyo. He and other analysts said they saw little risk to Japan's banking system from Sumitomo's action.
Sumitomo, part of the huge Sumitomo Group based in Osaka, is considered one of the most prestigious, aggressive and profit-oriented banks in Japan. It owns 12.5 percent of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street firm.
But Sumitomo ran into trouble because of billions of dollars of loans it made to the Itoman Corporation, a scandal-tainted trading company. Itoman invested wildly in real estate and bought Picassos, Chagalls and other works of art as a way to launder money, resulting in the arrests of several executives. Itoman was rescued by Sumitomo Bank and absorbed into another company in the Sumitomo Group in 1993.
Sumitomo Bank said today that it had been planning to write off 500 billion yen, or about $5 billion, worth of loans in the second half of the fiscal year, but has now increased that to 800 billion yen, or about $8 billion. This includes all the Itoman loans still on Sumitomo's books.
While the bank will sell some of its stock holdings to partly compensate, it predicted it would still end up with a net loss to its parent company of 280 billion yen, or $2.8 billion, in the fiscal year that ends March 31. Until today the bank had been forecasting a net profit of 35 billion yen.
At a news conference today, Yoshifumi Nishikawa, a senior managing director, said the bank made a "strategic choice" that would improve its financial condition in the medium and long term. He said the loss would be for this year only.
Sumitomo, which had 1.2 trillion yen, or $12 billion, of nonperforming loans on its books in September, said it had a strong capital position and could withstand the loss.
Sumitomo's announcement came after the close of trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The bank's shares had ended the day at 1,610 yen, a loss of 20 yen.
Most Japanese banks made unwise loans during the late 1980's, when Japanese land and stock prices were soaring wildly. But in the early 1990's, the "bubble" collapsed and Japan plunged into a recession.
Japan's 21 major banks reported 13.3 trillion yen, or about $133 billion, of bad loans in September, but that excludes restructured loans on which the banks receive little or no interest. Ms. Daniels of Morgan Stanley estimates that bad loans actually total 40 trillion yen, or $400 billion.
In October, the Nippon Trust Bank essentially collapsed and predicted a loss of $1.6 billion this fiscal year. Mitsubishi Bank rescued it by purchasing control for about $2 billion. Two weeks earlier, Mitsubishi had absorbed $1 billion in losses to prop up two affiliated finance companies.
In December, the Bank of Japan aided the takeover of two ailing credit associations, the first such use of public money.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Sent Lower By Low-Inflation Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Precious metals tumbled yesterday after the Government reported strong growth but with low inflation.
In its report on the nation's economic growth, the Commerce Department said its broadest gauge of inflation rose by 2.1 percent during 1994, the lowest in three decades. 
 "With lower inflation, there's no real reason to buy gold," said Leonard Kaplan, vice president and chief trader with Imperial Bank in Los Angeles.
On other commodity markets, energy and coffee prices fell sharply, dragging the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities down 1.48 points, to 234.01.
Gold for February delivery fell $4.90, to $376.80 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, while March silver dropped 12 cents, to $4.675 an ounce.
Gasoline prices fell to a two-week low amid concern that New Jersey will switch to selling a cheaper motor fuel, slashing demand by as much as 40 percent for the cleaner-burning grade traded on the futures exchange.
"The market's saying it's spooked by the fact that New Jersey could back out and there hasn't been any clarification yet that they can't," said John Saucer, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc. in Houston.
In March, New Jersey wants to begin selling gasoline with less methyl tertiary butyl ether, an additive that helps reduce carbon monoxide emissions. The state contends it can meet Federal air standards with less of the additive in its gasoline, and has cited concern about possible adverse health effects caused by it.
Gasoline for February delivery slumped 1.37 cents, to 56.07 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest price since Jan. 13. March crude oil fell 29 cents, to $17.95 a barrel.
Coffee prices plunged after Brazil, the world's largest producer, failed to join other growers in withholding exports.
Growers in Brazil met Thursday night to discuss a retention plan designed by producers in Central America and Colombia to keep coffee off the market until prices rise. The meeting adjourned without an agreement to join the plan.
"They just agreed to meet next month, and the trade thinks that means they aren't going to be able to keep a cap on supplies," said Luis Bethart, a coffee trader at Lamborn Futures Company in Miami.
The March coffee contract fell 4.5 cents, to $1.625 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the lowest for an active contract since Dec. 20.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Less Affluent Players Join Super-Rich Game

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
EVERY investor dreams of discovering the next Apple Computer or Intel. But investors who get in long before a public stock offering have the most to gain. And small start-up companies fail at an alarmingly high rate, leaving many people holding the bag.
To spread the risk, venture capital funds bet on many companies. Getting into such a fund, though, generally requires an investment of at least $1 million. 
 Now the United States Trust Company in New York, whose clients range from the super-wealthy to the somewhat affluent, has created a fund that requires a more modest commitment. Though not quite a populist play, the fund is open to bank clients who are willing to put up just $15,000 and who have investment portfolios of $250,000 or more.
The managers of the fund, called the UST Private Equity Investors Fund, hope to raise $50 million.
"It is a high-risk proposition, and should be sold to those who can take that risk," said David I. Fann, the fund's president and chief executive. "But we are trying to develop the ability to further diversify our clients' assets into areas that do not behave the way traditional equity or debt instruments behave."
Mr. Fann and Frederick Taylor, the bank's chief investment officer, consider the timing good because of a slowdown in corporate financing and initial public offerings. "A lot of companies that would have gone public this year won't be going public," Mr. Fann said. "These firms will still require capital, and the only place they have to turn to is the private marketplace."
Venture capital funds have often disappointed. Despite the risks, the top-performing funds have done only about as well as large company stocks over the last decade.
"The upper quartile of venture capital funds have about a 13 percent annualized rate of return," said Jesse Reyes, a managing director at Venture Economics Information Services, a Boston-based subsidiary of the Securities Data Company. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks has posted an average total return of 14.78 percent the last 10 years, Birinyi Associates, a stock market research firm, calculated.
"Most investors looking at venture capital now are expecting returns of anywhere from 13 percent to 15 percent," Mr. Reyes said. "Ten years ago, people were expecting returns of 25 percent to 30 percent."
Expectations have fallen in part because so much more money is chasing companies. By the end of 1993, venture capital firms had $34.7 billion, up from $6 billion in 1980, Mr. Reyes said.
Venture capital funds were not always dominated by the super-rich. Many publicly traded venture capital companies were begun in the early 1960's, said Steven P. Galante, editor of Private Equity Analyst, a monthly newsletter, "but they went private in the 1970's and 1980's."
Investors in the funds typically profit when a start-up company is sold or issues public stock. If the company fails, the money is gone.
U.S. Trust cautions clients that it may take four years for the capital to be fully invested, that the money cannot be withdrawn at a moment's notice and that any gains will not be realized for years.
"The main thing to realize is that this is a long-term, illiquid investment," Mr. Galante said.
The new fund carries smaller fees than its big-ticket cousins. Fees will be 1.5 percent of assets when the fund is fully invested, compared with 2.5 percent to 3.25 percent elsewhere, Mr. Reyes said.
The fund is also structured to be less risky. At least 70 percent of its assets will be invested in later-stage venture capital companies, described as closely held enterprises with more than $5 million in annual revenue, and middle-market companies, with annual sales of $25 million to $250 million. No one company will account for more than 10 percent of the fund's assets.
To take advantage of prominent manager's skills, the fund can invest up to 30 percent of its assets in buyout, private equity and other venture capital funds.

HEADLINE: Economy Grew At a Brisk Rate In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The economy accelerated to a 4.5 percent growth rate in the final three months of 1994, the Government reported today, but ended the strongest year in a decade with clear signs that the slowdown long sought by the Federal Reserve may be at hand.
In financial markets, bond prices surged, driving interest rates lower, as analysts concluded that a slowdown could mean the Federal Reserve was close to the end of a credit-tightening it began a year ago to keep inflation in check and the business expansion from overheating. [Page 33.] The broad stock market was steady, but blue-chip stocks fell. [Page 34.] 
 The Wall Street response was prompted by the Commerce Department's latest quarterly report on the nation's output of goods and services, which showed that the strong growth at the end of 1994 failed to cause inflation to budge. The report also disclosed that inventories of unsold goods climbed more than expected, suggesting that factory orders could taper off early this year as stores scaled back their demands for new supplies. That caused a scramble among private analysts to trim their forecasts of economic growth for the first half of 1995.
While most economists still expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates at its policy meeting next week -- probably by half a percentage point -- it now appears much more likely that any increase would be either the central bank's final move for a while, or at least that any subsequent action would be minimal.
"The slowdown in this economy is here," predicted James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "That big inventory number is the 400-pound gorilla that is jumping all over first-quarter growth."
It was not clear exactly what caused the large buildup in unsold goods, but analysts tended to interpret it as a tailing-off of consumer buying at the end of the year rather than as an intentional restocking of store shelves.
Nothing in the report pointed to an impending recession. Still, the inventory buildup and other economic signals suggest that the overall 1994 growth rate of 4 percent could turn out to be the last big advance in the continuing expansion that began in spring 1991.
Higher interest rates finally seem to be taking their toll. Car sales, for instance, appear to be peaking as dealers reduce their orders to avoid extra financing costs, causing some auto makers to idle factories producing models that were hot sellers only a few weeks ago. Meanwhile, there is evidence suggesting that Christmas sales were disappointing and that home building may slow after unexpectedly strong autumn and early winter sales, which benefited from warmer than usual weather.
Putting it all together, Mr. Annable, the bank economist, marked down his forecast for growth in the gross domestic product -- the value of all goods and services produced within the nation's borders -- in the January-March period to 2.3 percent from an earlier prediction of 3 percent. He also said the pace for the spring quarter might be less than 2 percent.
This would be below the roughly 2.5 percent rate that economists generally consider the fastest an economy with relatively low unemployment can grow without intensifying inflation. That growth rate is the target often cited by Fed officials.
Inflation remained remarkably subdued in the fourth quarter, today's report also showed, with the index of prices paid by American residents up at a 2.5 percent pace in the fourth quarter, compared with 3.5 percent in the third quarter. For the year, the inflation rate was 2.6 percent, compared with 2.8 percent in 1993.
"The economy has not enjoyed such a healthy combination of strong growth and modest inflation in 30 years," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Last year's inflation-adjusted gain of 4 percent was up from 3.1 percent in 1993 and was the best year-to-year increase since a 6.2 percent burst in 1984, when the economy boomed after pulling out of a recession that ended in 1982. Measured on a fourth-quarter to fourth-quarter basis, the increase was also 4 percent, the strongest rise since 1987.
Robust consumer spending and business investment undergirded the fourth-quarter gain of 4.5 percent, but much of the attention went to the jump in inventories, amounting to $68 billion at an annual rate, up from the already hot pace of $58 billion, on average, for the two preceding quarters.
Inventory figures, however, are notoriously hard to interpret, since stockpiles can rise for opposite reasons: conditions so bad that consumers have stopped buying or conditions so good that store owners have aggressively restocked their shelves.
Whichever the case, a buildup of inventories adds to G.D.P. in the period in which the goods are produced and implies that there will be a subsequent subtraction from future quarters as the excess is worked off.
Rosanne M. Cahn, director of the economics department at CS First Boston, expressed a relatively benign view of the situation.
"The pace of inventory restocking picked up," she said. "But stocks had been drawn down too much by the end of 1993." Still, once these goods are sold in coming months, she added, the higher level of inventories "will reinforce the 1995 slowdown once it gets under way."
John M. Godfrey, chief economist for Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla., largely agreed, describing the latest inventory data as sowing "the seeds of softness later on."
Despite earlier reports pointing to lackluster holiday shopping, the report released today found that consumer spending for the quarter accelerated to a 4.6 percent rate of growth from 3.1 percent in the July-September period.
This, however, was heavily concentrated in cars, light trucks and other durable goods, where a slowdown in sales is already evident in the reports from auto makers that they are temporarily closing some plants and offering rebates on some vehicles.
Growth in spending for nondurables like clothing slackened in the fourth quarter, just as many apparel chains and department stores had indicated in their post-Christmas reports. Mr. Annable predicted that consumers would be increasingly restrained this year by high amounts of debt, fewer new jobs and rising interest rates.
Consumers still maintain substantial buying power, however, and personal savings actually climbed a bit to 4.6 percent of disposable income after standing at 4.1 percent in the spring and summer quarters.
Businesses continued to invest feverishly in equipment during the quarter, lifting growth to a 20.2 percent annual rate. However welcome as a sign of the growing competitiveness of American industry, that is a pace, analysts said, that probably cannot be sustained much longer.
"The economy is becoming increasingly dependent upon business investment," cautioned G. David Orr, chief economist of the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
 Data included in the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 1994 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Dole Warns White House That Plan to Bolster Peso Will Not Pass

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, signaled today that the White House plan to rescue the Mexican economy by guaranteeing $40 billion in loans is headed for defeat in Congress.
 After two weeks of debate, the program is "out there in limbo somewhere," he said. 
 Mexico abruptly devalued the peso in late December to make it easier for the Government to repay vast short-term loans overseas. Since then prices have risen sharply and investors have shied away, and the Government needs a major infusion of cash to support the peso and restore confidence.
 Senator Dole, who pledged support for the plan two weeks ago, said many Democrats and Republicans who had supported the idea of helping Mexico are recoiling at the Administration's proposal, which calls for Washington essentially to act as a co-signer for Mexican bonds.
 In hearings this week, top Administration officials, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, won over few legislators. Administration officials appeared to regroup today, meeting leaders on Capitol Hill and talking vaguely of restructuring the plan.
 Mr. Dole said that he was sympathetic to Mexico's plight and that he wanted to help, but he suggested that the loan guarantees may not be enough to solve Mexico's problems. Mr. Clinton, he said, "needs to step up to the plate," adding, "Something dramatic has got to happen."
 Mr. Dole concluded: "I see people who were for it saying, 'I'm not going to vote for this thing.' 'You were for it last week.' 'That was last week.' "
 Mr. Dole suggested that the Administration had been increasingly hurt by questions of who would benefit. "Is it politicians from Mexico, and Wall Street?" he asked. "If that's the case, I don't want to cast my vote to expose the American taxpayer to any risk at all. It's not our purpose to bail out people who made bad investments."
 Some Democrats also say support is eroding, in part because there is no bill actually before either house.
 The Administration has been loath to commit the plan to writing until it can negotiate conditions acceptable to Democrats like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the minority leader, who are insisting on minimum-wage requirements and other assurances that Mexican companies would not increase their competitive advantage. Mexican products already cost 35 percent less in dollar terms than before the devaluation.
 But the White House also has to satisfy Republicans who are nervous about seeming to promote a package that has little public support.
 "It's like waiting for Godot right now," said one Democrat working on the negotiations. Republicans, he said, do not want to meet on the subject. "Meanwhile, support is eroding on both sides," he said.

HEADLINE: Governors Propose a Limit To U.S. Control of Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
On the eve of a White House conference on welfare policy, leaders of the National Governors' Association have devised a bipartisan proposal that would give states the option of taking a single Federal payment each year and designing their own welfare programs, with hardly any Federal regulations.
 Although President Clinton called the conference to promote bipartisan cooperation on welfare, top Administration officials have already expressed reservations about some elements of the association's plan, saying they could hurt poor children. 
 In a confidential memorandum to the President, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said Mr. Clinton would make a big mistake by "leaving welfare reform to the states in a grand bargain with the governors."
 "Simply passing the buck to the states is not welfare reform," she declared.
 In a similar vein, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said that Mr. Clinton wanted to protect "the entitlement side" of welfare, which guarantees that cash benefits will be available to people who meet certain eligibility criteria, regardless of the number who apply or the total cost. "You can't just roll the dice and hope that the states are going to pick that all up," Mr. Panetta said on Thursday at a meeting with journalists.
 Administration officials said they would play down such disagreements at the conference on Saturday, where Mr. Clinton will discuss welfare with six governors, sixteen members of Congress, two state legislators, two mayors and two county officials. The Administration hopes those attending will endorse certain basic principles, described as follows in White House documents:
 "Anyone who can work should do so. Welfare reform should include time limits. Anyone who brings a child into this world ought to be prepared to take financial and personal responsibility for that child's future. Teen pregnancy and out-of-wedlock childbearing are important problems that must be addressed through comprehensive welfare reform."
 The leaders of the association, who are attending the White House conference, have circulated a draft of their proposal among other governors, but have not made it generally available. Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who is chairman of the association, said in an interview today that he believed the full organization would endorse the proposal at its winter meeting, to be held here from Sunday through Tuesday. He described the proposal as "a reasonable compromise" between Republicans who wanted complete state flexibility and Democrats who wanted the Federal Government to guarantee some basic standard of living for children.
 The proposal would give states a choice of two alternatives to replace the main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
 States could take a lump sum of Federal money, or a block grant, to assist poor families and children in any way they wanted, "with no Federal restrictions." State plans "would not be subjected to Federal approval or Federal revision," and states would not have to put up any specific amounts of their own money to match the Federal dollars.
 Alternatively, states could continue welfare as an entitlement program. But they would have far more freedom than they now have to define eligibility, adjust benefit levels and design their own programs.
 With this option, the Government would set time limits for the receipt of welfare benefits, which would be "contingent on compliance with a social contract"; that is, welfare recipients would have to begin work within a specified time.
 Under the proposal, state officials would gain vast new discretion even if they kept welfare as an entitlement program. They could, for example, provide assistance in the form of vouchers rather than cash; penalize welfare recipients who failed to attend school; require teen-age welfare recipients to live with their parents, and "limit benefits to mothers with additional children born while they are on welfare."
 But the governors said they opposed Federal legislation that would "mandate such state policies."
 Some Republican governors, like John Engler of Michigan and Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, want to consolidate scores of Federal programs in a handful of block grants. But Governor Dean, a Democrat, said: "A lot of governors are concerned about what a block grant with a cap will do to state budgets and to the poorest, most vulnerable people, who are children. Under our bipartisan proposal, even in states that take the block grant with no Federal oversight, children must be the beneficiaries so they don't fall through the cracks."
 Aside from that requirement, he said, governors who chose the block grant would generally be free to "do their thing."
 Mr. Panetta, the chief of staff, said the proper degree of state flexibility was "an area of dispute" with the governors. One purpose of the meeting on Saturday is to "try to bridge the differences," he said.
 In addition to Mr. Dean, the Democratic Governors who devised the proposal are Mel Carnahan of Missouri and Thomas R. Carper of Delaware. The Republican Governors are Mr. Thompson, Mr. Engler and Arne Carlson of Minnesota. Mr. Thompson is vice chairman of the association. Mr. Carnahan is chairman of its committee on human resources, and Mr. Carlson is vice chairman of the committee.
 In her memorandum to the President, Dr. Shalala said that the governors' proposal for block grants seemed "consistent with your strong commitment to state flexibility" and was, in some ways, preferable to the "Draconian cuts" proposed by House Republicans. But she said block grants "hold considerable dangers."
 "Block grants fail to protect vulnerable children, will not result in real welfare reform and will not protect the states from economic changes," Dr. Shalala said.
 She also told the President that any move toward block grants would increase variation in the amounts of assistance offered to poor people in different states. "Some states would lower their already meager state contributions to benefit levels, and some states would completely eliminate eligibility for some groups of people," she predicted.
 In announcing the conference with the governors last month, Mr. Clinton said he wanted "an honest dialogue about our country's broken welfare system."
 A Democrat invited to the conference said today: "The White House staff is nervous. They are trying hard to make sure it doesn't blow up in their face because of partisan disagreements."
 Republicans working on the conference said they were somewhat irritated with the Administration. On the one hand, they noted, Mr. Clinton said he wanted a bipartisan dialogue. On the other, they said, the Department of Health and Human Services and the Agriculture Department have issued studies portraying Republican proposals on welfare as extremely harmful to welfare recipients, schoolchildren, pregnant women, infants, farmers and the retail food industry.
 The governors oppose a part of a welfare bill proposed by House Republicans that would terminate benefits for legal immigrants. Mr. Panetta said the President would not support such a "perverse provision."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The President met with former welfare recipients to prepare for today's White House conference on welfare with governors and other officials. The conference is intended to encourage bipartisan efforts on the issue. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Threaten Balanced-Budget Measure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Hours after the balanced-budget movement rolled its constitutional amendment, juggernaut fashion, through the House, the Senate served notice today that it might not be so compliant.
 At a news conference, Senate Democrats who had voted for a similar amendment in the past hinted broadly that they could change their minds unless the Senate's Republican majority agreed to produce a detailed budget-balancing plan as part of an amendment package. 
 They backed that up with a letter to the majority leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, urging that both parties draft legislation to erase the Federal deficit by 2002, the earliest an amendment would take effect.
 Forty-one Democrats signed the letter -- the minimum number, perhaps coincidentally -- that would be needed if Democrats chose to filibuster the amendment. Many oppose the notion of an amendment but say they favor a specific plan to balance the budget.
 "The Republicans have said they're going to increase defense spending, provide a tax cut, protect Social Security and reduce the deficit to zero by 2002," said the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. "We think they owe it to the American people to explain how."
 Mr. Daschle, one of four Democratic leaders at the news conference, denied that the letter was a filibuster threat. But he added that Democrats expected a full debate on the need for a deficit-reduction plan when the balanced-budget debate began next week. He said his own support for an amendment would be in doubt if a plan was not forthcoming.
 Another Democrat who signed the letter, Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, called the 41 signatures a signal to Republicans that Democrats could make trouble if their concerns were not addressed.
 "But," Mr. Leahy added, "I don't think anybody wants to filibuster something that requires a two-thirds vote to pass anyway."
 In truth, Mr. Daschle and the other Democrats have the Republicans in something of a box. Because the Senate's 53 Republicans need 60 votes to stop a filibuster and 67 votes to pass the amendment if all 100 senators vote, no balanced-budget amendment is going anywhere without Democratic help.
 The White House and Democratic leaders in Congress have been reluctant to oppose the popular amendment movement outright; indeed, many Democrats in Congress, like Mr. Daschle, favor some form of the measure. But all say it is irresponsible to pass a balanced-budget amendment without giving the states a clear explanation of the cuts in Federal money and services that it would bring.
 After Senate passage, 38 state legislatures would have to ratify the amendment before it would become part of the Constitution.
 Republicans rejected efforts to append a budget-cutting explanation to the House version of the amendment, saying that any budget forecast purporting to cover seven years of economic growth and recession would itself be irresponsible.
 Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed polite interest in the idea when the amendment was considered earlier this month, but also rejected it.
 Mr. Dole, who will control the pace and content of the balanced-budget debate, was noncommittal when asked about the Democratic letter. "It's a nice letter," he said, adding that he had not had time to consider it.
 In the House, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia said he planned to schedule a House vote in April 1996, close to the deadline for filing income-tax returns, on another constitutional amendment, which would prohibit tax increases without the approval of three-fifths of the total membership of both chambers of Congress.
 Many tax increases can now be enacted by majority vote, although the House rules bar income-tax increases without the consent of three-fifths of all representatives voting.
 Mr. Gingrich and other party leaders offered the vote to House freshmen to soothe their anger after a version of the balanced-budget amendment that included the three-fifths requirement failed to attract enough support to pass the House.
 In other action, the House subcommittee that oversees military appropriations approved legislation today that allotted $3.2 billion in emergency spending for Pentagon operations in Haiti and elsewhere, as well as additional money for military pay.
 The action drew immediate criticism from Democrats, who noted that only $1.4 billion of the new spending was offset by cuts elsewhere in the budget. That means that the bill would add $1.8 billion to the Federal deficit, something Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, called "incredibly ludicrous" in the wake of the House's approval of a balanced-budget amendment.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "DOING THE MATH -- Voting On a Balanced Budget" Last year, the senate failed to approve the balanced budget amendment, voting 63 to 37 in favor, or four votes short of a two-thirds majority. Eleven senators, 7 of whom voted for the amendment and 4 who voted against, were not re-elected. This year, the 11 new senators, all Republicans, plan to vote for the amendment. It takes 34 senators to block a constitutional amendment. The outcome will turn on the votes of several Democrats who voted yes last yer but now say they are having second thoughts.

HEADLINE: Group Offers Plan to Give Historic Area Modern Look

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In an effort to lift the local economy and turn one of the country's oldest historical areas into a bigger tourist attraction, an organization that promotes the United States Constitution has announced a proposal to develop a high-tech, underground museum with exhibits on the Constitution and Bill of Rights, the Declaration of Independence and the Liberty Bell.
 A proposed $170 million Constitution Center, to be financed largely through private donations, would replace a parking garage beneath the mall facing Independence Hall, where the Declaration of Independence was adopted and the Constitution was drafted. 
 The Liberty Bell, now displayed in modest quarters a block from Independence Hall, would be moved a half-block farther away into a new steel and glass pavilion at the ground-level exit of the proposed museum.
 The museum would feature galleries with computer games and a theater -- one film presentation is already called, "Is This a Great Country, or What?" Visitors could see original drafts of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution and Bill of Rights and sign electronic copies with a laser pen. The Declaration of Independence and the Constitution are in the National Archives in Washington, where they will remain.
 Mayor Edward G. Rendell and other supporters of the project, which is sponsored by the National Constitution Center, say it will pump $200 million a year into the city's economy and revitalize the mall.
 The National Park Service, which administers the area, known as Independence National Historical Park, will have the final say on its development and has not said where it stands on the plan, the most ambitious of several under consideration.
 Critics of the center's design say the glitz and gizmos could trivialize the history the center celebrates. Mounting the same kind of arguments used successfully last year when residents of Northern Virginia forced the Disney Company to abandon plans for a history theme park near Civil War battlegrounds, opponents of the museum plan say its designers might be tempted to simplify interpretations of the Constitution to appeal to a wider and younger audience.
 "The Constitution is complicated," said Craig Eisendrath, the former executive director of the Pennsylvania Humanities Council, a state agency that promotes the arts. "To dumb-down stuff for the American public is destructive."
 Mr. Eisendrath was one of about two dozen members of the board of the National Constitution Center, which was created by Congress in 1988 to insure "continuing interpretation" of the Constitution within the 44 acres of Philadelphia's land supervised by the Park Service. He and seven other members quit the board in 1990 because they believed that the museum's designers were not emphasizing the educational aspects of the project.
 The opponents also say that the proposal would detract from other parts of Philadelphia's historical district, like the Betsy Ross House and the small museum on the site of the house where Benjamin Franklin lived, and destroy the colonial ambience of the area.
 Robert M. Brasler, who is president of the National Constitution Center, predicted that, in time, detractors would vanish. "I have a feeling they'll see the light," he said in an interview.
 The group expects to finance the project with private donations, corporate gifts and sponsorships, direct-mail solicitations and help from grass-roots organizations like Kiwanis Clubs. The center also plans to ask the city and state for $42 million.
 "All this is just a wish list, what we anticipate," said Mr. Brasler, who expressed optimism that the money could be raised. "But we haven't asked for anything yet."
 Nor have the city and state indicated they would be willing to contribute.
 The Park Service has devised six more modest plans for the park, costing from $57 million to under $10 million. None stress an appreciable economic boom to the city. The most ambitious would feature a new pavilion for the Liberty Bell, a new visitors' center and an underground Constitution Center smaller than the one proposed by Mr. Brasler's group. The least expensive would leave the Liberty Bell where it is, improve the landscaping around the mall and create a modest memorial to the Constitution.
 After considering all proposals, including the one from Mr. Brasler's group, the Park Service intends to announce a choice in December.
 At first, Mr. Brasler's group considered several ideas to develop a center promoting the historical significance of the events that took place in the district. At the same time, the Park Service began its own review, as it does periodically with all national parks.
 None of the ideas aroused much public interest until the National Constitution Center pitched its proposal to Mr. Rendell as a means to attract almost twice the 1.4 million people who visit the park now. That, they predicted, would aid the local economy by creating 2,500 permanent jobs and generating $19 million in new city and state taxes.
 At a news conference last week when plans for the center were announced, Mr. Rendell provided a political boost for the plan and urged the Park Service to adopt it.

HEADLINE: George Baker, Harvard Dean And U.S. Adviser, Dies at 91

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
George P. Baker, dean of the Harvard Business School in the 1960's and a leading authority on transportation, air defense and the organization of business and government, died on Wednesday in the Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Phoenix. He was 91.
 The cause was complications from a stroke, the business school said. 
 Mr. Baker served on Federal agencies and on the Harvard faculty for more than three decades, retiring as dean of the business school in 1969.
 He led the school's drive to raise money for 22 endowed professorships, or almost twice as many as had been established in the 50 previous years. Throughout his career at Harvard, he held many governmental and corporate positions.
 After World War II, he served as director of the Office of Transport and Communications Policy at the State Department, leading a delegation to a conference that completed the first bilateral agreement on international air rights.
 In 1948 he was named vice chairman of President Harry S. Truman's Air Policy Commission, which planned the nation's strategy for a larger and more strategic air defense and a concept of mutual deterrence in the cold war.
 Fulfilling a commitment made by President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Baker helped organize a group of Harvard Business School faculty members in 1964 to assist Central American countries in integrating their economies.
 In 1969 he was a member of an advisory council appointed by President Richard M. Nixon to recommend changes in the organizational structure of the executive branch to make it "a more effective instrument of public policy."
 Mr. Baker, who was trained at Harvard as an economist, was attracted to the transportation field as a boy when he developed a lifelong fascination with railroads.
 He was an instructor in economics at Harvard College from 1928 to 1936, when he moved to the faculty of the business school. He earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard in 1934.
 He left the business school in 1940 to serve on the Civil Aeronautics Board, becoming vice chairman in 1942.
 After World War II, in which he served in the Army, he specialized in transportation issues at the business school. When the Korean War began, he directed the center that coordinated the school's military research programs.
 In 1963 he ended the business school's policy of admitting only men.
 In addition to being a leading consultant to major airlines, railroads and government, he served as a director of numerous major corporations, including the Mobil Oil and Lockheed Aircraft Corporations. After his retirement from the business school, he was a bankruptcy trustee for the Penn Central Railroad.
 From 1954 to 1968 he was president or chairman of the Transportation Association of America. He was also president of the Transportation Research Foundation. He was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations
 Mr. Baker moved to Phoenix in 1978, where his first wife, Ruth, died in 1981.
 He is survived by his second wife, Mary; a son, George Jr., of Boston; two daughters, Sarah Uhle of Salt Lake City and Ruth Ursul of Brookline, Mass.; eight grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.
