HEADLINE: Beliefs;
Dispelling a myth about class warfare but confirming a decline of old values.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Are the vociferous battles that Americans have long waged over values a reflection of class warfare?
 Reacting to the radical questioning of American institutions and beliefs that flourished in the 1960's, many conservatives and disillusioned liberals said, "yes." They contended that the challenge to long-held moral and social standards was the work of a powerful "new class" of educated professionals or "knowledge workers." 
 Infected with the "adversary culture" of intellectuals, this new class was said to be contemptuous of all stable norms, including the work ethic and what have since been labeled family values. The new class, the theory went on, sought to expand government, ostensibly in the name of ideals like insuring racial justice, combating poverty, protecting the environment and ending discrimination against women, but fundamentally because a larger government gave the new class itself more power over the business civilization that it supposedly scorned.
 "The simple truth," wrote the neo-conservative grandmaster Irving Kristol, "is that the professional classes are engaged in a class struggle with the business community for status and power."
 All this made for good polemics but fuzzy sociology. To make the menace of the new class convincing, conservatives and neo-conservatives suggested that it comprised not a small knot of intellectuals, journalists and political analysts, but a vast number of Americans who had benefited from the rapid expansion of higher education and the society's new need for technical knowledge.
 Although the "new class" specter still haunts conservative nightmares, Prof. Steven Brint, a sociologist at the University of California at Riverside has now produced a study that may finally put it to rest.
 "In an Age of Experts: The Changing Role of Professionals in Politics and Public Life" (Princeton), Professor Brint concludes that instead of forming a coherent bloc with a distinctive outlook, the nation's middle-class professionals are splintered into at least five major spheres.
 These he maps as business services (like financial analysts and corporate lawyers); applied science (engineers and geoscientists, for example); culture and communications (including academics, journalists and television directors); civic regulation (judges, government administrators, interest group experts and the like), and human services (like teachers, social workers and nurses).
 Just to see that map is to realize how diverse the so-called new class is and how many professionals work in large firms and generally entrepreneurial settings.
 So it is not surprising to find, as Professor Brint does, based on an extensive review and analysis of public opinion surveys, that on economic issues related to business, labor and government welfare programs, middle-class professionals are slightly more liberal than business managers and executives but much more conservative than the average American. They are strikingly conservative on issues like crime control and military policy.
 "Even the most liberal segment of professions -- the people who would be counted as members of the 'new class' in any version of the theory -- were, by and large, far from unconventional in their tastes or decidedly left-of-center in their political views, and they certainly show little opposition to the basic organizing principles of a business civilization," Professor Brint writes, relying on both poll data and his own systematic analysis of intellectual journals.
 In one important aspect, Professor Brint's findings appear to support the original new class theory, at least at first glance. Middle-class professionals are "relatively skeptical about moral certainties" and they remain clearly more liberal on numerous social issues, including civil liberties, personal choice regarding sexual matters, tolerance of political protest and acceptance of women and minorities.
But Professor Brint marshals evidence to show that these qualities stem from demographic realities, not professional status.
 Professional ranks contain more women, minorities and young people -- groups more likely to hold liberal social views. Among high-income managers, for example, census data show that about 5 percent were under the age of 30 in 1980 and fewer than that were women. But among professionals, nearly 30 percent were under 30 and more than 25 percent were women.
 All this is part of a larger story that Professor Brint tells, not just about the new class, but about the transformation of the very concept of professional. Early in the century, he says, professional status was defined as much by a sense of ethical and public responsibility as by specialized knowledge. Today, professionals increasingly define themselves strictly in terms of their command of technical matters, by their marketable knowledge and skills.
 Professor Brint discerns a real loss in this shift. The older notion of professional was susceptible to arrogance, but it also represented important precapitalist and nonmarket values that gave moral balance to a business civilization. By contrast, he suggests, both in economic and social matters, the new professionals have largely replaced public-spiritedness with private mindedness.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pataki Asks CUNY and SUNY to Cut Costs

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has asked the State University and the City University of New York to cut their spending by $40 million over the next five months to help the state close a $300 million gap in its current budget.
In letters sent out Thursday to university officials, the State Budget Director, Patricia Woodworth, told the State University that it must reduce spending by $25 million and City University that it must reduce spending by $15 million. The cuts, which must be completed by June 30, would represent about a 2 percent reduction in state aid for each system, state budget officials said. 
 "This is no different than what we are expecting from other state agencies," said Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget division. "The difference is, with other state agencies, we have the right to impose hiring freezes, contract freezes and other spending reductions so that we can insure that what is being spent is for critical things. We do not have that kind of control with the university systems."
Democratic legislators said, however, that while Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, has the authority to cut spending in the current fiscal year, which ends on March 31, he does not have the power to make cuts after that date without the Legislature's consent. That means the lawmakers could ease the cuts, they said.
"It would be fair to say this would meet with stiff opposition in the Assembly because SUNY and CUNY are the institutions middle-class people have availed themselves to for higher education," said Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan.
The prospect of a cut in state aid comes as City University's trustees are considering declaring a financial emergency at their regular meeting on Monday because of a proposed $7 million cut in aid from New York City for the current academic year.
The declaration would be the first step to laying off tenured faculty members at City University's six community colleges, which would bear the brunt of the city cut. City University is also preparing to defer enrollment of 6,000 community college students into the fall semester.
Rita Rodin, a City University spokeswoman, said City University officials were already pondering layoffs to cope with an additional proposed cut of $20 million in city aid for the 1995-96 academic year. The system has a $1.2 billion annual budget, of which $800 million comes from the state.
"We can't just absorb a state cut," she said. "We've had major cuts over the past few years even as our enrollment has grown."
Michael Riley, a State University spokesman, said university officials were still reviewing options and that he could not comment on what actions might be taken. But he said a $25 million midyear cut in the State University's $1.17 billion state budget was "considerable."
Both systems, with their low tuition, have long been distinguished as educational stepping stones for minorities and the poor. The State University system, with 64 campuses throughout the state, has 400,000 students and a full-time faculty of 15,000. City University, in addition to its 6 two-year colleges, has 10 senior colleges and 4 graduate schools for a total of 213,000 students.
State University union officials said that the $25 million, coming more than halfway through the academic year, would have the impact of a $50 million full-year reduction. They said that was potentially enough to cause layoffs, course cancellations and reductions in library hours and other services.
"We took a lot of hits since 1990," said William Scheuerman, president of the United University Professions, the union representing the State University faculty and professional workers. "We're right to the bone. Any cuts are going to hurt."
A $50 million midyear cut in state aid to the State University in the 1990-91 school year led to a $300 per year tuition increase in 1991. It also led to increases in course sizes, shutting down of campus buildings during holidays and reductions in library hours.
"Any cut like this that affects the quality of the program is shortsighted," said Linda Rosenblatt, a spokeswoman for the New York State United Teachers, the teachers' union. "SUNY drives the economy in many communities. This is a cut that could cost you in the long run."
City University officials declared financial emergencies in 1991 and 1992. The first was a response to a proposed $22 million budget cut by the city and state, which was ultimately reversed by the city and thus did not lead to layoffs. The 1992 declaration led to a small number of layoffs.
In addition to deferring 6,000 students into the fall semester to deal with the city's proposed $7 million cut this year, City University officials are also considering canceling as many as 1,864 class sections, or 28 percent of the total. The hardest hit would be college algebra, English composition and introductory courses in fields like psychology, sociology and history.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Charities Say Donations Are Weak

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Last winter, as the nation edged its way out of the recession, many New York City charities reported slight increases in private donations. But this season, officials at some of the city's largest social service agencies say giving has been surprisingly weak.
While giving has remained stable on a national level, all but one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund say that donations are flat or lagging up to 10 percent behind last winter. Citing reasons as various as the welfare reform movement and the mild winter, they say that a lag in all private giving -- not only to the Neediest Cases -- jeopardizes their most basic programs as record numbers of New Yorkers seek help. 
 Although the poor local economy is probably the central reason for the decline, the heads of many charities say they believe that cynicism at the government level is also to blame. The House Republicans' proposal to slash welfare benefits and eliminate other social programs, they say, has maligned the poor and discouraged middle-class Americans from giving.
"The cynicism coming from City Hall, Albany and Washington is taking a harsh toll," said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of UJA-Federation of New York. "People are being told that the poor take advantage of them, and that does begin to have a financial impact."
The Children's Aid Society reported that its donations have increased about 5 percent, or $200,000. But Philip Coltoff, the executive director, said most of the increase has been in restricted gifts. Unrestricted donations that support the society's health clinics, mental health programs and preventive services, are up by about $6,000.
"When you look at our core services for children, we are barely holding our own," Mr. Coltoff said. "When people hear the constant theme that the poor are getting too much, it definitely discourages philanthropic giving."
New York charities appear to be faring worse than others around the country, perhaps because the city has not recovered from the recession at the same rate as others. Whereas the stock market flourished in 1993, it was fairly unstable in 1994, and wealthy donors may have been less inclined to give.
Ann Kaplan, director of research at the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, said that on a national level, giving has remained consistent with last year. But in the aftermath of the recession, many charities in New York City remain vulnerable, particularly those that rely heavily on small, individual donations.
At Catholic Charities, Archdiocese of Brooklyn and Queens, private gifts are about $300,000 behind last winter. And at the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, a 10 percent drop in unrestricted donations has limited the number of cash grants the agency provides to poor people. Megan E. McLaughlin, the executive director, said the money, which is given out once a month, is gone within a few hours.
Charity officials are even pointing to the recent warm weather as a possible deterrent. In frigid weather, they said, the effects of poverty are more visible and moving, and people are more likely to help.
"There is no doubt that weather affects the way people treat the poor," said Donna A. Santarsiero, executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service. At her agency, individual donations picked up slightly over the holiday season, but are still down by about 10 percent from last year. The loss of private funds threatens rehabilitative programs for disabled adults and a program in Brooklyn public schools to prevent child abuse, among other things.
Another factor affecting charitable giving, officials say, is race. Ms. McLaughlin said that as increasing numbers of social service recipients are black and Hispanic, the white middle class is less likely to help. Immigrants of all races are also seen increasingly as "undeserving poor," she said.
"There is a belief that the only people who benefit from our programs are people of color," Ms. McLaughlin said. "In many cases, that makes it easy not to care."
But if cynicism and prejudice are major factors, charity officials say, they are equaled by a sense that the widespread, deep-rooted misery in this city is unsolvable.
"The situation around us has been going on for so long that people have become immune," Mr. Coltoff said. "They don't want to accept that they have to give again and again to make a difference."
The Rev. Kevin Sullivan, director of social development at Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, suggested that some Americans might have stopped giving because they aren't getting the speedy results they are accustomed to.
"We like to solve problems and we have made all these huge efforts," he said. "But they have failed, and that has dampened people's spirits."

AND BEAR IN MIND
 
ALL THE DAYS AND NIGHTS: The Collected Stories of William Maxwell. (Knopf, $25.) Stories, balanced, gentle and humane, concerned above all with reconciliation, from six decades of work by a master writer and editor who is now 86.
ANTARCTIC NAVIGATION, by Elizabeth Arthur. (Knopf, $25.) A first-person novel, alive with feeling and animated energy, whose heroine's aim is to vindicate by imitation the vision and morals of Scott of the Antarctic.
CHARLOTTE BRONTE: A Passionate Life, by Lyndall Gordon. (Norton, $27.50.) An engaging biography that connects the life and fiction persuasively, in particular the relationship between Bronte and her publisher that gave rise to "Villette," her other masterpiece.
DEMOCRACY ON TRIAL, by Jean Bethke Elshtain. (Basic Books, $20.) A thoughtful professor of ethics argues that the weakness of democratic institutions in America reflects the replacement of rights conceived as immunities from government interference by rights conceived as individual entitlements.
EAST, WEST: Stories, by Salman Rushdie. (Pantheon, $21.) Nine stories by the fugitive author of "The Satanic Verses," some boisterous, some provocative, all taking some advantage of Mr. Rushdie's difficult dual heritage.
FELICIA'S JOURNEY, by William Trevor. (Viking, $21.95.) Mr. Trevor's latest novel concerns an unmarried, pregnant, vulnerable Irish girl, wandering England's industrial Midlands until she encounters a predatory Englishman whose monstrosity remains long obscured.
AN INTIMATE HISTORY OF HUMANITY, by Theodore Zeldin. (HarperCollins, $25.) Informed rumination by a social historian who talks to many people, mostly Frenchwomen, about the basics of human experience (hope, despair, love, etc.) and thinks hope still has a chance.
NIGHT: Night Life, Night Language, Sleep, and Dreams, by A. Alvarez. (Norton, $23.) Personal and literary explorations of the less visible (and therefore more conjectural) half of life by a gifted critic and acutely intuitive memoirist.
THE PAPERBOY, by Pete Dexter. (Random House, $23.) An eerie and beautiful novel whose emotionally alienated title character, a reporter in quest of facts only, is outmaneuvered by violent half-wits who know what they want.
THE REVOLT OF THE ELITES AND THE BETRAYAL OF DEMOCRACY, by Christopher Lasch. (Norton, $22.) The ills of democracy, Lasch passionately contends, arise from such defaults as the abdication of responsibility for the community by economic elites and the propagation by academics of a skeptical relativism.
SHAKER BUILT: The Form and Function of Shaker Architecture, by Paul Rocheleau and June Sprigg, edited and designed by David Larkin. (David Larkin/Monacelli Press/ Penguin, $50.) Sumptuous color photographs of Shaker buildings, taken with care and devotion.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
The Goldilocks Recovery

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
ECONOMICS WAS LABELED "THE dismal science" in 1850 by the historian Thomas Carlyle, and its metaphors are suitably fearsome and depressing. An arrangement in the 1970's for exchange rates to fluctuate within a band within another band was called the snake in the tunnel, and the total of the unemployment and inflation percentages was called the misery index. In the 80's an aborted economic recovery was called a dead cat bounce. Even its euphemisms for recession give the users a sensation of seasickness, as in rolling readjustment.
How pleasant it was, in this sad trope-a-dope, to hear an economist introduce a happy figure of speech to the droopy discourse. It happened at a White House briefing this month by Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, and Laura Tyson, the Council of Economic Advisers chair. (Ms. Tyson is the chairwoman of the group, and not a piece of furniture, but the official Clinton terminology labels her chair. Although the White House press office, in its releases, uses an o to spell advisors, her council styles itself advisers, the spelling preferred by Merriam-Webster's Collegiate, 10th Edition, and by American Heritage. Advisors -- perhaps influenced by supervisor -- is listed first by Webster's New World Dictionary, Third Edition, giving cover to the White House press office and to the Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, Anthony Lake, who uses the controversial -or ending in spelling his informal title of National Security Advisor. However, most newspaper stylebooks, including that of The New York Times, use adviser, but who listens to the elitist media and its culture of personal destruction anymore? Amid this babble, a voice of cool authority is needed. My advice: in this devolutionary political era, don't knuckle under to any White House spelling diktat; spell it adviser. Live free or die. End parenthesis.) 
 Standing next to Adviser Tyson, whose hair is auburn, Secretary Reich made his sunnily hirsute contribution to economic jargon, referring to "the Goldilocks recovery -- not too hot, not too cold. . . ."
This catchy figure of speech is drawn, of course, from the story of "Goldilocks and the Three Bears," in which a hungry young blond woman breaks into the home of an absent family of carnivorous furry mammals. She samples their porridge, their chairs (the furniture, not their discussion leaders) and their beds. The comparisons invariably lead her to the bowl, chair and bed of the smallest bear, which in the case of the cereal was neither too hot nor too cold, and in the cases of the furniture neither too hard nor too soft, but -- just right.
The satisfaction of the bedtime story to the children of statisticians is in the discovery by Goldilocks of the perfect mean. (Others find in this story an example of the rip-off of third-world resources by the industrialized nations, but that could not be the Secretary's intent.)
Even as the Secretary of Labor was purveying the just-right picture of a Goldilocks economy, an anonymous White House aide was telling Todd S. Purdum of The New York Times about growing out of childish things, and adopting a less certain view of the political scene after the takeover of Congress by Republicans: "A lot of this is still seeing through a glass darkly."
Some spinmeister in that White House reads the Bible. This expression comes from I Corinthians 13, in which the Apostle Paul writes: "When I was a child, I spake as a child . . . but when I became a man, I put away childish things. For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then [we shall see] face to face. . . . " The point is that wisdom will come when a person wrestles with his personal angel and comes face to face with God's grace: "now I know in part: but then shall I know even as also I am known."
The phrase through a glass, darkly is used today to confess to uncertainty. But not even the most spiritually evocative phrase is above parody: Mark Twain, in his laceration of James Fenimore Cooper's obfuscatory prose a century ago, wrote about his target: "He saw nearly all things as through a glass eye, darkly."
 
Eye of Newt Revisited
"Allow me to join the herd of herpetologists," writes C. Leon Harris, professor of biological sciences at SUNY-Plattsburgh, "who are no doubt giving you a forked-tongue lashing for your definition of newt."
The faithful reader will recall a piece on eye of newt, an ingredient tossed into the witches' brew in "Macbeth." The creature whose eye was used, I explained, was "a small lizard related to the salamander and sometimes confused with a spotted eft."
Belay that. "A newt, like the salamander, frog and toad, is a member of a class of animals called amphibians," writes John Tucker of New York in collaboration with David Grow, a herpetologist with the Oklahoma City Zoological Park. "A lizard, on the other hand, is a member of an entirely different class of animals called reptiles."
Leo Kretzner, biochemistry prof at the University of South Dakota in Vermillion, explains further that "Amphibians and reptiles, while both in the vertebrate class, are members of separate orders. Their common body form is an example of convergent evolution." He notes, "The metaphorical appeal of a politician named after a reptile is obvious," but it would be wrong. However, the satirical possibilities are there: "After all, as a bona fide amphibian, the newt is slippery skinned and abandons its young."
W. T. Edmondson, a zoology professor at the University of Washington in Seattle, agrees: "A lizard is a reptile with a dry, scaly skin, while newts and salamanders are amphibians, frequently described as being slimy."
Other herpetologists -- it is fair to characterize my many correspondents on this as a herd -- dispute the sliminess factor. But even worse: "The Shakespearean witches' brew was a toxic mixture," writes Myrna E. Watanabe of Yonkers. "Newts secrete the neurotoxin tetrodotoxin," the writer continues, adding slyly, "structurally the same as the toxin found in the puffer fish."
Now let's clear up the confusion that has long been bothering me between the newt and the eft. Back to herpetologist Harris in Plattsburgh: "An eft is the adult terrestrial stage in the life cycle of an otherwise aquatic newt"; apparently when a newt grows tired of life in the water and climbs up on land, it becomes an eft.
Professor Harris adds etymological illumination: "Considering an eft to be a newt is not the result of confusion. The word newt resulted from a misdivision of an ewt, which in Middle English meant an eft."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 43; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 392 words

HEADLINE: STYLE;
Farewell, My Suite

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
I have spent much of my working life trying to convince people that it's "the mix, not the match" that makes for great-looking interiors. A radical suggestion coming from someone who was born and bred on perfectly matched furniture. But then, weren't we all? Furniture suites were the backbone of bedroom communities all across America: their stiff bearing made possible by chemical preservatives, their pseudo-historical styling as close to the original as Spam is to roast pork. But after years of editorial finger-wagging, the furniture suite is finally receding from the interior landscape. The ultimate proof of this came at this year's furniture mart in High Point, N.C., where even the most mass-market purveyors were pitching mixed sets over cookie-cutter ensembles. Now that a new era is dawning, I feel it's safe to wax nostalgic about the old, for the furniture suite may have lacked style but it had plenty of raison d'etre.
To the postwar homesteaders who believed most ardently in it, a matched set stood for progress, convenience, economic well-being and durability. More important, the furniture suite relieved an entire class of upwardly mobile suburbanites from the stress of having to make design decisions on a dime. 
 I think of my mother, who had been on the first convoy to the Philippines after Pearl Harbor. She'd been told to take all her belongings, furniture included, and then proceeded to live in a Quonset hut for the next four years. When she came back, chairless, and married my father, also chairless, they had to start furnishing from scratch. They didn't have time for Personal Style.
I grew up in a seven-set household. There was a color-coded suite for each of my three sisters and me, plus something Directoire-esque in the dining room; Williamsburg-y in the den. (I have yet to figure out the provenance of the master suite, but it was loaded with gold medallions.) Over time, the suites did not grow old, did not sag or fade. In fact, they never caused my mother a moment's worry. (The white lacquered set in my own bedroom even withstood my Italian grandfather's cigarette burns.) It was we who aged, moved on, wised up. The furniture remained pristine all the way to the Salvation Army. I wasn't sorry to see it go, but I understand perfectly all that it stood for and all that it accomplished.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Drug War, II

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
THE MAIL ABOUT THE LOST "WAR ON drugs," discussed here on Dec. 18, has been formidable. It has brought tomes and treatises, the thoughts of prisoners and preachers, and much evidence of anxiety across the land. Although most of the government warriors, from the Commander in Chief down, prefer to avoid the subject, people seem desperate for more discussion of alternatives to the failed policies of prohibition and interdiction.
The media have carried the news of the nation's defeat, but they do not dwell, as they would in a conventional war, on the daily cost and humiliation. Still, the letters from readers imply widespread support for the conclusion that there is no way to win the war so long as small, easily smuggled bundles of addictive cocaine or heroin can finance a large and aggressive criminal sales organization. Prohibition is what makes drugs so profitable, yet the thought of legalizing their distribution, even with rigid controls and treatment programs, arouses the fear of infecting millions of new addicts. 
 That fear, if valid, explains a central dilemma that Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan dug out of his writings of two years ago. The nation's choice of policy -- legalization or prohibition -- offers a choice of outcomes, he wrote: "An enormous public health problem on the one hand, an enormous crime problem [concentrated among minorities] on the other." Since he disliked the choice, he ducked, wishing instead that medical researchers would more vigorously pursue a chemical "blocking or neutralizing agent" to move drug users "as near to abstinence as possible."
One researcher, Dr. Pietr Hitzig of Timonium, Md., actually foresees such a possibility in experiments with a fenfluramine-phentermine combination. But the protocols for controlled study of its effectiveness are still under review, he writes.
From a different perspective, Prof. Avram Goldstein of Stanford's Medical School also argues for recognizing drugs as a health problem: "We do not need to legalize the drugs, we need to decriminalize the users and offer universal treatment, while seriously enforcing the prohibitions on sale and distribution."
What that might mean was suggested by Daniel W. Weil, a former director of corrections for Cook County, Ill., who observes that a nation unable to control its eating, drinking or smoking habits nonetheless expects, indeed demands, that drug addicts kick the habit -- or become sellers or commit crimes to finance it. He favors dispensing drugs at minimal or no charge "to registered addicts" under close supervision at government clinics. Any "possession or sale" of narcotic drugs outside the premises would remain illegal.
The Open Society Institute created by George Soros, the financier, sponsors the Lindesmith Center to challenge "conventional" thinking about drugs. Its director, Ethan A. Nadelmann, argues from historical experience that in a legal market consumers prefer less potent drugs. Both the health and crime problem could be reduced, he contends, if drug "use" were distinguished from the drug "abuse" fostered by profit-seeking criminals.
But to Joseph A. Califano Jr., the founding president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, any "stamp of legality" on snorting cocaine or smoking crack would bring drugs a "new social acceptability," lead to a huge increase in the number of addicts and "light a new flame beneath health care spending." In a new book, "Radical Surgery" about health care policy, from which he has drawn the essay on page 40 of today's Magazine, the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare pleads for a better balance of spending between enforcement of the drug laws and research, prevention and treatment.

BY FAR THE MOST POTENT PACKAGE IN THE mail response, however, brought the galleys of a book by a freelance writer, William Adler, to be published by Atlantic Monthly Press in April. He calls it "Land of Opportunity: One Family's Quest for the American Dream in the Age of Crack" and without the help of any illegal substance, it will blow your mind.
His tale was inspired by Isabel Wilkerson's front-page article in The Times of Dec. 18, 1988, recounting the trial of four brothers who moved to Detroit from rural Arkansas and turned an upstart marijuana business into a giant crack conglomerate "run like a Fortune 500 company."
The Wilkerson report was startling enough. She found a vast organization of kids "not using drugs as consumers but as capitalists," many lured from the cotton fields to be given a rigorous discipline, salaries up to $ 100 a day and an impressive work ethic: "If you are planning on getting rich," the gang's crude policy read, "you must forget about your girlfriends and family. You will not have too much time for parties and concerts. With hard work and dedication, we will all be rich within 12 months."
Understandably, Mr. Adler perceived a rare chance to illuminate the dynamics of the crack trade, from the coca paste production in Peru and Bolivia, to jungle refineries in Colombia, to wholesalers in Florida, then through "weight dealers" to street retailers like the Chambers brothers.
Like any successful entrepreneurs, he writes, they "learned how to buy wholesale, mass-produce and market their product and track inventory. . . . They implemented strict quality control measures, devised employee rules and regulations, benefit plans, performance bonuses, a customer incentive program. . . . At the height of their power, they grossed, conservatively, 55 million tax-free dollars a year."
Most commendably, Mr. Adler also explores the crushing poverty and prejudice into which the Chambers boys were born in Marianna, Ark., and the collapsed Detroit economy in which they found their customers. As he observes, "There is a reasonable explanation for the crack whirlwind: the head-on collision during the 1980's of the cultures of greed and need."
Mr. Adler lingers with his story after the Chambers boys are arrested and put away to note that smaller dealers were soon jostling to replace them. Of the 1,015 people sent to overcrowded prisons in the first three months of Detroit's major "crackdown on crack," nearly 80 percent were soon freed to find that drug selling remained a "rational" career choice. Many of the youngest Chambers employees returned to tiny Marianna, some to straighten out and go back to Lee Senior High, others to ply the retail and marketing techniques they had learned up north. Within just six months after the trial, the town's police chief reported, "I got a helluva crack problem down here."
So does all America so long as prohibition makes drug dealing the most profitable -- often the only profitable -- ghetto career, turning customers into pushers to replenish an unconquerable guerrilla army.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
How a Legend Tapped the Rock Underground

BYLINE: By Fred Goodman; Fred Goodman, a contributing editor for Rolling Stone magazine, is writing a history of the rock-and-roll industry.

 BODY:
IN 1963, THE STUDIO MOGUL JACK
Warner bought Reprise Records from Frank Sinatra. The deal did not signal an appreciation of the record business by the studio head: Reprise -- even with Mr. Sinatra on its roster -- was a loser. Rather, Warner's studio had recently enjoyed a hit with "Ocean's 11," a Las Vegas caper film featuring the singer and several of his "rat pack" buddies, and the purchase of the label was part of a broader deal to tie up Mr. Sinatra as an actor. Even if Reprise continued to lose money, it was a cheap way of assuring that Mr. Sinatra would make movies for the studio -- a potential gold mine for Warner Brothers.
The deal did prove a gold mine, but not because of Frank Sinatra. Reprise gave Warner Brothers the services of a man whose ultimate value to the company over 31 years would dwarf Mr. Sinatra's: Mo Ostin.
At 68, the balding, bespectacled and low-key Mr. Ostin looks more like the controller he is by training than the monumental cultural visionary and business tactician he has proved to be. He stepped down as chairman and chief executive officer of Warner Brothers Records on Dec. 31 after losing an unusually public corporate power struggle. But long after the dust of his departure has settled, Mr. Ostin's contribution to the record business will endure. Under his direction, Warner Brothers was transformed from a small, struggling label into the world's largest record company and the financial engine that drove Steve Ross's Warner Communications. Most significant, however, was the way Mr. Ostin achieved the transformation: by embracing the rock underground of the 60's when other, more conservative labels were loath to do so. 
 He built his company by developing careers rather than chasing hit records, a long-term strategy that empowered the rock underground and enriched Warner Brothers. But today, when record companies have become major profit centers for huge multinational entertainment conglomerates, quick hits are the order of the day. It is unlikely that this new global record industry will produce another executive of Mr. Ostin's patience and perspective.
"My feeling was always follow the artist, follow the music," he says. "It will lead you to the money." As a result of that philosophy, Warner Brothers Records became a creative and financial powerhouse and the label most admired by artists. George Harrison, Eric Clapton, Miles Davis, Elvis Costello, John Fogerty, Tom Petty, R.E.M., the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Quincy Jones have been among the established artists to come to Warner Brothers in the last 15 years. In contrast to the situation at other labels, money was rarely a deciding factor.
"We signed with Warner Brothers because of Mo," says Flea, the bassist for the Red Hot Chili Peppers, which jettisoned a more lucrative deal with Sony Music. "For me, dealing with most companies and most big record guys like Mo is always sort of uncomfortable. I feel like there's something going on that I don't understand. But he looks you in the eye, and you know there's an honest man talking to you."
Mr. Ostin says embracing rock music was "purely pragmatic business." Indeed, at the same time that Reprise was signing Jimi Hendrix, its sister label, Warner Brothers, was releasing Johnny Sea's pro-Vietnam War single, "Day for Decision." Still, once Mr. Ostin got a taste of the new music culture, he took to it with real fervor. By the late 60's Warner Brothers had been transformed from a record company whose roster was typified by Dean Martin and Allan Sherman to the home of the Grateful Dead, Joni Mitchell, Neil Young, Frank Zappa and the Fugs.
"Mo believed in personal freedom," says Ed Sanders of the Fugs. "The most important thing was that no matter how chaotic our vision was, he let us pursue it and lay down our brains on tape as we saw fit. He didn't do everything for money."
Mr. Ostin's willingness to empower artists grew out of his earliest experiences in the business. In 1954, when he joined the jazz impresario Norman Granz's Clef Records as controller, Mr. Ostin saw that Mr. Granz allowed artists -- including Count Basie, Billie Holiday and Dizzy Gillespie -- the freedom to make their own records. "Those guys got in the studio and improvised," says Mr. Ostin. "They had more control over their material than other artists might."
At Reprise, Mr. Ostin extended that control to rockers. When Joe Smith, a Warner Brothers executive, signed the Grateful Dead in 1967, it proved a turning point -- not because of their early albums, which didn't sell particularly well -- but because the Grateful Dead were standard-bearers of the drug culture. They were notorious -- and, by inference, so now was Warner Brothers. The group proved a magnet for other rockers who suddenly wanted to be on the label.

TO DEVELOP BOTH THE ART-
ists and the label, Mr. Ostin adopted an approach that Irving Thalberg had used in the 30's to turn MGM into a leading movie studio: hire the best people and give them their heads. Mr. Ostin believed that if he put the right recording artists under contract and paired them with a staff of outstanding producers and marketing executives, Warner Brothers would make the best records and attract the most ambitious artists.
At a time when other record companies were getting rid of staff producers, Warner Brothers was collecting them. Mr. Ostin's protege, Lenny Waronker, was the key executive on a staff that ranged from such eccentric producers as Van Dyke Parks and John Cale to mainstream hit makers like Richard Perry and Ted Templeman.
Mr. Ostin also assembled an irreverent team to handle advertising and marketing. While other labels stumbled over selling the new culture in the underground press -- Columbia's faux hippie campaigns like "The Man Can't Bust Our Music," for example, were publicly ridiculed -- Warner Brothers soared. The down-home honesty of Neil Young was promoted with a free bag of dirt from the Los Angles hippie haven Topanga Canyon; an ad for the Grateful Dead featured a "Pigpen lookalike contest," playing on the nickname for Ron McKernan, the band's hard-drinking keyboardist.
Mr. Ostin's approach also attracted other entrepreneurs and executives. "It was like walking into another world, a whole different planet," says Quincy Jones, who had spent more than 30 years in the music business before joining Warner Brothers in the early 80's. He points out that Mr. Ostin waited 10 years before he delivered his first album. "He'd noodge me and remind me," says Mr. Jones, "but he knew that when it was time I'd do it." That album, "Back on the Block." won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year.
Tom Silverman, who sold his hip-hop label Tommy Boy to Warner Brothers in 1989, views Mr. Ostin as "a natural Taoist."
"He's a guy who goes with the flow without overmanaging it," Mr. Silverman says. "He let people sink or swim on their own, as opposed to other labels where you got called on the carpet when you have your first failure. All of the charisma of Warner Brothers Records is Mo."
In Steve Ross, Mr. Ostin found a boss whose laissez-faire style of management matched his own. Mr. Ross's faith in Mr. Ostin paid huge dividends as the rock underground became the mainstream with best-selling artists like Fleetwood Mac, Prince and Madonna. In 1969, when Ross purchased the label's parent company, Warner-Seven Arts, the music operation's revenues were less than $200 million. In 1992, the year Mr. Ross died, those revenues exceeded $3.2 billion. During Mr. Ostin's tenure, the Warner Records Group -- which acquired Atlantic Records in 1967 and the Elektra label in 1970 -- added domestic and international distribution companies and its own manufacturing plant. By the mid-70's, Warner Brothers Records had come from nowhere to surpass Columbia as the industry leader.
Even competitors give Mr. Ostin his due, including Walter Yetnikoff, the former chairman of CBS Records who had vowed to "destroy" his rival. "I came up against Mo I don't know how many times, and I had very deep pockets," says Mr. Yetnikoff. "It's hard to knock anything Mo did."
Despite Mr. Ostin's extraordinary contribution to the growth of a company that has since become a part of the Time Warner conglomerate, Ross's death precipitated a change in management style that eventually led to Mr. Ostin's departure. He says only that he is leaving because the corporate culture has changed and that leaving was his decision, but he was reportedly unhappy at having a new boss, Bob Morgado, and at having his freedom to run the label curtailed. Mr. Ostin has said he will continue to work in the record business and is weighing several offers.
The industry's new economics, where business types have the final say over creative types, means there will probably be no more Mr. Ostins: executives with the freedom to shape large labels in their own image and throw their weight behind unorthodox signings, as Mr. Ostin did in 1968 with Tiny Tim.
"I signed unusual people all the time, whether it was the Fugs or the Sex Pistols or Captain Beefheart," Mr. Ostin says. "Tim was so unusual, he was so freaky, it just appealed to that perverse side of me."
Tiny Tim's commercial success was one more small proof of Mr. Ostin's business savvy. Even more telling, Mr. Ostin remains proud of the music on Tiny Tim's album. "The Beatles told producer Richard Perry that they loved that album," he says. "You should listen to it. It's wonderfully made."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1811 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN AUSTIN

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS; PETER H. LEWIS, who reports on cyberspace for The Times, lives in Austin.

 BODY:
AUSTIN surprises many first-time visitors who arrive expecting the capital city to be, well, more like Texas. Instead of dusty plains they find a hilly, green oasis laced by rivers and walking trails, where high-tech wizards, musicians, writers and artists are more common than cowboys or oil magnates.
Austin, which calls itself "The Live Music Capital of the World" for its many nightclubs and outdoor concerts, has been struggling to maintain its laid-back charm while coping with one of the fastest growth rates in the nation. But with the arrival of spring, which in Austin can begin in late February and is fully sprung in March, the town has more than enough charm and energy to share. 
 The economic bust of the late 1980's has ended with another boom. Formerly forested hilltops are increasingly covered with houses, and traffic, though modest by New York standards, has longtime locals grousing. Counting its swelling suburbs, Austin's population will probably surpass one million this year, nearly double its size a decade ago.
More than 100,000 students, half of them at the University of Texas, help keep the city intellectually lively and physically active. Hikers, bikers, runners, golfers, rowers, climbers, sailors and tennis players take advantage of the spring weather and fill the city's 11,800 acres of parks, and its winding lakes and rivers.
Austin has, per person, the highest bookstore sales among the country's 50 largest cities, the most highly educated populace among cities of 200,000 or more and the most computer-literate citizenry.
But Austin likes its parties, too. It claims the most restaurants, bars and movie screens per person of any American city.
 
Events
 The South by Southwest (SXSW) Music Festival in March has emerged as one of the most popular venues for new bands hoping to get the attention of record companies and critics. This year, the festival has expanded to 10 days of creative discussion, workshops and dusk-to-dawn entertainment, starting with a film festival March 10 to 12, and continuing from March 14 to 16 with a multimedia festival exploring the merger of computer technology and entertainment.
The music festival, however, is the big draw, and from March 15 to 19 hundreds of bands will fill the area's clubs, with jam sessions often spilling out into the streets. Hotel rooms and airline tickets are typically hard to come by around festival time. Wristbands good for admission to most clubs (arrive early) cost $35 and are available from Star ticket outlets, (800) 966-7469. The festival is headquartered at the Austin Convention Center, 500 East Cesar Chavez Street, (512) 476-5461.
A full pass to all music seminars and performances costs $250 until Feb. 24 and, after that, $295 until the festival begins. Call (512) 467-7979.
The annual Texas Hill Country Wine and Food Festival is scheduled for March 30 to April 2 at various locations around town, centered at the Four Seasons Hotel. On March 31 at the Four Seasons, there will be a tasting of signature dishes from 20 of the area's top restaurants. Tickets that will admit listeners to most festival events are $275. Friday through Sunday. Tickets are also available for individual events. Information: (512) 329-0770.
The annual Spam-O-Rama, on April 1, draws hundreds of devotees of the canned-meat product, for cooking and sculpture contests. The event will be held at the Cedar Door, 910 West Cesar Chavez Street, (512) 416-9307, from noon to dark.

 
The Outdoors
 Because temperatures rarely dip below freezing, and often sneak into the 70's and 80's even in midwinter, the city's 172 parks, 18 public and private golf courses and 30 miles of walking trails are busy year-round. The rolling hills to the west of town provide gentle challenges to hikers and bikers. A free map of the trails and other outdoor guides are available from the Austin Parks and Recreation Department at (512) 499-6700.
A short stroll south from Sixth Street, the main venue for music clubs, brings a visitor to Town Lake. The lake was created when a dam was built on the Colorado River, which flows through the center of town. It is lined with wide paths that accommodate feet and bicycles with equanimity.
The spiritual soul of Austin is Barton Springs Pool, on Barton Springs Road in Zilker Park, (512) 476-9044. Generations have gone to splash in the constant 68-degree water of this 1,000-foot-long spring-fed swimming hole. The pool is open 5 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily. Admission is free until mid-March, when it is $2, 50 cents for children 12 to 17, and 25 cents for children under 12.
Two of the most dazzling displays of nature return to Austin each March: wildflowers and bats.
Depending on such variables as sun and rain, the wildflower season typically begins on St. Patrick's Day, peaks in April and continues until May.
The formal opening of the new National Wildflower Research Center is scheduled for April 8 and 9. This 42-acre facility on the south side of town, at 4801 LaCrosse Boulevard, includes an innovative system of roof-top rain collectors, viaducts and cisterns integrated into Texas ranch- and Spanish mission-style buildings. Admission is free on rain days; when the sun shines, it is $3.50, $2 for students and seniors, $1 for children up to five years. Hours are 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday. For more information, (512) 292-4100.
The swallows of Capistrano are pikers compared to the bats of Austin. More than a million and a half Mexican free-tailed bats return late each March to the Congress Avenue Bridge downtown, creating the largest urban bat colony in North America. Starting before dark each day, a milelong cloud of bats billows into the sky. Even people who are intimidated by the flitting critters -- which avoid humans even more carefully than humans avoid them -- can enjoy the fact that they keep the city relatively free of mosquitoes until October. For information, call Bat Conservation International at (512) 327-9721.
 
Night Life
 Sixth Street flows through the center of Austin's music scene downtown, and in the course of a few blocks, a stroller will pass through currents of jazz, blues, rock, reggae, Mexican-influenced Tejano, pop, Texas swing, country, folk and assorted hybrids that pour from the doorways and make up "the Austin sound."
Not all the music clubs are downtown. Blues fans go to Antone's, 2915 Guadalupe Street, (512) 474-5314, where touring rock stars frequently show up in the wee hours. Open 8:30 P.M. to 2 A.M. Monday through Saturday; cover charge $3 to $12.
Any time after Independence Day (which in Texas means March 2, the anniversary of the Battle of San Jacinto), the music is likely to move outdoors -- often to Zilker Park or the banks of Town Lake near the statue of Stevie Ray Vaughan, an Austin-based blues legend who was to the guitar what Jim Bowie was to the knife. For concert and entertainment listings, check the weekly Austin Chronicle or the Thursday issue of The Austin American-Statesman.

 
Where to Eat

 Austin's restaurant scene is spiced by Southwestern, Gulf Coast and Mexican influences. Dining even in the finer restaurants is "Austin casual."
Zoot, just west of downtown, 509 Hearn Street, (512) 477-6535, is popular for imaginative dishes like salads of spinach and tatsoi (a green) with spicy walnuts, candied kumquats and sundried tomato vinaigrette ($5.95), and roasted duck breast on wild rice corn cakes ($15.95). Open every night 5:30 to 10:30. Dinner for two with wine, $65.
One of the most innovative menus in town is actually 25 minutes outside of town, at Hudson's on the Bend, 3509 Ranch Road 620 South, (512) 266-1369. The brave may want to try Omar's rattlesnake cakes with chipotle cream sauce ($7.50). Entrees often include such local or exotic meats as ostrich, venison, pheasant, elk and javelina (a boarlike creature), as well as more familiar fish, fowl and meats ($18 to $30). Dinner for two with wine, about $90.
Vegetarians can find refuge at the funky West Lynn Cafe, 1110 West Lynn Street, (512) 482-0950, which applies similar creativity to such dishes as the chile relleno ($8.50 at lunch, $7.95 at dinner), a roasted poblano pepper stuffed with jack cheese, corn, peas, brown rice, cilantro and Southwestern spices. Open at 11 or 11:30 A.M. daily and closes between 9:30 and 10:30, depending on the day of the week. Dinner for two with wine, $45.
Janis Joplin used to sing for her supper at Threadgill's, 6416 North Lamar Boulevard, (512) 451-5440, where, on Wednesday nights, one can still hear local musicians while sampling the vegetable plate that typically includes several down-home Southern favorites ($4.95). Open 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily. Dinner for two with Lone Star beer: $25.
 
Where to Stay

 The historic Driskill Hotel, 604 Brazos, (800) 527-2008, fax (512) 477-2214, has been deep in the heart of Austin's social and political life since 1886. The 177-room hotel is at the head of the Sixth Street entertainment district and a short walk from both the newly renovated State Capitol and Town Lake. Some say it also has a friendly ghost. Rates start at $122 for doubles, suites from $200.
Budget: Fifteen minutes west of downtown is the quiet 45-room Melbourne Hotel and Conference Center, 4611 Bee Caves Road, (512) 328-4000. The Melbourne is a good base for those who want to explore the hill country. The rooms include a small refrigerator. All rooms are $75.
Several national franchise hotels offer budget accommodations along Interstate 35 near downtown, including Ramada Inns, Motel 6, Holiday Inn and Best Western. One with modest rates and convenient location is the La Quinta Inn Capitol, 300 East 11th Street; (512) 476-1166, fax (512) 476-6044. Its rates start at $61.
Austin's historic areas offer several bed-and-breakfast options. The 10-room neo-classical Governor's Inn, 611 West 22d Street, (512) 479-0638, offers rates of $49 to $99, including a hearty breakfast.
Luxury: The Town Lake hike and bike path begins just beyond the swimming pool at the Four Seasons Hotel, 98 San Jacinto Boulevard; (512) 478-4500, fax (512) 477-0704. The Cafe downstairs is one of the best restaurants in town. Rates are $155 to $220; suites $210 to $1,200. Lakeside rooms have the best bat views.
Ausin's most luxurious secret is the Barton Creek Resort and Country Club, 8212 Barton Club Drive, (512) 329-4000, about 20 minutes west of downtown on the cusp of the Texas hill country. The ranch-style resort has 147 rooms, an elaborate fitness center and spa and several restaurants. Through February, special rates are $125 for a single, $135 for double. When golf season officially starts in March, room rates rise to $175 and $190. Greens fees plus cart for 18 holes: $80 on weekdays, $90 weekends.

TITLE: WHAT'S DOING IN...(TIMES COLUMN)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: TEXAS, USA (95%); 

CITY: AUSTIN, TX, USA (95%);

HEADLINE: 'Carousel' Comes to a Stop As Its Cast Takes a Final Bow

BYLINE: By SARA KRULWICH 

 BODY:
EVEN AS TEARS FELL,
along with the final curtain at the Vivian Beaumont Theater earlier this month, "Carousel" was not entirely over. Nicholas Hytner's shimmeringly dark version of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical has a new destination -- Tokyo -- and a new cast -- Japanese.
The Lincoln Center Theater presentation, originally produced by the Royal National Theater in London, received accolades when it opened in March of last year and went on to win five Tony Awards, including best musical revival. 
 Now, with its sets and costumes by Bob Crowley, the classic musical will open in Japan in May (where its top ticket price is expected to be close to 14,000 yen, or about $140 at current exchange rates; take that, Broadway complainers).
So the grim 19th-century New England factory that Julie Jordan escapes to ride the galloping red carousel horses with Billy Bigelow will live not only in memory. And as cast members in New York embraced, took snapshots, signed posters of the show and filled out unemployment forms, they, too, lived -- to be part of the next play or musical they join.
As the song says, and though it's not from "Carousel" it's true: Another opening, another show . . .

HEADLINE: Wyoming's Animals, Observed

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES; STEVEN A. HOLMES is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
WE parked the car on a deserted snow-swept road in Grand Teton National Park. As we unloaded our gear we paused to gaze at the craggy mountain peaks across the valley, disappearing in the cool January mist. But it was getting late, so our little group of six quickly snapped on snowshoes and set off through the deep, powdery snow, past stands of aspen and pine. About a mile into the forest we began scanning the treetops for our quarry. Five or six minutes later I spotted it: a kind of smudge sitting in the branches of a lodgepole pine.
"Hey Tom!" I yelled to the leader of our group as I pointed upward, "what's that up in that tree?" As we climbed a gentle slope toward the tree, we saw a porcupine, sitting serenely about 40 feet up. Tom Segerstrom, the research biologist who led our trek, filled a hypodermic needle with a blend of muscle relaxant and sedative, hooked it on a five-foot-long injection stick, grabbed a net and shinnied up the pine. We watched quietly, so we wouldn't scare the animal, as Mr. Segerstrom maneuvered close and stuck him in the left hip with the syringe. While he waited for the drugs to take effect, Mr. Segerstrom held the net underneath the porcupine. But, rather than dropping straight down, the animal tumbled backward off the limb, bounced off the net and fell to the ground. 
 Still in my snowshoes, I shuffled over to the animal, who was breathing shallowly, eyes blank. His mouth was slightly agape, exhibiting sharp orange teeth. I pulled on thick buckskin gloves to protect my hands from quills, hefted him by the tail and laid him on a big towel to keep him off the cold snow. Mr. Segerstrom was soon back on the ground, ashen-faced and angry at himself for the net mishap. But he had little time for self-reproach. He quickly got to work measuring and weighing the porcupine, ascertaining its sex (male) and collecting data for a research project on porcupines -- a project that we were able to observe and participate in.
After he recorded his observations, Mr. Segerstrom attached a blue tag to the porcupine's left ear and gave Jennifer, my 8-year-old daughter, the honor of naming him. She chose "Eric." Eric was still pretty groggy, but beginning to stir under the towel. Mr. Segerstrom waited until he was fully recovered while the rest of us showshoed back to the car. Fifteen minutes later he joined us, reporting that when last seen, Eric was scrambling up a tree.
A lanky native of Minnesota, Mr. Segerstrom, 39, has worked as a field biologist with the United States Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management and the Wyoming Game and Fish Department. In 1986 he started the Great Plains Wildlife Institute, a commercial venture that finances research on animals using the proceeds of wildlife-viewing tours.
"I'm doing what some people are calling free-market environmentalism," Mr. Segerstrom says. "I'm trying to show that it's good for enterprise, that wildlife generates revenue and jobs and economic activity."
Prices for the institute's winter trips range from $65 an adult for a four-hour expedition to $1,980 for a six-day trip. Under Mr. Segerstrom's guidance, participants help with observation and information-gathering. He and his staff later convert their data into reports for state and Federal agencies or papers for scholarly journals.
In this case Mr. Segerstrom and a graduate student from the University of Montana were conducting research on how porcupines are affected by forest fires. We were in an area near one destroyed by one of the devastating Yellowstone National Park fires in 1988. Seven years after the blaze Mr. Segerstrom was trying to determine whether the porcupines had returned to the fire-doneged area or had remained on the periphery.
In and around Jackson Hole, there is no shortage of subjects to study: elk, moose, mule deer, bighorn sheep, coyotes, eagles, martens, hawks, beavers, otters, minks, sage grouse, bison, bears and more. Winter is a wonderful time to view this menagerie. Forced out of their isolated high-altitude habitats by snowstorms and plummeting temperatures, big mammals like elk, deer and moose migrate to winter feeding grounds in the valley.
The valley -- Jackson Hole -- is about 20 miles wide and 60 miles long, hemmed in by the Tetons that rise dramatically to the west and the more gentle sloping Gros Ventre Range to the east. The prime lure for most winter visitors is skiing; as a bonus, there are plenty of opportunities to view wildlife. Bordering the highway running from the airport to the town of Jackson is the 25,000-acre National Elk Refuge, where some 7,500 head of elk spend the winter months. It can be toured by horse-drawn sleigh. Other options include a guided cross country ski tour, snowmobile trip or excursions by dog sled in the nearby Grand Teton National Park.
But for both entertainment and education, we opted for a day tour with Mr. Segerstrom.
Our group, which included a marketing executive and freelance writer along with my wife, Marian, and daughter Jennifer, set out early one morning in Mr. Segerstrom's four-wheel drive Chevrolet. He provided powerful binoculars and 1,000-magnification telescopes for each of us. When someone spotted an animal, we would grab our scopes and hook them onto the car's side windows or pop up through the vehicle's sliding roof hatches and set them up on mini-tripods.
Mr. Segerstrom is a natural teacher, especially with children. At the start of the day, he endeared himself to Jennifer by asking her to sit up front with him and keep a list of the animals we would see. With his help, she categorized our finds -- among them, waterfowl, large mammals and raptors -- as he patiently advised her on the spellings.
Traveling in the elk refuge we saw a group of coyotes nuzzling in the snow, searching for field mice. Suddenly, one began to hop backward on all four legs, a sign that he had sniffed out a meal. He dug his snout deep into the ground, but when he raised it, his jaws were empty. For the moment, the mouse had escaped. As we watched, Mr. Segerstrom played recordings of the coyotes' moody high-pitched wail over loudspeakers on the car to see if the animals would respond. But, busy with their hunt, they paid us no heed.
A short way down the road and high above us on a stone outcropping, we spied several Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep, including mature rams and ewes with their lambs. The horns of one adult circled almost completely around his ears, like enormous spit curls.

OUT in the huge meadow was the elk herd itself. Inclined by nature to stick together, the males stayed in one part of the refuge while the females huddled with the young several yards away. Pawing through the light layer of snow, the animals seem to have no trouble finding grass. When harsher weather and deeper snows set in, the rangers will supplement their diets with alfalfa pellets; nevertheless, scores will succumb to the harsh conditions and the lack of food.
At Nowlin Pond, in the refuge, three trumpeter swans floated regally on the chilly water amid merganser and pintail ducks. Snow white with ebony beaks, they are the world's largest species of waterfowl, weighing up to 30 pounds, with a wing span of eight feet. Mr. Segerstrom had Jennifer note the number of swans, the exact location and time they were spotted, and whether they had bands around their necks indicating they had been captured and tagged as part of a census of native trumpeters. Since 1991, the number of swans in the region has been declining, and biologists suspect the problem to be an invasion of Canadian swans competing for food. Mr. Segerstrom would report his observations to the State Game and Fish Department.
Lunch, which is included in the tour price, was at Jackson's Wort Hotel, where the menu includes buffalo steak and venison stew. Once a part of the town's red-light district, the Wort was a haven for illegal gambling, and occasionally cowboys rode their horses into the hotel's Silver Dollar Bar, named for the 2,032 silver dollars laid into its serpentine counter. Despite its history and Old West memorabilia, the Wort wasn't built until 1941.
South of town, we saw several bald eagles, including one sitting on a sandbar in the Snake River feeding on a dead eagle. Seeking a better photo angle, I urged Mr. Segerstrom to inch the car closer to the bird. He was reluctant, fearing we would scare the bird off its meal. Sure enough, as we moved closer, the eagle took flight. I contritely absorbed the lesson about impinging.
Mr. Segerstrom drove us to sites where he had seen buffalo earlier in the week, but we never did spot the behemoths. We also hoped to catch a glimpse of an otter snoozing in the sun, but no luck.
As we headed northeast from Jackson, Mr. Segerstrom told us to look for huge black shapes against the white landscape and thickets of red willow bushes. We soon had a moose in our sights. As we looked through the telescopes, we focused on one near a stream chewing indolently on red willow, its favorite food. For the rest of my stay in Jackson Hole, I never passed a clump of red willow without scanning them to see if any moose lurked about.
 
Following the herds
The Great Plains Wildlife Institute runs summer trips from May through September, and winter trips from November through March.
The prices are these:
Four-hour sunrise (in winter) and sunset (in summer and winter) trips: $65 per adult and $35 per child.
Full day: $135 per person, includes lunch.
Six days (winter): $1,980, includes meals and hotel accommodation, plus transportation by dog sled, snow coach on treads, snowmobile and customized Chevy Suburban.
Six days (summer): $1,835, includes a one-day river float to look for otters.
Contact the Great Plains Wildlife Institute, Post Office Box 7580, Jackson, Wyo., 83001; or call (307) 733-2623. S. A. H.

HEADLINE: DANCE ECONOMICS;
Sole Expense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former principal dancer with the Dance Theater of Harlem, I am aware of the financial struggles of professional dancers living on sub-starvation wages ["Dancing Precariously on the Bottom Line," Jan. 8]. In addition to the cuts in funding and fierce competition faced by modern-dance companies, ballet companies have an extra handicap in their efforts to stay solvent: they must spend hundreds of thousands of dollars a year on pointe shoes. (New York City Ballet, for example, spends $500,000 annually.) 
 Unfortunately, these delicate satin slippers, made of paste and cardboard, begin to disintegrate after a few releves. At about $55 a pair, they are a parent's nightmare. A more durable, better quality slipper may eventually provide some financial relief to ballet companies -- and to the parents of budding ballerinas.
 
TAI JIMENEZ
New York

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island;
6 Downtowns Form Business Improvement Districts

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
RIVERHEAD wants to capitalize on the area's tourist economy.
Huntington needs to do something about the kids who hang around its bars. 
 Great Neck wants to promote its stores to a wider radius of shoppers.
Long Island's central business areas may not be suffering from the same crime and problems pf the homeless that gave rise to many of Manhattan's Business Improvement Districts.
But over the last four years, six Long Island downtowns -- in Great Neck, Cedarhurst, Huntington, Patchogue, Riverhead and Westbury -- have turned to that same solution. And it looks like a seventh BID will soon start up in Greenport.
"Only a well-funded central business authority can compete with a shopping center with a huge war chest," said Robert Werner, a Great Neck property owner.
All of the BID's are grappling with economic and demographic forces that are unlikely to reverse themselves with the current economic improvement. Malls, including huge ones like Americana in Manhasset and strip malls along the Long Island Expressway, have simply siphoned away too many downtown shoppers.
Many Long Island downtowns entered the 90's with their shopping streets pockmarked with vacant stores. The remaining stores found themselves increasingly competing against new outlet centers and discount megastores, offering bargains within easy driving distance.
Ad hoc merchants' groups that tried cooperative ads or other joint competitive attempts generally fell apart.
"There's always a core group that will do the work and provide the funds, and a group that figures it will get the free benefit," said Patricia E. Frankenbach, who owns a store that sells uniforms in Riverhead and is vice president of the Riverhead BID.
Shopping-center tenants are not allowed such recalcitrance. Most are required in their leases to chip in for advertising and promotion. Thus, the centers can afford full-page newspaper ads and fancy promotions.
"The neighboring malls simply presented a more united face," said Bernard Flaton, a landlord who helped start Cedarhurst's BID last April.
The Long Island BID's are having to fight back without much money. By law, a BID's budget cannot exceed 20 percent of a general municipal tax. In New York City, that tax includes school taxes. In most Long Island villages, school taxes are separate, so the general municipal tax is a relatively small figure. Great Neck's BID, Long Island's largest, covers an area with 32 office buildings and 250 stores, yet its budget is only $140,000 a year.
Still, the BID's have been able to afford holiday decorations, street fairs, jazz concerts and advertising. Several have set up recruitment committees to woo new stores to town. And others have quietly pressured local property owners and storekeepers to do a better job of cleaning up, and to be flexible in negotiations.
"We try to get landlords to split the cost of building out a store, or to take $10 a foot rather than hold out for $13," said David Friedman, a Westbury jeweler who is president of the Westbury BID.
The results can be heartening. In most of the BID areas, store vacancies are down and shopping traffic is up. BID officials insist a great deal more than an improving economy is at play.
"With a BID you don't have to knock on doors every time you need money," said Ron M. Edelson, executive director of the Great Neck BID. "You can plan things."
Mr. Edelson offers this example: Great Neck's annual downtown street fair used to be a haphazard affair, with each merchant maybe hiring a clown, or arranging for face-painting for kids.
Last year the BID paid for an antique car show, kiddie rides and a food court. And it got the word out in advance: Bobby Rivers of WNBC-TV provided live coverage of the event.
It had a record turnout.
"WHEN you have Channel 4 saying, 'Come to Great Neck today,' you get people who normally wouldn't come," said Millie Gubbins, who has run a local restaurant, Millie's Place, for 18 years.
Actually, until recently, many Long Island downtowns might have suffered from the spotlight. Patchogue's BID, which was formed in November 1991, took as its first tasks putting in new sidewalks and street lights and arranging for extra police in its downtown parking areas.
"We needed beautification and security before promotion," said Gerard R. Nocita, Patchogue's deputy village clerk.
But now Patchogue is promoting with a vengeance. Late last year Burlington Coat Factory opened a large Patchogue outlet. And Mr. Nocita says the BID is trying to woo the Brookhaven town hall away from Medford, its current home.
Huntington, too, is concentrating on safety and cleanliness. Its downtown has weathered the recession fairly well, but its new BID sees itself as preventive medicine.
"This is an upscale area, and it can't be adequate, it has to be excellent," said James S. Margolin, the BID's president.
Huntington's BID only officially came into being on Jan. 1, but the village gave it an advance on its $75,000 annual budget. It used the money for holiday decorations and new trash receptacles, and to start Sunday trash pickups "so Monday morning doesn't look so terrible," Mr. Margolin said.
Huntington's BID will also pay for a private security officer to patrol at night in warm weather and at high traffic times like Halloween and New Year's Eve.
"We have so many bars and restaurants, and they are frequented by so many young people, that we simply have to have better security," Mr. Margolin said.
Huntington has been luckier than some in that it has attracted Sam Goody's, Bombay Company, the Gap and other Triple A national retailers. Other Long Island BID districts either do not have large-enough storefronts to accommodate such chains, or have conceded such product lines to the malls.
"The megastores and malls are in our backyard now, and that's where the clothing and shoe stores belong," said Mr. Friedman of Westbury. "We need service stores, and stores that will help us capitalize on the traffic the malls generate."
Through direct mail and cooperative advertising, the Westbury BID has been promoting sights around the town -- including the sight of Mr. Friedman's artisans making jewelry. And it has offered brokers extra bonuses for bringing in new service stores, like appliance-repair shops and restaurants.
Riverhead, too, is de-emphasizing traditional retailing in favor of what Ms. Frankenbach calls a "tourist economy." Its BID has persuaded the local government to buy an abandoned movie theater and turn it into a cultural center. It encouraged a local businessman to start paddlewheel lunch and dinner cruises on the Peconic River. It is working with the Okeanos Research Federation, which may open an aquarium in the center of town. Its real estate committee, meanwhile, is gearing up to woo restaurants and other tenants that can cater to the traffic that such operations might generate.
GREAT NECK, in contrast, remains geographically isolated enough to get a bit of protection from mall competition. But that sword cuts both ways: It is on its own peninsula, so it is not a town that anyone goes through on the way to someplace else. And a few chain retailers -- CVS, for example -- have opened in town, providing a boost for the landlords but a kick to the long-time local shopkeepers.
"We were a trendy, upscale, boutique shopping area that always felt immune to the ups and downs of the economy," Mr. Edelson said. "Then this recession hit, and we found out we weren't immune at all."
What local merchants want most from their BID is publicity. "The BID can help show what this town really has to offer," said Neil Jacobson, who owns Vogue Discount, a health and beauty-aids store that Mr. Jacobson says has been "devastated" by competition from discounters like CVS.
The BID already has bombarded consumers with newspaper ads and direct-mail brochures. Soon it will widen its net, to ensnare shoppers from New Hyde Park and Manhasset to the east, and from Bayside to the west.
But the BID's consumer research has indicated that shoppers will continue to defect to malls unless service in Great Neck stores is vastly improved. The BID is developing seminars about the mechanics of personalized selling -- say, calling customers when an item they might like comes into stock. And it hopes to persuade Great Neck merchants to share data about customers.
"That's not easy, getting store owners to share, but we think we can do it," Mr. Edelson said. "We have to."
