HEADLINE: Lowly Banana Has a High Profile in a Trade Dispute

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
HAS GATT slipped on a banana?
Despite the signing last year of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the monumental world pact to reduce trade barriers and disputes, all it takes is a garden variety fight over a humble product like the banana to show how little things have changed. 
 Tensions have been high over the fruit for nearly two years, since the European Union proposed restrictions on big-selling bananas from Latin America -- as well as imports from the United States -- while continuing to wave through shipments from former British and French colonies in the Caribbean, Africa and the Pacific. The beneficiaries also include European growers in tropical spots like Crete, the Canary Islands and the Portuguese archipelago of Madeira.
American growers with big interests in Latin America, particularly Chiquita Brands International, have been furious, and not just with the Europeans. They have also been angry with several Latin American governments, which cut side deals with the Europeans to get around the new rules at the expense of the Americans.
What's more, the restrictions have caused tensions within Europe, pitting the British and French against the Germans, the biggest consumers of bananas on the Continent, who favor the Latin fruit.
Now comes the latest shot across the bow in the Great Banana War. In a letter to the European Commission earlier this month, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said he might take retaliatory measures against a host of European exports if Europe did not ease up on the banana.
To be sure, the United States and Europe have continuing disputes in a number of trade areas, including broadcasting and computer technology. But nothing seems to push the hot button quite like the banana, which inspires deep nationalistic sentiments in Europe that go beyond the size of the fruit's $3.2 billion market there.
Chiquita and other American producers, including a growers' association in Hawaii, have complained that the import policy has cut their sales to Europe by half, causing losses of "hundreds of millions of dollars at a minimum," Mr. Kantor said. The policy was announced in February 1993 by the European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union.
Many critics of the policy say it is just another example of how the European Union is still prone to a "Fortress Europe" approach to trade, agreeing only grudgingly to open markets.
"I have made a preliminary decision that the E.U. banana regime is adversely affecting U.S. economic interests," Mr. Kantor wrote in his letter to Sir Leon Brittan, the European Commission's senior trade official in Brussels. Mr. Kantor added that he had requested public comment in the United States "on specific European goods and services against which retaliatory trade action might be taken."
European trade officials are clearly upset by the tone of Mr. Kantor's letter. They wonder to what extent the threats of retaliation were sparked by President Clinton's weakened political position, with Republicans now controlling Congress, and attempts by the trade office to get political mileage from an aggressive posture.
Indeed, some see Mr. Clinton's free trade global strategy -- including the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the pushing through of GATT in Congress and long-term plans to create a free trade zone in the Pacific -- as among the main political achievements that he will have to play up.
But the banana dispute also underscores what many analysts see as an inevitable tension between the two trading blocs over business in developing markets, including Latin America and Southeast Asia, where both are fighting for influence.
Many European countries are trying to move quickly into those areas, because they see them developing faster than many eastern European markets during the next five years. But in terms of new political initiatives to those areas, the European Union is far behind the United States.
In global trade terms, the losses to the banana growers cited by Mr. Kantor amount to small change, and American officials have tried to play down the threatening tone of his letter, saying there is room for negotiations and no impending trade sanctions. Moreover, they noted, under the provisions of Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, the Government is obliged to carry out retaliatory trade measures if it finds that American industry is being discriminated against and harmed.
But the dispute has left a bitter taste in Europe and has taken on proportions that are larger than expected. For one thing, the letter was sent less than two weeks after the founding of the World Trade Organization, which will monitor the implementation of the new GATT accord. For another, Europe, having fought bitter battles over the banana restrictions two years ago, does not want to reopen the old wounds.
What seems to make officials here the angriest, however, is Mr. Kantor's threat to take unilateral action, rather than try to work things out within the context of GATT.
"I AM disturbed by your reference to 'possible trade retaliations' against European goods and services," Sir Leon said in a return letter to Mr. Kantor, adding that GATT called for the settlement of such disputes through the new trade organization. "Europe clearly cannot accept any unilateral action against our interest in breach of those obligations."
Trade officials from the United States say the number of items over which there are frictions with Europe has been greatly reduced by the GATT treaty. But judging by the early days of 1995, it seems the two giant trading blocs are heading into a period of more tension.
The two are battling over influence in the World Trade Organization, specifically about who heads the agency. The United States has backed the former President of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, though its support has waned a bit in the wake of the currency crisis in Mexico. The Europeans are backing the former Trade Minister of Italy, Renato Ruggiero.
The United States has told Brussels that it is concerned that exports of computer equipment and software will fall by $1 billion to Sweden, Austria and Finland -- which earlier this month became European Union members -- because they now must adopt certain trade restrictions on those products under the union's rules.
And the movie and broadcasting industry, with Washington's support, is trying to stop Europe from restricting even further the broadcasting of films not produced in Europe.
Then there is the business with bananas. Under the European Union rules that went into effect in July 1993, bananas could continue to be imported duty-free and without limit from former British and French colonies like Dominica, St. Lucia, Martinique and Guadaloupe.
But a quota was set on bananas grown in the United States and Latin America, called dollar bananas. The quota limited duty-free imports to two million tons a year, a level that has since been raised to 2.56 million tons. Beyond that amount, heavy duties are imposed.
The policy brought out the ire of the Germans, who consume almost a pound of bananas a person a week, twice as much as the British.
Germans say the fruit from the former European colonies is of lower quality than Latin American bananas. In a more extreme argument, they have said that the barriers to bananas could produce a large new inflow of cocaine into Europe, as some Latin farmers are forced to turn to raising coca leaves, the raw material of cocaine.
In any event, while the change in the import policy appears to be benefiting the small farmer in the former European colonies with increased sales, most of the added expense to the consumer is winding up in the pockets of European middlemen. A study by the World Bank found that European consumers are paying $700 million extra a year because of the new banana policy, and that $400 million goes to the middlemen, with only $300 million going to farmers.
MR. KANTOR's recent letter is the result of an investigation by the United States trade office that began last October, after Chiquita and the Hawaii Banana Industry Association filed a complaint under Section 301.
The office has also told four Latin American countries -- Colombia, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Venezuela -- that they could be subject to sanctions as well. After successfully complaining to GATT about the European restrictions, the four worked out individual agreements with the European Union about the control of their banana exports.
The agreement essentially allows their farmers unlimited duty-free exports to Europe, while controlling the amount that American producers in their countries can ship, an arrangement that hurts American interests, the trade office said.
With sentiments divided as much as they are in Europe, few bureaucrats in Brussels want to see the issue reopened and fan the flames of a trade battle.
"This is one of those things that can get out of hand," one commission official said. "So why is the U.S. threatening a trade war over what is not of major economic importance to them?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers at a plant in Ecuador prepare bananas for export. (James Brooke/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How I Survived Off Off Broadway: One Man's Tale

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
WHEN Aunt Chiche went for her checkbook, I thought I had it made.
There I was, a young playwright home for the holidays, watching my 86-year-old great aunt, my family's final link to old money, teetering toward her purse with a pen in her hand. I could barely contain my joy. I had just laid bare my ambitions and neediness and she'd bought it. I envisioned my actors getting paid, my four-colored posters plastered on the walls of SoHo and my production heading straight to -- 
 I saw a $50 bill. "For the taxi back from the airport, honey" said my dear old aunt.
Welcome to the sordid world of Off Off Broadway.
It is a world where actors and stagehands are more likely to be paid with brunch than cash; where day jobs and conflicting schedules make for midnight rehearsals, where investors want more letters home. Here, the constant groveling for help and money is considered an art form and legions of young unknowns hurl themselves into outrageous projects, desperate to avoid that most insidious of poison: anonymity.
Unfortunately, it has been my world. But after six years of storing up favors, building sets, raising money for others, sweeping up rubble backstage, this month, at age 24, I finally got my chance: My own play on stage.
In the process of getting it to its feet, I turned an art gallery into a parking lot, pushed good friendships to the limit and spent a good portion of my life savings. Why I and so many others go through and try to buck the odds is no mystery: We have no choice. In America's theater scene, all roads lead through New York. But beyond the professional necessity, there is something else. I left Kansas City when I was 18, and came to New York to go to acting school, fully expecting to be a star. It didn't work out that way. I became a clerk. I remember after I arrived, watching the speed and flow of the city's pedestrians, and now I feared becoming another piece of that mass. New York is oppressive that way. In my mind, the play was my chance to show the world that I was more than a paper pusher.
Every night, all over the city, you'll find an Off Off Broadway production, put on by the same people who serve your meals, deliver your messages by bicycle or sell you theater subscriptions over the phone. The creations from their minds include the stories of cannibalistic biker girls, pajama-clad post-apocalyptic wanderers, singing and dancing Lizzie Bordens and stagings of more traditional fare, like Brecht, Chekhov and Shakespeare.
I finished my play in August. The product of sporadic obsession, it had taken four years to write. It was a dark comedy based on Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" entitled "Quick Bright Things." I placed updated Midsummer's players in present day Nevada, and set the whole thing at a strip-bar bordering a nuclear test site. In the play, a rock 'n' roll cowboy returns after a decade, intent on reassembling the family he left behind. It was a stretch but that was the idea.
My first draft included 146 pages, 3 acts, 21 characters, and too many subplots. I gathered some friends for the first read-through, to hear the words that had sat on the page for so long. It took place on Oct. 17, lasted three-and-a-half hours and cost me a case of beer. By the end, the compliments were flowing. So were suggestions for cuts before the play went into production. Problem was, there was no production.
 
 
Getting the Space
 I had a play but nowhere to put it. There was one hope: I had been promoted in June to managing director of Teleotheater, a small three-year-old company. Teleotheater had just got its first break -- a residency at Here, a performance space in SoHo. For normally transient Off Off Broadway companies, residencies are golden, providing office space and a place to perform.
Being the managing director was a glorified way of saying I handled the business side of things. The position was unpaid and largely bureaucratic but I thought it would give me a chance to get my work produced. But by the time I had finished the play Teleo had booked its two slots for the season and the schedule at Here was full. Rental fees for another theater would be prohibitive.
But then, the god of bankruptcy stepped in. $3 Bill, another resident company at Here, hit hard times and forfeited its three- week slot in January in the main theater at Here. I asked whether the slot might be available. Randy Rollison, co-artistic director of Here and a mentor of mine, warned me that eight weeks wasn't a lot of time to prepare a new play. I didn't care. He warned me of problems getting rehearsal time. I still didn't care. He warned that very loud shows might go on in the other theater. I wanted my show up. Barbara Busachino, another artistic director, said, "If you've got the gumption, it's yours."
I had the gumption. And then, I had the space.
 
 
Getting the Money
 I decided to act as producer of my own play for two reasons: one, I had produced before, and two, I was so much of an egotist that I felt only I would get it just right. And everything needed to be just right.
The deal was this: in return for the space I was to do 100 hours of clerical work for Here, plus turn over money from the first 15 tickets sold each night -- about $180 per performance. This kind of arrangement is common in Off Off Broadway, where deals often include barter and work agreements, kind of like the economy of medieval Europe. I felt lucky I didn't have to throw in a bushel of winter wheat.
Producers in Off Off Broadway are different from Broadway types. Broadway producers raise the money, usually a few million, and hope to reap the rewards. Off Off producers have no hope of making money, scrape to raise even a few thousand dollars, almost always fail, feel guilty, end up spending their own money, and then hope to work overtime to make rent. And even at this level, productions are always over budget. The budget for "QBT" was about $6,000, which left us only about seven grand short.
Small companies use all kinds of schemes to raise money: benefits at bars, bake sales, raffles. We'd thrown a benefit in August featuring a naked poet and a band called O.J.'s Last Request. That netted Teleo a grand total of $281 and a reputation for lousy parties. So benefits were out. Bake sales required skill and raffles required possessions, so I was forced to retreat to the most basic of fund-raisers: begging.
I began writing cloying letters to family friends, talking about the worthiness of the show and true meaning of the holiday season. And, if worst came to worst, I knew I had my savings ($4,000), and about a third of the money would come from the box office -- if there was a box office.
Because of the time it would take to cast and the holidays, eight weeks of real time would be cut down to about five weeks of rehearsal time. I would pay actors $100 for a two-month commitment.
 
Cuts and Casting
 I had eight weeks from the time I got the space (Nov. 12) to opening night (Jan. 7). I chose my friend Michael Laurence to direct and he immediately suggested cuts. Big cuts. Larger cuts than I had imagined. For the first time, I felt a twinge of self-doubt. I felt, suddenly, like he was saying that I didn't get it right the first time. Logically, I recognized that a three-and-a-half-hour play is torture unless you're really good, and after the suggestions for cuts, I didn't think I was any good. So I began cutting. Gone was the character that most resembled me.
Most of the casting was easy. Michael, the director, would play a lead. Several of my former N.Y.U. classmates were signed up. Auditions, limited to actors we invited, filled in other gaps. Other auditions were held simply to soothe the egos of friends we liked but knew weren't right for parts.
What was left were the parts of a 10-year-old boy (Robbie) and a 50-year-old man (State). I didn't think the boy would be too tough to find. The older actor would be more difficult because we didn't know many, let alone one willing to trade two months of his life for $100. Michael and I knew auditioning them would be a delicate task. There we were, kids with an untested script, shaking hands with men twice our age, and then telling them that they weren't good enough. By the time of the second draft, we still hadn't cast either of the parts.
 
 
A Sense of Dread
 I finished the second draft (now 115 pages, 2 acts, 15 characters) on Nov. 29, an hour before the first read-through with the cast. The cast, minus an older man or young boy, stumbled through. The words, fresh in the first read, had lost their newness. Again, I felt the twinge of dread. Other things were different. Michael, as director, was now the man responsible for describing the play. The actors sat in a circle. I sat outside and read stage directions.
After, my closest friends dissected the play in front of me and proposed more cuts and reworkings. I resisted quietly, partly out of honest objection, partly out of anger and hurt. Finally Michael pulls out the big guns, "It's the difference between a good play and a great one," he said.
I did the rewrite.
 
I Am Asked to Leave
 Rehearsals began the next day, five-and-a-half weeks before opening night. I sat with a fresh copy of the second draft and a pair of new pens. One actor arrived early and gently suggested that a lot of my writing was "confused." Another was late and accused me of using pedophilic references. (Her reasoning: The final scene had a man saving a child from a nuclear wasteland. . .go figure.) I didn't understand. Michael turned to me and quietly asked me to leave so he could work all this out. I smiled, grabbed my coat, my pens, and my new script and left. Door shuts. Thrown out of my own rehearsal. I wrote a note on the script: "Tears." I don't remember whether I was talking about cuts or crying. I just remember a blinding panic: my cast hated my confusing, pedophilic script.
Two days later, we lost our first actor. George Demas, a close friend who was meant to play a key comic role that I had written with him in mind, dropped out after hearing that he has got a role in a big production of Henry VI Off Broadway. The role would allow him to work on an Equity show, an important step in the career of a young actor. Though I knew my anger was unjustified, I still felt betrayed. "It's just what I feel I have to do, at this point, professionally," he said. He felt terrible, too. Friends do your shows because they love you, but the career's the thing.
Two days later, two actors just didn't show up for rehearsal. I began to feel cursed. And still no checks.
 
 
More Rewriting
 Michael recast George's part and recruited another friend, Edgar Oliver, as our older man. He laid the responsibility of finding a boy on me.
The next day Michael called me at work, before I was supposed to go down to rehearsal. Michael says don't bother, rehearsal ended early. "The actors kept asking me questions I couldn't answer because I don't get it," he said, "Rehearsal was just a total wash." Total wash. The words chilled me. After pushing so hard to put the show together, I began to worry that I was forcing people to do something they don't like, or worse, that they were doing it out of pity. I felt like a emotional tyrant, which was hard to explain since I hardly spoke to the actors anymore. They were always in rehearsal. And I wasn't. I rewrite three scenes, and fall asleep during the fourth at 5 A.M.
 
 
Help Wanted: A Boy
 Producing began to take up a lot of my time. I call the mother of a child for whom a friend baby-sits. He's 6 years old (but can play 10, his stage mother assures) and taking classes at the Lee Strasberg Institute. The child is excited. The mother believes she has a "young" Macaulay Culkin. "I told him that if he does this play, then he has to do another year of Strasberg," she said.
I decided to hire a publicist, saving myself from having to pitch critics. The publicist needed a description of the play and $750. (It was telling of my worry that it took me two days to write a 50-word blurb on what the play was now about.) The production needed a stage manager. Posters, palmcards and promotion were all behind schedule. And the stage mother wasn't calling back.
At the end of the week, we do the first run-through. It was only the fourth full rehearsal I'd been in. Still lacking a little boy and scripts still in hand, my play staggered to its feet. Kind of. One actor had taken a character I envisioned as a quiet, nervous young man and turned him into a young Clint Eastwood ripoff. I couldn't tell whether it was mockery or flattery, but I feared the worst. Another actress had completely rewritten her scene. I watched and listened, heard words I hadn't written and characters I hadn't imagined. But then, slowly but surely, I realized that it was alive.
It was in that moment, that first happy glow, that Michael asked me about the car.
Michael Laurence is a sane man with a lot of strong ideas. But he wanted a car, my car, in the theater -- to stress the little boy's near suffocation in the back of a car.
The plan was this: drive the car through the front doors of Here, through their gallery, turn the corner and park it right in the corner of the theater. To avoid the panicked eyes of the Here staff, we decided to try the elaborate parking job one night when no one was around -- three days before we opened.
 
 
Nearing the End
 Some things began to pull together. Money started to trickle in: 100 from a friend in London, $500 from my parents, $132.43 from friends in Kansas City from a hat they passed around a party.
But minor disasters followed. The stage mother said her little boy couldn't do the show because her ex-husband had seen the script and thought it too "raunchy." And the replacement for George Demas dropped out. Other actors, worried about the show, began to complain about each other. With 10 days left, I am short two actors and face a near-mutiny. Desperate for a boy, I called a casting agent and offered $100 a week, money I didn't have, for a child actor.
Then, when all seemed lost, two miracles occurred.
George Demas returned to play the part that he'd had to quit, freed up by a delay in the Henry VI performance schedule. And Stephanie Tardiff, a 4-foot tall actress, auditioned for the role of the little boy and agreed to perform at a regular, meager rate. True, she was 24 years old but she had plenty of acting experience. By the New Year's Eve, a week before opening, we'd finally cast the show.
 Saturday was opening night. Building the set, a 72-hour ordeal, began the Monday before, attended to by the lighting designer, Jason Boyd, the set designer, Derek Stenborg, the production manager, John Lewis, and an old friend who appeared out of nowhere, Timothy Reynolds. By the time we got to sneaking the car at 4 A.M. Thursday, none had slept more than four hours, or changed clothes, in the previous three days.
For the record, a 1984 Nissan Sentra is 53 1/2 inches wide and the front door at Here is 55 inches wide. And Here's gallery is plenty big enough for a drive. That last corner, though, into the mainstage, just isn't made for auto-transport. The lowest moment came when the car got stuck between the theater door and a collection of erotic sketches in the gallery. The high point was getting it back out before the paintings melted from the carbon monoxide.
 
 
Opening night
 People I didn't know came. They paid money. The actors said most of my words. I sat in the back. I sweated a lot. Every silence in the audience brought on a panic. That's about all I can remember. There were lights, I think, and music. Finally, it got real dark and people started slamming their hands together.
 
 
Epilogue
 When the lights went down, the party began, I felt strange. It wasn't what I had expected. The play, the thing I had invested so much in, now had less to do with my work than with the cast's. This moment, this play was theirs. I felt removed.
But I realized that for me, the experience was not about exploring myself or big ideas through characters. It was about defining myself -- as a playwright and a member of the world that I want to belong to, the world of late nights, low budgets and good friends. And if theater is about creating characters and stories, I had been a success. The strange feeling I felt was of myself in a new role. Suddenly I was a playwright.
Now, I won't tell you about the night the cast tripled the audience, or the reviews ("When a writer uses Shakespeare as a model, sometimes the results can be amusing or enlightening. And sometimes not."), or the clerical work I still have to do. (My bank account is a mess.) That's all another story. Or perhaps, another play.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MELROSE;
Burned Strip Plans to Rebuild

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Since a fire burned down the coffee shop he has owned for the last 15 years, Peter Katsihtis has been surprised to learn just how important Crown Donuts was to the neighborhood.
"I get people coming up to me, literally crying -- I'm not exaggerating," Mr. Katsihtis said. "There was one little guy in his 60's, retired. He's been coming here for 15 years, seven days a week, every morning and every afternoon. He seemed like a lost puppy. He goes, 'Peter, what am I going to do?' I told him to go across the street. But he said it wouldn't be the same." 
 Mr. Katsihtis, like other restaurant and store owners next to Yankee Stadium, have survived over the years despite slipping attendance at games and the vagaries of the team's performance. Now, the seven businesses on Mr. Katsihtis's strip are facing their toughest test ever, since a fire destroyed most of their block early this month.
The Yankees' future in the South Bronx remains uncertain despite the city's most recent proposal to create a theme park around the stadium, with new stores, restaurants and roads. But the owners of the businesses that burned are committed to reopening quickly, and borough officials are helping them do so.
The fire gutted all of the businesses on 161st Street between River and Gerard Avenues, except for a McDonald's at the western end of the block. Once a vibrant strip near the Yankee Stadium subway stop and Borough Hall, the site is now occupied by scorched walls and exposed steel beams surrounded by eight-foot-high boards.
Shortly after the fire on Jan. 5, borough officials began plans to rebuild the strip. Because the stores fall in the recently established Federal urban empowerment zone, it will be easier for the buildings' owners and the merchants to obtain permits and qualify for loans, said Kevin Nunn, president of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which is coordinating the rebuilding effort.
At a meeting with the merchants, the borough also offered to help with temporary relocation for some of the businesses, including a group medical practice. The fire destroyed a branch of H & R Block accountants, a grocery, a newspaper store, a clothing store, a pizzeria and Mr. Katsihtis's coffee shop.
"All the merchants expressed interest in reopening there," Mr. Nunn said.
Clint Roswell, a spokesman for the borough president's office, said the rebuilding effort should not face delays, because fire marshals determined that the fire had started with a heater and they ruled it accidental.
No timetable has been set, but merchants said it would take at least half a year to reopen their stores.
For the last seven years, Anastasios Kostarelos had owned Quality Pizza, a restaurant with six tables and 16 stools. Business had fallen in the last five years, he said, because of declining attendance at Yankee Stadium. Most of his customers lived in the neighborhood or worked at Borough Hall, but he had counted on baseball fans for extra revenues.
"You're not making a killing in the area," Mr. Kostarelos said, "you're just surviving. But if we can afford the new lease, we would love to go back." NORIMITSU ONISHI

HEADLINE: The Nation;
How Foreigners Invest, And Lose Their Shirts

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
FOREIGN investors have lost billions of dollars in Mexico, and the recriminations are flying. American investors want to know why their Government didn't warn them that the Mexican economy was sicker than it looked. The Mexican finance minister says things would not have gotten this bad if investors on Wall Street hadn't been so eager to send money. And as the United States Congress began balking at the Clinton Administration's proposal to bail out Mexico with $40 billion in loan guarantees, the Mexican stock market and the peso took another plunge.
So what else is new?
The history of foreign investing is littered with disaster stories. Governments fall, and their successors renege on their debts. Currencies are devalued. Bull markets collapse and in the rubble evidence of fraud emerges. The supposed experts who should have been on the lookout for problems were in fact too busy selling securities to pay attention. 
 It has long been a truism of investing that foreigners tend to buy at the top of almost any market. That is probably because they are not paying attention when a foreign market is cheap, only noticing it after prices have doubled and tripled and then rushing in. At first the waves of foreign buying push prices up even more, bringing in even more foreign money. But no boom lasts forever. And when rumors of problems begin to spread, foreigners are unlikely to be among the first to hear them.
Time after time in the late 19th century, British investors bought American securities, only to lose much of their money in a panic or in a bankruptcy that seemed to leave insiders unscathed. J. P. Morgan became the dominant banker in America in part because he was trusted by British investors to try to protect their interests. They needed protection from the likes of Jay Gould, who once kept control of the Katy Railroad (the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad), despite the opposition of most shareholders, by printing the announcement of the annual meeting in an obscure Kansas newspaper. By the time the shareholders, most of them British, found out about the meeting, it was too late.
"A lot of money was lost by foreigners investing in the United States," said James B. Rogers, Jr., a former Wall Street money manager known for his investing in risky foreign markets. "But those who got it right made a great deal of money investing in this debt-ridden underdeveloped country."
In fact, the Mexican debacle is, in many ways, tame by historical standards, even by Mexican historical standards. As recently as 1982, the Mexicans defaulted on promises to pay high interest rates on American dollars deposited in their banks, instead paying off the deposits in sharply devalued pesos. But this year, similar promises made by the Mexican Government have been honored, greatly reducing the losses for investors. And so far, the drop in Mexican stocks has not been tinged by scandal.
That is not always the case. Two decades ago, during a wild bull market in Hong Kong that drew in a lot of foreign money, some enterprising people took advantage of the swell by printing and selling counterfeit share certificates. Brokerage back offices were so overwhelmed by heavy trading that it was some time before they noticed the counterfeits. Soon after, the market crashed, and everyone lost money, whether or not they had been snookered into buying a phony certificate.
Just three years ago, a boom in India's stock market was fueled by phony bank certificates, which were traded like money. Profits vanished when the fraud was uncovered.
"There is always the risk of unexpected developments in any kind of investing," notes Barton Biggs, the chief international strategist for Morgan Stanley. "In international markets, the risks are compounded" because markets are not as open as the American market.
Foreign markets are also complicated by differences in accounting standards around the world. Standards can be surprisingly lax even in some major countries like Britain, where Robert Maxwell carried out a massive fraud without his auditors noticing. And in some countries, there are no real audits at all. China had a brief stock market boom in 1993 despite a lack of reliable profit figures. And last year the Bank of China, a government-owned bank, sold $500 million of bonds to American investors. Although the bank's balance sheet looked good, it was not audited by any other accounting firm. Instead, the figures were certified by the bank's very own in-house accountants.
So far, that loan has not been a disaster for the lenders. But the willingness of investors to overlook the lack of an outside accountant is a sign that greed has gotten the better of them. "There are," says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, "cycles of financial credulity just as sure as there are business cycles."
In the 1920's, Mr. Grant recalls in "Money of the Mind," his book on financial history, Ivan Krueger, a Swedish financier who dominated the world's match industry -- that's right, the things you light candles with -- borrowed huge sums of money at extraordinarily high interest rates. Although he used the best investment bankers, no one noticed that his auditing firm, a predecessor of today's Ernst & Young, had not certified his accounts. (In fact, they refused to do so because they could not confirm the figures.)
When Krueger's fraud was eventually exposed, the American investment bankers were blamed, even by Swedish investors. The investors said they had relied on the bankers to investigate Krueger. Max Winkler, a financial commentator of the time whose own warnings had been ignored, responded to those pleas by quoting, "Mundus vult decipi -- ergo decipiatur." The world wants to be deceived -- let it therefore be deceived.
Before the current Mexican crisis, there were in fact some warnings sounded. Last spring, Gert von der Linde, the retired chief economist of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, predicted the devaluation of Mexican currency. But his words were all but ignored. Indeed, most big Wall Street firms were eagerly recommending, and selling, Mexican investments right up until the peso fell.
Now American government officials say they saw the risks in Mexico and began warning Mexican officials as early as late summer. But they decided not to sound a warning here because they believed that it was important to support the Mexican Government and economy, particularly in the wake of the bruising ratification battle over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
There is plenty of precedent here, as well. In the 1920's American investors were persuaded to lend huge sums of money to Germany to help with its reconstruction and with reparations payments after World War I. The bankers who arranged the loans by selling bonds feared that Germany would default, and so did the American Government, but they kept quiet and emphasized how America would benefit from the loans, through increased trade. The fears, of course, were prescient.
Historically, the excesses of international markets have produced big profits and big losses, with the losses killing investors' enthusiasm for years or even decades. Now, President Clinton appears to be trying to avoid discouraging Americans from investing in Mexico.
Many Wall Street strategists argue that if Congress fails to approve the loan guarantees to Mexico, it will be playing Russian roulette with the hemisphere's economy. They say that America's responsibility to the economy far outweighs any concern about unjustly enriching foolish investors, whose bad bets on Mexico will prove much less costly to them if the bailout is approved.
That is an argument that grates on Mr. Grant, who thinks that the loan guarantees would be a bailout not of Mexico but of reckless investors. "This scheme has shown that Wall Street is not in favor of free markets," he said last week. "It is in favor of free bull markets. It is so much opposed to bear markets that it would like the Government to intervene to stop them."

HEADLINE: The World;
A Language Divided Against Itself

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
THE calls for holy war that adorn the walls in slums throughout the Middle East, and fill the speech of Islamic militants, are written in a special brand of Arabic. This is not the classic language of 1,500 years of science, poetry and philosophy. It is a far simpler argot, of cliches, religious verses and slogans. Expressed in the cruder rhythms and pronunciations of street language, they become almost incomprehensible to educated Arabs, only widening a dangerous gulf between an elite that looks to the West and an enraged underclass from which suicide bombers and murderers of tourists can be recruited. The cliches and slogans are made to burst with emotion, leaving them ill suited for reflection or debate.
How, for example, is an outsider to answer a shout of "Islam is the solution"? Where does "There is no god but God" fit into the political discourse? And how can those with a different point of view communicate with sloganeers like those in Gaza who last week applauded a curbside massacre in central Israel as "the killing of 20 pigs and the injuring of 60 monkeys?" 
 The point is that they can't. Americans can't. Israelis can't. And neither can the educated Arab elite, now the West's tacit allies in the Middle East.
In one sense, the problem is obvious and familiar: Demagogues everywhere exhort supporters with chants, shouts and epithets, to unify and isolate them.
Here in the Middle East the problem goes deeper. For the ways in which both the Arabic language and Arab societies have evolved make the language of the poor an exquisite tool with which to corrupt the Koran into an instrument of class hatred and tribal warfare.
The poor man's Arabic is not the same as that of the elite, who speak an idiom that the illiterate, and semi-literate, underclass often does not understand.
The forms of Arabic range from classical to colloquial; speaking one or another quickly identifies an Arab by class and by level of education. And, since enormous social and economic gulfs have been allowed to grow, language itself has become a barrier to understanding. The poor often cannot grasp the subtle rationalizations put forward by the educated. And the elite, isolated and besieged, are perplexed by the string of slogans and rote scriptural quotations, which they dismiss as an incoherent babble even as they fail to comprehend the anger beneath.
It is not easy to find parallels for this in the highly educated and more egalitarian societies of the West, but consider this: What if 80 or 90 percent of Americans spoke every day in the brutal and angry cadences of gangsta rap, while the members of a feudal upper class mused over their own demise in Elizabethan English?
That is an exaggeration, of course. While the Arabic of the Koran is as poetic as the full theology of Islam -- nuanced and difficult to master -- everywhere the language has undergone some adaptation for modern usage, even among the highly educated.
But it occurs in its most degraded form in the slums and poor villages across the Middle East -- in Cairo and Algiers and in Gaza. This is the language that has been adopted by political Islam, and this is where it is gaining ground.
At the same time, the militant clerics, in their calls for fire and blood, cling only to select passages of their holy book, in the manner of zealots elsewhere. So corruptions of Islamic terms and passages are numerous in the militants' ideology. None is as gross as the use of the word "jihad." For the militants it conveys carte blanche to kill, kidnap, hijack and bomb anyone they see as an infidel, including children and other Muslims. More temperate Muslims point out how often the prophet Mohammed denounced bloodthirstiness.
In fact, jihad does not always mean "holy war," or even "war," in the Koran. According to Islamic tradition, the "great jihad" is the battle within one's self to live in accord with God's will. A jihad, for Mohammed, is often the struggle to achieve inner-worldly asceticism, in accord with his call "to command the good and forbid evil with the heart, the tongue and the hand." And the Koran is even more blunt about using violence to propagate the faith. "There is no compulsion in religion," it states; it condemns forced piety and conversion as insincere. Calls to martyrdom, presented by militants as a direct path toward eternal life, conveniently eschew the Koranic ban on suicide.
But theological nuance is beside the point for the zealots. It is enough for unexamined quotations to be injected into the everyday flow of street Arabic, which often uses cliches or slogans in every third or fourth sentence anyway.
"These slogans are valued by the poor as much as their television sets, or other electronic devices, that they own but do not understand and cannot devise or manufacture themselves," said Dr. el-Said M. Badawi, the Director of the Arabic Language Institute at the American University in Cairo and one of the Middle East's leading linguists. "The slogans satisfy a real need. Because the poor lack the educational tools to dissect a cliche, or a slogan, they accept it whole and do not question it."
 
A Legacy of Ruin
 That the average Arab has such a poor grasp of political language is largely the fault of the fiery Arab nationalists, such as Gamal Abdel Nasser, who two generations ago mobilized the dispossessed with impassioned slogans of their own. These directed hatred at colonialists and Israelis while promising wealth and an Arab resurgence. Once in power, however, the Arab nationalists proved corrupt, brutal and inept. They ruined educational systems that could have helped the masses develop a more sophisticated vocabulary. Now the clerics are taking advantage of the social and intellectual wreckage left behind.
The great mistake opponents of the militant movements often make is to assume that the skeletal nature of the language used, and the intellectual shallowness of the slogans, mean that the message won't be effective. The Egyptian, Tunisian and Algerian Governments use a lot of air time and newspaper space to criticize the militants' ideology (but often in the highbrow Arabic that the masses have trouble understanding).
Judge Sayid al-Ashmaway, who lives with bodyguards and rarely leaves home, is Egypt's most prominent intellectual critic of the movement. His books are required reading in many schools inside and outside Egypt. "Either Islam is reformed or we are finished," he said in an interview. "The Islamic mind is confused. People do not understand the proper definitions of Islamic terms, but believe the distorted definitions. Religion has become mixed up with politics and out of this has come an ideology. This militant doctrine must be replaced by a liberal Islamic doctrine."
But just as secular Arab regimes and movements like Algeria's socialist government and Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization squandered the chance to educate the masses to a more sophisticated level of political participation, so the intellectuals like Judge Ashmaway, who attack the Islamic militants in the state-controlled press, have squandered their credibility by siding with these dying political systems.
W. B. Yeats once observed, in "Meditations in Times of Civil War": "We had fed the heart on fantasies. The heart's grown brutal from the fare." Such is the real tragedy of the Middle East, in the end: that the brutalization of political conversation has left so few Arabs able to talk to one another.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A militant in Gaza spread the word about an Islamic guerrilla group in December 1993. (Allan Tannenbaum/Sygma)

HEADLINE: CHINA TRADE RIFT WITH U.S. DEEPENS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The latest round of trade negotiations between the United States and China broke down in Beijing today, and the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, threatened to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods if an agreement was not reached by next Saturday.
The United States is demanding that China crack down immediately on the pirating of copyrighted American computer software, movies and music, and that it stop Chinese businesses from putting phony American labels on consumer products. 
 In a conference call with reporters, Mr. Kantor said he had invited Chinese trade officials to come to Washington next week to resume the talks but had not received a response.
In Beijing, the official New China News Agency maintained that Chinese negotiators "made ultimate efforts and showed considerable flexibility" during the latest talks but that the United States had made new demands that made an agreement impossible.
The talks over the last nine days were the latest in negotiations that have gone on for years as the Chinese Government has refused to close down 29 factories in southern China that turn out 70 million compact disks and other illegally copied products every year.
Many of these products are sold elsewhere in Asia, and officials here estimate that American businesses lose $1 billion a year because of the thievery.
"We want a detailed agreement that's going to address the problem," Mr. Kantor said.
If such an agreement is not reached by Saturday, the deadline for imposing sanctions under an American law called Special 301, 100 percent tariffs will be imposed within days on some Chinese exports, Mr. Kantor said. That would double the price that American consumers pay for these items. In theory, that would cause sales of Chinese-made products to fall.
Mr. Kantor did not identify today the exports that would be affected, but a list of potential products published late last year included consumer electronics, toys and clothing.
Asked whether he was serious about imposing the stiff new tariffs or was just seeking to strengthen the United States' hand in the negotiations, Mr. Kantor responded, "Watch our actions."
He added, "With this Administration, it's been quite clear that we're willing to impose trade sanctions."
Chinese negotiators have often waited until the last moment to present concessions, as was the case during textile talks last year. So an agreement by the deadline Saturday is not impossible.
Two years ago, the United States threatened similar measures but backed off after China agreed to new laws to prevent the illegal copying of foreign products. The laws were never enforced.
Then, last May, President Clinton reversed a promise he made during his election campaign and agreed to renew trade benefits to China, called "most favored nation" treatment, without regard to the way China dealt with its political dissidents.
The President maintained that continuing the trade benefits would be good for American business and good for the dissidents. But since then, crackdowns on dissidents have worsened, and China has not followed through on commitments to let the Red Cross visit dissidents in prison to check on their conditions.
With American markets open to the Chinese and markets in China largely closed to American products, the United States' trade deficit with that country has mushroomed. The trade imbalance last year was about $30 billion, second in size only to the $60 billion deficit with Japan.
Mr. Kantor said that on the street in Beijing, American negotiators were able to buy a package of illegally copied American computer software worth $10,000 for only $100. He said he found it "somewhat stunning" that even Government ministries in China used pirated American software "on a daily basis."

Beijing Blames U.S. Negotiators
 BEIJING, Jan. 28 (AP) -- China blamed the United States today for the failure of the two nations' talks aimed at ending patent, trademark and copyright piracy in China.
The New China News Agency said American negotiators had made new demands as the talks were about to end that went "beyond the scope of intellectual property." American negotiators here were not immediately available for comment.
"We don't want to see a trade war," the official news agency quoted an unidentified spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation as saying.
The official said China believed it important to protect intellectual property rights. But he repeated China's warning that it would retaliate with trade sanctions of its own if Washington made good on its threat.
China contends that it has made significant progress in protecting intellectual property rights. American negotiators say China's enforcement of laws to protect these rights has been inadequate.

HEADLINE: 2 Californias Face Off; This Time It's a Game

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28

 BODY:
At kickoff time in Sunday's all-California Super Bowl, Mary Schafer's household will be gathered around the television set with their San Diego Chargers sweat shirts and their "Southern California quiche": a stack of pizzas.
Five hundred miles north, in Sacramento, her twin sister, Sue Whitehead, will be rooting for the San Francisco 49ers with the finely honed disdain that Northern Californians reserve for their sisters to the south. "Of course we're superior," she says. "I keep telling my sister she better behave or we'll turn the water off." 
 This longstanding rivalry, and the San Andreas fault, are among the few things that the north and the south of this huge state have in common. With as many people as the combined population of 22 other states -- and even bigger portions of brawn and glitter -- California has been likened to two Arnold Schwarzeneggers trying to squeeze into one body.
The rivalry has its serious side: Southern California has made its deserts bloom with water siphoned from the north and has used its economic and electoral muscle to sway state policies -- but much of it is a contrast in style.
Two weeks ago, when the 49ers qualified for their fifth Super Bowl, a headline in The San Francisco Chronicle neatly captured the mood of that city, which is sometimes compared to a Victorian dowager. "Low-Key Jubilation," it announced.
Here in the home of the San Diego Chargers -- underdog team, underdog city -- joy and disbelief have risen to near-hysteria, with people shaving the Chargers' lightning bolt onto their hair and repainting their cars in Chargers blue and yellow.
Priests are sewing yellow lightning bolts into their robes and saying special Masses for the team. On Friday thousands of fans formed a human lighting bolt in a parking lot and sent a photograph to San Francisco to be printed as a full-page advertisement in local newspapers.
Whether the reaction is studied calm or wild delight, this first all-California Super Bowl, in which the 49ers face the Chargers in Miami, is most certainly more than just a game. It is the latest clash in a rivalry that can be traced almost to the founding of the state a century and a half ago.
There is an undergirding of truth to the California stereotypes: the lush and laid-back north with its redwoods and rainfall, its beatniks and its free-speech movement; the arid, glitzy south, an oversized bully that fills its swimming pools with water from the north and sends its smog drifting out over the Grand Canyon in Arizona.
What better way to compare the north and the south than by contrasting the character of their surfers.
"In parts of Southern California there is definitely enormous peer pressure to be very cool and wear the right clothes," said Nick Carroll, editor-in-chief of Surfing magazine. "In San Francisco you're under pressure to avoid being cool as much as possible."
In Northern California, he said, where the waves are cold and wild, "Surfers like to think of themselves as a hard-bitten, hardy breed who will brave anything in order to go surfing. They look down on Southern California surfers as namby-pamby little warm-weather guys who don't have the guts."
On the other hand, he said, "Southern California surf style is one of high performance and extremely high skill."
"They tend to mock the San Francisco guys for being old, stiff, geriatric types who wouldn't know how to do an aerial turn on a wave if it hit them in the face."
Since the 1850's, there have been 27 legislative attempts to wrench the state apart: into two sections, into three; left to right, top to bottom. With all their differences, it sometimes seems the only thing the north and the south have in common is the San Andreas fault and the earthquakes it spawns.
"The San Andreas provides a backbone for the state," said Allan G. Lindh, a seismologist with the United States Geological Survey who, as a typical northerner, prefers to characterize himself as a "carpenter-philosopher."
But it is the San Andreas that will eventually succeed where legislators have failed, he said, splitting the state from the Gulf of California north past San Francisco, at a rate of 60 miles every one million years.
"I don't think Los Angeles will ever reach San Francisco," he said, waving aside a common prediction of geologists. "That's a false rumor being spread by people in L.A. who are trying to stake a future claim on our water."
With an eye always on impending disaster, as they bask in the state's riches, some Californians note that the last time two California teams met in a national championship -- the 1989 World Series -- parts of San Francisco crashed to the ground in the Loma Prieta earthquake.
If that were to happen in San Diego, the people here might be too frenzied to notice. Though their team will be playing a continent away, Chargers fans are expected to fill Jack Murphy Stadium here on Sunday to watch the game on two giant television monitors.
"Respect" is the assertive new slogan here, in yellow block letters on a blue field, on banners and baseball caps everywhere, and Mayor Susan Golding has announced a parade of celebration on Monday, win or lose. The nation's sixth largest city, everyone here agrees, is finally on the map. It is honor almost too much to absorb that San Diego will play host next year to the Republican National Convention and two years later to the Super Bowl.
In San Francisco, by contrast, said the newspaper columnist Herb Caen of The Chronicle, "We're getting so blase about winning Super Bowls that there probably won't even be a victory parade; just the Mayor going down the street by himself."
This may not be the moment to say it, but for all their rivalry and their apparent differences, the city of fog and the city of sunshine could be soul mates. Both are turn-of-the-century towns, with San Francisco clinging to the elegance and culture of the last one and San Diego emerging at the cutting edge of the next. Both are compact, livable, expensive bay-side communities that prize science and the arts.
But more than anything, both are cities that have defined themselves by not being Los Angeles.
That sprawling, disorderly giant, with its congestion and smog and crime, its energy and ferment, its conflicts and its creativity, is the gaping absence at this Sunday's game, the biggest man on campus without a date to the prom.
It is a tough moment for Los Angeles. At the start of the football season, many people predicted an all-California Super Bowl, but they predicted that the 49ers would be facing the Los Angeles Raiders. Instead, with the Raiders finishing out of the running, the city has had to absorb as well the defection of its other professional football team, the Rams, to St. Louis.
"No one was sorry to see the Rams go," said Dawn Setzer, a football fan who works in the Los Angeles Museum of Modern Art. "They were so bad for so long. I get the feeling that everyone here expects to see San Francisco win but wants San Diego to do well; the Chargers are so likable."
David L. Ulin, a writer and editor who lives in Los Angeles and is backing the 49ers, said, "The final irony is that an all-California Super Bowl is being played in Miami. I think it's karmic justice."
As Mayor of Los Angeles, Richard J. Riordan has had many a disaster to deal with, but being left out is a new one. In an interview, he was quick to remind the world of the city's importance.
"I feel that we in Los Angeles have more serious pursuits than chasing an oval ball around a field," he said. "We've got the Grammies. We've got the Academy Awards. We've got beach volleyball."

HEADLINE: Residents of a Brooklyn Enclave Create Their Own Renewal Plan

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
In a city of skyscrapers and shadows, people have always talked about the natural light that drenches Red Hook. The Brooklyn neighborhood has almost no tall buildings and sits squarely on New York Harbor, and so residents, artists and visitors have long regarded the abundance of available light to be one of Red Hook's greatest physical gifts.
But for all the light, it has for decades been hard for anyone to see much of a future for the neighborhood. Isolated, abandoned, damaged by poverty and decay, Red Hook has long been in decline. Its 1950 population of 21,000 has shrunk to 11,000. The old rough-and-tumble waterfront, once bustling with factory workers and stevedores, is not only inactive, but inaccessible. Half the people live below the poverty line, and nearly a quarter of the neighborhood's 343 acres stand vacant. 
 Now, however, the residents of Red Hook believe they have a vision to go with all of their cherished light. Thirteen volunteers -- including a foster care worker, a schoolteacher and a statistician -- have produced an ambitious urban renewal plan, formally released at Brooklyn's Borough Hall last week, that aims to all but reinvent their historic neighborhood.
It is a plan that city officials call the most sophisticated and practical effort at city planning since the 1989 revision of the City Charter granted community boards the authority to map their own futures. Even though city officials agree it offers a realistic blueprint for remaking Red Hook into a thriving community, the plan could face a decade of bureaucratic challenges before it has hope of becoming reality -- an indication of the barriers residents face in trying to plan the future of their neighborhoods.
Red Hook's plan, laid out in 88 pages of graphs and charts, history and imagination, essentially calls for a working-class maritime village on the peninsula that lies south of Brooklyn Heights. It would have hundreds of units of new housing, a new 500-student high school, and a revitalized waterfront. Now isolated because no subway or major bus line runs through it, the new Red Hook would have direct public bus service to lower Manhattan. And major zoning changes would allow for a mix of residential and commercial development so that the community could be more integrated.
"Look, it's easy to talk a grand, bold line about urban design, and then watch as plans collect dust on office shelves somewhere," said Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
"But this plan, simply put, is one of the best we've seen. It's not an advocacy plan, not an ideological plan. It's not a wish list, but based in reality. The process behind the plan and the product itself should be a model for how neighborhoods plan for themselves in the future."
The future offered by the plan registers in a more human and less academic way with Wally Bazemore, a father who lives in one of Red Hook's housing projects.
"I have seen the neighborhood go from the sublime to the ridiculous, but I have chosen to raise my son here," Mr. Bazemore said of Red Hook. "I have a lot of faith in the plan, otherwise I'd be scurrying out of there with everybody else. I hope the politicians do justice to the plan with those mighty pens of theirs."
 
A Case Study In Urban Design
 Created over three years, the plan reflects the input of the neighborhood's poorest residents as well as its most eager property owners. Urban planners consider it singularly likely to succeed because its proposals for new housing do not call for a lot of construction, its requests for zoning changes are close to gaining final city approval, and its plans for economic development will depend mostly on private enterprise. And, finally, because there is so much that is physically appealing about Red Hook: its piers, its views, its unmatched array of vacant land.
"Because of its actual and perceived isolation, it's easy to deal with Red Hook as a kind of separate village," said Tom Angotti, a professor of city planning at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn who served as the residents' consultant. "This is not just a land-use plan, but more like a traditional urban design master plan. It might be an ideal case study for the future of planning in the city."
No one in Red Hook or in city government harbors illusions about vast subsidies or instant transformations. No one has even started to estimate eventual costs.
Indeed, the colossus of bureaucracy the neighborhood faces as it fights for final approval of its plan is captured by one of the final pages of the document: Page 81 lists 23 separate government agencies or institutions, from the City Council to the Department of Environmental Protection, whose help or approval will be required to carry it off.
To date, the plan has received initial approval by the City Planning Commission, and is expected to be given the official blessing of the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, by the end of February. It would then have to be given final approval by the Planning Commission as well as the City Council. In a measure of the optimism surrounding the plan, Mr. Golden has taken the unusual step of forming a task force to begin implementing the plan.
"It feels challenging, but it doesn't feel intimidating," Maria Favuzzi, a Brooklyn resident who headed Community Board 6's urban renewal committee, said of the task ahead. Community Board 6 covers Red Hook and parts of Park Slope and Cobble Hill.
"The people of Red Hook don't want any more trauma, and they didn't wait around for their political leaders to lead them," Mrs. Favuzzi continued. "One could assume there isn't a lot of political clout in Red Hook, but the people have started something I don't think the government can fail to respond to."
 
A Failed History In Reversing Decline
 Red Hook's decline began with the demise of the post-war maritime industry. Its physical and psychic isolation was cemented by Robert Moses' plans for the Gowanus Expressway. Mr. Moses' Brooklyn highway network, developed in the 1940's, bypassed and effectively severed Red Hook from the rest of Brooklyn.
The city's first effort to rescue Red Hook failed fantastically in the 1970's, abandoned before it was meaningfully started. What was left was a shambles of condemned houses, abandoned construction and manufacturing projects and a vanishing population.
The sense of ruin and regret still haunts the peninsula that looks out on the Statue of Liberty. The area is cursed by some of the city's most intractable problems, poverty and violence.
More than 70 percent of Red Hook's residents live in the Red Hook Houses, a public housing project.
According to the 1990 census, the average annual household income was $9,500. More than 78 percent of the children lived in households lacking both natural parents. Only 6 percent of the people over age 25 had college degrees.
And a whole range of the neighborhood's social service programs have been diminished or eliminated by recent budget cuts.
"It's not a neighborhood that is a great political risk to ignore," said Fran York, an official with Good Shepherd Services and the director of a number of social service programs in Red Hook. "Even if people in Red Hook are in favor of the plan, how will they get the political backing for all the funding that will be needed?"
The plan's promoters are not troubled by that kind of time frame, and estimate that it may take 25 years for all of its ambitions to be realized. That is why, they say, it is called a plan.
"If your aim is for what is accomplishable at the moment, then you don't plan," said Ron Shiffman, a member of the City Planning Commission who also served as an adviser to the residents of Red Hook.
 
The Modest And the Grand
 The specifics of the plan range from the modest to the audacious.
The first phase of its housing aims will revolve around 250 units of "in-fill housing" to be built on vacant land or salvaged from rehabilitated structures already in place around what the plan calls Conover Square, a two-block-by-two-block chunk of central Red Hook. Improvements in security and service at the Red Hook Houses would take place. And additional housing could result from the renovation of a city-owned five-story industrial building on the waterfront as well as the mixed-use development of the waterfront property currently zoned only for manufacturing.
What the plan envisions as "Education Plaza" would also be built, including a 500-student school for grades 7 to 12, centers for teen-agers and job-training centers. Satellite branches of the Red Hook Public Library would be established, plans already under way for a recreational pier at the end of Coffey Street would be completed and a corridor of streets to be known as "Ecology Way" would be refurbished and ultimately link Red Hook's pool and sports fields with the waterfront.
The designated truck route in Red Hook, which is now Van Brunt Street, would instead run along Conover Street under the plan. Van Brunt Street, now the only real commercial strip in Red Hook, would then be rezoned to allow for residential and commercial development. A bus route would be devised to carry residents of Red Hook to Manhattan through the nearby Brooklyn Battery Tunnel.
The closed Revere Sugar factory could be converted to a maritime museum, the underused New York Shipyards could be home to an imagined New York flower market, the abandoned grain terminal could be rebuilt to serve as a terminal for the storage of animal feed products to be exported overseas.
"Red Hook was very nicely zoned for the Civil War," said Greg O'Connell, a Red Hook developer who now has 20 small businesses operating on his converted pier. "But Red Hook is definable enough, appealing enough to developers and industry that you can really get a handle on what's possible."
The plan's sponsors worked hard to prevent overwhelming gentrification of the neighborhood. Two-thirds or more of all the new housing must be affordably priced, no new housing can be built that exceeds the four-story height of most of the neighborhood's current stock, no houses can be condemned for reconstruction without the consent of both owners and tenants.
Bea Byrd likes to think she and the other residents of the Red Hook Houses had much to do with both the plan's most ambitious and protective aspects. A leader of the tenants association, Ms. Byrd fought to be included on the community board's planning committee before it had opened the process to Red Hook's full population, and she made a point of taking the microphone at the committee's final meeting on Tuesday.
"When I think of this plan, I think of Martin Luther King Jr. and the notion of why we as a people can't wait," Ms. Byrd said. "We have children, and so we have hope. When the plan was done, I wanted to speak publicly. I wanted the privilege of saying I supported the document."

HEADLINE: Book, Citing Hanoi Files, Finds M.I.A. Data Withheld

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
A new book based on Vietnamese military archives asserts that Hanoi withheld considerable information on American prisoners of war for decades, and began releasing it only after the cold war, when Soviet-bloc support evaporated and Vietnam urgently sought to end an American-led economic embargo.
"Perhaps hundreds" of Americans who survived crashes and ambushes were killed by their captors in the 1960's and 1970's, Vietnamese officers are quoted as saying in the book, "Inside Hanoi's Secret Archives: Solving the M.I.A. Mystery." 
 The book was written by Malcolm McConnell of Reader's Digest, a former Foreign Service officer, using material provided by an American researcher, Theodore G. Schweitzer 3d. It is a summary of the pieces of information that have been put together so far about those missing at the end of the Vietnam War, and suggests that the number of Americans killed in captivity was higher than previously believed.
Mr. Schweitzer, who has often been in the public eye but rarely speaks to the press, describes himself as a former librarian. He was a field officer in Thailand for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. After the war he was involved in private relief efforts to aid the Vietnamese.
Colleagues from his United Nations days remember him as an adventurer, and he was known around Southeast Asia for his tales of derring-do. He told the Vietnamese that he was an independent author, although when most of his archival work was done he was a covert agent of American defense intelligence. Mr. Schweitzer did the bulk of his research in Hanoi in 1992, armed with a scanner provided by American agents and a good supply of dollars to reward the Vietnamese army archivists assigned to help him.
Soon after his project became public, the United States military was able to set up its own research teams in Vietnam, where work continues.
The author and researcher believe that the Vietnamese understood and accepted the ruse because Hanoi wanted to use an indirect conduit to Washington to test American reaction to material it had previously withheld.
Some officials who have been close to the issue say that the fact that the Vietnamese withheld information in cases where there were serious questions helped to fuel a militant P.O.W.-M.I.A. movement in the United States.
 "We know the Vietnamese had a lot of information they had not given us," Roger Shields, a former Pentagon official who was in charge of the prisoner release when the United States withdrew its troops from Indochina in 1973, said in an interview this week. "We were not surmising. We absolutely knew, and they knew we knew."
The book, published on Jan. 25 by Simon and Schuster, quotes a Vietnamese officer identified as Lieut. Col. Nguyen Van Thi as saying, "Our Government does not want America to know that our darkest secret is that we killed many American prisoners in cold blood."
Officials in Hanoi say this is fiction.
Former Pentagon officials say that they have always known of some cases of murder or death by torture, some of them incidents disclosed by Vietnam during the war and others described by American prisoners released in 1973.
At the time, however, President Richard M. Nixon, beginning to come under pressure from the Watergate scandal, overrode Defense Department apprehensions and declared on March 27, 1973, that "all of our American P.O.W.'s are on the way home."
Yesterday, Hanoi and Washington signed an agreement to exchange diplomats with Vietnam for the first time in two decades. The action came just a few weeks before Defense Secretary William J. Perry is to give Congress the latest information on Americans missing in Indochina. Officials said that the United States is holding out full diplomatic relations as an incentive for cooperation from Vietnam.
 Officials at the Pentagon would not discuss the book, but Beverly Baker, a spokeswoman for the Prisoner of War-Missing in Action Office at the Defense Department, said that Mr. Schweitzer's work to confirm that records were available in Hanoi allowed the Pentagon to establish the research there on an official footing.
Hanoi, eager to see the embargo lifted before President Bush left office, quickly complied with the request to permit the research. It was another two years before the Clinton Administration lifted trade barriers, and since then dozens of cases of missing Americans have been solved.
The book appears to corroborate the belief that Hanoi did not make a full accounting of missing Americans, despite its insistence to the contrary.
But the book returns to some cases and demolishes some of the more extreme claims, that Americans were knowingly left behind in Vietnam and that Washington has covered up the fact.
The McConnell-Schweitzer account also discounts reports that Americans were turned over to the Soviet military by the Vietnamese, as prisoners were by Communist forces in Korea in the 1950's. It was in that context that Colonel Thiwas reportedly told Mr. Schweitzer that "giving American prisoners to the Russians was not our darkest secret" and then proceeded to talk about executions and deaths under torture.
Mr. Schweitzer told the author that Hanoi held files that might shed light on the deaths. These included the so-called Blue Files, which Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts and co-chairman of a now-disbanded Senate Select Committee on P.O.W-M.I.A. Affairs, tried unsuccessfully to pry loose in 1992.
In the 22 years since United States forces were withdrawn, the debate over those missing in Indochina has polarized into a confrontation between those who believed that Vietnam did all it could to account for prisoners, and those who not only think that Hanoi withheld information but also often believe that some Americans remain alive in captivity.
In between has been a small, often silent but experienced group of officials and veterans who have argued that it is inconceivable that American prisoners could still be alive but it is also certain that Hanoi knew far more than it acknowledged about many cases.
Today, the United States lists 2,211 Americans still officially missing in action in Southeast Asia. About half are known to have died, but remains have not been recovered. Only a few dozen cases are considered genuine puzzles that the Vietnamese are likely to have the power to solve.
A spokeswoman at the Foreign Ministry in Hanoi dismissed the book as a "fabrication," adding that the timing of its publication was intended to derail improved relations.

HEADLINE: James P. Grant, 72, Director of Unicef

BYLINE: By By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
James P. Grant, the American foreign aid expert who in 1980 became executive director of Unicef and made it into a major force for helping children, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 72 and lived in Croton, N.Y.
The cause of death was cancer, Unicef officials said. Mr. Grant resigned from the United Nations Children's Fund last week. 
 The direction and urgency he gave to Unicef have widely been credited with helping to save millions of children's lives. Mr. Grant, who had also been an Under Secretary General of the United Nations, was still traveling and promoting what he called his "child survival revolution" until late last year.
His message was simple: low-cost, practical methods for saving young lives and curtailing the spread of easily preventible diseases can quickly make a difference. He advocated treating diarrhea, a leading killer of children, using doses of water, sugar, and salt that village people could make themselves.
To measure the successes and sometimes the failures of Unicef and the countries it assisted, Mr. Grant introduced an annual report, The State of the World's Children, now in its 15th year. In 1990, he organized a World Summit for Children, which he considered a highlight of his career.
In a statement after Mr. Grant's death, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said: "Very few men or women ever have the opportunity to do as much good in the world as James Grant. And very few have ever grasped that opportunity with such complete and dedicated commitment."
In 1994, Mr. Grant received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Clinton, who cited him for his "compassion and courage in his crusade for the world's children."
Mr. Grant was born in Beijing on May 12, 1922, the son of a public health expert working in Asia. He received a bachelor of arts degree from the University of California at Berkeley and a law degree from Harvard.
He began a lifelong career in international service in the 1940's, working with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in China.
In 1962 he became Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs and a deputy director of the International Cooperation Administration, a precursor of the United States Agency for International Development. In 1964, he moved to Turkey to head the American aid mission there.
Three years later, Mr. Grant was appointed an assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, serving until 1969, when he helped found the Overseas Development Council and became its president and chief executive officer. He remained there until moving to Unicef in 1980.
In 1943, Mr. Grant married Ethel Henck. The couple had three sons, John, James, and William. His wife died of a heart attack in 1988 on a trip in India. In 1989 he married Ellan W. Young, a photographer. He is survived by his wife, his sons and five grandchildren.
