HEADLINE: Uganda Strongman a Favorite of World Lenders

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda

 BODY:
He does not believe that multiparty democracy is right for Uganda today. His critics call him authoritarian and at times dictatorial. But Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, an articulate and charismatic leader, is still very much a favorite of the World Bank and international powers.
Diplomats here call Mr. Museveni, a former guerrilla commander, "America's darling" and "Africa's new man." Nine years ago he took power in a country battered by decades of civil war and killings that eclipse even the Rwandan massacres. In that period, his focus on building and liberalizing the economy has brought new life to Uganda, though the country is still not an economic power. 
 In part because of his liberal economic policies, and in part because of a straightforward style so different from that of his neighbors, President Museveni has for many years succeeded in defying international pressure that makes aid contingent on democratization efforts.
But lately international donors have been restive about Mr. Museveni's pronouncement that for at least the next five years, Uganda will remain a nation with a single political movement. And Uganda cannot survive without the roughly $800 million of foreign aid it gets annually.
A Western diplomat in Kampala said: "Democratization will be a big nut to crack. This is the critical period. This is 1995, Uganda's year of decision. He's popular and he's good, but he's not opening up, and it will cause him problems. He's so good in so many ways. He's the exact kind of man an African state needs at this point. But if he stops the clock, then in five years his own system will get hardened arteries. To me Museveni lives in a glass house."
Mr. Museveni's army swept into Kampala after a five-year guerrilla war, and in 1986 he formed a broad-based Government under the National Resistance Movement. Though the Government does not allow political parties, opposition figures have been allowed to run for office as individuals. Mr. Museveni argues that multiparty systems aggravate tribal divisions.
Last year the elections for the Constituent Assembly were deemed by diplomats and human rights officials to be one of the freest and fairest elections in Africa. There are many independent newspapers in Kampala and two independent radio stations, the only ones in the region.
Mr. Museveni says he believes that his economic program is crucial to the country's stability. He has freed markets, stabilized the currency, cut inflation, sold off state-owned companies and trimmed the civil service and the army. None of it was easy. Landlocked Uganda is mostly agricultural and very poor, its fabric torn apart first by the civil war and now by the AIDS epidemic.
He has a very personal style that contrasts most with the unsmiling rigidness of Daniel arap Moi, President of Kenya, Uganda's main trading partner. While the Kenyan President, the longest-governing leader in the region, is not approachable and always flanked by heavy security, Mr. Museveni is constantly on the move both in Uganda and abroad, "holding court," as the Ugandans describe him. He prefers a khaki safari suit and floppy hat to a suit and tie, delivers his riveting speeches from such unlikely podiums as the roof of his car, and rarely misses a chance to crack a joke, although his travels this month made it impossible to get an interview with him.
But the same man's Government has arrested and harassed opponents and been accused of authoritarian tactics. In November he shuffled his Cabinet to get more of his supporters in it, diplomats say.
In Africa, where governments are all too often defined by regions and tribes, Uganda is one of the most stable, yet it remains polarized along ethnic lines.
The most powerful ethnic group, the Baganda -- the wealthy educated urban elite -- are pushing for a federal state with more power for their titular king.
In the last year, there has been increasing instability in parts of the north as rag-tag guerrillas of the Lord's Resistance Army, armed by the Sudanese Government, have fought with Ugandan soldiers and planted land mines, making roads impassable. They adhere to no particular religion, despite their name, and their leader embraces an eclectic collection of beliefs including living by the Ten Commandments and eschewing riding bicycles and eating the meat of white chickens.
The opposition is weak and without a clear platform. The strongest are supporters of the Ugandan People's Congress, the party of former President Milton Obote. Mr. Obote, now in exile in Zambia, was responsible for tens of thousands of deaths during his rule. Unapologetic about its own history, the party views Mr. Museveni as just another despot.
"As a person, Museveni is highly ambitious," said Cecelia Ogwal, the assistant secretary general of the People's Congress. "The man cannot tolerate debate. He wants to solve problems by military ways. The U.P.C. of today is not the same one as the U.P.C. of yesterday. Let us not be judged by the childish behavior of our youth."
"Sincerely speaking and knowing democracy the way I do, we have reached a deadlock," she said, adding in reference to Mr. Museveni's party: "The N.R.M. is anti-democratic. In effect it is a military government."
Publicly, Ugandan officials say they have cordial relations with all their neighbors except the Sudan. In reality, relations are tense with Kenya and Zaire, while Uganda remains very close to Rwanda, whose rebels -- now the new Government -- fought alongside Mr. Museveni in the Ugandan civil war. Ugandan territory is the conduit for military equipment to the Sudanese rebels.
Mr. Museveni's main theme, echoed by his ministers and in almost every one of his speeches, is that Africans are "backward."
"We know Africa is backward," said Amama Mbabazi, the minister of state for defense. "We need to resolve the differences. We have to focus on other development issues. If we don't resolve our petty differences, then we shall perpetually remain backward."
Although Kenya and Uganda rely on each other, tensions between them constantly simmer.
Kenya, wary that its neighbor may have expansionist goals, has accused Uganda of arming Kenya's dissenters and believes that Uganda was responsible for helping the Rwandan rebels take over Rwanda last year. In the last month, scores of Ugandans have been arrested in Kenya. Ugandan officials and diplomats say Kenyan officials have accepted bribes from the Sudanese Government to stall ongoing regional Sudanese peace talks.
"Museveni views the other leaders as bad guys with dismal records, and he's right," a Western diplomat said. "This guy is formidable. He's very engaging, very charming. He reads a lot; he's very broad-minded. He has very strong views, but he doesn't mind testing them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, is a favorite of international lenders because of his economic reforms, but the donors are becoming restive about the country's lack of democracy. Unlike other African leaders, he often visits with his people with no visible security, as he did here outside Kampala. (The New Vision)

HEADLINE: Behind Tax Pledge: How the Numbers Came Up for Whitman

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The news came on Jan. 4 in a low-key way, just the State Treasurer wrapping up another tedious budget briefing with the words, "So, Governor, if you want to do it, my feeling is that the revenue is going to be there to cover the whole fifteen."
No one seated around the conference table in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's murky, wood-paneled office needed to be told what the full fifteen was, nor its political significance. 
 Even some in her own party had scoffed during her run for office 16 months ago when she had pledged to cut state income taxes 30 percent in three years, and now, with the Jan. 4 numbers, it was looking as if they might be able to deliver the promise in two years.
State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer had been churning out computerized budget projections for nearly three months by the time of that Jan. 4 meeting. He was tracking the course of New Jersey's tax receipts like an astronomer following a rogue comet. He kept factoring in income tax cuts of 5 percent, 10 percent and the full 15, the cut that would complete Governor Whitman's 30 percent tax-cut pledge a year early.
Peter Verniero, Mrs. Whitman's chief counsel, sat at the table, along with Judith L. Shaw, the chief of staff, and Jane M. Kenny, director of policy and planning, along with several aides to this inner circle. Mrs. Whitman had taken her seat in the middle of the conference table, closest to her desk, and the only question the Governor asked at Mr. Clymer's news was, "Well, what would it take?"
Last Monday, Governor Whitman answered that question to the state: cutting the state income tax 15 percent would take severe cuts in several departments, the loss of 3,400 state jobs, a virtual freeze on municipal and school aid for all but the poorest school systems. It would mean a flurry of small taxes and fees, on computer software, on grocery store coupons. It would take a few strange twists: a visit to a state motor vehicle agency in person, instead of sending that renewal in by mail, would cost $5 extra under Mrs. Whitman's budget.
But delivering on her tax-cutting promise early, the officials at that meeting knew, would also be a sensation in the state and cement Mrs. Whitman's reputation as a comer in a Republican Party that is leading an anti-tax revolution and looking to the states to prove that Washington no longer has the answers.
In October, the Governor had seemed to be moving the other way. She conceded in a radio interview that the cuts might take four years to complete instead of three, setting off a flurry of I-told-you-so's among state Democrats and from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who was fighting for a fourth term and used the admission against his rival, George E. Pataki.
Governor Whitman now maintains that she intended only to say that she would put prudence over politics in setting the tax-cut schedule, yet the dynamics of budget-writing may also have played a role in the October warning.
That is the jittery month when commissioners and bureaucrats begin to focus on their coming year's spending plans, and the Governor and her staff began bearing the brunt of intense lobbying from people interested in protecting their share of the pie. With so many dire warnings being made against this cut or in favor of that financing increase, and so little firm information about the prospects for tax revenues, the Governor's staff began making worried noises about the three-year timetable.
All that changed on Jan. 4, however, before the regular budget briefing. Ms. Kenny recalled Mr. Clymer's beckoning excitedly from a door in the Governor's outer office.
"Brian is very even, very steady," Ms. Kenny recalled, "but before the meeting that day he was gesturing at me, like he's really excited, to come over. He said, 'Jane, I want to show you something. If we do this and this and that, I think we can do the whole fifteen.' "
Mr. Clymer is a certified public accountant by training, but his background was in public transportation management, a tax-spending way of life that is far from the tax-saving, program-cutting purview of a state treasurer. He had spent the four years ending in 1992 running the Urban Mass Transit Administration in the Bush Administration, doling out Federal subsidies to city transit agencies.
Even now, two years later, Mr. Clymer's ground-floor office fronting West State Street in Trenton is festooned with models of commuter rail cars and with the kind of commemorative plaques that ranking public officials collect, like the testimonial from the city of Los Angeles to Brian W. Clymer for his help in restoring the Los Angeles Red Car Line, signed by Mayor Tom Bradley.
But it did not take a fiscal genius to see the importance of what Mr. Clymer had in his hand that day. Sales tax receipts, which grew by only $3 million from 1993 to 1994, were running $300 million above the 1994 figure, and income-tax collections were reflecting similar increases. The opening for a tax cut, a big tax cut, was growing wider.
Mr. Clymer had started his budget-making months earlier, in the heat of July and days after the current fiscal year's budget took effect. He began with three ground rules laid down by Mrs. Whitman:
"Any increase in spending had to be kept at or under the rate of inflation," the Treasurer recalled. "That was No. 1. No. 2, there had to be some extra money in it for Abbott versus Burke," the shorthand name for a State Supreme Court order to increase state aid to New Jersey's 30 poorest school districts.
"And three," Mr. Clymer said, "there had to be a tax cut in there."
In fact, early on, Mr. Clymer had picked an arbitrary figure out of the air, $300 million, 2 percent of the total 1995 state budget, as the goal for the cut, but first the state's 17 departments, the state colleges and universities, the state-owned New Jersey Transit system and dozens of other constituent groups were assigned the task of finding places to cut their budgets.
Those agencies use about a third of the state budget, with the other two-thirds devoted to school and municipal aid and to social services. A proposal was made -- no one will admit to it now, "but it was always out there," said Mr. Vernerio, the chief counsel -- to make an arbitrary across-the-board cut of state agencies, say, 10 percent, which would produce about $400 million in savings. The idea had appeal because it was easy, Mr. Verniero said, and it would be easier to defend than a line-by-line review of the 550-page spending plan. The Governor said no.
At another time, it looked as if extra savings would be gained by raising the number of state job cuts above 5,000. That figure, too, was trimmed, to the final 3,400 figure.
Meanwhile, rumors about state money grabs began to circulate, like the story that the Treasurer had his eye on a dormant $130 million fund held by the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission to maintain its huge, now-closed landfills in the future. The Meadowlands agency quickly issued defensive press releases against the potential grab, and nothing came of it. But Mr. Clymer is not saying never.
"Do you keep public money sitting in an account when there's not an immediate need for it?" he asked, the Treasurer offended by idle cash. "Well, there are a lot of symbolic reasons and aggravation reasons" why he decided it was too much trouble to fight for the money now, "and you end up selling a marina or something for $7 million because it becomes unavoidable."
Conflict also arose within the administration as the budget cutters from the Office of Management and Budget took after numerous small programs, like the $430,000 for the State Commission on Science and Technology, and Ms. Kenny, as keeper of the Governor's agenda, fought to put them back in.
"It's understandable," Ms. Kenny said. "They see a lot of money there. But the Governor is also committed to developing these economic incubator programs."
By mid-November, the once-a-month budget meetings in the Governor's office had increased to two a week, with the Governor combing the print and instructing her staff to separate programs into three categories: a "cut" list of programs that could be reduced, a "look" list of programs that needed more study, and a a "booked" or untouchable list, like the $10 million she wanted for a new juvenile justice program.

HEADLINE: Plan to Spread Pain of Medicaid Cuts Draws Wide but Tempered Criticism

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey's proposal to cut Medicaid embraces a simple strategy: make deep cuts, but share the pain.
Ms. McCaughey has proposed cutting $1.2 billion, or 13 percent, from a Medicaid budget that has doubled since 1989. Advocates for patients say the reductions would force many older people who now receive care at home to move to costly nursing homes. Union officials say the plan would mean layoffs of hospital employees and low-wage nursing home attendants. And hospitals and nursing homes say it might force hospital closings and a decline in patient care, especially at poor institutions that depend heavily on Medicaid payments. 
 The loudest protests came last week from New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which serves mostly Medicaid patients and which estimated that the cuts, along with corresponding reductions it could expect from Federal and city governments, would cost the agency $820 million.
Yet much of the criticism, especially from patient groups, seems tempered because Ms. McCaughey would spread the pain between the institutions that provide care through Medicaid and the people who receive it -- the poor, disabled and elderly. Hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, which have donated heavily to Republican candidates, including Gov. George E. Pataki, would absorb at least half the cuts.
Certainly, in selling any Medicaid cuts to the public and the Legislature, it could help Mr. Pataki to make the case that the state was trying to be even-handed.
"We understand this is a difficult situation," said Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki. "But given the fact that medical costs have skyrocketed over the last couple of years, it is imperative that we get this under control. Balance is necessary in order to maintain adequate services, and also it's necessary that the burden be shared by the provider."
Mr. Pataki has not said how much of Ms. McCaughey's proposal he will include in his budget, which is due on Wednesday, but hospital executives fear that cuts to health care providers may be even more than she has advocated. All of which raises the question of whether New York will continue its historically high level of health care for the poor.
"Over all, the whole thing is too deep and too drastic," said Anne Erickson, the legislative coordinator for the Greater Upstate Law Project, an advocacy group that helps Medicaid patients. "Should the providers have been brought to the table? Absolutely. Should we be looking at nursing home profits? Absolutely.
"But you cannot take this much out and still call it a health care system."
Advocates also specifically question whether the state can realistically force 1.5 million more people into managed care by next year, which is what the McCaughey plan calls for, without compromising quality. They argue that the proposal unfairly penalizes hospitals that take on the greatest number of Medicaid patients, like those in New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation. And they criticize a proposed limit on care at home, saying it would send thousands more into nursing homes.
Then there is the question of whether a plan like Ms. McCaughey's can pass the Legislature. She concedes readily that many of the ideas -- for example, some of the provider cuts and the limit on personal care -- had been proposed or developed by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo only to be crushed by lawmakers. (One hospital executive dismissed the proposed cuts to providers as a collection "of old Cuomo chestnuts.")
So far, it remains unclear whether legislative leaders will do for Mr. Pataki what they would not do Mr. Cuomo. Sheldon Silver, the Speaker in the Democrat-controlled Assembly, has already questioned many of the cuts in services for elderly people.
"I don't know why we want to bash the elderly of this state," said Mr. Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan.
 
Managed Care
A Big Change, A Modest Savings
 Though the amount of money saved would be relatively small, no aspect of Ms. McCaughey's report would affect the delivery of services more than requiring managed care for most Medicaid recipients. This change is projected to save $76 million in state money next year, out of total state Medicaid spending of $6.4 billion (the total cost of Medicaid in the state next year, including the Federal and local shares, is estimated at more than $20 billion).
The proposal would shift care away from the emergency rooms and hospital clinics that now serve most poor Medicaid recipients to some form of managed care, which seeks to save money by limiting patients' access to doctors and services. Most patients would enroll in health maintenance organizations.
Nearly every other state has some plan for Medicaid managed care, and New York has enrolled more than 400,000 in its own voluntary and more gradual plan, which was created in 1991. But Ms. McCaughey would rapidly pick up the pace, requiring that nearly all poor and some disabled recipients be enrolled by the summer of 1996.
That has prompted the question: Does New York have enough primary-care doctors in practice outside of hospitals to achieve such a rapid changeover, especially in poor inner-city areas or rural areas upstate?
A report prepared last year for Mr. Cuomo questioned whether there were enough doctors and services to accomplish his administration's more modest goal of placing 50 percent of eligible Medicaid recipients in managed care by 1996. And estimates issued under Mr. Cuomo said health maintenance organizations could enroll only 600,000 new patients, which is far fewer than the 1.5 million that would enroll under Ms. McCaughey's plan.
But Ms. McCaughey said health maintenance organizations had assured her that they could meet her goal. The state Departments of Social Services and Health are working on a survey to determine exactly how many doctors and other services would be needed.
 
 
Hospitals and Clinics
At What Cost To the Big Picture?
 About $604 million, or half the cuts in Ms. McCaughey's report, would come from cuts in payments to health care providers. Hospitals would be cut $238 million, nursing homes $234 million and home-care providers $67 million. Beyond that, $42 million would be cut from providers of personal care, which includes nonmedical services like cooking, shopping and housecleaning.
But the cuts to the providers -- which are the state's second-largest employer, after the government itself -- would actually be much larger, because for every $1 the state spends, the Federal Government and the local governments pitch in roughly $3. That would mean the total cut to providers would be $2 billion or more.
Though some health care analysts say the hospital system in New York State should be smaller, hospital and nursing home executives say the impact of the cuts would go beyond expected layoffs and possible closings: They say it could hurt patient care, as well as a state economy that depends heavily on heath care.
But the administration has so far shown only a little sympathy for providers. Despite all the cuts, the report includes $70 million in increased subsidies to the poorest hospitals. Meantime, some hospital executives say they doubt they will be as successful as they have in the past in fending off cuts.
"I think there has been a significant sea change that would make the prognosis here very likely that most, if not all, of these cuts will take place and the health care economy in New York will really go into a tailspin," said Kenneth E. Raske, the director of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
 
Care for the Elderly
Sharp Limits On Home Services
 The part of the proposal that may take the most political heat is Ms. McCaughey's plan for sharp limits on care at home, mostly for the elderly. These programs, put in place in the late 1970's to avoid more expensive nursing home care, have grown so much that personal care now runs at more than $2 billion alone.
Ms. McCaughey's plan would eliminate services like housecleaning and cooking for people who do not need more intensive services like feeding or help going to the toilet. But it would also limit, to 100 hours a month, personal care services for those who need the most help; under a new system, one attendant would travel between several homes during a shift rather than stay with one patient.
The proposal could send to nursing homes an estimated 2,000 people who need so much care at home that it costs more than nursing home care.
Critics say that the cuts could force into nursing homes some people who are almost self-sufficient; for example, a blind person who needed help shopping or cleaning and could quickly become helpless without an aide.
"There can be savings," said Bonnie Stone, the executive director of Selfhelp Community Services, a home care and housing organization based in New York City. "But how you do it is critical. And what we saw in the specific proposals were cruel, they were mean and they are easy targets."
The proposal also calls for a moratorium on building new nursing homes, on the theory that, like jail cells, they will be filled to capacity no matter how many are built. Some critics wonder how the system will take care of those who can no longer stay at home because of the cuts.
"I don't get it," said Cynthia Rudder, the director of the Nursing Home Coalition of New York State. "Where are they going to go?"

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Energy Aid Plan Helps Older Couple Survive a Hard Winter

BYLINE: By ROBERT WADDELL 

 BODY:
When B. Johnson thinks of how cold it was last winter, he shudders from more than the memory of frigid air. Last year, he and his wife faced a financial crisis that could have taken his home and left him penniless.
"My story is not unusual for senior citizens," Mr. Johnson, 72, said recently. "It's a hard thing after working all your life to find yourself in this kind of predicament." The Johnsons live on $1,100 a month, from his Social Security benefits and a small pension. 
 The Johnsons fell behind on their Brooklyn Union Gas bill because of high heating costs. Mr. Johnson kept the house heated warmly for fear that the pipes would freeze and burst. Despite a deferred-payment plan from the gas company, all of the Johnsons' bills seemed to arrive at the same time.
"We had the gas bill, car insurance, insurance on ourselves," said Mr. Johnson. "You get into a position where you start dipping into your retirement savings, borrowing, getting on the credit cards, then you get into a rut where you borrow from Peter to pay Paul."
Making matters worse, Mrs. Johnson was injured in a fall from a ladder, and Mr. Johnson had to undergo prostate surgery. Their health insurance ended with Mr. Johnson's retirement in 1986, and Medicaid would grant benefits only for Mr. Johnson. Forced to use their retirement savings to pay medical bills, the Johnsons had to cut back on necessities.
It wasn't until he applied to the Home Energy Assistance Program, which was established to help people heat their homes, that Mr. Johnson heard of emergency aid he could receive from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund's 83d annual appeal began on Thanksgiving Day and will continue through next month. Neediest Cases has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled since 1912, when it was founded by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times. So far this season, the fund has received more than $3.6 million from thousands of individuals and foundations. All the contributions go directly to the seven charities, which use them to help people like Mr. and Mrs. Johnson.
"They were able to help immensely,' Mr. Johnson said. "The federation helped us get back on our feet."
The emergency aid the Johnsons received helped them stabilize their debt to the gas company. The federation paid the $600 the Johnsons owed, which to them was like the first rays of springtime warmth after a bleak winter.
The Johnsons took out a second mortgage on their Bedford-Stuyvesant home to consolidate their debts. And with their health and financial problems slowly improving, Mr. Johnson breathes a sigh of relief. "I have a clear head when I don't owe anyone," he said. "I have my wife, my house and my health. What else could I ask for?"
But Mr. Johnson still fears the rising cost of living and the possibilities of failing health. "What we need in this country is national health coverage for older people," he said. "If the illness doesn't kill you, the doctor bills and the pharmaceutical bills will."
Mr. Johnson said he would like to work, but thinks no one will hire him because of his age.
"This past year," he said, "I nearly lost everything: my house, my wife, my health. I'm very greatful I didn't cash it all in."

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXIX: Sports of The Times;
When the Pageantry Obscures the Poverty And Social Action

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
THE MOST amazing aspect of extravaganzas like the Super Bowl is the extent to which the pageantry numbs, often obliterates, reality. So many private parties. Dances. Mountains of food. After a week of watching the wealthy and the near-wealthy, the notion of poverty becomes an abstract concept. The subject rarely comes up.
Today's game marks the seventh Super Bowl in Miami, the first since 1989, when a Miami police officer fatally shot a black motorcyclist. Three days of rioting followed during the week leading up to the game. 
 The National Football League was shaken in 1989, but didn't immediately grasp the implication. In 1993, unrest in Los Angeles before Super Bowl XXVII finally got the league's attention. Suddenly it registered with league officials that many of the players came from areas like South Central Los Angeles and the Overtown and Liberty City sections of Miami. They saw the relationship -- if only in a business sense -- between the survival of their product and the urgency of social action.
The N.F.L. returns to Miami with a more realistic, if not expanded, social consciousness. The league recently reached an agreement with the players association that would put $6 million into youth-oriented programs.
On Wednesday, the league announced a commitment of $2 million for its third Youth Education Training facility. The center provides organized athletic activities and also provides computer training as well as tutoring in basic academic skills.
The first center was built three years ago in Los Angeles, the second was committed to last year in Atlanta, although construction has not begun. The newest center will be in Gwen Cherry Park in Liberty City.
Paul Tagliabue, the league's commissioner, said the N.F.L. wants to identify the most effective means of contributing to communities that play host to Super Bowls.
Asked about the N.F.L.'s social responsibility, Tagliabue said: "Having a unique impact with something like Y.E.T centers rather than doling out funds is a key part of our philosophy. We see young people, the mix of education and athletes, as a focal area. The other piece is the concept of partnership -- with the private sector, the public sector and the players."
Should the N.F.L. do more?
Drive through areas in Miami, in Atlanta, in Los Angeles. The answer becomes apparent: There's never enough. The question is how much can you afford to give?
Rather than focusing on the league, the players should step forward and give more, not individually but in a collective sense. At a time when black athletes in professional baseball, football and basketball are rewarded so richly, you'd think they would have a vested interest in a assuming greater social responsibility.
In many cases, the willingness does exist. Individual players say they are interested in doing more. Those who come from places like Overtown know that the difference between making it and not making it is a helping hand and a firm nudge forward.
But the magnitude of the challenge is greater than one individual's ability to solve it. It's amazing that black professional athletes, given all the issues of image and responsibility, have failed to form an association that crosses the boundaries of their sports.
Players' unions act in the best interest of the majority of their members, although much time is taken up with labor issues. Issues specific to African-American and other minority athletes are not a priority.
Minority-group lawyers, doctors, architects and journalists belong not only to professional organizations but also to subgroups that address specialized needs. Minority-group athletes are the only professionals with no such association. Whenever they organize, they will be a powerful group.
H. T. Smith, an attorney in Miami plans to initiate a series of meetings with Heat, Panthers, Dolphins and Marlins players to do just that.
Smith organized the so-called quiet riot, an economic boycott, that began here in July 1990 after the city refused to honor Nelson Mandela, now the South African president, on his release from prison.
The boycott lasted three years, cost the city tens of millions of dollars and ended with a series of economic concessions by the city: $2 million deposited in a black-owned bank, an agreement to pave the way for a black-owned hotel and a commitment to bring blacks into the economic mainstream.
Smith wants to bring black professional athletes into the mainstream, too. Not in piecemeal fashion, but as part of a collective.
The N.F.L. can hold increasingly elaborate functions and no one will be offended. The issue is not the banquet, but the bank.

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXIX;
Huizenga's Field, but Minus Dolphins

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a career built on dramatically altering how garbage is hauled and videos are rented, the Miami Dolphins' owner, Wayne Huizenga, had no way to change the course of the field-goal attempt by Pete Stoyanovich with 6 seconds left in Miami's 22-21 divisional playoff loss to San Diego Jan. 8. Huizenga walked from a luxury box to field level at Jack Murphy Stadium, and watched from behind the goal posts as the 48-yard kick faded right.
"It was a big, big disappointment, to be up, 21-6, at halftime and not score another point in the second half," Huizenga said on Thursday. "We didn't deserve to win. Now, we just have to put on our happy face." 
 In a dispiriting irony, Huizenga has had to prepare Joe Robbie Stadium, which he owns, to play host to Sunday's Super Bowl between San Diego and San Francisco.
Two other teams, not Huizenga's Dolphins, had their names painted in the end zones. Two Miami icons, Dan Marino and Don Shula, were better known for their restaurants this week. The Dolphins, in fact, will cease to exist for three and a half hours on Sunday.
"In a split second, it was gone," said Huizenga, the sports world's only three-team owner: the Dolphins, baseball's Florida Marlins and hockey's Florida Panthers.
The end of the Dolphins' season precedes Huizenga's exit in March from Blockbuster Entertainment, which he steered from a chain of 19 video stores to a leviathan of 4,500. His departure is the last major step in Blockbuster's $7.6 billion acquisition by Viacom last September.
No one expected Huizenga to stay, working for Sumner Redstone, Viacom's chairman. "I said to him, 'If I acquired you, would you expect me to keep you?' " the bald-headed Huizenga said as he sat at a conference-room table in Blockbuster's 11-story headquarters.
Huizenga, who previously built Waste Management into a garbage behemoth, did not want his almost eight-year Blockbuster reign to end. Not when he was shifting into TV and film production. Or as he planned a $1.5 billion theme park near the Everglades that was opposed by environmentalists. Or as the chain had defied marketplace and Wall Street skeptics who suggested that its stores were headed to obsolescence, replaced by home video-on-demand.
Before the deal with Viacom, Forbes estimated his wealth at $700 million; it may be closer to $1 billion because his Blockbuster-turned-Viacom stock is worth about $200 million more.
But in December, Viacom scotched Huizenga's Blockbuster Park, with its planned baseball stadium, hockey arena, golf courses, interactive amusement park, film and TV studios, an office park, hotels and time-share units.
"The handwriting was on the wall," said Huizenga, 57, standing beside an illuminated scale model of the project. "I wanted it. But Viacom has theme parks and film and TV production with Paramount. And $10 billion in debt."
Huizenga still has his teams -- all of them personal investments -- which will be his primary focus until he finds a new industry to enter. He declined to buy the Heat last year. His brother-in-law's attempt to buy a $60 million stake in the team landed in court but the suit was dropped Friday when the majority partners, Lewis Schaffel and Billy Cunningham, were bought out by the Arison family.
Huizenga's ownership of the Marlins and Panthers put him in the middle of hockey and baseball's labor woes. He voted against settling the hockey lockout, arguing for a salary cap or payroll tax.
Losing the theme park hasn't diminished his desire to build a new home for the unprofitable Panthers, who play in the undersized Miami Arena. The Panthers, subtenants to the Heat, get nothing from parking, concessions and souvenirs, Huizenga said. "Maybe the worst lease in sports," he said.
In baseball, he is not about to buck his brethren's plan to field teams with replacement players, as the Orioles' Peter Angelos has. He alternates between conciliation and tough talk. "You don't want to go head to head with your players," he said, but added: "The players struck, we didn't lock them out. And they've gotten nothing out of it."
He cites surveys showing that baseball fans will return to Joe Robbie Stadium, where baseball ticket prices have been cut in half for now. "Sure it's painful to put replacement players out there," he said. "But think of the thousands of other people out of jobs. We have a responsibility to them and our fans."
Huizenga faces uncertainty as the Dolphins' owner. The National Football League prohibits cross-ownership in other sports. His Dolphins shares are in a trust, awaiting league review of its ownership policy. If the league doesn't change its rules or give Huizenga a waiver by June 1996, he'd have to sell.
"That would be a very big blow," he said.
Huizenga has much to admire about N.F.L. ownership, which cost him $138 million. Two-thirds of average team revenues come from television. Recent team sales of the Eagles and the Buccaneers have been for $185 million or more, exceeding the $140 million expansion fees for Jacksonville and Charlotte.
But in baseball, sales of the Padres, the Pirates and the A's have fallen below the $95 million Huizenga paid for the expansion Marlins. "Baseball's economics are so bad," he said. "That alone says something has to be changed."
Huizenga does not admire his Super Bowl economics. Huizenga will get no game revenues, which are all collected by the league. Meanwhile, Huizenga has made $4 million in improvements to his stadium, including planting 750 palm trees. "I had to pay for my tickets in my suite," he said. "No freebies."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
THIS ABSOLUTELY FREE* ARTICLE WILL EXPLAIN EVERYTHING ABOUT THE WORLD OF ADVERTISING!**

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Specifically, it is about how asterisks and fine print have become fixtures in advertising, and about the efforts by some to rein them in.
Last week, for example, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena announced that his staff would spend more time scrutinizing airline ads for deceptive or misleading claims. Candidates for tougher regulation, he said, include promotions of one-way fares that require travelers to buy a return ticket, and sales that make only a few seats available at the discounted price. 
 New York State legislators also passed a law last year requiring car-leasing companies to more fully disclose terms that add to the total cost of leases, like high charges for excessive wear and tear.
But asterisks and their accompanying restrictions remain popular gimmicks. In fact . . .
* Special offer available only to qualified readers who have already paid for the paper.
** Due to space constraints, this article actually has a more narrow focus.
 
EVER ADVERTISER IN THE WORLD IS USING THEM!***
 A recent Amtrak ad lists five fares to cities from New York. Four of them are simple one-way fares, but the fifth -- follow that asterisk -- is based on a round-trip purchase. "Other restrictions may apply," the fine print adds.
Car companies trumpet low monthly leases with no down payments, as in a recent ad for Infiniti. But the small type noted twice that dealers set actual prices.
Cellular phones are sometimes advertised for $1 or even less, but require a hefty fee to activate the phone number. Long-distance phone companies serve up a baffling array of discount calling plans while they raise base rates for customers too time-starved to wade through the Byzantine terms of the special deals.
Fine print is also no longer only the domain of disclaimers written in legalese, like this passage buried in a recent Hotel Intercontinental ad: "Number of attendees cannot exceed 120 percent of group room block."
Now, advertising copy writers have seized the space. Along the bottom of a recent Tower Air ad in tiny letters: "Hello. You're reading the part of the ad where you usually see all the restrictions you have to meet to get the low fare. But this is Tower Air. There are no restrictions. So, congratulations on your good vision and your eagle-eyed appraisal of all the ads you read for the small print."
Jack Trout, a marketing consultant in Greenwich, Conn., said companies began following the airlines' lead during the last recession. Marketers began enlisting the help of their colleagues in finance to structure clever deals.
"It's what I call marketing slipping and sliding," Mr. Trout said. "Businesses want to attract people to buy their products, but they also want to find a way to not exactly give it to them at those prices."
*** Well, not quite. But a quick skim of the ads in just about any newspaper yields plenty of examples.
 
THERE IS A TIDAL WAVE OF OPPOSITION AGAINST THE TREND!****
 Continental Airlines, for example, has blared the bold-print phrase "NO RESTRICTIONS" in ads for its Continental Lite service. And Saturn, the car company, has played up its no-haggle, no fine-print pricing policy.
Even so, Mr. Trout said that restrictions on prices as a marketing tool are probably here to stay.
"It's hard to stamp out the fine print," he said. "Somebody is always going to try to put a deal together."
**** Maybe a ripple is more accurate. State and federal regulators aside, some marketers have touted simplified prices as a way to separate themselves from the pack.

HEADLINE: States of Mind;
You Say You Want a Devolution

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR Newt Gingrich and the band around him, his words are words to live by: "We are committed to getting power back to the states, we are committed to breaking out of the logjam of Federal bureaucrats controlling how we try to help the poor, and we believe you can trust the 50 states and the 50 state legislatures to work together on behalf of the citizens of their states."
It is not government itself that is the enemy, the Speaker and his friends believe; it is central government, national government, Federal Government; if most power devolved back to the states, our problems would end. 
 Their favorite piece of the Constitution is the 10th Amendment, which provides that "The powers not delegated to the states by the Constitution, nor prohibited to the states, are reserved to the states respectively, or to the people." Classic small-government, Jeffersonian stuff, quite at odds with the Hamiltonian dictum that Congress should provide for "the general welfare."
So on Friday the new ruling class on Capitol Hill pushed through a bill that would make it much harder for Congress to issue instructions to state and local governments without providing the money to pay for them. The Republicans would like to give the states much more responsibility for welfare, hoping that other governors will emulate Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin and come up with fresh ideas.
Representative Scott Klug, a Wisconsin Republican, would do away with the kind of Federal regulations that condition Federal funds on the states' pushing the legal drinking age to 21, setting speed limits no higher than 65 and requiring the wearing of seat belts in cars and helmets on motorcycles. And his party would also like to import ideas from the state capitols to Washington, such as balanced budget laws.
 
Democracy's Labs?
 But what, one feels compelled to ask, gives the states a special connection to the people, in an era when airlines and interstate highways mean that most Americans cross state borders without thinking about it, whether to pursue their careers or to take a vacation? Are states necessarily wiser? More efficient? More frugal?
"The states," said Gov. Christine Whitman of New Jersey in response to the State of the Union message last week, "are the laboratories of democracy."
In the early days of the nation, states made some kind of geopolitical sense. Virginia was different from Pennsylvania, and Pennsylvania was different from Rhode Island. There were obvious regional similarities (South Carolina and Georgia, for example), and there were intrastate tensions (western North Carolina decided to call itself the State of Franklin for awhile), but by and large, each state did represent a kind of community, with shared interests and values.
That is much less true today. Brooklyn and rural Western New York share little beyond the Government, a currency and (up to a point) a language. The suburbs of Atlanta and the suburbs of Washington, D.C. are more similar than downtown Atlanta and suburban Cobb County. Surely it is difficult to say how California clings together, culturally or economically.
States are undeniably smaller than the nation as a whole, and therefore more flexible. Changing policy in Indiana is easier, at least theoretically, than changing it in D.C. There are innovative states (New York, California) and stick-in-the-muds (Texas, Ohio). Some state governments are close to the people, such as Vermont's where there are almost enough legislative seats for everyone, and others are not, such as Arkansas's, about whose traditions of cronyism the nation has learned so much.
But talk shows, faxes, C-Span and CNN mean that most people know a lot more about what goes on in Washington than they used to, and Washington knows more about what they think. What happens in Albany or in Jefferson City, Mo., is still more hidden from public view.
Heretical as it may sound, the Federal Government, for all its failings, attracts far more talented people than most state governments, in both elective and appointive offices. There are obvious exceptions, but most are in the big states -- people like Willie L. Brown Jr., the once and future Assembly Speaker in California, and William Weld, the brainy Republican Governor of Massachusetts.
States don't run deficits, it's true. But many would if they could. They are prevented from doing so by their constitutions, a fact that says more about the drafters of those documents than about the wisdom of modern officialdom.
Americans have always been nervous about lodging too much faith in the central government; the colonists' experiences with the English Crown set a pattern. However, the failure of the Articles of Confederation convinced them that they needed something stronger, and in the Constitution they gave the central government substantial if carefully delineated powers, such as the right to raise money.
For the Republic's first 150 years, state government maintained the predominant role, except in time of war, but the onset of the Great Depression and the New Deal that was designed to combat it, radically altered the balance. For three decades, Washington ran things, largely unchallenged by state capitals.
Largely, but not wholly. In the South, states' rights were put forward as justification for a system of apartheid that denied basic rights to black people. Strom Thurmond, now a Republican Senator, then a Democratic Governor, ran for President in 1948 as the candidate of the States Rights Party. Memories of segregation -- and of Ross Barnett in Mississippi or George Wallace in Alabama confronting the Federal Government over it -- are one reason most liberals cock a wary eye at the idea of devolving power to the states. "States' rights," for them, is encoded racism.
Since the high-water mark of Federal activism, which might be dated to the Voting Rights Act of 1964, the tide has been flowing the other way, slowly at first and now with a rush.
Richard M. Nixon's revenue-sharing program was one early effort. Increasingly, the states became regional franchises of the Federal Government. While ministering to their usual concerns like roads and insurance, and inheriting some, like education, from local governments, state governments had to play mid-level manager for programs like Medicaid.
"The current era," wrote Alice M. Rivlin, now head of the Office of Management and Budget, in her 1992 book, "Reviving the American Dream," "has been called a period of 'competitive Federalism,' meaning the Federal Government and states are competing with each other for leadership in domestic policy."
 
Clinton's Boast
 President Clinton has joined the states' cheerleaders, even though it was his party that beefed up the Federal Government in the first place. He boasted in his State of the Union speech Tuesday that "our Administration gave two dozen states the right to slash through Federal rules and regulations to reform their own welfare systems."
Yet the truth is that for all of the talk of decentralization, neither the liberals nor the conservatives wholly trust the states at least not all of them. Welfare reform is a perfect example. Conservatives are worried about giving all the responsibility to the states because they are afraid some won't reform at all. Liberals are worried that some states will reform the system out of existence.
There are other problems, too. In unbridled competition between the states, for example, what would prevent some states from cutting services and taxes to the bone to lure businesses, forcing others to do likewise and creating a downward spiral?
Which takes us right back to colonial days. The Founding Fathers were a committee, after all, and they could never quite resolve the question of how much had to be mandated from the center and how much could safely, from the perspective of the commonweal, be left to the tender mercies of the Federal States. A tough call then, a tough call now.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about efforts to put more power in the hands of states, rather than the Federal Government, rendered the 10th Amendment to the Constitution incorrectly. It states: "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states respectively, or to the people." The article also misstated the date of the passage of the Voting Rights Act. It was 1965, not 1964.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
NATURE THURSDAYS 
A Young Explorers program for children 4 through 6 will begin on Thursday from 1:30 to 2:30 P.M. and continue for two subsequent Thursdays at the Trailside Nature Museum in Cross River.
 Brenda Freeman-Bates, a naturalist at the museum, will take her charges on nature walks, tell stories and supervise craft sessions and games, all keyed to the theme of wildlife. Animal bones, rocks and fossils will be examined, and the children will have an opportunity to tap maple trees and boil the sap into syrup.
 The fee is $ 15 for the three days, and the program will vary each day. To obtain more information or to register, call 763-3993. The museum is operated by the Westchester County Parks, Recreation and Conservation Department.
ART OF 3 BOWENS
 Three members of the Bowen family will exhibit their art at the Hopper House Art Center in Nyack beginning Saturday and continuing on weekends only through Feb. 26. A reception will be held next Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.
 Eric Bowen's abstract paintings have been shown in 35 solo shows in the United States, Italy, Scandinavia and India, where he was born.
 Indian mysticism permeates his work, softening his abstractions with personalized color and texture and intensifying his preoccupation with the cause of world peace. Working in rectangles within rectangles, his paintings have sometimes been likened to shrines. He will give a gallery talk on Feb. 12 at 2 P.M.
 His wife, Mette, is a native of Norway, where she was a textile designer before turning to clay sculpture, the medium that she will be exhibiting in Nyack. His sister, Dr. Mavis Bowen, was educated in Delhi and at Columbia University. She became an artist after an auto accident in 1975, which precluded continuing her work as a traveling community health specialist and social psychiatrist. Her work in that field earned her a listing in the World Who's Who of Women. She will be showing still lifes.
 The center, at 82 North Broadway, is open on Fridays from 5 to 8 P.M., Saturdays and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. Call 358-0774 for more information.
INDUSTRIAL SKILLS
 The days when artists were confined to painting at easels, or on walls and ceilings, and sculptors worked in studios, have long been over, and Mary Ann Lomonaco, artist in residence at the Rye Art Center, is a prime example of the new breed. She knows no bounds when seeking ways to express herself.
 In learning how to work with steel, aluminum, kitchen mops and other materials, she has spent many days in the company of auto mechanics, furniture makers, hardware store owners, pizza-oven manufacturers, recycling center employees and dealers in electrical wiring, among others. The results are eminently original, smooth, sophisticated and frequently amusing.
An exhibition of her work opens tomorrow and will remain through March 25, with a reception scheduled next Sunday from 4 to 6 P.M. The center is at 51 Milton Road, and visiting hours are Mondays through Fridays from 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 1:30 to 5 P.M., Saturdays from 1 to 4 P.M. For more information, call 967-0700.
MORNING POLITICS
 Reservations must be made by Wednesday for the yearly New York State Legislators Breakfast organized by the Westchester County Association on Friday at 8 A.M. at the Tarrytown Hilton Inn on Route 9.
 All five Senators and eight Members of the Assembly for Westchester County will attend and talk about the state's $ 5 billion budget gap for 1995-96, Medicaid reform, state aid, the Clean Air Act, Gross Receipts Tax, economic prospects and incentives for the county and the restructuring of state government under the new administration.
 Some of the issues raised by Gov. George E. Pataki that will draw criticism from some and approbation from others are restoration of the death penalty, reduction of income taxes, welfare reform, privatization of some government services and term limits for elected officials.
 Seating is on a first-come-first-served basis, and the fee is $ 45 for nonmembers of the association. Questions for the legislators will be accepted with breakfast reservations. Call 948-6444.
TOMMY DORSEY'S BAND
 Tommy Dorsey's Orchestra keeps going, and going, and going -- testimony to the bandleader's posthumous popularity. A rigorous set of rules has been laid down for purchasing tickets to the orchestra's concert and dance scheduled March 25 in the Willcox Hall Gymnasium of Pace University in White Plains.
 They go on sale Wednesday and must be purchased by check or in person. No credit cards and no reserved seating. Checks for $ 14a person, $ 12 for students and people 62 and older may be mailed to Pace University, Elm Road, Dow Hall, Briarcliff, N.Y., 10510. They must be payable to Pace University's Performing Arts Series.
 To purchase tickets in person, an appointment must be made at the Performing Arts Department Mondays through Fridays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Call 923-2653 during those hours.
MORE PEEKSKILL ART
 The newest addition to Peekskill's growing list of downtown art emporiums is the Westchester Art Workshop's Peekskill Gallery at 27 North Division Street, the first and only branch of the original venue at the County Center in White Plains. A continuation of last fall's County Center exhibition may be seen in Peekskill through Feb. 17. A closing reception will be held on Feb. 16 from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M.
 Titled "Take Three: Digital Cannibals II," it features the work of Steve Bradley, Dale Leifeste and D. Dominick Lombardi, artists who work separately and jointly on computers.
 The exhibition explores art-cum-communication on a personal-to-global scale, using video, sound, digital photography, painting, mixed media, sculpture and interconnecting with other cultures by means of a fax component.
 Hours at the workshop are Mondays through Thursdays from 10 A.M. to 8:30 P.M., Fridays from 9:30 A.M. to 3:45 P.M., and Saturdays from 9:30 A.M. to 12:45 P.M. The gallery phone number is 734-4682.
LOBS AND LIFE
 There are people who have attended Bob Litwin's "Focused Game Method" seminars who will never lob a fuzzy white ball over a net but who consider tennis "a metaphor for life" and so find Mr. Litwin's talks uplifting.
 The two-time United States professional Tennis Association Player of the Year and National Champion will conduct one of his seminars on Saturday at 7 P.M. at the Armonk Tennis Club. A $ 45 advance registration fee is required and may be obtained, along with special group, team and family rates, by calling 273-8124.
 Mr. Litwin's premise is that working on any game, not only tennis, improves basic skills, technique and strategy and develops the ability to focus mind and emotions on the matter at hand. His five-step approach to upgrading performance is said by fans to be of great value in business and life as well as in sports.
LOFT'S WINTER DANCE
 The Loft's yearly winter dance will be held Saturday at 8 P.M. in the Jewish Community Center of White Plains at 255 Soundview Avenue. There will be a traditional room for dancing to the tunes spun by the disk jockey John Martin and a second room with a piano bar featuring Jim Allen. Beer and wine will be served, and free nonalcoholic beverages will be supplied to designated drivers. Admission will be $ 15, or $ 10 for members.
 The Loft, in White Plains, is a nonprofit lesbian and gay community services center, serving the Lower Hudson Valley. For more information, call 948-4922. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Travel Agencies Try the Personal Touch

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
BUYING travel today is a cinch. "In a matter of minutes, anyone plugged into the information superhighway can find the lowest air fare to anywhere and buy a ticket," said Norman S. Sherman, vice president of the Hudson Valley chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents, an industry group made up of 124 agencies. "And this has caused vast changes in the industry."
Especially among travel agencies, he emphasized, adding that only those agencies that are well-equipped to give clients personal, professional service are likely to thrive. 
 "In the new electronic world the travel agent today has to be a truly knowledgeable expert in order to survive," Mr. Sherman said. "For example, 60 new agencies in the Westchester-Mid-Hudson region were started last year, and that includes those who have new owners and those that were started from scratch, but half of them went under in less than a year mainly because their owners were people with no expertise who were attracted by what they perceived to be a glamorous business."
Mr. Sherman has first-hand knowledge. "Two years ago, after 40 successful years in the industry, my wife, Vera, and I sold our agency, Suburban Travel Center in Larchmont," he said. "One year later, what had been a $3 million business was closed. But thankfully, as part of our pre-sale agreement, we were able to take back our name, our telephone number and our accounts. Our commercial accounts are now with Rich Worldwide Travel in Harrison, a specialist in corporate accounts. And Mrs. Sherman is handling leisure travel for our old clients, who are coming back."
The new Suburban Travel office, on the second floor of a building next to their former street-level office in a small Larchmont shopping center, illustrates what Mr. Sherman says is a trend in the industry.
"Being removed from street level, we are not seeking walk-in trade," he said. "Unfortunately, it is not economically feasible to spend an hour or so discussing travel options with someone who may or may not be serious. We decided to spend the time giving more service to the good clients we already have."
And service was foremost in the minds of Patricia and Robert Watson when they established their travel agency, Watson & Watson in Scarsdale, 10 years ago.
"Our philosophy was that as in real estate, where the word for success is location, location, location, in the travel industry the word should be service, service and more service," said Mr. Watson, who formerly headed a commercial real estate concern in Manhattan.
"In defining our market, we decided to take the rifle approach, not going after the walk-in trade, but well-traveled and knowledgeable clients," Mr. Watson said. "That was because we were motivated to fill what we as consumers believed was a void in the industry. We had traveled extensively, and we thought there was a need for an agency devoted to providing custom travel services for people like us."
Financing this start-up agency with their own capital, the Watsons opened a small second-floor office in Scarsdale. "We soon learned that the travel business is not easy," Mr. Watson said. "What it was was the two of us doing everything, including hand writing all the tickets. But we worked assiduously to establish good relationships with vendors, the airlines, hotels and cruise lines. Coming from real estate, where the dollar volume of a transaction is normally in the five- or six-figure range, the commissions in the travel agency seemed minuscule. I remember thinking, I have never worked harder in my life for so little. And the first year we had a negative cash flow, but by the end of the third year, we were in the black and able to take salaries for the first time."
Two years ago, the Watsons moved into a larger office and increased their staff to eight in response to the increase in business. Their client list grew primarily through word-of-mouth recommendations, Mr. Watson said. "People appreciated the type of service we deliver," he explained. "It's extremely personal. And in order to give personal service you have to be a good listener. My wife, Pat, is especially good at hearing people correctly. And that way we get to know our clients, their likes and dislikes. And because we travel constantly ourselves, we can give them updated, on-the-spot information."
The Watsons, he said, deliberately choose destinations they believe their clients are interested in.
"Our clients are well-traveled people who like the offbeat and the exotic," he said. "We have been down the Amazon, and this month we went to Antarctica. When we are on trips, we don't announce that we are travel agents because in that way we see things as they really are."
The majority of the Watsons' clients, more than 1,000 of them, are leisure travelers. But Mr. Watson said the agency had acquired a number of corporate accounts that came to it as the result of arranging a vacation for the company's chairman or president.
"We are also getting some second-generation clients, for instance, honeymooners who are sons and daughters of clients," he said. "Repeat business is the lifeblood of this industry."
Mr. Sherman added, however, that the cost of giving clients service comes high. He said that for years the industry has been debating the question of whether or not to charge customers for service.
"It's a very sensitive subject," he said. "For good customers, I know that we will never impose a service charge nor would most agencies. But when people come in and take a lot of time asking for information, a service fee may be a future option."
And despite an increase in leisure travel this season, Mr. Sherman said, the average travel agent is not earning any more money.
"There is a lot of wasted motion in the business today," he said. "An agent, for example, will issue a ticket to a client going to Florida, and the next day the airline drops the price. What happens is the agent is obliged to rewrite the ticket. Fares have become a nightmare."
Fares on cruise ships, though, are an exception, Mr. Sherman said, adding: "Cruises are a best buy in travel. What happened is that so many cruise ships came on line at the end of the 80's, which coincided with the height of the recession, that there is an oversupply. Even the best ships are offering heavy discounts."
An agency that specializes in charter and theme cruises is Custom Cruises of Mamaroneck. Angela Sculti, the president, said: "Our business is very good. Values are terrific. There is literally a cruise for everyone."
As people become more sophisticated about travel, Ms. Sculti said, cruise lines have begun to provide a variety of special-interest cruises. "By offering the right product to the right client, they have carved out a big new niche in the travel industry," she said. "There are literary cruises with discussion groups and lecturers, historical cruises with college professors, health and fitness cruises, and we designed a 'Fun and Fitness at Sea' three-day Bahamas cruise aboard Carnival Cruise Line's Ecstasy in conjunction with Prevention magazine that features spa, cuisine and a package of health and fitness programs. Two hundred and fifty people signed up for it."
Among future theme cruises, Ms. Sculti said, are a country-western cruise in April on Norweigan Cruise Lines' Norway and a cigar-lovers cruise on Holland America Line's Ryndam. "That is scheduled for November and already interest is high," Ms. Sculti said. "It includes a very interesting land itinerary."

HEADLINE: Catastrophe? It Can't Possibly Happen Here

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
YOU would think that with the horrific rash of catastrophes -- devastating earthquakes in Kobe, Japan, and in Los Angeles, just to name two -- most companies would be signing up for disaster contingency plans.
But despite recent scenes of devastation straight out of a World War II newsreel, the big temblor in Kobe is expected to add only 5 percent to the growth of the disaster recovery business. 
 Management remains cavalier about emergency plans, says Wilson Haddow, an industry analyst for Input, a market research firm in Mountain View, Calif., the same way some homeowners don't buy property insurance. "It's human nature to think it won't happen to me."
"There are a lot of risk takers out there," contends John E. Nevola, manager of the International Business Machines' disaster recovery service, an industry leader. Fewer than 10 percent of an estimated 300,000 companies in North America that rely on computers for manufacturing or customer services buy this type of business insurance. "The rest are in some stage of denial."
In fact, disaster recovery planning amounts to less than 1 percent of the $152 billion spent last year on software and services, says Mr. Haddow.
About 60 percent of the companies that do have contingency plans are financial services companies, which are required by law to carry such insurance. Federal regulators began requiring banks to assess their vulnerability to disruptions in 1984, and only since 1986 have Federally insured institutions been required to develop and test disaster recovery plans. The same rules were applied the next year to companies making money transfers electronically. Today, medical-support companies -- which provide such data as patient records and billing to hospitals -- are the disaster-recovery industry's second-fastest-growing sector.
Disaster recovery specialists generally help banks and other businesses cope with man-made mishaps like an ammonia spill or a fire. More than 80 percent of business disasters are man-made.
The industry's three leaders -- Comdisco, Sungard Recovery Services and I.B.M. -- account for 65 percent of the $850 million domestic disaster recovery business, says Mr. Haddow. Hardware makers like the Hewlett Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation account for most of the rest. It is, of course, not surprising that major computer companies are big players in this industry. I.B.M. has been offering disaster recovery services to its customers since the late 1960's.
The cost for a small business with a network of 25 computer stations can be as little as $1,000 a month, which will, in the event of a calamity, pay for desk space and the use of a mid-range computer and 25 terminals and a phone system at a recovery site. Fees can exceed $100,000 a month for a big computer user that needs its data continuously mirrored at a remote location; in the event of an emergency the company can shift to a backup computer source at the flip of a switch. The service is becoming cheaper as prices for computers continue to fall, says Michael Tobin, Comdisco's vice president for marketing development.

ONCE upon a time, a disaster recovery service would provide a client whose facilities have been destroyed with backup mainframe computers and tape storage at a secure "hot site." Nowadays, disaster-proofing services will provide construction crews and employee relocation strategies.
Driving the change is the proliferation of computer technology, which puts even the smallest business -- from an equipment leasing company to a law office -- at risk because of its reliance on information that cannot be reproduced by hand.
"A stricken business lacking contingency planning has an excellent chance of dying," says Frederick B. Joy, a research analyst for META Group, a market research company in Stamford, Conn.
Although many companies seem unwilling to adopt disaster recovery protection, the recovery industry's growth is being fueled by the fall in computer prices. During the recent recession, many large companies shrank their global computing centers to fewer sites. They also distributed networks of desk-top machines in far-flung locations.
Computer networks make disaster recovery planning more complex, says Michael F. Mulholland, president of Sungard. Companies with critical networks -- like a catalogue company's order-fulfillment line -- need multiple contingency plans, he adds.
Computer minitiaturization has also added a new twist. Previously, recovery centers fell into two categories. "Cold sites" were empty rooms where computers can be shipped when the need arises. "Hot sites" are equipped with an array of powerful mainframe computers and telecommunications equipment. These days, a powerful mid-range system, which does not require the controlled environment of a mainframe, can be rolled to the doorstep of a destroyed business.
Sungard, for example, has a fleet of a dozen 18-wheel trucks. After the Northridge quake, it dispatched a rolling computer center to its client, the North Los Angeles County Regional Center, situated four miles east of the quake's epicenter. The agency provides job and welfare assistance to 7,200 developmentally disabled people, but cracked support beams made the building unsafe for agency staff.
Four days after the quake, from a data center in a parking lot, the agency turned out 2,800 checks worth $1.3 million to local caregivers. They were one day late.
"I wouldn't have had the same cooperation from employees if I had told them they had to go to Santa Ana," says Robert J. Michael, the center's information systems manager, referring to the location of Sungard's nearest hot site.
Some companies devise internal recovery plans that relocate workers to unaffected satellite offices or set up reciprocal arrangements with other companies. There could be drawbacks to such plans, says William Buscaglia, whose New York Design Collaborative has mapped corporate emergency strategies for more than a decade.
THE alternate site might not have enough parking space or, in a high rise, enough fresh air. Air flow in sealed high rises is set for a specific occupancy level. Without a secondary air source, overheating can create health problems for doubled-up workers, he says.
A.B.N. Amro North America Inc., the Chicago bank holding company, which processes $2 billion daily for customers, has had to scramble to avert a number of business melt
 Rebuilding Kobe will bolster economic activity in Asia.
World Markets, page 11.

downs. First in Chicago in 1992 after an underground tunnel flood and then in Florida in the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew in 1993. Harrison T. Tempest, the company's chairman, then realized that his 9,000 employees needed a backup plan every bit as much as the company's data center.
Last year, A.B.N. Amro began a thorough risk analysis, says John H. Collins, the executive vice president. It placed a price tag on each department, with the tally reflecting the cost of its going dark for three days, and also devised a relocation strategy for emergencies.
A typical recovery plan calls for a business to ship its computer data to a center distant enough to keep clear of whatever regional mayhem has affected its offices. "The flaw is that the information is not instantaneous or always up to date," says Mr. Nevola of I.B.M.
At I.B.M.'s hot site in Gaithersburg, Md. -- I.B.M. has 17 such sites worldwide -- there is enough horsepower to allow real time backup for some of the largest computer users. Among the clients, says Mr. Nevola, is a utility company that has an emergency system for dispatching crews, monitoring repairs and power sources.
I.B.M. entered the disaster recovery business in 1989 at the urging of its customers. Big Blue's vast resources have helped redefine the industry's boundaries. For Synergistics Systems -- a hospital billing company and an I.B.M. disaster recovery client near Northridge -- Big Blue rebuilt its data center as well as its ceiling, roof and walls.
"Customers who need that service are afraid of unscrupulous contractors," says Mr. Nevola. "Business recovery is more than just providing equipment. It demands consulting, education, risk management, anti-virus and network management."
For its part, Texas Instruments, the Dallas-based company, discovered how disaster planning and a little luck averted millions of dollars in lost sales after the Kobe quake.
In a masterful display of high-tech hot-wiring, a team of Texas Instruments' technical experts restored one of the company's primary sources of computer memory chips only a week after the quake struck. The 400 employees of Texas Instruments' Kobe plant -- a joint venture with Kobe Steel -- resumed production last Tuesday.
The seven-member rescue team was drawn from Dallas and a manufacturing site in Taipei. Their target, the stilled plant controlled by Kobe Steel's damaged computer center, had no disaster backup. Fortunately, Texas Instrument does. It relies on I.B.M. to provide hot site backup for its four global computer centers, one of which is in Mijo, 300 miles from Kobe. The rescue team drew on a computer recovery script for Texas Instruments own computer centers, one that had taken months to refine.
Working from 2,500 backup computer tapes retrieved from the ruined Kobe Steel data center, the team rewrote the script and restored the plant's manufacturing specifications on a spare Mijo mainframe. The Mijo mainframe, in good working order, had been unplugged only four weeks before when a newer model had been installed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael J. Tobin, a vice president of Comdisco. (Mary Beth Meehan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nordstrom Looking for 800 to Fill Jobs

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
EIGHT HUNDRED jobs, available to Westchester residents, have become available. The employer is Nordstrom, which plans to fill the 800 positions locally for its new store in the Westchester Mall in White Plains. The store is to open on March 17.
"At Nordstrom we feel it is important to support the communities in which our stores are located by recruiting locally as much as possible," said Cody Kondo, Nordstrom vice president and general manager for the Northeast region. "We are looking for goal-oriented people with a 'can do' attitude to be part of the Nordstrom team." 
 The company, Mr. Kondo said, believes strongly in a "promote from within" philosophy and plans to fill management positions from the ranks of its stores in the Northeast.
Nordstrom, one of the country's leading fashion-specialty retailers, has 77 stores in 14 states, 3 in the Northeast. The Westchester store of 225,000 square feet will be the company's first in New York State.
Mayor Sy Schulman of White Plains, said: "I think Nordstrom will give the local economy a welcome shot in the arm. They are a very service-oriented company who believe personal contact is important. They encourage their employees to be entrepreneurial and move ahead and give them the opportunity to do so. What's more, they will be paying taxes, buying supplies and goods here, which will benefit even a larger part of the county."
The Nordstrom Westchester store is holding a series of employment fairs. An informational seminar and interviews for sales positions will be held from Feb. 6 through Feb. 11 at the Crowne Plaza Hotel, 66 Hale Avenue in White Plains. The employment fair is open to the public. For information, prospective applicants can call Nordstrom's employment service line, (800) 899-8966.
"Those attending will have an opportunity to learn about career paths, company benefits and policies and position openings," Mr. Kondo said. "Representatives from our personnel and human resources offices will be on hand to give out applications, meet applicants and answer questions."
Nordstrom, he reported, was named in the book "The 100 Best Companies to Work For in America in 1993" by Robert Levering and Milton Moskowitz. PENNY SINGER
