HEADLINE: Once-Booming Horse-Breeding Industry Falls on Hard Times

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
NEW tax laws and tougher breeding restrictions have forced many horse breeders out of the business in the last decade, leaving few horse farms on the Island.
In recent years, a difficult economy, along with rising property taxes and increased farm expenses, have added to the gloom. 
 Today, with looser requirements on what is classified as a New York-bred horse, the New York thoroughbred breeders are trying to take charge of their destiny.
By showcasing New York horses and obtaining money to encourage New York breeding, they hope to revitalize the industry, which on Long Island dates from more than 100 years ago.
The Long Island representative for the New York State Breeding and Development Fund, George Carey, said the focus of the business had changed from quantity to quality. Today most people are looking for horses with either proven records or proven bloodlines, he said.
Since the 1980's, when horse farms thrived on the Island, most of the larger farms have slimmed down. The Entenmann family, which sold its bakery business in 1980, owned two of the largest, the Big E in Jamesport and Timber Bay in Old Westbury. But the family has sold much of the land from each farm.
Although the two farms remain active, they operate on a much smaller scale than a decade ago.
"The horse industry has coincided with the economy," Mr. Carey said. "Coming off the highs of the 80's, it backed off in the early 90's. And now we're seeing a stabilization."
Many breeders have left Long Island because of high property taxes and increasing labor costs, according to the president of the New York Thoroughbred Breeders, Dr. Douglas Koch.
"Breeding is an expensive business," said Dr. Koch, a veterinarian. "But a horse is a fixed cost. It doesn't cost any more in New York than in Kentucky. It's property taxes and labor that are the two factors making it so difficult to have breeding operations on Long Island. That's why most breeding is done in the Hudson Valley, the Genesee Valley and the Saratoga region, where the cost of land is much lower."
The Big E, on 130 acres in Jamesport, has scaled down, from 150 to 200 horses in the mid-80's to an average of 35 to 40, the manager, Jeffrey Raine, said. The farm, once a public breeding and boarding business, is now private, breeding horses exclusively for the Entenmann stable.
At the Manor, a 50-acre farm in Manorville, the number of horses has also decreased significantly, to 40 horses, said the farm veterinarian, Dr. Jud Butler.
"It's a tough business," Dr. Butler said. "When the economy is down one of the first things to suffer is the horse business, because it's a luxury, and it can be very expensive to breed horses. People used to be able to deduct their expenses. But they can't do that anymore, which makes it an even tougher business. Over the last few years I've seen many horse farms go out of business."
In Nassau County, Penmor Farm, on 88 acres in Muttontown, had 140 horses at its peak in the early 80's, the manager, Sharon McCaig, said. Today the farm has 20. Ms. McCaig saidthat the owner, Moreton Binn, had moved most of the horses to Kentucky, Florida and France.
"There are few good stallions left in New York," she said. "Most breeders have gone to Kentucky, where there are the best stallions, the best grass, and where it's more economical to farm them because land and labor are less expensive."
On 28 acres in Upper Brookville, the Pinebournefarm is one of the few horse farms remaining active in Nassau. It has 31 horses, including 6 mares in foal.
Frank Nastasi, who owns the farm with his wife, Denise, said many people had left the business because land values had risen so much that selling the farms for subdivision and development was more profitable than raising horses.
Horse farms require about two acres a horse, to rotate paddocks and prevent grass from dying, Mr. Nastasi said. Raising a horse cost $15,000 to $20,000 a year, he said. After a horse goes to a trainer, he said, the sum soars, to $30,000 or $40,000.
"When they named horse racing the Sport of Kings, they were right," he said. "Unfortunately, too many people who got into the industry were more interested in making money than in careful breeding, and they turned the industry into a disaster."
Traditionally, one-year-old thoroughbreds, known as yearlings, are broken and start training in the fall. They remain on the farm until the spring of their second year when they go to the track.
Long Island horses usually start racing at the tracks of the New York Racing Association, which are Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga. Among the best-known Long Island horses are Bold Reason from the Gold Mills Farm, now known as Samantha Farm, and Twixt, who was farmed at Timber Bay.
Troubles in the horse-breeding industry also affected the polo-horse farms, said Allyn Ehrlich, president of Polo International Farms, which has 10 polo horses on a farm in Glen Head. Horses raised for polo are often thoroughbreds that have been rejected for racing, he said, adding:
"We're dependent on the horse breeders. When the horse-breeding industry suffers, there is a smaller field for us to choose from. And at the same time this raises our prices."
The decline of the industry stems from changes in tax laws. According to Andrew Tarquinio, senior tax manager in the Grant Thornton office in Melville, the Federal Government in 1977 said a breeder had to show a profit for two out of seven years to deduct any losses. Any less frequent profit would be a hobby loss.
The tax law of 1986 included other provisions that also hurt investors, Mr. Tarquinio added. Passive Loss Rules suspended deductions on any losses for an investor who was a passive member of a partnership, until the horse or the interest in the partnership was sold.
Another provision eliminated the deduction of preproductive expenses, or breeding expenses before a horse could provide income. The tax law of 1988 reversed that, but it still hurt the horse business, Mr. Tarquinio said.
Restrictions on breeders also hurt, said Dr. Koch. In the late 70's, New York started a statewide program to encourage the use of undeveloped land for horse farming. The state offered incentives to breeders.
The Breeding and Development Fund, created in 1973, sponsored state-registered races at Belmont and Aqueduct with larger purses for New York-bred horses. It also started a subsidy program for breeders who raced and won at local tracks.
But a mandatory breed-back law required breeders to use just New York sires in order to qualify. Dr. Koch said that was a drawback, because the best stallions were in Kentucky.
The state reversed the law in July, qualifying horses as New York bred based on breeding back or the residency of the mare. That allows horses to leave the state to be bred, as long as their residence remains here, adding flexibility for the breeder, Dr. Koch said.
"People are hoping that this relaxation of restrictions will bring breeding back to New York," he said. "This is the first breeding season that will be affected by the reversal. So it's too early to tell what the impact will be. But we've already seen signs of more mares' coming to New York and this is renewed hope for New York breeders."
Dr. Koch added that to stimulate the industry, the New York Thoroughbred Breeders created a New York Showcase Day at Belmont State Park and showcases New York bred horses. The breeders also are working to increase financing for the Thoroughbred Breeding and Development Fund, to make it more attractive to breed New York thoroughbreds, and working with the New York Racing Association to increase attendance.
"If we can get New York racing on the right track," he said, "that will help the breeding program."
There has been recent evidence of a turnaround in the market, Mr. Raine said, adding:
"Prices are up on the sales of horses, which is a good sign. Allowing New York breeders to breed with stallions in Kentucky and raise the horses here will improve the quality of New York breeding, and hopefully, will revitalize the industry. But it will probably be two to three years before we'll see the fruits of the labor."
"Getting Kentucky blood means a lot to the New York breeding program," Ms. McCaig added. "It won't happen overnight, but we horse people are diehards. For us this is a labor of love, and it will be very hard to kill us."

HEADLINE: Getting Real

BYLINE: By Andrew Delbanco; Andrew Delbanco teaches English at Columbia University. His next book will be "The Death of Satan: How Americans Have Lost the Sense of Evil."

 BODY:

FACING FACTS
Realism in American Thought
and Culture, 1850-1920.
By David E. Shi.
Illustrated. 394 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $35. 
THE word "reality," Vladimir Nabokov once wrote, is "one of the few words which means nothing without quotes." Surely the same is true of "realism" -- a word that seems to exist mainly to give writers and critics something to squabble about. At first, when pioneers like William Dean Howells and Stephen Crane (under the influence of European novelists like Balzac and Zola) set out to banish sentiment and prudishness from the American novel, the realist agenda seemed clear: it was "the business of the novel," as Howells put it in a 1894 interview with Crane, "to picture the daily life in the most exact terms possible." But anyone who spends a little time with these writers, or with Henry James and Theodore Dreiser, or with lesser-known figures like John W. De Forest and E. W. Howe, quickly discovers that there was little agreement about what constituted daily life, or about what kind of representation met the standard of exactness.
In "Facing Facts: Realism in American Thought and Culture, 1850-1920," David E. Shi takes up the problem of what the realists meant by the real. Mr. Shi, the president of Furman University in Greenville, S.C., recognizes that whatever realism meant to its practitioners, the term was highly elastic. For Ambrose Bierce, realism was "the art of depicting nature as it is seen by toads." For Henry James, it was fiction that is "bravely and richly, and continuously psychological." Mark Twain -- arguably the first major American writer to try to catch accurately a regional dialect -- never used the label "realism." And most writers, then as now, showed little interest in their putative membership in any school: the New England story writer Mary Wilkins Freeman remarked in the 1890's that "I didn't even know I was a realist" until critics "wrote and told me."
Yet Mr. Shi is determined to find common ground. Surveying not just writers and critics but also painters, photographers and furniture makers, he brings shared commitments into view: a broadening of the issues (divorce, poverty, prostitution) and social classes (factory workers, the unemployed) that could be legitimately addressed by respectable novelists, and an antipathy to ornament (in the architecture of John W. Root and Louis Sullivan) and decoration (in the furniture of Gustav Stickley) as distractions from the plain truth of functional form.
In his zeal for inclusion, Mr. Shi even counts certain poets among the progenitors of the realist school -- such as Walt Whitman, who, having witnessed the lopping off of gangrenous limbs in the Civil War hospitals, lamented that the "real war will never get into the books." Mr. Shi declares that the publication of "Leaves of Grass" (1855) -- in which Whitman proclaimed "the scent of these arm-pits" to be an "aroma finer than prayer" -- had "monumental results for American literary history." Whitman, he says, was "the ferry linking antebellum romanticism to late 19th-century realism."
But what exactly did Whitman carry and to whom? Whitman was certainly a pioneer in introducing sexual candor into American writing. Yet there is precious little body odor in the work of Howells or of Sarah Orne Jewett (one of the leading "local color" realists) or of Henry James, who was perhaps the greatest realist in our history in the sense of having perfected the capacities of the novel to transcribe the intricate modulations of consciousness.
It is certainly true that in these years the quotidian rather than the exceptional became the stuff of literature. (One writer complained that Howells had turned fiction into "the drama of a broken teacup, the tragedy of a walk down the block.") And it is also true that changing social conditions -- the influx of immigrants and the migration from farms to factories -- seemed to make obsolete the old literary picture of a hardy, rural American stock. But it is also true that any adequate concept of realism has to cut deeper than surface changes in American life. It has to acknowledge that realism was more than new topics, new idioms and new candor.
At the heart of the new temperament -- as Mr. Shi suggests in a key section of his book, entitled "Pragmatic Realism" -- was the proposition (encouraged by science generally and Darwinism in particular) that there lay beneath appearances no transcendent meaning, no meaning that exists independently from acts of perception and interpretation. It is, for instance, one of the paradoxes of realism that the invention of photography -- a medium that seemed intrinsically realistic -- appeared at first to be a kind of miracle of objectivity, a way to capture truth on metal or glass or paper where light itself inscribed reality without any human tampering. (Mr. Shi quotes one visitor to an early picture gallery exclaiming that "it is impossible for photography to lie.") But in time, it became clear that photographs themselves -- no more or less than other media -- were interpretable, and that the photographer, even more than practitioners of words or paint, was compelled to regard the world from a fixed point of view.
So realism was less about objectivity than about the inevitability of perspective. In a typically brilliant exposition, the philosopher William James explained the attraction of what he called the "fallacy" that reality, or truth, has an existence independent of the human perceiver. In making the point, James employs Nabokovian quotation marks:
"In the case of 'wealth,' we all see the fallacy. We know that wealth is but a name for concrete processes that certain men's lives play a part in, and not a natural excellence found in Messrs. Rockefeller and Carnegie, but not in the rest of us.
"Like wealth, health also lives in rebus. It is a name for processes, as digestion, circulation, sleep, etc., that go on happily, tho in this instance we are more inclined to think of it as a principle and to say the man digests and sleeps so well because he is so healthy."
But, James explains, "all these words" -- health, wealth, truth -- "in th are exactly similar. Truth exists ante rem as much and as little as the other things do."
Truth, or reality, in other words, is to be found in what James called "the relations perceived" between facts -- not in the facts themselves. Meanings are to be made, not found. They are imposed on concrete facts; they do not inhere in them.
According to this kind of pragmatic realism, the mind "engenders truth upon reality.""Our minds are not here," James insisted, "simply to copy a reality that is already complete. They are here to complete it, to add to its importance by their own remodeling of it." This was the principle (though it was rarely raised to this level of philosophical articulation) that lay at the heart of the realist movement.
AND it was this conviction that accounts for the reformist impulse evident in most of the significant works of American realism, from John W. De Forest's novel of the Civil War, "Miss Ravenel's Conversion From Secession to Loyalty" (1867), to Norman Mailer's novel of World War II, "The Naked and the Dead" (1948). Although these realists held a range of political commitments, and included some whose world remained very much circumscribed, they were, by and large, writers who broke open literary conventions in order to bring into view aspects of life with which most American readers and viewers had previously had no relation at all.
By representing the poor or the disfranchised or the exploited, writers like Howells and Dreiser and, later, James T. Farrell and Richard Wright, created a relation that had not previously existed: a relation between middle-class readers and the world beyond their immediate experience. "Nothing is so hard," Howells's character Basil March says in "Their Wedding Journey" (1872) -- a genteel novel about a couple on honeymoon that critics tend to dismiss today as tame and provincial -- "as to understand that there are human beings in this world besides one's self and one's set."
One could do worse than choose this statement as the motto of the whole realist movement. Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of Mr. Shi's timely reminder of this pragmatist faith in the transforming power of representation is how alien it feels in our own day, when relations between distinct groups within American society are weakening, and when the hope of changing the world by reimagining it is diminishing. One closes Mr. Shi's book with a sense of gratitude for writers who once tried to restore and sustain these relations and that hope.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 2; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 602 words

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY

 BODY:

Brooklyn's Shrub
 Q. I recently stumbled across the fact that the forsythia is the official botanic emblem of Brooklyn. How did it come to be that it's not a tree? 
 A. True, forsythia is a shrub, not a tree. And one might expect Brooklyn's borough-sanctioned arbor to be the ailanthus of "A Tree Grows in" fame. But files from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden tell a different story. In 1940, Florence Abraham Blum, the wife of the president of the Abraham & Straus department store and a member of the garden's ladies auxiliary, led an effort to beautify the borough. She persuaded the Borough President, John Cashmore, to anoint the forsythia as Brooklyn's official bloom. Borough residents were urged to plant the shrub in their frontyards from the Heights to Coney Island to inspire brotherhood, unity and understanding.
Mrs. Blum also began a Forsythia Day (still celebrated each April) and crowned a Forsythia Queen. The Hotel Granada, which opened in 1946 at Ashland Place and Lafayette Avenue in Fort Greene, named its dining room the Forsythia Room.
Starting in 1954, the garden bestowed a Forsythia Award for civic leadership, in honor of Mrs. Blum, who died in 1959. The award is still given annually to someone selected by borough officials and Botanic Garden members.
 
 
Books on the Move
 Q. How does the New York Public Library move books from one branch to another? Does a fleet of anonymous vans shuttle books around the city?
 A. "Yes, basically," said a spokeswoman for the New York Public Library, which serves Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. The system has five unmarked trucks that carry books, interoffice mail, videotapes and internal publications among its 82 branches. It also has four nonlending research libraries.
The city has two other library systems, and both use plainly marked vans to carry books. The Brooklyn Public Library uses an "interchange system" of four trucks that travel four routes among the central depository at Grand Army Plaza, 58 branches and the city's only bookmobile. Three vans make their way among the Queensborough Public Library's Central Library on Merrick Boulevard in Jamaica and 62 branches.
 
 
Orphan Building
 Q. There is a building on the northeast corner of West 57th Street and 10th Avenue that has never been completed. It is approximately 35 stories tall, and it has been about three years since any work was done on it. Is it on the market?
 A. Vahe Tiryakian, director of public affairs at the Department of Buildings, used the building, whose address is 475 West 57th Street, to explain that the city does not set a deadline for completion of construction on any building. To do so, he said, would be impossible "because of the complexity of the city."
"It would not encourage a healthy economy," Mr. Tiryakian said. "Besides the industry is not dilatory. After all, time is money."
But the good news is that the building is about to be reactivated. In a deal not yet completed, plans call for it to be used to house low-income residents, mainly from the entertainment industry, starting early next year.
It is a project of the Actors Fund of America, a national nonprofit social services organization that has hired a management company, Housing and Services Inc. of Manhattan, to manage the property. Housing and Services records show that the deed is currently in escrow, and the negotiations are still delicate, said Joseph P. Benincasa, the fund's general manager. He said the previous developer had "run out of money." He would not disclose the developer's name. ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: Germany's Telephone Pie Is Just Too Big to Pass Up

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 25

 BODY:
With Germany's telephone service scheduled for deregulation by 1998, almost everyone who is anyone in telecommunications wants a piece of the German information superhighway these days.
So far this month, the BellSouth Corporation said it was forming a partnership with Thyssen, the German steel company, to compete against Deutsche Telekom, the state monopoly. Northern Telecom has teamed up with Daimler-Benz Aerospace. British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced a joint venture with the German utility Viag A.G. to provide voice and data transmission to corporations. And Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain is joining forces with Veba A.G., another German electric utility, on a telephone joint venture. 
 [Veba announced Thursday that it would acquire up to 10.5 percent of Cable and Wireless for about $1.5 billion as part of the deal.]
The basic strategy is for foreign telecommunications companies to ally themselves with big German partners who can offer assets plus access to customers in Germany, while the foreign partner provides the technology and operating skill.
"All the major players are looking at Germany now," said Hans Peter Peters, managing director of Morgan Stanley's office in Frankfurt. "The rush is on to see who will get a joint venture going first and then hope that the German Government will give them a license to set up a telephone system."
The race in Germany reflects growing competition throughout the Continent, where European Union rules have mandated that all telephone business will be deregulated as of the beginning of 1998. This will also open more big markets in France, Italy and Spain to outside competition.
Indeed, analysts say telecommunications is the most profitable industrial area in Europe, generating profit estimated as high as $30 a telephone line each year.
There are good reasons for the rush of interest in Germany, which offers the world's third-largest market for telecommunications, after those in the United States and Japan. What is now a $40 billion annual business will grow to almost $70 billion in eight years, according to industry and analysts' projections. And while the overall German market is growing by 7 percent a year, annual growth in what was East Germany has reached 26 percent.
As a telecommunications market, Germany can be seen as underdeveloped. Deutsche Telekom has lagged behind its free-market counterparts in Britain and the United States by as much as eight years, according to some analysts. This has left a big technology gap waiting to be filled in the largest economy in Western Europe.
The German Government has announced it will award licenses for a number of mobile telephone systems, in addition to four that now exist. And beginning in 1998, or possibly sooner, the Government will lift Deutsche Telekom's monopoly on consumer telephone service, throwing the field open to competition.
More than a dozen joint ventures have been formed in Germany, with planned investment of more than $12 billion over the next few years.
The American giants include MCI Communications, Sprint and some regional telephone companies. AT&T and GTE, two of the largest American telephone giants, have been silent so far, but appear certain to enter the market. AT&T is said by industry officials to be negotiating with Veba.
The most actively sought partners have been Germany's giant utilities. This is because companies like Veba, Viag and RWE, which own the country's three largest electric utilities, have installed vast electrical-distribution grids that can be used to carry fiber optic cable into millions of German homes.
"Basically, the utilities will be the big beneficiaries over the next few years," said Bernd Janssen, an analyst with the Union Bank of Switzerland here. "They have all the cables currently in place, so their cost is greatly reduced. Moreover, they have experience dealing with consumers and big businesses, and they are used to the investing dynamics of telecommunications, spending large amounts of money and waiting a long time for the return."
Veba, through its Vebacom subsidiary, has formed seven separate telecommunications ventures. It owns 28 percent of the E-plus mobile phone system in Germany with BellSouth, Thyssen and Vodafone of Britain. It also owns Meganet, a private networking and data system and is part of the Teleport Europe satellite system. Veba has 10 percent of Iridium's world satellite system set up by Motorola, cable television interests and a 15 percent stake in another company that will offer a mobile phone system in France. Finally, it has started a project with Deutsche Bundesbahn, the German national railroad, to lay fiber optic cable using the railway system.
RWE has the largest corporate client base because it operates in the heavily industrialized Ruhr and Rhine Valley regions. It has teamed up with Mannesmann and Deutsche Bank with the aim of providing corporate network communications. It also owns 40 percent of Teleport Europe and has a license to operate a mobile phone system.
Viag, a latecomer that announced plans to team up with British Telecom last week, will use not only its Bavarian customer base, but also more than 2,400 miles of high-power transmission lines around the country.
These upstarts in telecommunications will be facing Deutsche Telekom, which has teamed up with France Telecom and Sprint in a venture that could create one of the world's largest telecommunications networks.
While much of the interest has focused on the end of 1997, when Deutsche Telekom loses its monopoly on consumer voice service, the more immediate prize is the license to offer corporate network telecommunications, which are not under monopoly control, through a cellular phone system. Once businesses are operating a corporate network, analysts say, they may find a legal way to get around the existing ban on offering consumer service.
But the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, which has generally embraced privatization and open markets, has hinted that it might end Deutsche Telekom's monopoly sooner.
Analysts predict that Deutsche Telekom will be preoccupied with trimming as many as 30,000 employees, improving its technology and preparing for its own privatization. Next year, the Government plans to sell as much as $10 billion in Deutsche Telekom stock, with another sale of an equal amount in 1997 or 1998.
All this should give competitors breathing space in the market.
"Prices to consumers are quite high in Germany," said a telecommunications analyst in London, who asked not to be identified. He added: "And Deutsche Telekom's costs from investments and excessive employment are so high that it has little room for bringing them down. That means any entrants will find they will not get in big price wars and their return on investment will be faster."
Still the race may be won by the leanest contender, and if the telecommunications market opens early, Deutsche Telekom might not be ready to compete. Its rotary dialing technology is a source of German jokes, and the company still cannot itemize long-distance charges.
But the Government, while moving toward faster deregulation, has also sent conflicting signals about how much it will stay involved in Deutsche Telekom.
Of 10 new directors recently named to the company's board by the Government, half were political appointees. The resignation of Deutsche Telekom's chief executive, Helmut Ricke, three days later caused rumors that he was fed up with political meddling, particularly by the Minister of Postal Services and Telecommunications, Wolfgang Botsch. The new directors appointed to the Deutsche Telekom board included Gerhard O. Pfeffermann, the Government bureaucrat in charge of awarding new mobile telephone licenses to Deutsche Telekom's competitors.
Yet, would-be investors have not been deterred.
"This is a market you have to be involved with," Mr. Peters said. "It's too big to stay away."

HEADLINE: Aid for Mexico Loses Backing In Both Parties

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
When President Clinton decided earlier this month that the United States urgently needed to bail out Mexico from a deepening financial crisis, he argued that his primary purpose was to save the jobs of hundreds of thousands of Americans who labor to produce exports to America's third-largest trading partner.
But after two weeks of public hearings and behind-the-scenes arm-twisting, leaders of both parties are declaring Mr. Clinton's proposal all but dead in its present form, even though estimates of the number of American jobs at risk are growing. [Page D4.] 
 It is not that they doubt the seriousness of the problem, they insist, or question that the American economy will suffer if Mexico's problems are ignored. Instead, Democrats and Republicans alike say they are unconvinced that the $40 billion package of loan guarantees will actually save many jobs on Main Street. And they are more certain than ever, they say, that the package will bail out Wall Street investors who staked billions on the certainty that Mexico was a sure thing.
This is hardly the first time a President has been caught in the maw of a Main Street-Wall Street argument, or forced to argue that the only way to help out workers making $7 an hour was to first help out bondholders who measure their monthly winnings or losings by the millions. But it is the first time in the post-cold war era that the White House has made a case that failure to intervene in the financial markets would result in an imminent national security threat only to be met with a bipartisan wall of resistance.
The underlying concern was articulated most clearly last week by Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who under ordinary circumstances might be expected to support her party's President, especially on a plan ostensibly intended to keep Mexico prosperous enough that its workers would not seek better pay across the border.
"I know no one in the financial community who is against this," Senator Feinstein, her voice rising in anger, said to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Secretary of State Warren Christopher at a Senate hearing last week. "I know no one in my constituency who is for it. There is no support."
That theme resounded all last week in Washington, leading the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, to backpedal from their earlier pledges to help President Clinton push the package through.
Today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, expressed doubts about whether failure to help Mexico would be as big a disaster as Mr. Clinton had argued.
"The other thing that is a big question is who gets bailed out," he said. "Are we bailing out Wall Street bankers, or are we bailing out pension funds that affect the American workers? Who's getting saved here, and are they taking their part of the loss because they have gone into high-yield, high-risk investments? That's a big question."
No one really knows the answer to Mr. Nunn's questions. But it is assumed that the $15 billion or so of Mexican short-term bonds in American hands are held by everyone from millionaires to pension funds to the mutual funds that invested heavily in Mexico and Latin America. Perhaps with that in mind, Mr. Nunn did not dismiss the possibility that Congress would eventually come to Mexico's aid in some form.
Appearing on the same program, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, one of the states with the most to lose from a deepened crisis in Mexico, joined a growing number of Republicans who have parted with their own leaders and dismissed the President's plan outright.
"Any country banker would laugh at the proposal the President has made to guarantee that we get our money back, that we get the interest back, and that we have viable collateral," he said. "There is a crisis, but losing $40 billion of money we don't have is not going to make me feel better about it."
Mexican leaders helped create the crisis by issuing far too many short-term bonds, known as tesobonos, to cover the country's long-term debts. The strategy worked as long as there was a ready supply of foreign capital flowing in to buy new notes when the old ones came due, allowing Mexico to roll over its debts. In 1992 and 1993, Mexico's financial reports show, so much money poured into Mexico that the country had to buy dollars on the foreign exchange market to keep the peso from becoming too strong. By early last year, it had $25 billion in the bank.
But investors grew wary last year, and overseas investment began to slow. With a presidential election coming, the Mexican Government could not stop borrowing, lest it destroy the illusion of an ever-growing economy. So it drew down its huge dollar accounts to keep the peso -- and with it Mexico's self-image -- strong.
"Mexican authorities evidently believed or fervently hoped that the reduction in foreign investor interest was temporary," Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said last week. "If so, they were tragically mistaken." When the truth could no longer be hidden, they devalued the peso and then were forced to let it float, touching off the international equivalent of a bank run.
The Administration's plan to issue loan guarantees is an effort to stop that run by assuring the world that Mexico's debts are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. That should enable Mexico to borrow at an interest rate of 6 or 7 percent, rather than the 35 percent it was forced to offer last week in a failed effort to float some new bonds. The loan guarantee would also keep the Mexican Government from being forced into default on its tesobonos.
If all goes well, American taxpayers could even profit from the strategy, because Mexico is paying hefty fees for the loan guarantees. The United States is also insisting on first rights to Mexico's oil export earnings in case of default, an annual income flow of roughly $7 billion.
Many people say, however, that it would be impossible for the United States to demand those oil profits if Mexico falls into deeper crisis and its unemployment rate soars. With so many in Congress skeptical that the plan is workable, the White House seems almost certain to rethink its package this week and find a way to make it more palatable on Capitol Hill.
And as it tries that feat, it will face a fundamental conundrum: There is no way to bail out Mexico without also bailing out those who invested there.
The reason is that President Clinton's foreign policy goal -- insuring social and political stability in Mexico -- is entirely dependent on convincing investors that they are bearing little risk by returning to the Mexican market.
As Secretary Rubin, a former co-chairman at Goldman, Sachs & Company, discovered last week, that is a hard argument to make out in the heartland.
"I couldn't care less about bailing out those investors," he told the House Banking Committee. "If they lost every cent of their investment I couldn't care one whit." He then proceeded to describe how failing to bail them out could begin a financial panic around the world, slowing economic growth and desperately hurting American jobs dependent on exports.
His conclusion: The United States can find an inexpensive solution to the problem now, or an expensive one later. No one can estimate how far the contagion might spread, or how many jobs might be lost.
To economists, said Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, this may all make sense. But back home, he concluded, "it's not a very neat answer."

HEADLINE: Big Companies in Mexico Among the Peso's Worst Victims

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The first reports detailing the impact of the peso devaluation on businesses in Mexico paint a brutal picture of huge foreign-exchange losses, steep declines in sales and an erosion of confidence so great that even the most ambitious expansion plans are being scuttled.
Wal-Mart, which was gung-ho on Mexico before the devaluation on Dec. 20, announced last week that it had shelved plans to open 24 new stores in Mexico in 1995. "They are temporarily on hold," a Wal-Mart spokesman, Gerardo Ruiz, said. "We are monitoring the situation daily." 
 Ford, Mercedes-Benz and Volkswagen have temporarily shut down their Mexican assembly lines to clear inventories that have ballooned since the peso was devalued last month, and sales dropped about 40 percent. In that time, the peso has lost 39.65 percent of its value against the dollar.
Mexico's largest banks reported foreign exchange losses during the last two weeks of 1994 that were big enough to drag down balance sheets for the entire year. Banamex, the nation's biggest bank, lost $234 million in the fourth quarter and reduced its total net income to about 17 percent of what it had been in 1993.
Mexico's biggest companies have also reported enormous losses. Cemex, one of the world's largest cement companies, reported $127 million in foreign-exchange losses. The devaluation cost Televisa, the powerful media company, $142 million.
And the biggest Mexican company of all, Telefonos de Mexico, was hit with a fourth-quarter foreign-exchange loss of $862 million.
Analysts say that despite such losses, many companies will soften the effect of the devaluation by taking the huge losses on their 1994 taxes. Still, investor concern about company performance, and worries over the prospects for a $40 billion package of loan guarantees from the United States, has depressed the Mexican stock market. Last week, the market dropped more than 5 percent and closed at 1,957.65, its lowest level in nine months.
Inflation is the Government's big fear, and the first glimpse of the devaluation's effect shows why. During the first half of January, prices on average rose 2.3 percent, which may not sound like much. But if prices kept increasing at that rate throughout the year, the final compounded figure for 1995 would exceed 70 percent.
The Government hopes, and economists generally agree, that 2.3 percent should represent the inflationary peak, as businesses responded directly to the devaluation by giving their prices one big boost. If the Government can maintain control in subsequent weeks the rate should decline, although many private economists still think that the official estimate of 19 percent annual inflation is optimistic.
One way the Government controls inflation is an agreement with labor and business to limit wage and price increases. Minimum wages, which are set by the Government, were allowed to rise 7 percent, plus a tax rebate of 3 percent for workers with the lowest incomes.
The Government, however, cannot control union wages, which companies negotiate with the workers at each plant. The 7 percent minimum-wage increase is only used as a guideline. Many analysts fear that as prices soar, pressure will build to raise contract wages just as much.
But one of the first big contracts to be renegotiated after the devaluation left Government officials smiling. The several thousand union workers at the Nissan Motor Company plant in Aguascalientes, 260 miles northwest of Mexico City, agreed to a wage increase of 11.19 percent, after originally seeking 18 percent. "With that, the recovery plan will work," said Santiago Onate Laborde, Mexico's Labor Secretary.
Official unemployment figures showing the effect of the devaluation will probably not be available for a month. But the Confederation of Mexican Workers says that at least two small businesses have been closing each day since the peso was devalued. Volkswagen is reported ready to lay off 1,400 administrative workers, and the nation's oil monopoly, Pemex, said it might have to lay off 3,000 people.
Jonathan Heath, an economist in Mexico City, said the biggest effect on businesses has been the deep uncertainty left by the collapse of the economic strategy that the Mexican Government relied on for six years. For example, since the decision was made to let the value of the peso float freely, executives have not known what index to use to set prices.
"Nobody really knows what to expect," he said.
A business assessment by Lehman Brothers uses each company's foreign-exchange exposure and level of debt as measures of vulnerability. Companies like the food retailer Cifra, which has few assets or liabilities in foreign currency, are expected to weather the storm. At Tamsa, an international steel-pipe producer, exports amount to 68 percent of sales, but 95 percent of its liabilities are in foreign currency.
For some companies, the devaluation presents a bittersweet opportunity. Mauricio Brener is director general of an industrial group that makes and also imports rubber products. Fierce competition from the United States and East Asia since Mexico lowered tariffs had severely cut into one of his primary businesses, automobile gaskets and seals.
However, since December, those foreign-made parts have become at least a third more expensive than those he produces, and the auto makers have come to him for help.
Mr. Brener finds it striking that by replacing imports with locally made products, Mexican companies like his will survive. Import substitution had been Mexico's basic economic strategy for many years until the mid-1980's.
"Even though it sounds crazy, in the medium term, this is going to be beneficial for Mexico," he said. "It will set our minds straight about where we are, where we want to go and how we are going to get there."

HEADLINE: Peso's Plunge May Cost Thousands of U.S. Jobs

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
The plunge of the peso and the sharp drop in Mexicans' purchasing power will cost tens of thousands of American jobs, the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas has estimated, and private economists say the damage to the United States economy will be even greater.
The peso's drop is expected to slash about $10 billion, or more than 20 percent, from American exports to Mexico this year, business and Government economists say -- turning a healthy trade surplus with Mexico into a large deficit. 
 The Dallas Fed puts the resulting job losses at 20,000 to 30,000, but private economists expect the losses to run into the hundreds of thousands. The regional bank's research, completed last week, will go to top Federal Reserve officials as they meet in Washington this week to consider a rise in interest rates.
Opponents of free trade with Mexico have focused on how many jobs might be lost in the United States as manufacturers relocate south of the border to take advantage of lower labor costs there. But some economists now foresee an even greater toll from a slump in American exports to Mexico. Demand in Mexico, they reason, will be choked off both by the loss in the peso's purchasing power and by a likely slowdown in that country's economy.
The new, unmapped territory of free cross-border commerce resists ready analysis, economists caution. Uncertainties include the chances for approval of the $40 billion American rescue package, the peso's exchange rate and the fortunes of both nations' economies.
Opponents of the Administration's plan to provide $40 billion in loan guarantees call it a bailout for investors. They say the peso's drop has raised the costs of free trade and borne out Mexico's risks.
The Administration says the number of American jobs at stake leaves the United States no choice but to become a co-signer.
But no one expects the peso or the Mexican economy to rebound sharply any time soon. Economists say that even with loan guarantees, American exports will fall sharply and Mexican exports will increase.
The Dallas Fed's estimate of job losses in 1995, after the peso's plunge of nearly 40 percent since Dec. 20, includes jobs lost to increased imports and as a result of illegal immigration. That estimate is higher than the 17,320 jobs the Labor Department said were lost to Mexican imports or job shifts last year, the first under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
In 1994, the Administration said, those losses were more than offset by a gain of about 140,000 jobs as the total value of American shipments to Mexico rose in excess of 20 percent.
Several private economists said the peso's plunge would more than erase these gains. The WEFA Group, a Philadelphia-area forecasting firm, is among the most pessimistic, seeing the evaporation of $21 billion in exports and 500,000 jobs. Daniel Bachman, a senior economist there, said electronics, automobiles and other consumer goods would show the sharpest declines.
"When consumers are hit with lower incomes, they put off discretionary purchases," he said, "and autos are discretionary purchases."
According to unpublished research by the Dallas Fed, exports to Mexico will fall from an estimated $49 billion last year to $38 billion this year, a figure roughly in the middle of estimates by several leading private economists.
"Clearly, there will be some big losers," said Carlos E. Zarazaga, executive director of the Center for Latin American Economics at the Dallas Fed. Mr. Zarazaga noted that Wal-Mart, the largest American retailer, has already halted its Mexican expansion plans. Job losses, he said, would remain below 30,000, including the damage from higher imports and illegal immigration, as companies found domestic and other foreign buyers.
Many United States companies, including auto makers, have already asked the Mexican authorities to let them raise prices in pesos to reflect the currency's weaker purchasing power. Mexico, in most cases, has agreed, acknowledging the higher costs that American manufacturers face.
Mexico pulled virtually even with Japan late last year as the United States' second-largest export market after Canada, affording Washington an estimated $5 billion trade surplus.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in an interview earlier this month that the surplus might well vanish this year. But most economists predict a deficit.
Jose Barrionuevo, a senior economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank's securities unit, expects a gap of about $5 billion. He figures a $5.6 billion increase in Mexican shipments to the United States and a $4.5 billion drop in the other direction.
Mexico cannot increase its trade with the United States any more than that because last year's 20 percent-plus jump pushed its exporters near capacity, Mr. Barrionuevo said. Other economists say that Mexican exporters are more likely to crowd out goods from low-wage nations than from the United States.
But some leading forecasters are taken aback by their own estimates of how many jobs Mexican imports will cost. DRI/McGraw Hill's economic model forecasts the loss of $10 billion in sales this year and a total of 350,000 jobs over two years, compared with the outlook if there were no Mexican crisis.
"Larger than my intuition thought," said Christopher Probyn, the firm's director of forecasting. But he added that the loss of imports and of American jobs could be even greater if Mexico slid into recession. As it stands, the firm forecasts 6.1 percent unemployment in the United States early in 1997, compared with 5.9 percent had the peso maintained its value.

HEADLINE: Data Change May Distort Auto Sales

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Just as investors and auto companies are straining to see signs of the strength or weakness of the auto market, one of the clearest signals -- monthly sales reports -- is vanishing in a statistical fog.
Changes that most companies are making in how they report sales mean that the January results, to be reported this week, are likely to look even limper than they actually are. The changes seem arcane, but their effects may well panic investors, already edgy over signs that the market may be weakening as interest rates climb. 
 "Our primary concern is that people don't overreact to these numbers," said Paul D. Ballew, an economist with the Detroit branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "January's going to be particularly ugly."
Auto stocks have been falling since mid-January on fears that the upstroke of the industry's cycle is over and the downstroke is about to commence. Some companies have cut production and sweetened rebates, signs that their vehicles are not selling as swiftly as they hoped.
Many auto analysts, including some at the auto makers, already expect this month's sales to be soft compared with January last year, when sales were remarkably robust. But when the sales are tallied this week, the billion-dollar question will be: How much of the softness is because of too few customers and how much because of methodological tinkering?
"The temptation will be to say, 'My God! Recession's around the corner,' " said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto industry analyst for Salomon Brothers. Like most analysts, however, Mr. Kirnan argues that the industry is entering a period of slower but steady growth through 1996.
Most auto makers, with notable exceptions that include the Ford Motor Company, plan to switch from reporting each month's sales on the third business day of the following month to the first business day. That means January car and light-truck sales for most makes will be reported on Wednesday rather than on Friday this week.
The companies that are switching say that virtually instantaneous computer communication allows them to gather and compile sales reports much faster than they once did; the three-day lag, they say, is a holdover from when reports trickled in by mail.
Only a few sales late on the last day of the month may not make the new deadline, the companies say. "It's not as if these sales are stacking up on the sales manager's desk," said Jim Crawford, a spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation. "We're not too concerned about it." There is simply no reason, he said, to preserve the lag in the reporting system.
But some dealers say the reporting time varies widely, from as few as 8 hours to more than 48. "We do the reports the following day," said Pat Cameron, sales manager at Ed Voyles Chrysler-Plymouth in Marietta, Ga. "The manufacturer will know about it within 24 hours after the sale." He added that some dealers could take up to three days if "paper flow isn't as good."
Ford, Nissan, Volkswagen and a handful of other companies still plan to report on the third business day. That alone will skew the numbers, making accurate market shares impossible to determine on the first day of the month. Thereafter, analysts will face an apples-and-oranges quandary in trying to calculate market shares, since the companies that report later will probably include more January sales, and some early-February sales as well.
Further, a mathematical formula developed by the Commerce Department to determine a seasonally adjusted selling rate for vehicles, widely used as the index of market strength, does not reflect this change in format. The January rate is likely to look particularly lackluster, and the rates for the rest of the year will not be comparable to 1993's. Wall Street analysts are bracing for peculiar results, and developing back-of-the-envelope methods for adjusting the numbers to try to make them comparable to last year's.
Ford dismisses other companies' assertions that reporting is instantaneous. More than half of sales are reported in the two days after the day they are made, according to a study of Ford dealers. And Ford asserts that its reporting system is as good as anyone's. "We're not getting our reports by Pony Express," said Joel Pitcoff, Ford's market analysis manager. "Our computers are probably better."
Ford says that as a result of reporting earlier, its competitors will not tally most sales they make in the month's final days.
And those days tend to witness a flurry of selling, as dealers lean on their sales staffs to reach monthly goals. This is particularly true for September and December, as auto makers try to win sales contests at the end of the model and calendar years. Over the last five years, Ford says that the last two days of January account, on average, for 14.7 percent of the entire month's sales of Ford cars.
Auto makers reported sales in December under the old system, meaning sales from the final days of December were counted as usual. If Ford is correct about the two-day lag in reporting, the final sales of January under the new system will actually be counted as February sales, on the first business day of March; that will compensate, fuzzily, for the fact that the final sales of February will be counted as March sales. But January, as the pivotal month in switching from the old reporting system to the new one, will simply lose its final sales days, and its sales will seem low as a result.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: LEADERS IN STATES PLEDGE TO REDUCE TAXES THIS YEAR

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Taking a cue from the new Republican-controlled Congress in Washington, political leaders in more than half the nation's state capitals have pledged to cut taxes this year. And the rancorous debate is less about whether to cut taxes than about which taxes to cut -- and by how much.
Paradoxically, though, many fiscal experts are warning that such cuts could prove perilous precisely because Congress itself is thinking of making major cuts in Federal aid to the states. 
 Moreover, a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, approved by the House of Representatives last week, could prove even more onerous. One state lawmaker referred to the amendment as a "neutron bomb" aimed at state budgets even as he said he was likely to support the amendment since his constituents seemed to be demanding it.
Another possible risk of state tax cuts is that many are based on optimistic economic assumptions. In California, for instance, Gov. Pete Wilson's proposed 15 percent cut in personal and income taxes assumes 5.9 percent annual economic growth in the state and a victory in California's lawsuit against the Federal Government to recover costs related to illegal immigration.
At a meeting in Washington of the National Governors' Association, some governors voiced concern that Congress would balance its budget by cutting state aid, although governors of both parties said they welcomed the prospect of more autonomy in spending Federal money. [Page A14.]
Republicans swept to power in last fall's elections, taking control of 17 state legislative chambers that had been in Democratic hands or split between the two parties, and becoming the majority party in more legislatures than the Democrats for the first time in nearly 40 years. And with new legislatures being sworn in across the country this month, tax cuts are clearly on the horizon.
In Mississippi, for instance, the State Senate recently passed, by 36 to 16, a measure to cut state income taxes by 10 percent. A similar bill failed in the chamber last year.
"I think many legislators saw the national mood as of Nov. 8 and are translating that into Mississippi policy," said John Arledge, a spokesman for the state's Republican Governor, Kirk Fordice, the chief proponent of the tax cut. "I know it's an overused phrase, but 'they got the message.' " The bill, amounting to a $200 tax break for the average family, is pending in the House.
In many states, even as there is broad agreement that there will be tax cuts, there is considerable partisan squabbling over just how to structure the measures.
Perhaps the best example is in New York, where Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have basically agreed that there will be roughly $1 billion in tax cuts enacted this year. But the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan's Lower East Side, has offered a plan that he says would offer more relief for low- and middle-income New Yorkers than plans backed by Mr. Pataki, a Republican, or by the Republican-controlled State Senate.
In other states, the fighting is less over the mechanics of a tax cut than over who deserves the credit for suggesting it.
In North Carolina, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., a Democrat who will be up for re-election in 1996, has proposed a $483 million tax cut. His announcement came just a few weeks after last fall's election, in which Republicans had campaigned on their own pledge of a tax cut. The Republicans won the House of Representatives, thus controlling a branch of the legislature for the first time in 125 years, and nearly took the Senate.
These Republicans have been receptive to Mr. Hunt's plan but scoff at the notion that he deserves any praise for offering it.
"Governor Hunt is a great tester of the winds," said Don Follmer, a spokesman for the House majority. "The Republicans have loudly and frequently welcomed him to the dance. He can see what is happening in North Carolina and the nation."
But J. Clay Johnson, an aide to Mr. Hunt, said: "Republicans have cried this is a bidding war, one-upmanship. This is not some kind of knee-jerk reaction. Because of the state's tremendous economic growth, we were in a position to give some back."
Indeed, strong economic growth has provided a rationale for tax cuts in many states. In New Jersey, for example, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, announced last week that she wanted to speed up a 30 percent income tax cut, saying that better-than-expected revenues and a new round of spending cuts would make the measure affordable.
State tax collections soared an average of 6 percent last year, well above inflation, according to Steven D. Gold, director of state fiscal studies at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany.
But tax cuts based on the assumption that the economy will remain strong could prove dangerous, Mr. Gold said. "If the economy is about to slow down, the slowdown is probably going to come too late to influence state decisions about cutting taxes," he said. "States are going to be looking in the rear-view mirror to decide how much money they have."
Twenty-one states cut taxes last year by a total of $1.6 billion, according to a recent report by Mr. Gold. But in most cases the reductions were small, averaging only about one-half of one percent of all state tax revenues.
This year's cuts are expected to be larger. In a December 1994 annual survey of legislative leaders, the Denver-based National Conference of State Legislatures identified 22 states where tax cuts were considered likely. Since that survey was conducted, leaders in at least eight other states have announced tax-cut plans.
"We haven't seen a list like this in a long time," Arturo Perez, a fiscal policy specialist at the organization, said. Indeed, just a few years ago, tax cuts would have been unthinkable in most states, which were struggling to fill huge budget gaps.
"They say, 'O.K., money's coming in, let's give it away,' " Mr. Perez said. "Of course, they regret it when the recession comes back to haunt them."
The battle over tax cuts is perhaps most pitched in the handful of states that have elections this fall. In Louisiana, for instance, where Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, a Democrat, is retiring, prospective candidates are already tripping over each other with tax-cut plans.
Quentin Dastugue, a State Representative from the New Orleans area, and a Republican, has proposed cutting sales taxes on food, drugs and utility bills, for an estimated annual savings of $400 per family. Buddy Roemer, who became a Republican when he was Governor four years ago and is vying for a political comeback, has said he wants to eliminate state income taxes for people 66 years and older to help make Louisiana a major retirement haven like Florida.
In a few states, partisan maneuvering has bordered on the comical.
Earlier this month in Virginia, the Democrats who control the Legislature actually adjourned just before the state's Republican Governor, George F. Allen, was to come to their chamber and deliver his annual State of the Commonwealth address, renewing his call for a five-year $2.1 billion tax cut.
But Mr. Allen summoned the news cameras to his office. "I'd rather talk to you all anyway," he told Virginians in his address. "I reckon these folks in the Legislature will get things straightened out one of these days."
There are cautionary voices about tax cuts. In Virginia, for instance, the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Donald S. Beyer Jr., has led the opposition to Mr. Allen's tax-reduction plans.
"No one has called for us to blow up the basic trust between citizens and government," he said in a recent speech. "We must be lean but not cruel, smart and not reckless. Are we now promising a rose garden, but also congested roads, poor health, eroding schools and jobs that have fled the state?"
And Mr. Gold, at the Rockefeller Institute, said states might be much wiser to plan for tax cuts by bolstering their reserve funds. "The possibility of Federal aid cuts, both in the short term and in the long run from the balanced budget amendment, ought to instill some caution here," he said.
Still, tax cuts can provide an enormously popular platform to run on, and those who stand in their way can expect plenty of verbal abuse. In Maryland, the newly sworn-in Democratic Governor, Parris N. Glendening, has said the state should wait on any decision about cutting taxes for a few years, partly to see what happens in Washington. But even the Democratic-controlled legislature is widely expected to hand him tax-cut legislation this spring, putting enormous pressure on him. Republicans are already pouncing on the issue.
"I don't agree with the Governor's idea of keeping the money in a sock until it's close to his re-election time," Robert H. Kittleman, minority leader in the House of Delegates, said. "Our high personal income tax is the biggest reason we are having such a terrible time attracting business. Virginia, which has much lower taxes, is just eating our lunch."

HEADLINE: Clinton Tests Cooler Congressional Waters on Raising the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL with LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
After a month of trial balloons and uncertainty within the Administration over how best to push for a higher minimum wage, this much has become clear: the White House is still grappling with the question of how best to act in a new political world dominated by a Republican Congress.
Just last Tuesday night, President Clinton promised that he would fight for an increase in the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour, only to have his aides disclose the next morning that he had no immediate plans to submit legislation calling for that step. 
 Since November, there has been almost total agreement within the Administration about a need to increase the minimum wage -- a move the White House is convinced will help the plight of struggling workers while resulting in few jobs lost. With Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich playing a leading role, the President's advisers agreed to seek an increase in the minimum, the preference being 75 cents an hour, to $5, over two years. And by early this month, advocates of the plan were saying Mr. Clinton would unveil the proposal no later than his State of the Union Message.
But those disclosures clashed with the strategy of Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, and other political advisers. Wary of setting public targets that the Republicans could shoot down, they embraced an unorthodox view that the wisest course for Mr. Clinton in the last two years of his term would be to test Congressional waters before adopting a rigid public line.
"What the President is doing -- correctly in my opinion -- is consulting with us on what is doable in this Congress," Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who is the chief deputy whip, said in an interview at week's end. "He did not do enough of that on health care. This is an indication that he has certainly learned."
Yet the mixture of policy making and commitment to consensus-building resulted in muddiness when the White House said on Wednesday that the President was not yet ready to spell out what terms he favored, despite his call for action the previous night.
That apparent edging away from a plan, many of whose details were already widely known, generated so much adverse publicity that Mr. Clinton and his aides had to spend much of the rest of the week arguing that the President truly intended to fight.
White House officials acknowledged that the experience had underscored the notion that too much consultation could also give the impression that Mr. Clinton is irresolute.
Nevertheless, White House aides pointed to the strategy of consulting first as the model that Mr. Clinton intends to embrace. On issues ranging from immigration to welfare to Mexican loan guarantees, they say, it is the best way for him to try to maintain some sway over a Congress whose new Republican majority could quickly strike down everything he proposes.
"We're in an environment now where our efforts will have to be aimed less at legislation and more at a legislative strategy," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman.
If he is careful about picking his fights, aides to Mr. Clinton say, the President firmly believes that he can achieve more in the next two years than commentators have predicted. And on issues like the minimum wage, the aides say, he regards even a victory in which he must share credit with Republicans as far preferable to principled defeat.
It was not until last weekend, after Mr. Clinton sought advice from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, that the White House strategy was finally set, Administration officials said. Mr. Kennedy, who had already introduced a bill that would increase the minimum wage by $1.50 in three annual steps, to $5.75 an hour, convinced Mr. Clinton that the more modest White House plan would have a better chance of winning support if the President withheld its specifics for now and left the Senator's plan as the Republicans' chief target.
"I have to create the conditions in which we can raise the minimum wage if I possibly can," Mr. Clinton said in an NBC interview last week in explaining why he had accepted that counsel. "I don't want to waste a lot of time making strong posturing and undermining the chance that we can raise it."
But the strategy of consulting with Democrats in Congress to develop a consensus on the minimum wage is not an easy one, and has been plagued by leaks from within the Administration. This limited Mr. Clinton's room to maneuver, some Administration officials said.
"There was some sense here that the President was being boxed in, and that was not appreciated," Mr. McCurry said. He declined to say exactly whom the White House blamed.
Despite the disclosures, the President's senior advisers have agreed that 1995 should be the year for him to press for the increase. Indeed, inflation has eroded the minimum wage to a 40-year low in terms of buying power.
Until the election, the Administration had been unwilling to push for both a health care plan and a higher minimum wage, both opposed by business groups. But with the Republican victory and the roadblock it erected to the health care initiative, the President and his aides saw a fresh opportunity on the wage issue.
At the same time, the proposal to raise the minimum wage seemed to Mr. Clinton's aides to be consistent with his strategy of turning more attention to the plight of ordinary Americans. Even Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, the most conservative among Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, told fellow Cabinet members at a meeting before he left office last month that he favored a prudent increase in the minimum wage.
Varying degrees of enthusiasm remained for the plan among Mr. Clinton's economic team, with Mr. Reich described by participants in the meetings as the most enthusiastic. Alan Krueger, the President's current chief economist at the Labor Department, and Lawrence Katz, Mr. Krueger's predecessor, had done considerable academic work suggesting that an increase in the minimum wage would result in only modest job loss, or none at all.
At several meetings beginning in December, Mr. Reich advocated a $1 increase in the wage. But others, including Robert E. Rubin, the incoming Treasury Secretary, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, were less enthusiastic about so big a step. There was broad support instead for the 75-cent increase over two years -- 50 cents the first year and 25 cents the second -- an increment that Administration officials described as unlikely to result in noticeable job loss and therefore "very safe."
The final recommendation of the President's advisers did not reach Mr. Clinton's desk until late last week in the form of a memorandum signed by Gene Sperling, the economic aide who shepherded the process. Much of the discussion in the last two weeks dealt not with the merits of a 75-cent increase, but with the politics.
As discussions proceeded with Congressional leaders, the word that Mr. Clinton was preparing to put forward a proposal to increase the minimum wage appeared in newspaper accounts on Jan. 5. That propelled the issue onto a public plane far sooner than the White House had intended, with Mr. Panetta and Vice President Al Gore forced to concede in television appearances three days later that Mr. Clinton favored such a step.
A senior Administration official, who said the disclosure carried political benefits, noted that it had allowed Mr. Reich and others to speak publicly about recent research by economists suggesting that the potential loss in jobs would be negligible. But the official also noted that the leak could lead to the early mobilization of small businessmen, restaurant owners and Republicans in a campaign to oppose an increase in the minimum wage.
What was most harmful, White House officials now say, was that the disclosure and the resulting public discussion about an increase had raised widespread expectations that Mr. Clinton would soon be specific about his plans. And then, in the face of accusations that the President was not showing backbone, Mr. Clinton and his aides contended that their cautious new strategy of seeking consensus with Congress was the only workable one.
"This 'walk the walk business' is a bogus charge," Mr. Clinton protested in an interview with the NBC News broadcaster Tom Brokaw, who cited the shying away from a specific minimum-wage plan as evidence that the President was not being true to his convictions.
"I'm going to push very hard for it," Mr. Clinton said. "I want to raise it. I want to get it done."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
It's Almost Jury's Turn in Zion Trial

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
On Friday, after 11 weeks of trial, testimony in the lawsuit against New York Hospital and four doctors in the death of 18-year-old Libby Zion concluded at last, leaving many questions unanswered.
Forty-five, and counting. 
 After summations, which are to begin today, the jury will work through one of the longest verdict questionnaires ever in a New York State civil trial. The questions address the judgment calls made by the doctors during that long March night in 1984 when Ms. Zion went to the hospital with fever and chills. She died about eight hours later, after her fever spiked to 108 degrees and she went into cardiac arrest.
A typical question goes something like this: Did Dr. X depart from accepted medical practice by failing to order Test Y for Ms. Zion?
And each question is followed by: If the answer to the first is yes, did that action contribute to Ms. Zion's pain and suffering and to her death?
Only if both answers are yes can a defendant be found negligent.
Now for that indelicate question: How much is the case worth?
Not very much, say many medical malpractice lawyers. Under New York law, damages for wrongful death are limited to the economic worth of the deceased to the next of kin. Ms. Zion was not, for example, a working parent with two dependent children. She was a college freshman, supported by her parents.
Her father, the journalist Sidney Zion, who is bringing the lawsuit, stands a better chance of collecting for his daughter's pain and suffering. Her lawyers have argued throughout the trial that her discomfort worsened because doctors gave her the wrong drug and, when she started thrashing around, ordered nurses to tie her down.
While Thomas A. Moore, the Zions' lawyer, may ask for a whopping amount, lawyers in the field predict that an appellate court will reduce it to about $300,000.
This assumes, of course, that the jury comes down entirely against the defendants. Jurors could buy outright the defense's argument -- that the doctors' care was appropriate and that Ms. Zion contributed to her death by failing to disclose that she had taken cocaine -- and award nothing. Or jurors could find only some of the doctors negligent.
They could also split the award, saying, for example, that Ms. Zion was 30 percent responsible and the doctors and the hospital 70 percent. Defendants would then pay 70 percent of the total damages amount.
But Friday evening, Judge Elliott Wilk of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, gave Mr. Moore his dearest wish: the right to ask for punitive damages.
To make such an award, a jury also has to find that the defendants were grossly negligent -- that they acted with reckless disregard for Ms. Zion's condition. It is a very high hurdle: New York appellate courts have virtually never upheld punitive damages, in part because medical malpractice cases are usually settled before a plaintiff's lawyer gets to pose such a question to a jury.
If jurors vote to send a deterrent message with punitive damages, the amount is limited only by the defendants' net worth. Small wonder, then, that this case has been so hard fought. For Mr. Zion, punitive damages would underscore his decade-long struggle to correct what he says were flaws in the supervision of young doctors. For the defendants, there is an institutional stake in turning away such a verdict.
There is also a powerful pecuniary one: the money would come out of their pockets. Insurance covers awards for malpractice, but not punitive damages.
 
Stuffing a Cat Back in a Bag
 In the 10th week of testimony, the Zion lawyers' worst nightmare was realized.
Before the trial started, Judge Wilk had blocked any testimony about possible cocaine use other than Ms. Zion's inconclusive autopsy results. Such information would be prejudicial, he said, because no one had witnessed her using the drug just before she went to the hospital.
But the defense's psycho-pharmacologist, Dr. George Simpson, broke that rule during cross-examination by Mr. Moore.
Dr. Simpson had testified that a factor in Ms. Zion's death had been the interaction between cocaine and Nardil, the potent anti-depressant she had been taking.
Mr. Moore pressed Dr. Simpson to concede that his opinion that Ms. Zion had been using cocaine was based on unreliable tests. Unless the doctor had other information -- meaning about the tests. Mr. Moore assumed Dr. Simpson had none.
"It was the information that she had used cocaine in the past, with her boyfriend's testimony," Dr. Simpson said, alluding to pretrial statements.
The remark was a deadly blow to the Zions' case. In a rapid attempt to recover, Mr. Moore ignored those statements and instead tried to discredit the expert.
Are you saying, doctor, that you relied on information from a "jilted boyfriend?" asked the lawyer, looking aghast.
"Do you pride yourself on your professionalism?" he thundered.
Later, Judge Wilk instructed jurors to disregard most of Dr. Simpson's testimony. But as a Court TV commentator said, that was like telling them to forget they had seen a pink elephant.
 
An Alarming False Alarm
 Under the gaze of the Court TV camera, tension built steadily during a trial that was fought ferociously by lawyers whose ill will toward one another exploded regularly.
After the jury had left for lunch on Friday, Judge Wilk appeared to have finally reached his limit.
"Miss Karas!" he shouted to the Court TV reporter. "I've just learned something disquieting. Turn off those cameras! We'll do this off the record."
Elizabeth J. Karas, who had joined Court TV only six months ago, dashed into the well, pale and trembling. Memories of the mishap from the O. J. Simpson trial, in which a Court TV camera inadvertently showed an alternate juror for nearly a second, sprang to mind.
Then Judge Wilk jettisoned his wrath-of-justice mask. "I just heard it was your birthday," he said, with a grin. Then he handed her a piece of cake with a lit candle and led the entire courtroom in singing "Happy Birthday" to a stunned, blushing and abundantly relieved Ms. Karas.
