HEADLINE: Attention Is Turning Governors' Heads

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
For governors, this is in many ways the best of times.
Congress is soliciting their advice as never before. A major goal of the Republicans controlling Congress is to give power to the states. 
 The Republican Party chose a governor to respond to President Clinton's State of the Union address. The Senate is voting on a bill long sought by governors to curb the imposition of costly Federal requirements on the states. And the new Congress is continually citing the 10th Amendment to the Constitution, which emphasizes the powers "reserved to the states."
But as the National Governors' Association opened its winter meeting here today, many of the states' chief executives expressed uncertainty and apprehension. They worry that Congress will balance the Federal budget by cutting aid to the states for education, health care and assistance to poor people.
Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, a Republican, rejoiced at the changes sweeping through Washington. In the next decade, he said, "You will see a radical transformation -- what the Founding Fathers intended -- with more responsibility going back to the state and local level." Another Republican, Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, said, "This is a pivotal change, a sea change in our history."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who is chairman of the governors' association, said that in recent years, when Democrats controlled the House of Representatives, "they didn't pay any attention to governors whatsoever."
In an interview, Mr. Dean observed that the new Republican leaders of the House were listening to Republican governors, at least. "That's a significant improvement," he said.
On the other hand, some Democratic governors, including Mr. Dean, said the Republicans would shift so much power to the states that there would no longer be Federal standards guaranteeing a safety net for poor children.
"I believe there is a national interest in making sure that children don't starve," said Governor Dean.
Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, said he feared that the Republicans in Congress would impose new requirements on the states to achieve conservative policy goals.
"We're not any more interested in conservative mandates than in liberal mandates," Mr. Carnahan said.
He also said he was worried that if Congress gave states a lump sum of cash to run their own welfare and nutrition programs, as some Republican governors have proposed, states would run out of money in the next recession.
"At the state level," Mr. Carnahan said, "we will have to cut people off the welfare rolls in their time of need."
At their meeting today, the governors considered the proposal to replace dozens of Federal programs with a lump-sum payment, or block grant, but reached no conclusion. Republicans said 5 percent of the money could be set aside to help states experiencing high unemployment or other economic difficulties.
Gov. Evan Bayh, an Indiana Democrat, said: "There is a great opportunity here, but also a great risk. There will be a great temptation for Congress, in a politically cynical way, to shift the burdens to state and local taxpayers. I use the analogy of the Trojan horse. It looks pretty good right now, but what's waiting inside that could be potentially harmful?"
In addition, Mr. Carnahan said, it is mainly the Republican governors that Congress is listening to these days.
One of those Republicans, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, said the new leaders of Congress seemed to believe that "they can learn something from governors."
Governors of both parties welcomed the prospect of new autonomy and flexibility, promised by House Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republicans. "I like it," said Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, a Democrat. "I want more flexibility. I want to run these programs without Federal strings."
Thirty of the 50 governors are Republicans -- as compared with 20 before November's election -- and some have played a large role in helping the new Republican Congress shape its agenda. Their negotiations with the Republican leaders of Congress, on issues like welfare, have caused severe strains in the governors' association, which has a history of bipartisan cooperation.
James L. Martin, a lobbyist at the association for 28 years, said the governors' influence soared after November's election. "The Republican Party is state oriented," he said. "At least, it has been for three or four decades."
Of the nine most populous states, only Florida does not have a Republican governor.
Mr. Martin said that the Republican leaders of Congress and the national Republican Party were fascinated, in particular, with the political success of three Republican Governors just re-elected in the Midwest: John Engler of Michigan, who won more than 61 percent of the vote in November; Mr. Thompson in Wisconsin, who carried 67 percent of the vote, and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, who won 72 percent.
Mr. Thompson carried Milwaukee and says he won nearly 40 percent of the black vote statewide. John Truscott, press secretary for Mr. Engler, described the Michigan Governor as "very activist" and estimated that he won half the union vote.
The success of the Congressional Republicans' domestic program, embodied in the Contract With America, depends on governors like Mr. Engler, Mr. Thompson and Mr. Voinovich. "The Republicans who run Congress have to listen to the Republican governors," Mr. Martin said. If the contract works in big states, he said, Republicans have reason to hope it will work elsewhere.
The ambivalence of many state officials was captured in a statement issued today by the Democratic Governors' Association. The Democratic governors said they supported a constitutional amendment to require that the Federal budget be balanced. But they said that the version of the amendment approved last week by the House would shift costs to the states and might force some states to raise taxes.
The theme of the new Federal-state relationship is trust. Republicans in Congress say they are willing to place more trust in state officials than the Democrats did.
Over the last 50 years, Congress has set detailed Federal standards for welfare, food assistance, Medicaid, civil rights and protection of the environment. State officials contend that they are entitled to more discretion and a larger degree of trust.

HEADLINE: Slopping the Hogs, the Assembly-Line Way

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROSE HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
Barney Rhodes gave up his father's poultry and corn farm in 1983, trading the risks of working on the land for a construction business.
But about two years ago, he started getting other ideas when farmer after farmer asked him to build long, low cinder-block buildings for a mechanized, assembly-line system of hog rearing. 
 "There was something big going on here," Mr. Rhodes said, "and so I got into the hog-contracting business myself a little over a year ago."
Now, Mr. Rhodes and his wife, Joy, own four long buildings packed with more than 5,000 grunting, snorting hogs that they feed for about 20 weeks, starting when the animals are about three months old and until they reach a market weight of 250 to 260 pounds. The couple run a finishing farm, one of 400 in North Carolina that tend hogs under contract with Murphy Family Farms, a local company that recently became the country's largest producer of hogs.
The "something big" that Mr. Rhodes spotted could be considered a revolution in livestock farming. It takes a method that had been spottily used -- keeping the hogs inside, away from the elements -- and raises it to a new level. The buildings are standardized, and the feeding, watering and cleaning up after the animals are done by automated equipment.
The hogs are bred in farrowing farms, where they stay for 17 to 20 days, until they are weaned; then, they are moved to the nurseries, where they stay for 10 weeks until they weigh about 50 pounds; finally, they go to finishing farms like the Rhodes's.
The mechanization has meant that one farmer can do the work of what used to take dozens of laborers. And thousands of hogs can be raised on one farm, many times the number on traditional farms.
The new methods are based on the contract-farming system developed in the chicken industry. They have enabled some hog farmers to stay afloat in a pork market that has been dropping sharply.
On the other hand, some experts trace the lower prices to the increase in the number of hogs on the market, which is partly attributable to contract farming. There are also widespread complaints about the stench from the large farms.
The operations have also reduced, or perhaps elevated, to a science the quaint arts of animal husbandry that once made 4-H Club members beam with pride.
In the process, North Carolina has become the nation's second-largest hog producer, pushing its annual production to seven million hogs in 1993, up from two million a decade ago. (In 1993, total United States hog production was 50.7 million.)
But the hog industry has about hit its limits in North Carolina because of slaughterhouse capacity and the prohibitive cost of shipping feed from the Midwest's corn farms. Large contract growers like Murphy Family Farms are preparing to expand contract farming techniques into Iowa, the No. 1 hog-producing state, with 13 million hogs in 1993.
Barbara Grabner, assistant director of Prairie Fire, a farm advocacy group based in Des Moines, said the coming of the contract farms is "the hottest issue now" among Iowa hog farmers who take pride in their image as independent entrepreneurs but are looking for ways to become more efficient as market prices fall.
Ms. Grabner raised some of the same concerns that have been debated in North Carolina. "It's the scale of these operations and some of the environmental problems they may bring which makes people here nervous, even with our wide open spaces," she said. "They even smell different and worse than our traditional hog farms."
Because of the large concentration of animals, the area around a hog farm is saturated by a nose-wrinkling, ammonia-tinged smell of the animals even on crisp, windy days.
Most of North Carolina's 8,000 hog farms are in the eastern part of the state stretching between the Virginia and South Carolina borders. While the number of farms is down from 21,000 in 1984, production is up. Last year, hog operations in the state brought in $1 billion, making pork as valuable to the state as tobacco and chickens. And while many hog farms have shut down, some farmers say the contracting system has allowed their operations to stay alive.
"The company tells us everything we need to do for the pigs to perform properly," Mr. Rhodes said. He is guaranteed a flat fee regardless of the day's market price. "There's absolutely no risk here for me," he said.
Indeed, it is the company, not the farm, that owns the hogs. The farmers, however, buy the equipment and own the buildings.
Company-employed experts provide the farmers with stock that is genetically manipulated for leanness and rapid growth, and with custom-mixed feed in specific amounts needed from one week to the next.
By shifting risks away from the farmer, the contract concept has kept farmers like Jimmie and JoAnn Stroud in the farming business. They were barely staying afloat five years ago growing corn and tobacco on their 150-acre farm in Duplin County. Now, they run a 2,500-hog nursery under contract to Murphy Family Farms, tending the animals from the time they are 17 days old until they are about 10 weeks old.
"We tried to be independent with tobacco, corn and soybeans, but sometime you can just independent yourself into a hole," Mrs. Stroud said. "There are some out there who just want to be independent, but I don't mind taking the direction of the company. I'd rather have part of something than all of nothing."
Not everyone feels so kindly. Environmental groups say the quantum leap in the number of hogs on the farms is matched by an increase in environmental problems, including the constant odor, which some fear may be harmful. In fact, the state has created a Hog Odor Task Force to study whether there is any risk to farm workers or neighbors.
The potential hazards are much clearer when it comes to the large, odoriferous, man-made lagoons into which large farms pump the hog waste and allow it to sit and decompose. The nitrogen-rich waste water is then sprayed on fields as a fertilizer. The lagoons attract swarms of flies, and if the water is not handled properly in dry weather, heavy concentrations of waste in the water can get into ground water and contaminate the aquifers, and, when used in fertilizers, can kill crops and grass.
Dr. Leon Chesnin, a former University of Nebraska professor and an expert in waste management on hog farms, said small hog farms posed few risks to the environment because of the low concentration of waste. "It is entirely different with the large contract farms," he said. Lagoons are not leak-proof, and something the size of a municipal waste-treatment plant would be needed to render the waste totally safe, he said.
In Wilson, N.C., Ann Joyner, 58, told of what it was like to live within a mile of a 24,000-hog farm just outside town.
"The smell of hog manure, urine and ammonia and dust would just float all over and it made me so depressed and so angry," she said, noting that damp and rainy days were the worst. Last June, she said, she moved to town "to get away from it."
Wendell Murphy, the founder of Murphy Family Farms, a privately held company that started in the early 1960's as a feed and grain business, says he merely picked up on something that the chicken industry had been doing efficiently for years. "There's a stigma attached to it in some places," he said, "but it makes sense economically."
Last fall, Successful Farming magazine rated the company as the largest pork producer in the United States, with 180,000 breeding sows producing an estimated 3.6 million marketable hogs a year.
John Morrison, president of the National Contract Poultry Growers Association, agrees that the contract farms are the wave of the future in the hog and other livestock businesses, but he fears that hog farmers will find themselves with problems that chicken farmers have endured. The contract system has turned many chicken producers into little more than low-paid employees of the large broiler companies, he said, totally dependent on a single company for a stream of birds to sell and pay their bills and subject to being squeezed by the company whenever necessary.
So far there have been few complaints from contract hog farmers of bad treatment. But, Mr. Morrison said, it is just a matter of time.
Mr. Morrison's organization recently started a new nonprofit foundation. "It's called the National Contract Growers Institute," Mr. Morrison said. "We named it that way because, like with chickens, we know the honeymoon will be over soon with hogs."

HEADLINE: Arizona Moves Up Its Primary To Catch Political Limelight

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 29

 BODY:
"I'm tired of Arizona being ignored by the rest of the country!" declared Gov. Fife Symington, setting off one of the noisiest skirmishes between states since Long Island tried to send its garbage by barge to North Carolina. "The West is rising!"
Indeed, in past years Arizona has been little more than a whistle stop for national candidates on their way to California. The only attention it got was over the peculiarities of its governors, like Rose Mofford and her platinum beehive hair-do and Evan Mecham, a former Pontiac dealer who was removed from office for misuse of state money. 
 So in a brazen bid for influence, Arizona passed a law in 1992 moving up its Presidential primary to the same day in February as New Hampshire, which for about the last 70 years has gained stature beyond its size by having a lock on the nation's first primary.
In New Hampshire, where the threats from Arizona have made headlines on the front pages day after day, Gov. Stephen Merrill responded by vowing to do battle with his fellow Republican, Mr. Symington. He accused Arizona of engaging in "a clear attack on the people of New Hampshire and the tradition of the political primary system in this nation."
A few days ago, the warring parties struck a compromise. Mr. Symington agreed to schedule the Arizona primary a week after New Hampshire. "We will not be the aggressor," he said. But other states are itching to challenge New Hampshire's pre-eminence. "Now I can concentrate on getting Delaware officials to back off," said Steve Duprey, chairman of the Republican Party in New Hampshire.
As House Speaker Newt Gingrich observed, "This gets to be sort of a stupid game." If states keep trying to leapfrog over one another, he said, "then we'll have the first primary this June."
The arm-wrestling over the calendar is the latest manifestation of states trying to cash in on Presidential politics. Just like the Republican contenders who are maneuvering for attention, the states want the recognition, power and economic boost that can come from being a big player.
For those same reasons, several cities mounted costly and intense lobbying drives to woo the national political conventions in 1996. The Democrats, after being enticed by deep-dish pizza flown from Chicago, as well as the persuasive powers of Mayor Richard M. Daley, picked that city; the Republicans, drawn by California's huge harvest of electoral votes, settled on San Diego, rather than other cities, like New York, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani backed the wrong horse.
Trying another increasingly popular scheme for attention, the Arizona Republican Party held its first Presidential straw poll here on Saturday, even though such nonbinding tallies have never been reliable indicators of who will be the next nominee. "It's better to finish first than last," said Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, "but it doesn't have anything to do with the nomination."
Such dismissive remarks did not prevent Senator Phil Gramm of Texas from trumpeting his 54 percent victory, saying it would "lay the foundations to carry Arizona in February of next year."
For the Arizona boosters, catching some national limelight is also a matter of civic pride. Several Republicans here said they could not fathom why Presidential candidates would prefer chilly New Hampshire next winter over the warmer vistas of the Grand Canyon state.
"I don't mind stealing the thunder from New Hampshire," said Jean McGrath, a Republican state legislator. "They don't have nearly as many things going for them as we do. We like to think we're one hot state."
Despite the compromise, Arizona, which in the past has held party caucuses in the late spring, has already benefited from the fracas. Several Presidential prospects have trooped to the state, many of them more than once.
Mr. Symington said, approvingly, that the feud with New Hampshire led to publicity "which talked about the clear skies, the sun, the 80-mile vistas and contrasted it with the snow and ice in New England."
"I thought, 'Gosh, that's pretty good advertising for my state,' " Mr. Symington said.
But an unanticipated consequence of Arizona's effort to get noticed is that it risks getting ignored a year from now. Motivated by the knowledge that Arizona would hold an earlier primary, Mr. Gramm began building support here so early that other candidates may bypass Arizona next year, accusing the Senator of having the state wired. Already, Mr. Gramm's opponents are blaming him for staging a power play to get Arizona to hold an early primary as a way to make the most of his support, something he denies.
Mr. Gramm's popularity has much to do with the aggressive backing of Mr. Symington and Senator John McCain, whose home he stayed at this weekend. "I was watching McCain, following him around like a little puppy dog," said Larry Krieger, a delegate to the state convention who backs former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.
Seeking to tweak Mr. Gramm, Senator Bob Dole, who is also vying for the Republican nomination, commissioned a poll showing that he was the favorite candidate of Republican voters in Arizona -- and released it at the convention here.
Arizona Republicans are taking delight in all this extraordinarily early maneuvering. Senator Jon Kyl, one of the few leading Arizona Republicans who has not endorsed Mr. Gramm, said it would be best for his state if Mr. Gramm does not have an easy victory here. He has visions of Arizona as a Sun Belt battleground.
"Phil Gramm's interest is to nail down so much political support early that he can carry Arizona," Mr. Kyl said. "But the Governor and the Legislature would probably prefer to have a very hot contest."

PATAKI PLANS 4-YEAR TAX CUT
 Governor Pataki will release a budget on Wednesday that will propose a four-year tax cut that would remove 400,000 people from the tax rolls and reduce state revenues by $6.8 billion a year by 1998.
The plan is essentially the same as the one Mr. Pataki proposed during the campaign: to reduce the top tax rate by 25 percent over four years, keep the bottom rate at 4 percent, reduce the number of people paying the top rate and provide a range of credits and deductions that would benefit lower-income taxpayers. HEADLINE: New Focus on Cable Competition;
Latest Technologies Giving Communities Greater Leverage

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 27

 BODY:
One day, Harry Taubenfeld turned on the television in his daughter's house in Westchester County and discovered something that really ticked him off.
"I looked over her channels," Mr. Taubenfeld recalled. "She's got the Comedy Channel, this channel, that channel. Two C-Spans! She shows me the bill -- and she was paying one dollar less than me. For 60 channels! And I've got only 27!" 
 Soon, Mr. Taubenfeld, a lawyer and a trustee of this village, was organizing a committee of the Nassau County Village Officials Association to look into the costs of programming supplied by Cablevision, the hometown company that has long had a monopoly on cable television in Nassau.
Now, two years later, the committee is negotiating with a Manhattan-based cable company, Liberty Cable, hoping to offer subscribers here a gift that many have dreamed of: a choice.
Frustrated by their inability to force local cable operators to improve service and reduce rates, a growing number of officials and subscribers in New York State are using the threat of competition as a new weapon in their battles against their cable companies.
Because the cost of wiring a community for cable has traditionally been so high, virtually every municipality in the metropolitan region, and in the nation, is served by only one cable operator. But with new technologies making it easier to bring cable into the home in novel ways, such as over phone lines, communities are finding new upstart companies like Liberty eager to establish beachheads.
And local officials are embracing any opportunity to shake up their cable operators.
"The only time they listen is when the threat of competition is real," said Paul Feiner, the Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh, in Westchester County. The town has been negotiating for more than a year with Liberty, which has 30,000 subscribers in Manhattan apartment buildings, as an alternative to the town's sole provider, Tele-Communications Inc.
Hy Fishoff, a retired clothing salesman who lives in Greenburgh, said he helped organize a committee to bring in a cable competitor after becoming fed up with what he called T.C.I.'s lack of responsiveness whenever the cable went out.
"They just felt they had a monopoly, that they could do what they wanted whenever they wanted," he said. "That catapulted me to want to do something about it."
Liberty has found no shortage of potential takers since it began putting out feelers in the suburbs in 1993. Not only is the company negotiating with representatives of Nassau's 64 villages, but it is also talking to officials in Oyster Bay, a sprawling town of 290,000 people that also happens to be the home of Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision.
"When you don't have a choice, you feel that things are being foisted on you and you really don't have any options," said Louis Savinetti, a member of the Oyster Bay Town Board. "My bottom line is, hey, I'm looking at price, and people should have a choice."
If the relationship between a cable company and a community sometimes resembles a loveless marriage, that may be as much a result of viewers' high expectations as it is the performance of the cable company.
Michael J. Dolan, who once worked in the cable industry and now acts as a consultant to communities negotiating renewals of their franchise agreements, says it is rare to find a subscriber with a kind word for the local cable company.
"No matter who you talk to, their cable operator stinks and they want any other one," said Mr. Dolan, who is based in Sloatsburg, N.Y., and is not related to the Cablevision chairman.
Steven A. Shaye, director of the Municipal Assistance Division of the State Commission on Cable Television, said his agency receives 20,000 calls a month on its toll-free complaint lines. When Huntington, L.I., was involved in renewing a franchise agreement with Cablevision a couple of years ago, he said, 700 people showed up at a meeting to vent their ire at the cable company.
Officials on Long Island, where cable was introduced more than two decades ago, have been among the most active in looking for alternatives. Last year, for example, a Federal judge blocked an effort by the Town of East Hampton to cancel its contract with Cablevision after the company raised rates and reduced the number of channels in its lowest-priced service. The decision not only upheld the company's right to alter service, but also showed how difficult it is for a community to divorce its cable operator.
By Federal law, cable companies have a presumptive right to renew their municipal franchise agreements, which normally expire every 10 or 15 years. And though communities may enter into franchise agreements with more than one company, it almost never occurs. "A municipal government has the right to grant a second franchise," said Mr. Shaye. "It just hasn't happened in New York State because of the economics of the industry."
Cable company officials say the lack of competition is not their fault. "The monopoly hasn't been our doing," said Norm Fein, vice president of press relations for Cablevision, a cable giant that deals with 750 franchising authorities in 19 states.
He and others point to the variety of services, from free cable hookups in schools to an all-news channel for Long Island, as evidence that the companies are mindful of their responsibilities to the community.
Mr. Fein said Cablevision was upgrading its channel capacities and giving subscribers more flexibility in buying the channels they want. "We assume there will be competition; we think it's a good thing," he said.
In some localities, however, there is a feeling that cable companies have grown arrogant. Some Connecticut customers of Cablevision, for instance, were angered in 1993 when the company announced plans to drop virtually all Connecticut stations, a proposal it later abandoned. And strained relations in some places became even testier after legislation passed by Congress in 1992 to reregulate the industry and reduce cable rates did not have the desired effect.
"After the Federal regulations came into effect, Cablevision made the grandiose announcement that they were reducing the rates by two cents -- two cents!" said J. Leonard Samansky, the Mayor of Saddle Rock and president of the Nassau County Village Officials Association.
That is why spirits soared at the news that Liberty might come to town. Peter O. Price, Liberty's president, says he will provide 60 channels as a basic service for about $18 a month. According to an analysis prepared by Cablevision for the Nassau village officials, Cablevision charges $22 for a "family service" package of 36 channels.
In Manhattan, Liberty has used microwave antennas to transmit cable from building to building. In the suburbs, Mr. Price is considering a plan to send programming over fiber-optic telephone lines. Nynex is testing the system in three apartment buildings in Manhattan, with a goal of carrying 300 digital channels for cable providers like Liberty, said Walter Silvia, vice president of broad-band marketing for Nynex.
Mr. Price said he could begin offering service in Greenburgh as soon as Nynex provides the fiber-optic link from his transmitters in New York City. But even before Liberty arrives, he said, he may be doing a service for municipalities renegotiating their franchise agreements.
"I think it's a win-win situation for them," Mr. Price said. "They all feel that no matter what we provide, it will put some competition into the marketplace and make the current cable operator more responsive, and hopefully provide more choice."
But not everyone is waiting for television to arrive by phone.
In Flower Hill, a village of 4,500 people on Nassau's North Shore, Mayor John W. Walter decided the community would do better by building its own cable system.
No sooner did a small electronics company place satellite dishes at Village Hall as a demonstration than the Mayor received a call from Cablevision. The company wanted to see if it could provide some of the services Mr. Walter was seeking, like more channels, elimination of the charges for extra television sets and a village-run public access channel.
After winning the concessions from Cablevision, Mr. Walter is rewriting the village's franchise agreement. In fact, Mr. Walter said, residents broke the tradition of a three-term limit for mayors just so he could finish the agreement.
"They said to me, 'O.K., you got our attention,' " Mr. Walter said, referring to the cable company. " 'Any time you suggest that you are going to overbuild our system, you get our attention.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter O. Price, president of Liberty Cable, on the roof of his company's headquarters in Manhattan, hopes to offer subscribers a choice of providers. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "PRIMER: Television Transmission Technologies"
 
TRADITIONAL CABLE: TV transmissions are carried overhead or underground into homes by fiber optic and coaxial cables. In many places, cable companies are replacing much of their coaxial cable with fiber optic to, among other things, increase channel capacity.
 
MICROWAVE: A transmitter on the tallest building in an area sends signals on microwaves to individual dishes or antennas on homes. Apartment buildings with the technology often have a microwave antenna on the roof that picks up transmission and sends it down wires to each apartment.
 
SATELLITE DISHES: TV programming is beamed to dishes mounted on the exterior of homes from satellites orbiting around the Equator 22,300 miles in space. Signal is transferred to a receiver hooked up to the television set.
 
DIGITAL SATELLITE SYSTEM: Uses the satellite dish technology, with an 18-inch dish that is connected to receiver hooked up both to a TV and a telephone line. Customer buys the dish from an electronics dealer, and then can buy packages of digital channels from program suppliers. Monthly costs could range from about $6 to $65.
 
VIDEO DIAL TONE: Technology being developed by telephone companies, in which TV transmissions are carried by fiber optic cable along telephone lines, and would allow subscribers to "dial up" much of their programming any time they want.
 
(pg. B6)

LENGTH: 1352 words

HEADLINE: For Homeless, Free Voice Mail Can Be a Key to a Normal Life

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Carl Hygrant encountered no shortage of indignities as a homeless person in New York, but one of the worst was not having a phone number. In his persistent hunt for work, he put on resumes the number of the Bronx shelter that was his temporary home. Repeatedly, when a prospective employer called and learned it was a shelter, interest in him would evaporate in a matter of nanoseconds.
Then he got voice mail. 
 Within weeks, Mr. Hygrant found a temporary maintenance job at the Fashion Institute of Technology -- a place outside of whose doors he had sometimes slept -- that lasted until the end of December. He got his own apartment. His ultimate goal is to embark on fashion design; on the side, he already makes custom clothes for people who learn of him by word of mouth. Voice mail strengthened that business. A call came in for a navy-blue pin-striped suit. A call came in for a shirt, in an extra-large size.
"Voice mail has been fabulous," said Mr. Hygrant, who is 30 and out actively looking again for a permanent position. "People could never get in touch with me. Friends kept saying, 'Carl, get yourself a phone already.' I'd say, 'Yeah, right, first I've got to get someplace to sleep.' Voice mail has made me a new man."
Mr. Hygrant is one of 50 homeless people in New York who were enlisted in a pilot program last June sponsored by MFS Intelenet, a telephone company based in Parsippany, N.J. Carolyn LoGalbo, the chief marketing officer for MFS, said the company had been searching for a community service project and settled on the notion of giving a gift of technology to those who have the least. The program is administered by the Partnership for the Homeless, the nonprofit advocacy group.
MFS donated the mailboxes, for which it normally charges $10.50 a month, and is also paying for a toll-free "800" number to make it easier for homeless clients to retrieve their messages.
The partnership said that of the initial group of 50 clients, 14 have found full-time jobs and another five have found temporary work; nine have found housing. Seven others have had promising job interviews, and three have enrolled in college. Five people gave up their boxes after deriving little benefit.
Officials at the partnership caution that the sample thus far is thin. But they say that successful voice-mail clients are finding jobs or housing in about three months, about one-third the time that those without it tend to take. They point out that this time saved can translate into meaningful savings in money spent supporting the homeless. Among other things, case managers can reach clients more speedily.
Distinct psychic benefits have also accrued. "It has really made a lot of people feel that they have an identity again," said Linda Nelson, who oversees the program at the Coalition for the Homeless. "A lot of homeless people talk about a house and a phone. That's what mainstream society has that they don't have. Well, this gives them the phone."
Buoyed by these results, MFS Intelenet is furnishing an additional 250 voice mailboxes, all of which are expected to be distributed by the summer. And the Coalition for the Homeless, another New York advocacy group, says it is on the brink of inaugurating its own program, which will initially include 400 voice mailboxes and might expand to 4,000 within three years.
The notion of matching the homeless with voice mailboxes was apparently spawned in Seattle in 1991, when Community Voice Mail began there. Initially, 50 boxes were assigned.
Seattle Community Voice Mail, a nonprofit group, said that roughly 80 percent of those using the boxes found jobs and 60 percent were able to find housing. Now Seattle has 700 homeless people in the program.
The progress in Seattle, along with a Ford Foundation grant, encouraged Community Technology Institute, a Seattle nonprofit group that conceived the idea, to promote replications elsewhere. Patricia Barry, the group's executive director, says that 10 more cities have established programs, with another four to start soon. The biggest system is in Minneapolis-St. Paul, which boasts 1,200 boxes.
MFS Intelenet itself says it intends to begin programs, perhaps later this year, in Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston, Washington, Dallas and Atlanta.
Community Technology is assisting the Coalition for the Homeless with the start-up of its voice-mail operation and has helped it get a discounted price for a voice-mail system that will operate out of the coalition's offices. From various private sources, the coalition has raised a total of $80,000 to pay for the first year of the program.
In mid-February, training will begin and homeless clients will be assigned their boxes. Most of the voice mailboxes, the coalition says, will be distributed through an assortment of New York agencies. It estimates it will take about six months for the first 400 boxes to be assigned.
In doling out the MFS mailboxes, the partnership says it is careful to give them to people who will use them responsibly, and excludes those with drug or alcohol problems, or mental illness. It says it does not want voice mailboxes being used to sell drugs and studies usage reports monthly for suspicious activity.
So far, only two cases have caused alarm. One person had 52 messages in one month and had checked them 800 times; another had checked his more than 400 times. In both cases, nothing untoward was going on: the people were just a little giddy about the technology.
"It's been a lifesaver for me," said Vincent Richardson, 32, who was unemployed and living in a shelter in the Bronx with his wife and baby when he received a voice mailbox last summer. Shortly afterward, he found temporary work as a security guard and in December he found a full-time security position at a Bronx methadone clinic.
His true interest is in being a computer operator, so he continues to send out resumes with his voice-mail number. Just weeks ago, he also found an apartment in Brooklyn.
"Without the voice mail, I probably wouldn't have the job I have now and I wouldn't have the apartment," he said. "Now I've become a productive member of society."
Another mailbox-holder, a 40-year-old woman, said was living at a shelter on West 30th Street last summer when she went onto voice mail. She had lost her job as a home attendant almost a year before.
"I was temping as a secretary out of the shelter," she said. "But that didn't work out too well because I didn't get my messages and I'd miss jobs. A lot of places didn't want me when they heard I lived in a shelter. Society is cruel that way. When I got my voice box, that opened doors."
Last August, she was hired to work three days a week as a receptionist at an office in Long Island City, Queens. The job enabled her to get an apartment several weeks ago.
The other day, a woman in her late 50's was being trained on voice mail by Linda Nelson at the offices of the Partnership for the Homeless, in midtown.
Ms. Nelson got the session underway. She told her, "It will sound just like a home answering machine, so you should think about what message you'd like to leave."
The client, who became homeless last October when she lost her job as a home attendant, dictated a message that Ms. Nelson scribbled down. The woman said she was battling bronchitis and was embarrassed to record her own message. Ms. Nelson offered to be a pinch-voice.
"Now, you've got a great phone number -- 376-1000," Ms. Nelson said. "Really easy to remember."
The woman said, "Well, that sounds like a business number. They'll know it's not my home."
"Good point," Ms. Nelson said. She gave her another number.
After recording the message, Ms. Nelson had the client pick a numerical password and then left a message in her box so she could practice retrieving it. The woman did it once, but said she was still uncomfortable, so she retrieved it a second time and then felt all right.
"I can't thank you enough for this," she said. "It feels so stupid making calls and saying I don't have a number to leave you. Now I have a number."

HEADLINE: James P. Grant, Unicef Chief And Aid Expert, Is Dead at 72

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
James P. Grant, the American foreign aid expert who in 1980 became executive director of Unicef and made it into a major force for helping children, died on Saturday in Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 72 and lived in Croton, N. Y.
The cause of death was cancer, Unicef officials said. Mr. Grant resigned from the United Nations Children's Fund last week. 
 The direction and urgency he gave to Unicef have widely been credited with helping to save millions of children's lives. Mr. Grant, who had also been an Under Secretary General of the United Nations, was still traveling and promoting his "child survival revolution" until late last year.
His message was simple: low-cost, practical methods for saving young lives and curtailing the spread of easily preventible diseases can quickly make a difference. He advocated treating diarrhea, a leading killer of children, with doses of water, sugar and salt that village people could make themselves.
To measure the successes and sometimes the failures of Unicef and the countries it assisted, Mr. Grant introduced an annual report, "The State of the World's Children," now in its 15th year. In 1990, he organized the World Summit for Children, which he considered a highlight of his career. The conference, held in New York, established 27 child health and welfare goals that were later incorporated into national planning in more than 100 countries.
In a statement after Mr. Grant's death, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said: "Very few men or women ever have the opportunity to do as much good in the world as James Grant. And very few have ever grasped that opportunity with such complete and dedicated commitment."
In 1994, Mr. Grant received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Clinton, who cited him for his "compassion and courage in his crusade for the world's children."
Mr. Grant was born in Beijing on May 12, 1922, the son of a public health expert working in Asia. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley and earned a law degree at Harvard.
He began a lifelong career in international service in the 1940's, working with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in China.
In 1962 he became Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs and a deputy director of the International Cooperation Administration, a precursor of the United States Agency for International Development. In 1964, he moved to Turkey to head the American aid mission there.
Three years later, Mr. Grant was appointed an assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, serving until 1969, when he helped found the Overseas Development Council and became its president and chief executive officer. He remained there until moving to Unicef in 1980.
In 1943, Mr. Grant married Ethel Henck. The couple had three sons, John, James and William. His wife died of a heart attack in 1988 on a trip in India. In 1989 he married Ellan W. Young, a photographer. He is survived by his wife, his sons and five grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James P. Grant holding a child at a community center last year in Grand-Bassam, Ivory Coast.

HEADLINE: A Big Leap in Pursuit of Smallness

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
When Satish Kumar first set foot in New York City half a lifetime ago on an 8,000-mile peace walk around the world, his only American acquaintance was a man from Philadelphia who had offered him a lift in the Khyber Pass.
Now Mr. Kumar, a former monk and a kind of international catalyst for unorthodox thinking, is back in the New York area. This time, his itinerary maps out dozens of meetings with Americans who consider him a friend. 
 For Mr. Kumar has become the world's greatest promoter of the ideas of E. F. Schumacher, the economist whose 1973 book, "Small Is Beautiful," changed the way many people think about bigness and its human costs.
And Mr. Schumacher's ideas -- about the importance of a human scale, of strong communities and of respect for the land -- have brought together in this country a loose network of supporters trying to make those ideas real.
Some have set up local currencies in places like Ithaca, N.Y., to try to keep economic power in local hands, and community land trusts in places like the Berkshire Mountains to encourage common ownership of land.
Others are trying to promote worker management and ownership of corporations, or are developing natural systems for purifying waste water -- based, for example, on the principles of swamps.
The movement's philosophers now include writers like Wendell Berry and Kirkpatrick Sale; David Ehrenfeld, a biologist at Rutgers University, and Hazel Henderson, the futurist and economist.
All of those, and many others, will be meeting with Mr. Kumar during his five-week nationwide tour, which began in Virginia late last week and includes appearances in New Jersey this week and in New York City next week.
There will be talks sponsored by environmental organizations like the Worldwatch Institute in Washington, by professors and New Age thinkers, and by the Utne Reader, the Minneapolis-based magazine often described as the Reader's Digest of the alternative press.
"What we're talking about here is a body of true dissenters," said Mr. Sale, who is holding a dinner for Mr. Kumar in Manhattan next week. "These are the most critical critics of contemporary society."
In little ways, too, many are living their dissent.
Mr. Sale has what may be the only compost pile on Eleventh Street. He writes by typewriter instead of computer -- "the instrument that allows the international system that we oppose to work as effectively as it does."
Susan Witt, the executive director of the E. F. Schumacher Society in the United States, who grew up moving 20 times before she was 20, has now lived in the same house in Great Barrington, Mass., for 14 years. She burns wood for heat, grows her own vegetables and plants perennials instead of annuals. "I'm connected with my community in a way I never was," she said.
Their movement encompasses both ends of the political spectrum -- from John McClaughry, a libertarian and former adviser to President Ronald Reagan now living in rural Vermont, to Mr. Sale, who describes himself as not an anarchist but an "anarcho-communalist." They find common ground in Mr. Schumacher's ideas about decentralization, local control and community strength.
While Mr. Schumacher's ideas became widely popular in the 1970's and were taken up by such politicians as Gov. Jerry Brown of California, they seemed to recede from view after Mr. Schumacher's death in 1977.
But Mr. Kumar, who lives in England and edits the magazine Resurgence, in which many of Mr. Schumacher's ideas were first published, has pieced together a kind of international infrastructure for realizing Mr. Schumacher's goals.
He helped start Schumacher societies in England and the United States for perpetuating Mr. Schumacher's ideas, and he has opened a secondary school and a college in Devonshire, England, based on Mr. Schumacher's principles.
In this country, the E. F. Schumacher Society, based in Great Barrington, has helped set up community land trusts and a lending program for small businesses with "ecologically sound and socially useful products and services."
The society, which claims 500 dues-paying members and some 1,500 supporters, has also sponsored several experiments using local currencies to, among other things, stimulate local self-reliance and community spirit.
In the tiny town of Monterey, Mass., the general store each year issues its own scrip to borrow $5,000 to $8,000 from its own customers rather than take out a bank loan to cover operating costs during long, cold winters.
Each fall, local residents buy Monterey store money at a discount -- say, $10 worth of currency for $9. They then use it to buy goods the following summer when seasonal tourism leaves the store feeling more flush.
"People love it," said Maynard Forbes, the store manager, who said the experiment has not only made old customers more loyal, but has also brought in new ones. "It kind of makes them feel like they're part of the community."
One of the biggest local-currency projects is in Ithaca, N.Y. There, a group inspired by an early Schumacher Society experiment has issued more than $49,000 worth of a currency called Ithaca Hours over the last three years.
According to Paul Glover, who started the project, the money can now buy more than 300 different services such as carpentry and child care. Some grocery stores, delis, movie theaters, a bowling alley and a bank also accept it.
Eventually, Mr. Glover hopes the currency will support more ambitious community projects -- for example, the cultivation of new, environmentally sensitive local industries and the mounting of a home-insulation program to reduce the amount of money lost to the local economy through utility payments.
Elsewhere, admirers of the ideas of Mr. Schumacher and Mr. Kumar are teaching subjects like "Environment and Ethics" to aspiring engineers at New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, and are experimenting with using everything from microorganisms to snails to purify contaminated water.
"It has become an important strand of thinking in the environmental community," said Lester Brown, president of the Worldwatch Institute, who described Mr. Kumar as "the principal embodiment of the Schumacher school of thought."
Mr. Kumar said he had so many invitations to speak during this tour that he could have filled every day for three months. In a telephone interview last week, he suggested that the country is ripe for "spiritual renewal."
The evidence, he said, is "the kind of discontentment you see around" -- the alienation, crime, loneliness and breakdown of families and communities. "People are deeply unhappy," he said.
"We are realizing, after 200 years of industrial revolution, that we have gone too far in one direction," he said. "We need to bring some kind of balance between the spiritual and material."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
On Madison's Grave

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
"Miracle at Philadelphia," Catherine Drinker Bowen called her book on the Constitutional Convention of 1787. And it was a political miracle. The delegates produced a document that has ordered a huge country for 200 years, balancing state and nation, government power and individual rights.
The Constitution has been amended 27 times. Some of the changes have been profound: the Bill of Rights, the end of slavery. But none has altered the fundamental structure, the republican system designed by James Madison and the others. Until now. 
 Now the House of Representatives has approved an amendment that would make a revolutionary change in the Madisonian system. It is called the Balanced Budget Amendment. A more honest name would be the Minority Rule Amendment.
The amendment does not prohibit unbalanced budgets. It requires, rather, that a decision to spend more in any fiscal year than anticipated receipts be made by a vote of three-fifths of the whole House and Senate. The same vote would be required to increase the debt limit.
The result would be to transfer to minorities effective control over many, perhaps most, significant legislative decisions. For the impact would not be limited to the overall budget resolution. Most legislation that comes before Congress bears a price tag. If a bill would unbalance a budget, a three-fifths vote would be required to fund it.
In short, a minority of just over 40 percent -- 175 of the 435 representatives, 41 of the 100 senators -- could block action. It takes no great imagination to understand what is likely to happen. Members of the blocking minority will have enormous power to extract concessions for their votes: a local pork project, a judgeship for a friend . . .
Just think about the debt-ceiling provision. Even with the best of intentions to stay in balance, the Government may find itself in deficit at any moment because tax receipts are lagging. Then it will have to do some short-term borrowing or be unable to meet its obligations. Instead of a routine vote for a temporary increase in the debt ceiling, there will be a session of painful bargaining for favors.
The amendment is also a full-employment measure for lawyers. Suppose the figures that produce a balanced budget are suspect, or suppose the demand for balance is ignored. How would the amendment be enforced? Sponsors say it would be up to the courts. So this proposal, labeled conservative, would turn intensely political issues over to judges!
It is in fact a radical idea, one that would subvert majority rule and turn the fiscal debates that are the business of democratic legislatures into constitutional and legal arguments. How did a conservative polity like ours ever get near the point of taking such a step?
The answer is plain. The enormous Federal budget deficits that began in the Reagan years have frightened us -- all of us, conservative and liberal. We do not want our children and grandchildren to have to pay for our profligacy. We are not strong-minded enough to resist deficit temptation, so we are going to bind ourselves as Ulysses did to resist the lure of the Sirens.
The binding would introduce dangerous economic rigidities into our system. In times of recession government should run a deficit, to stimulate the economy. But the amendment would force spending cuts because of declining tax receipts, digging us deeper into the recession.
The rigidities of the amendment would also inflict pain on millions of Americans. The target year for balancing the budget, 2002, could not be met without savage cuts in middle-class entitlements such as Social Security and Medicare.
"It's a bad idea whose time has come," Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, said. "It's like Prohibition; we may have to do it to get it out of our system."
If someone as sensible as Nancy Kassebaum can succumb to such counsels of despair, we have truly lost Madison's faith in representative government. Madison knew that majorities can go wrong; that is why he and his colleagues put so many protections against tyranny in their Constitution. But they also left government the flexibility to govern.
Their design, the miracle that has sustained us for 200 years, is now at risk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
International
 The Mexican peso plunged nearly 10 percent, dragged down by fears that Congress would not approve the proposed $40 billion in loan guarantees. The peso's plunge unsettled markets in Mexico, elsewhere in Latin America and in the United States. [Page A1.] 
 President Clinton sought support for the Mexican package, asking the nation's governors to endorse it. But the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, said he was not sure when a bill approving the package would be introduced. [D6.]
 >Peru, once roiled by terrorism and soaring inflation, is booming. Foreign investors are streaming in, more than doubling their holdings. Peru's prospects have improved since the Government began selling state enterprises and liberalizing markets while holding in check the Shining Path guerrillas. [D1.]
 
The Economy
 This is the week for the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates for the seventh time since last February, according to the expectations of the markets and many analysts. The Fed begins a policy-making meeting today, and many analysts expect an increase of half a percentage point in rates. [D1.]
 Consumer spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December, and income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the month, as the economy headed into 1995 with strong momentum. [D2.]
 
Companies
 Promus, the owner of Harrah's casinos and Embassy Suites, plans to split its hotel and gaming businesses into independent companies. [D1.]
 Caremark International will sell its home-infusion business to Coram Healthcare in a deal valued above $300 million. [D5.]
 Double-digit profit rises were reported for two General Motors units, General Motors Acceptance and Electronic Data Systems, but GM Hughes Electronics posted a lower profit. [D5.]
 Prodigy Services said it has had a surge of new customers since it began offering special software on Jan. 17 that allows users to connect to the Internet's World Wide Web. [D5.]
 L.A. Gear agreed to acquire Ryka, a small but admired maker of women's athletic shoes, for more than $16 million. [D5.]
The U.S. Steel Group showed strong gains, but its sister companies, USX-Marathon and Delhi Group, did not fare as well. [D5.]
 A drug manufactured by Bristol-Myers Squibb was found to be an effective treatment for sickle cell anemia. [C1.]
 
Markets
 Worries over Mexico's financial crisis drove stocks lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.88 points. [D1.]
 Prices of Treasury notes and bills rose ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. But the 30-year bond fell. [D19.]
 The dollar tumbled to a three-month low against the mark and was weaker against other leading currencies. [D20.]
 Soybean prices dropped after a forecast for a huge Brazilian crop and a proposal that could increase American acreage. [D20.]

Many spots worked because they focused more intensely on the products being pitched than on extraneous elements like celebrity endorsers or special effects. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Peru: On the Very Fast Track

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Which country recorded the world's highest growth rate last year? If you thought it was China, Malaysia or Brazil, guess again. It was Peru, which had been written off a few years ago as a bomb-scarred basket case. In 1994, though, the Peruvian economy expanded 12 percent.
Foreign investors are suddenly big players in this $32 billion economy, more than doubling their holdings last year, to $5.8 billion from $2.3 billion. Even Peru's current border skirmishes with Ecuador look unlikely to tarnish the nation's luster for investors. 
 Peru started to become desirable after President Alberto K. Fujimori declared war on his nation's twin enemies: inflation, which had reached 7,650 percent a year when he took office in 1990, and terrorism by the Maoist guerrillas of the Shining Path.
Mr. Fujimori liberalized the climate for foreign investment and began an extensive program of selling Government-owned companies.
A strategy of police offensives and tough military courts has reduced the Shining Path rebellion to its lowest level of activity since 1980, when the revolt erupted. In the process, the group's leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, was captured by the authorities in September 1992.
Last year, Peru recorded 15 percent inflation, the lowest in 23 years. This year, it looks likely to join the exclusive club of Latin American nations with single-digit inflation.
"In short, Peru keeps getting better and better," said Robert J. Pelosky Jr., an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company.
The change is apparent from the American business visitors packing into Lima hotels and tourists returning to the Inca ruins at Machu Picchu. To accommodate such traffic, United Airlines this month inaugurated flights five times a week between Miami and Lima.
Two dozen United States companies have started drilling for oil or digging for minerals in Peru, attracted by one of Latin America's most liberal foreign-investment codes. Other American companies have taken advantage of the most radical privatization drive in Latin America and purchased the four biggest copper mines in the country.
Foreign mining companies expect to quadruple annual gold production to 100 tons by the end of the decade, pushing Peru past Brazil to become the continent's largest gold producer.
Other foreign businesses have benefited, too. Peru has become the fastest-growing market in the Americas for DHL Worldwide Express. The company has shifted its routes and aircraft, sending cargo by Boeing 737 daily to Peru and using a smaller plane to Venezuela. "We are experiencing incredible growth in Peru, 130 percent in the last two years," Andres Borrero, DHL's Andean region manager, said.
Ace Home Center Peru S.A., a local affiliate of Ace Home Center of Chicago, opened here last April in a shopping center once damaged by terrorists' car bombs. "One year ago, all the windows around here were broken and this was an empty warehouse," Rafael Treistman, its general manager, recalled.
Today, all the windows in surrounding buildings have been repaired and an office tower is being constructed. Business is so strong that Mr. Treistman plans to open three more home centers over the next year. Other chains considering Peru include Inter-Continental Hotels, Hilton Hotels, Blockbuster Video and Domino's Pizza.
To cope with a record 500,000 tourists and business visitors expected this year, four luxury hotels are under construction in Lima. To draw investment capital to tourism, 19 state-owned hotels were auctioned last week for a total of $25 million.
"We opened in December 1991 and jumped straight into an empty swimming pool," David Griffith, general manager of the Hotel Las Americas, recalled of the business hotel's initially low occupancy rates. "This year, we expect to run at 85 percent occupancy."
Some economic analysts say Peru is essentially climbing back to where it had been a decade ago, before guerrilla violence and the Government's mismanagement drove the country into economic depression. From 1988 to 1992, the economy shrank by 25 percent -- more than the 21 percent growth it has recorded during the last two years.
But economists predict that Peru will grow 7 percent this year, which could again be the highest level in the Americas. For the rest of the decade, economists are forecasting 5 percent annual growth.
The traumatic peso crisis in Mexico has cast only a slight shadow over Peru's economic revival. Its currency, the sol, has a free-floating exchange rate. Peru has $5.7 billion in hard-currency reserves, more now than those of Mexico, whose economy is 10 times as big.
President Fujimori has made clear his determination to change what was once Latin America's Lebanon into Latin America's Taiwan.
"Just as Japan and Germany arose from the ruins of war, Peru has the enormous possibility to become within a short period of time the leading country in the region," Mr. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, said in July on his fourth anniversary in office.
To attract investment, Mr. Fujimori's administration has created one of Latin America's most permissive investment codes. Peruvians can hold dollar accounts in local banks and send money abroad whenever they want to, unlike in some other Latin American nations.
"Peru is now the most liberal in Latin America," Michael Donovan, general manager of the American Chamber of Commerce of Peru, said of the foreign-investment climate.
Investors' enthusiasm has glossed over some of Peru's drawbacks -- including a history of nationalizing American enterprises in the 1960's, and unresolved economic inequalities and regional and racial differences, which gave rise to the Shining Path insurgency. And Peru, with 22 million people, offers a relatively small emerging market.
Still, Mr. Fujimori, an enthusiastic free-market advocate, has moved to radically reduce the state's share of the economy, to 5 percent this year from 35 percent in 1992. The Government's plan is to sell 75 state-owned companies, of which 49 have already been sold for $3.2 billion in cash. The buyers committed themselves to invest a further $3.2 billion. The Government calculates that foreign companies will put $5 billion into Peru through the end of the decade.
"You have a stream of investment money locked in through the privatization process," said an American economist who asked not to be identified. "The real issue is, given Peru's history, how long is this going to last?"
In the past, Peru zigzagged between a nationalistic socialism and monopoly capitalism. But today, foreigners believe that its free market and privatization are protected by the diversity of investors, by the broad Latin American trend to open markets, and by Mr. Fujimori's expected re-election in June.
With nationalization now virtually absent from Peru's political vocabulary, Royal Dutch/Shell plans to negotiate a contract this year to exploit a huge gas field called Cami-seas, which the company discovered almost a decade ago. The field is estimated to hold 11 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, and could require more than $1 billion to develop -- the largest energy project in Peruvian history.
Though privatizations netted Peru $2.6 billion last year, a bigger selloff may only be starting. Assuming Mr. Fujimori is re-elected, he plans later this year to sell the state oil company, the state water company, the state steel company, the state electricity company, the state railroad and the state mining conglomerate. These companies represent 60 percent of the state's initial stake in the economy.
"We are not privatizing dogs, we are privatizing opportunities that the private sector can take advantage of," said Carlos Montoya, an economist trained at Stanford University who directs the privatization program.
Groundwork for sustained growth is also being laid in Peru's own capital markets and in its basic facilities and services.
Since the program began in 1993, a million Peruvians have joined six private pension funds, which are now worth $300 million and are growing. Pension funds are entering the Lima Stock Exchange, where only 250 companies are listed and trading takes place for three hours a day. Last year's surge of foreign investment -- largely American -- pushed the exchange index up 50 percent in dollar terms, third after the Chilean market's 52 percent and the Brazilian market's 59 percent.
Today, though, stocks on the Lima exchange fell an average of 8 percent, apparently reflecting concern about Peru's border dispute with Ecuador. The drop surpassed those in Mexico, Brazil and Argentina.
Two Peruvian companies, Banco Wiese and Cementos Lima, started selling American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange last year. Southern Peru Copper is now offering 16 million shares. To raise other capital, Peruvian companies also sold $243 million in bond issues in 1994.
Foreign governments and international lending agencies are expected to funnel $1 billion in low-interest loans to Peru this year. In the largest such project, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank are helping finance a three-year, $1 billion project to rebuild the country's dilapidated highways. These and other construction projects caused a sharp increase in Peru's cement production last year.
With new roads and new money, Peruvians have increased the number of cars in the country by one-third since 1992. During the same time, Goodyear of Peru increased tire sales by 60 percent.

HEADLINE: Rate Rise Is Widely Expected

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Some of the players will be new but the result, most analysts say, will be more of the same -- higher interest rates -- when the Federal Reserve meets Tuesday and Wednesday.
The Fed's chief policy-making arm, the Open Market Committee, is expected to raise short-term interest rates for the seventh time in a year. Many analysts expect an increase of half a percentage point in the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other when they borrow money overnight. Such a move would lift the Fed's target for short-term interest rates to 6 percent, exactly double the level from which the increases started last February. 
 The Fed's goal is to keep inflation subdued as the surprisingly strong economy, despite some recent signs of slackening, nears the fourth anniversary of its current expansion. Commodity prices have already climbed sharply and, with the unemployment rate down to 5.4 percent, signs of upward pressure on wages have also begun to emerge, although consumer prices rose less than 3 percent last year.
"We're growing too strongly," said Robert T. Falconer, senior vice president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a specialist in Treasury securities and one of the many analysts who believe the Fed panel will raise rates half a point.
Mr. Falconer said that "we have passed through the natural rate of unemployment," the point, wherever precisely it is, below which the competition for workers pushes up wages and, in turn, inflation. In addition, American industry is operating at the fastest pace in 16 years.
To be sure, the economy is exhibiting clear signs of slowing from the robust pace of 1994, a year that in its final three months was showing an economic growth rate of 4.5 percent. That rate is nearly twice what economists consider to be sustainable over the long term without higher inflation.
But that was last year, and the signs of a slackening have been coming from several areas recently, like the automobile industry, which has had such a severe sales plunge in recent weeks that it is idling some factories, and home construction, where builders report a steep drop in potential customers visiting model homes.
Also, though matched so far by higher sales, inventories in general have soared since last spring, inspiring predictions of cutbacks in production that will act as a drag on the 1995 economy.
The Federal Reserve, however, remains extremely wary, not knowing yet the full effect of last year's rate increases and determined to head off inflation before it can gain a foothold.
"I think we're in the danger zone with respect to inflation," Janet L. Yellen, a Fed governor, said in mid-January just before the so-called blackout period on policy comments that surrounds meetings of the Open Market Committee. "The economy has had considerable momentum and the extent of the momentum has been a surprise."
As the committee meeting convenes Tuesday morning, the Labor Department is scheduled to publish its quarterly tabulation of the employment-cost index, the broadest gauge of wage and benefit costs.
The Fed's caution is justified, said Marina Whitman, an aide in the Nixon Administration who is now a professor at the University of Michigan Business School. "Once inflation shows up in the Consumer Price Index, it is late in the game and then the Fed would be forced to take draconian measures," she said.
Nor is it likely, analysts said, that the results of this week's meeting will be much affected by Mexico's economic crisis or by the annual rotation of voting committee members that takes effect this month.
Active though he has been in creating and promoting the loan-guarantee plan for Mexico, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is not expected to shy away from raising rates in the United States for fear of further weakening the peso. Last week he told Congress that sound American policy is in the best long-term interest of Mexico.
The 12-member panel that votes on policy has 4 seats that are rotated at the start of each year among the presidents of 11 of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks (the president of the New York Fed is vice chairman of the committee and has a permanent voting seat).
One or two of the four new voting members may be a bit less hawkish on inflation than their immediate predecessors, but analysts said they did not expect the personnel change to have much effect on policy. Two of the new voters, Cathy E. Minehan of the Boston Fed and Michael H. Moskow of the Chicago Fed, are serving their first terms as voting members and might have a newcomer's reluctance to take a strong position, analysts say. The other two, Thomas C. Melzer of the St. Louis Fed and Thomas M. Hoenig of Kansas City Fed, have served before and are known to have staunch anti-inflation views.
The other voters are the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board, which is expected to take a separate vote to raise the discount rate by half a point. The discount rate, currently at 4.75 percent, is what the Fed charges member banks for loans.
Although the dominant private view is that the committee will raise rates half a point and then defer further action until perhaps early summer -- by which time the need for further tightening may have vanished -- some analysts still believe this week's decision will be to repeat the jump of three-quarters of a point made at the Nov. 15 meeting.
John M. Godfrey, chief economist at Barnett Banks, based in Jacksonville, Fla., contended that the Fed should make a decisive move that would reassure the markets that the rate increases were near an end. Holding this week's increase to half a point, he said, "begs the question of when's the next one."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sharp Earnings Shown For 2 Divisions of G.M.

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation reported today that profits at its finance and computer service units rose at double-digit paces in the fourth quarter, but its military electronics division had lower earnings.
Together the three nonautomotive subsidiaries -- the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation -- earned $734.1 million in the last three months of 1994, up 7 percent from a year earlier. For the full year, they had combined profits of nearly $2.8 billion, up 7.7 percent from $2.6 billion in 1993. 
 G.M.A.C., which provides wholesale and retail financing for G.M. vehicles, reported the biggest gain in quarterly income, with profits jumping 17 percent, to $242 million.
"We're encouraged by the continued strong performance of our financing operations and are optimistic that this earnings trend will continue," John Rines, president of G.M.A.C., said.
For the entire year, however, G.M.A.C.'s profits slipped 6.2 percent, to $920 million, as higher interest rates combined with a less favorable credit rating to put pressure on margins.
G.M.A.C. said it lost some automotive finance business to banks and other finance companies last year, adding it could not offer competitive rates because its cost of funds had risen as a result of lower credit ratings at its parent, General Motors. A spokeswoman for G.M.A.C. said, "They're buying a G.M. car but not with us."
G.M.A.C. said it financed or leased 1.24 million cars and trucks in the United States last year, down from 1.3 million a year earlier.
G.M. is scheduled to report consolidated financial results today. Its stock slipped 12.5 cents today, closing at $37.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Industry analysts estimate G.M. earned about $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter, up from $1.2 billion a year ago. For the full year, G.M. is expected to post a profit of about $5.4 billion, up from $2.5 billion in 1993.
G.M.'s computer services division, E.D.S., earned $236.5 million in the last three months of 1994, up 16.6 percent from a year ago. For the full year, E.D.S. earned $821.9 million, up 13.5 percent. The unit's stock rose $1 to $39.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"We are delighted to report another record year at E.D.S. and to say that we expect continued strong performance in 1995," Les Alberthal, chairman of E.D.S., said. E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., has been a key source of revenue as the company tries to turn around its core automotive operations.
In May, G.M. said it would like to spin off E.D.S. as part of a plan to contribute more than $6 billion to G.M.'s underfunded pension plans and allow E.D.S. to pursue a possible partner with a telecommunications company.
G.M. is expected to receive approval from the Labor Department shortly to deposit the E.D.S. stock in its pension plan, but G.M. said the spinoff would be completed only if the transaction could be tax-free.
GM Hughes Electronics earned $255.6 million in the fourth quarter, down 7.5 percent. For all of 1994, Hughes earned $1.05 billion, up 14 percent. The unit's stock lost 87.5 cents, closing at $34.375 on the Big Board.
GM Hughes's chairman, Michael Armstrong, attributed the fourth-quarter profit drop to expansion costs related to the company's introduction of DirecTV and a provision for traffic control contracts.
G.M. said it had 350,000 DirecTV subscribers by the end of 1994. The satellite-delivered system allows consumers to watch a variety of sports and entertainment programs.
