HEADLINE: Plunge by Mexican Peso Jars U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The markets opened with a shudder yesterday. Another headlong plunge by the Mexican peso sent American stock and bond prices tumbling, with the dollar falling to a three-month low against the German mark.
The peso dropped to its lowest value yet in the current crisis, closing at 6.35 to the dollar, down nearly 10 percent from Friday's close of 5.735. It has lost 45 percent of its value since Dec. 19, when its malaise began. 
 Meanwhile, the normal market anxiety before a Federal Reserve policy meeting further reinforced traders' hesitation to buy stocks, bonds or dollars. The two-day meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee begins today.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.91 points, to 3,832.08; the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.88 points, to 468.51. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index slid 7.08 points, to 751.83.
Mexico and Congress were on the minds of traders. Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said yesterday that the Clinton Administration's $40 billion aid package for Mexico, if put to a vote this week, would not pass the Senate.
Senator Gramm has been especially adamant that detailed safeguards from Mexico should be a condition of the package. But financial markets worry that overly strict American conditions would lead to a lengthy review by the Mexican parliament, during which the peso would deteriorate further, necessitating an even larger rescue package.
"The markets want decisive action," said Paul Hennessey, senior vice president for the Boston Company, which manages $16 billion worth of stocks. "A delay of weeks or months -- that's when you start having problems."
The market worries started yesterday with currency traders abandoning North American currencies. The peso's fall was the biggest in a single day since December. The Canadian dollar slid four-tenths of 1 percent, and the dollar lost seven-tenths of 1 percent against the mark.
A declining dollar makes stocks and bonds less valuable. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.75 percent from 7.73 percent to coax buyers.
"It wasn't hard to figure out today," said David De Rosa, a director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "From the North Pole to Tierra del Fuego, people are selling Canadian dollars, U.S. dollars and Mexican pesos. And if you sell something, you have to buy something, and they're buying Deutsche marks."
The worries in the financial markets will make for an even more closely watched Fed meeting today.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, is "caught between a rock and a hard place," said Gary Evans, senior vice president for Baring Securities, which specializes in emerging-market securities. "If he raises rates, then he drains liquidity from emerging markets. But if he doesn't raise rates, he might weaken the dollar."
Some stocks rose. Mitsubishi Bank, the Tokyo bank, rose 3 1/8, to 24 3/8, on bargain-hunting, after falling 3 points in the last nine sessions on earthquake-induced anxiety. Baby Superstore, a retailer of baby products, hit a 52-week high of 53 3/4, before closing at 53 1/8, up 1 7/8. The company said sales for its fourth quarter jumped 74 percent.
Declining stocks included the American depository receipts of Telefonica de Argentina, which fell 2 7/8, to 46, probably because of the worries over the Mexico crisis.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 318.6 million shares, below this year's daily average of 325 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.99 point, to 254.90, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 835 to 1,402. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.21 points, to 433.54.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pushes Harder for Aid Plan

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Scrambling to rally support for his proposed $40 billion in loan guarantees for Mexico, President Clinton asked the nation's governors to endorse the package today, and in a stepped-up publicity campaign released a bi-partisan list of past Presidents and Treasury Secretaries who supported it.
But while the President worked to get a bill introduced in Congress as soon as possible, the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, said he was not sure when the $40 billion package would be introduced. Though he still favors the plan, which is intended to stabilize the Mexican economy, Mr. Gingrich said it had "almost no support in the country at large," and added that Mr. Clinton "has not adequately explained it to the country." 
 Each day of delay risks more loss of Congressional support and more turmoil in Mexican financial markets, so the Administration is seeking new ways to bolster its case. Treasury officials said today that the United States and Mexican Governments had approached the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, about serving as Mexico's financial adviser in an effort to allay Congressional anxiety.
Mr. Volcker, who administered bitter fiscal medicine to curb inflation in the early 1980's, confirmed that he had been approached by both sides 10 days ago or so, but said he had heard nothing further as of tonight.
The White House had hoped a bill could be ready by tonight, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin stood ready to go to Capitol Hill for negotiations. But House Republicans canceled a late afternoon meeting with Democrats to discuss the issue among themselves, and by early evening both sides said they did not expect an agreement tonight.
Mr. Clinton has spoken out about the problem almost every day for 10 days and spent much of Sunday talking with Congressional leaders. But in remarks to the National Governors' Association at the White House this morning, he acknowledged that he was having difficulty being heard.
"I realize that it's not politically popular back home," Mr. Clinton said in urging the group to support the plan, as its executive committee recommended during the weekend. "It's a rather complex issue, but it is clearly in the interest of American workers, American businesses and the United States as a whole."
Later, asked about criticism that the plan amounted to a bailout of international investors, the President said: "It isn't a bailout for Wall Street. First of all, helping the economy stay strong down there is more important than anything else for our working people and our businesses on Main Street that are doing such business in Mexico. If they want to continue to grow and to have that as a market, we can't let the financial markets, in effect, collapse the Mexican political and economic structure."
"Secondly," he added, "there are a lot of pension plans and ordinary Americans that have their investments tied up there." Many Americans hold shares of mutual funds that have investments in Mexico.
The White House said Mr. Clinton was striving to get agreement on the specifics of a legislative proposal so he could undertake a more aggressive lobbying campaign with members and the public. But the President said today that "time is not a friendly factor."
On Tuesday, the Senate Banking Committee has a hearing scheduled on the proposal at which prominent skeptics, including Ross Perot, are to testify.
The White House said Mr. Clinton sought to re-emphasize that the plan was not direct aid. The Mexican Government would pay a fee in exchange for the guarantees, and would grant the United States first call on its oil export earnings in case of default. Critics contend that the collateral would be inadequate if the Mexican economy worsened.
"I think the President will look for every opportunity he can find to make it clear that this is not a bailout," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. "It is not, you know, welfare for Mexico, that this is in a sense an insurance policy that helps protect our interests as well as the fundamental strength of the Mexican economy."
The nature of the remaining sticking points on a bill remained unclear.
In the latest of a series of rallies, Mr. Rubin held a briefing at the Treasury Department, announcing that former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford had joined George Bush in urging passage of the guarantees. He also announced the bipartisan backing of six former Secretaries of State, five former Secretaries of the Treasury and six former Secretaries of Commerce.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Mixed In Advance of Fed Meeting

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury notes and bills rose yesterday as traders speculated that a string of short-term interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve might be nearing an end.
A weaker dollar, meantime, prompted some traders and investors to sell bonds after a three-day rally that drove yields on the benchmark 30-year bond down 20 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. 
 The prices of the 30-year bond fell 8/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose 2 basis points, to 7.75 percent. That remains about 40 basis points below the three-year high of 8.16 percent in November.
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday amid doubts that Congress will pass a $40 billion loan guarantee package to help stabilize the battered Mexican financial markets. A weaker dollar makes dollar-denominated assets like Treasury bonds less attractive.
But Treasury notes and bills with a maturity of three years or less, a sensitive barometer of interest-rate expectations, rose as traders and investors wagered that an increase of 50 basis points this week in the Federal funds rate for overnight loans will be the last for months to come. The Fed begins a two-day meeting of its policy-making committee today.
At the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, rates fell to their lowest levels in two weeks. The Treasury sold $13.5 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.79 percent, down from 5.80 percent last week. Another $13.5 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.12 percent, down from 6.24 percent.
Prices of notes and bills rose because "there's a perception that the Fed is slowing up a little bit," leaving a profitable cushion for investors between their yield and the Federal funds rate, according to David Duerson, head trader at BA Securities in San Francisco. As prices of bills rose, yields were driven down as much as 4 basis points.
The Fed has raised the Federal funds rate six times since last Feb. 4, pushing it to 5.5 percent from 3 percent. Even so, the central bank can afford to slow the pace of its rate increases because inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities, "really hasn't stuck its head up yet," Mr. Duerson said.
The Mexican crisis could provide a reason for the Fed to delay raising rates this week, some money managers said. The Fed will "try not to add gasoline to the fire by raising rates," said Kenneth Lynch, the head of fixed income at the Pitcairn Trust Company, which has about $200 million in bonds.
Other investors said the situation in Mexico would not be enough to stay the Fed's hand.
Fifty basis points "is pretty much in the bag," said Jonathan Francis, head of global fixed income at Putnam Investments in Boston, which has about $60 billion in bonds.
In other trading, municipal bonds were little changed even though fewer bonds are scheduled to be sold this week than last week, traders said. There are $416 million in bonds scheduled to be sold, down from $3.3 billion last week.
In the corporate market, Merrill Lynch & Company sold $150 million of five-year notes.
Merrill, the nation's largest securities firm, sold $150 million of five-year notes at par to yield 8.375 percent, or 82 basis points more than the five-year Treasury note. The issue is noncallable.
Following are yesterday's results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Spending and Incomes Both Up in December

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Consumer spending picked up in December, but a surge in incomes allowed them to save more, as well, the Commerce Department reported today, and the economy headed into 1995 with strong momentum and only scattered signs of slowing.
Incomes jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in December after a one-tenth of 1 percent dip in November and registered the biggest gain in four years for all of 1994, the Commerce Department said. 
 While spending kept rising last month, it was by a modest three-tenths of 1 percent after increases of four-tenths of 1 percent in November and seven-tenths of 1 percent in October. The spending increase for all of 1994 was the lowest since 1991.
Personal savings climbed in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $245 billion from $219.5 billion in November. The savings rate, a figure widely watched by economists that shows savings as a percentage of disposable income, rose to 4.8 percent in December from 4.3 percent in November.
Analysts said the report offered scant evidence of an expected economic slowdown early in 1995 and was not likely to deter the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates this week for a seventh time in a year.
"Based on what I see, I'm not sure there's any convincing evidence of the economy slowing," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
"I would want to see a slowdown in income and spending first," Mr. Sohn added. He said that he expected the Labor Department to announce on Friday that 250,000 jobs were created on January on top of 256,000 in December.
If so, that would add to the impression that the Fed's bid to slow economic growth down to a pace less likely to fan inflation is taking much longer than anticipated.
Mr. Sohn and other analysts say that eventually costlier credit will cut the economy's growth by making it more expensive for consumers and businesses to borrow or to finance purchases.
The Commerce Department said on Friday that the nation's output of goods and services, or gross domestic product, expanded at a 4.5 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1994 -- the fastest quarterly growth in a year.
Mr. Sohn said he estimated the G.D.P. would ease to a growth rate around 3 1/2 percent a year in the first quarter, still higher than the 2 1/2 percent rate the Fed has indicated it sought to achieve through six interest-rate rises in 1994.
The central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee starts a two-day meeting on Tuesday to consider interest rate policy and is widely expected to announce on Wednesday a seventh rate increase to cool the expansion.
The president of the National Association of Manufacturers, Jerry Jasinowski, said he thought the economy was "on a glide path" -- a gradual slowdown over 1995.
"The slowdown in consumption in December is the first sign that the Federal Reserve's aggressive increases in interest rates are slowing demand," he said, predicting the trend would become more pronounced as adjustable-rate mortgages are renewed at higher rates.
Income from all sources, including wages and salaries as well as interest, rents and dividends, increased 6.1 percent for all of 1994 to $5.70 trillion. That was up from a 4.3 percent rise in 1993 and was the largest annual rise since 6.7 percent in 1990, department officials said.
Spending, by contrast, grew more slowly than in 1993.
Personal spending in 1994 was up 5.7 percent from 1993, when it grew by 5.8 percent. That was the smallest rise in annual spending since 1991, when it rose 3.8 percent, the department said.

HEADLINE: Fleet Offer Is Opposed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The outside directors of Fleet Mortgage Group are opposing a $191 million bid from Fleet Financial Group to purchase the mortgage unit's publicly held stock.
Thomas Hollowell and W. Whitley Hawkins, the only unaffiliated directors on the eight-member board at the Charleston, S.C., unit, rejected the $20-a-share offer as too low, according to a filing today by Fleet Financial with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Fleet Financial, based in Providence, R.I., originally sold 19 percent of Fleet Mortgage's stock to the public in February 1992 at a price of $23 a share. Morgan Stanley & Company, as financial adviser to Mr. Hawkins and Mr. Hollowell, provided preliminary estimates stating that the publicly held stock should be worth $24 to $26 in a buyout, according to the S.E.C. filing.
But the Federal Reserve's effort to raise interest rates has cut mortgage demand, leading to a decline in the price of companies like Fleet Mortgage that originate and service such loans.
Fleet Financial's adviser, Salomon Brothers, valued the Fleet Mortgage stock at only $16.50 to $19.50 a share, the filing said.
Fleet Financial, which already owns 40 million Fleet Mortgage common shares, officially opened its offer today to purchase the 9.54 million shares held by the public at $20 each.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Steel Operating Profits Were Strong in 4th Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The U.S. Steel Group reported strong fourth-quarter operating earnings today, helped by the best steel market in two decades.
The results from U.S. Steel, a subsidiary of the USX Corporation, surpassed Wall Street expectations. But mild weather limited earnings at its sister companies, USX-Marathon Group, an oil company, and Delhi Group, a marketer of natural gas. 
 USX, based here, said U.S. Steel earned $90 million, or $1.11 a share, in the quarter as profits from operations nearly tripled. While the earnings were down from $124 million, or $1.67 a share, in the quarter a year earlier, the 1993 quarter included gains totaling $87 million from asset sales and other items. The most recent results exceeded Wall Street's estimate of 92 cents a share, based on a survey of 13 analysts by Zacks Investment Research.
"It was a great quarter and above everybody's expectations," said Chuck Bradford, analyst with UBS Securities Inc.
Still, shares of U.S. Steel fell $1.50, to $32, reflecting concerns about the effect of rising interest rates on economically sensitive companies.
The company said its steel shipments rose to 2.9 million tons in the quarter -- the highest level since the second quarter of 1989, when U.S. Steel had six primary plants, compared with three today.
U.S. Steel and other steelmakers also benefited from higher prices and increased efficiency at their mills.
But USX did not fare as well in oil. Marathon said higher oil prices and production helped increase profits in the fourth quarter but gains were limited by warm weather, which cut into heating oil demand, and the cost of introducing new, cleaner-burning gasoline as required by Federal regulators.
Marathon earned $37 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $88 million, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $3.4 billion from $2.9 billion.
Marathon stock fell 50 cents, to $16.
USX said fourth-quarter earnings at the Delhi Group fell to $1.3 million, or 9 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 15 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said profits were hurt by lower gas prices.
Delhi's stock was unchanged at $9.50.

HEADLINE: Thousands of Peruvians Flee Border Fighting

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TUMBES, Peru, Jan. 30

 BODY:
With bicycles, house fans and other household goods stacked in their pickup trucks, Peruvian civilians fled south from the Ecuadorean border to this city today as convoys of military trucks rumbled steadily north.
Fighting over a disputed section of the border is taking place in remote jungle 125 miles east of here, but there has been a heavy military buildup in this region, the most heavily populated stretch of the border. 
 By nightfall, an estimated 3,000 people evacuated from border villages had arrived, as well as hundreds of Peruvians forcibly deported from southern Ecuador. In a city that is only 15 miles south of the border, residents displayed their loyalties to Peru by flying the red and white colors of its flag.
"They gave us 24 hours to leave," said Dubelio Castillo, a Peruvian who fled here from Ecuador on Sunday. "There were threats of arrest if we did not obey. There is a lot of fear in the border towns, and that is why Peruvians are leaving Ecuador."
With troopships steaming up the Pacific Coast from Lima, residents on both sides of the border are bracing for an escalation in skirmishes that have killed nine soldiers and wounded at least 13 since Friday.
The border dispute dates back to the early 19th century, when the countries were left with vague maps as the Spanish empire broke up. In 1941, Peru won a 10-day war over the disputed area against Ecuador, its smaller neighbor. On Jan. 29, 1942, a peace treaty granted Peru 70,000 square miles of Amazon jungle. In recent years, tension has heightened around the anniversary date each year.
Argentina, Brazil, Chile and the United States signed the treaty as guarantors, and today both sides agreed to attend talks on Tuesday in Rio de Janeiro sponsored by those nations.
Ecuador renounced the treaty in 1960, and since then Ecuadoreans have grown up using maps showing the country's territory as extending about 200 miles east of the current border to the Amazon River port of Iquitos. In addition, Ecuador has flatly refused to recognize a 48-mile stretch of border that has been demarcated by international arbiters.
Ecuadorean officials said today that fighting had spread beyond that contested border area to other points on the border, which runs for 1,000 miles through Amazon rain forest and over Andean mountain ranges to the Pacific Ocean.
Peruvian forces hit Ecuadorean border posts with mortar fire and rockets fired from helicopters, and they said today that they had captured an Ecuadorean position on Sunday.
The Ecuadoreans said, though, that their forces had repelled the attack by five Peruvian military helicopters. In retaliation, the Ecuadoreans said, their planes bombed Pachacutec, a Peruvian border post named after an Inca king.
Peru's military acknowledged today that Ecuadorean forces shot down a helicopter Sunday, killing the five crew members.
"While an MI-8 helicopter was on a supply mission for our troops, and in our territory, it was attacked and shot down by an Ecuadorean missile," said the armed forces joint command.
With the war news, a wave of patriotism has swept Peru, which only recently emerged from 15 years of divisive guerrilla revolt. Ecuador has also been swept with patriotic fervor.
Today a Lima newspaper reported that former guerrillas of the Shining Path and Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement had offered to fight alongside Peru's army. The guerrillas are reportedly battle-hardened veterans of jungle warfare in Peru's Amazon region.
Air-raid blackouts are being conducted nightly in Talara, a port city 100 miles south of here where one of Peru's most important fighter wings is based. To prevent spying, all commercial planes flying to northern Peruvian cities keep their passenger window shades drawn.
In Ecuador, teachers in schools across the nation conducted special flag-raising ceremonies today and lectured pupils on Ecuador's "Amazon rights."
With an economy half the size of Peru's, Ecuador announced today a series of war taxes, largely on vehicles and on banking transactions.
President Sixto Duran Ballen told a cheering crowd of 10,000 in Quito on Sunday, "Ecuador is united in front of the world, and in front of those who want to offend us."
"I said no to retreat because that has always been the road taken in the 164 years of our history as a republic," he continued. "Each time something like this happened, people asked Ecuador to retreat. This time we will not retreat."
A few hours later, Peru's Foreign Ministry reacted sharply, saying, "This assertion unmasks Ecuador's aggressive face."
In Washington today, delegates to the Organization of American States met to try to devise a way to stop the fighting here, the first time blood has been spilled in a Latin American sovereignty dispute since the Falkland war of 1982.
